HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Fund for Colleges Loses $128 Million
The Common Fund, which oversees almost $20 billion for colleges and other educational institutions, said it lost about $128 million after a rogue trader at First Capital Strategists, which manages securities owned by the fund, failed to hedge investments.
The loss was discovered late on Thursday, and it was still not clear which of the fund's investors would suffer. The fund organizes investment programs for 1,421 colleges, including the University of Michigan, Vanderbilt University and the University of Southern California. [Page 1.]
 
Filibuster Blocks Budget Bill
A Senate vote on a package of midyear budget cuts negotiated by the White House and Congressional leaders was stalled when Senators Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois, refusing to go along with the deal on the $16 billion bill, went into a filibuster. [1.]
 
Dole Backs Microsoft
Bob Dole has criticized the Justice Department for what he said was "overzealous" conduct in its investigation of Microsoft's proposed on-line service. [35.]
 
Mixed Signals on Economy
Gross domestic product grew 2.7 percent during the first quarter, the slowest growth in one and a half years. But factory orders rebounded in May, rising 1.4 percent. [35.]
 
Profit Taking Slows Stocks
Stocks rose modestly, giving up bigger gains in the last hour of trading as portfolio managers booked profits in the best performing issues before the end of the second quarter. The Dow industrials closed up 5.54, at 4,556.10, after a late afternoon sell-off pared gains of more than 30 points. The average fell 29.74 for the week. [37.]
 
BellSouth to Take a Charge
BellSouth said it was altering accounting methods because of regulatory change and would take a $2.7 billion noncash charge. [35.]
 
N.B.A. Locks Out Players
The National Basketball Association said it was locking out its players and suspending its operations until a new collective bargaining agreement was reached. It was the first labor action in N.B.A. history. [27.]
 
Taiwanese Trade Ban Lifted
President Clinton announced that the United States was lifting trade sanctions on imports of Taiwanese sea and wildlife products like coral jewelry and lizard boots, a move that may further provoke China. [4.]
 
GTE Shuffles Management
GTE announced sweeping changes in its management. It named Kent B. Foster to the new position of president, and Nicholas L. Trivisonno, executive vice president of strategic planning, promptly resigned. [35.]
 
Citicorp in High-Level Shifts
Rearranging the highest ranks at Citicorp, John S. Reed, the chairman, named new leaders for the business areas that he expects to be most critical for growth. [35.]
 
Boeing to Cut Production
Boeing said it would scale back production of its 737 and 757 commercial jets, but said the changes would not result in job losses beyond those announced earlier this year. [36.]
 
Bolivia Sells Stake in Utility
Bolivia has sold a controlling interest in its state electricity company to three American companies for $139.8 million. [34.]
 
I.M.F. Funds to Mexico
The International Monetary Fund released the second half of its Mexican aid package, saying that the Government's emergency stabilization effort had significantly improved the country's economic condition. About $2 billion of the remaining $10.7 billion in assistance will be immediately available to Mexico. [34.]
 
Plan for Hong Kong Airport
Ending a four-year dispute, Britain and China agreed on a financing plan for Hong Kong's new airport, clearing the last major hurdle for the $20.3 billion project. [34.]

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Casino Plan Excludes New York

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vowed yesterday to oppose a ballot referendum that would permit casino gambling in New York State unless legislators change the measure to permit gambling in New York City.
 Late Thursday, the State Legislature approved a resolution that would allow casinos in certain areas of the state, including Niagara Falls, Lake George, and the Catskills -- but not in New York City or on Long Island. To become law, the constitutional amendment must be approved again by the Legislature in 1997 and would then go before voters late that year or in 1998. 
 The Mayor said it was strange that New York City legislators, including Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker from Manhattan, had voted for an amendment that he said would hurt the city by driving revenues upstate. The city, he said, should be treated the same as other areas of the state.
 "If it were on the ballot as a referendum in its present form, I would oppose it," he said at a news conference. "And I would urge people in New York City to all vote against it."
 He suggested that the decision to leave out the city might have been a deliberate ploy by anti-casino forces who hope the matter can be defeated. Because city voters are the ones most likely to support gambling, he said, it made no sense to alienate them by restricting gambling to rural areas.
 The Mayor's comments added another layer of opposition to the gambling amendment, already under fire from religious groups on moral grounds and from those who believe that gambling is an improper way for governments to collect revenue. The amendment had been considered dead, but was revived in the State Senate at the last minute Thursday night by the majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. Hotel and resort executives, as well as the casino industry, had been lobbying for passage.
 Patricia Lynch, the spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said the Mayor's comments were premature, because the city could still be added to the amendment in the next session. New York City was left out, she said, because the intent of the amendment was to provide relief for economically depressed tourist areas of the state, which she said did not include the city. In addition, she said, many legislators were concerned that the social ills that have been known to accompany casino gambling in urban areas such as Atlantic City should not be encouraged in New York City.
 Mr. Giuliani said the decision on how and where gambling should be implemented in the city is one that he and the City Council should make. Tying the city's hands, he added, eliminates those options and all but insures that there will be no gambling anywhere in the state.
 "If you think about the votes on how you get a referendum through on gambling, you'd need New York City, and you'd need New York City big," he said. "Because you're going to probably have the most support for gambling in New York City, you're going to have the least amount of support for gambling in upstate New York, and you're going to have kind of a swing in the suburbs. It seems to me if you really want to have casino gambling, you're going to want to get a big vote in New York City for it."
 Several legislators complained privately that Mayor Giuliani never spoke to them before the vote or made his feelings known on the subject. The complaints were similar to those made after the Legislature passed a state budget that fell far short of meeting the city's request. Democratic legislators said the Mayor never made any attempt to lobby them.
 Aides to the Mayor said the city's inclusion was likely to be a higher legislative priority when the matter is taken up again in the next session.
 Gov. George E. Pataki seemed to agree, saying the city's inclusion was something that could be looked at next year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lifting Trade Penalties On Taiwan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
President Clinton announced today that the United States was lifting trade sanctions imposed against Taiwan last year for refusing to stop the sale of tiger bones and rhinoceros parts.
The move, which ends a ban on imports of Taiwanese sea and wildlife products like coral jewelry and lizard boots, was in response to Taiwan's recent actions to raise penalties for trafficking in tiger and rhino parts and to increase police efforts to crack down on such sales. 
 Administration officials said the announcement was not related to Washington's soured relations with Beijing, although several analysts said China was likely to react unfavorably to the move on the grounds that it is yet another kind gesture to Taiwan. American relations with Beijing, which views Taiwan as a renegade province, took a sharp turn for the worse last month when the Administration agreed to allow President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to attend an alumni reunion at Cornell University.
"I would not read anything into the timing as to wider issues of U.S.-Taiwan relations or U.S.-China relations," a State Department official said. "We made this decision now because Taiwan did everything we asked it to do to stop the trade in animal parts."
When Mr. Clinton imposed the sanctions in April 1994, it was the first time a President had used such penalties to protect endangered species. The Administration moved against Taiwan because it was doing less than some other nations to discourage its citizens from using tiger and rhino parts and to crack down on smugglers.
Many people in Asia use tiger and rhinoceros parts as medicines and aphrodisiacs. Rhino horn is often used as a fever-reducing compound, and tiger bone is often prescribed for arthritis and rheumatism.
While trade sanctions often have little effect, Administration officials said they had worked well in this case because Taiwan's leaders were embarrassed by the displeasure of a longtime ally. The sanctions affected only about $25 million of Taiwan's exports to the United States, which totaled $24.4 billion last year.
Mr. Clinton imposed the sanctions after wildlife groups had pressed him to protect the fast-diminishing tiger and rhino population.

HEADLINE: President Weighing Risks of Rejecting Base-Closings List

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Facing outrage in California, the White House and Pentagon are weighing the political costs of rejecting, for the first time, the recommendations of an independent commission on the closing of military bases.
A tug-of-war centered on McClellan Air Force Base near Sacramento has developed between White House political operatives, who view California's 54 electoral votes as crucial to President Clinton's 1996 campaign hopes, and commission members, who are vowing to stick to their guns to close it and eliminate nearly 11,000 military and civilian jobs. 
 The Administration is considering a complicated political calculus: what does Mr. Clinton gain with California voters if he rejects recommendations that the commission will likely return to him unchanged? And what might he lose if members of Congress accuse him of politicizing a process that has successfully worked in 1988, 1991 and 1993 to save billions of dollars?
The President has the opportunity to suggest changes in the panel's decisions, but ultimately, both he and the Congress must accept or reject the findings in their entirety.
"The leanings here are toward rejection, but we're waiting to see if the Pentagon has a credible enough reason to do that," said one White House official, who emphasized that no final decision had been made.
Pentagon analysts have been reviewing the commission's recommendations, which will be formally submitted to the White House on Saturday, looking for reasons of military value, cost and economic impact on California to justify rejecting the eight-member commission's work.
"Obviously, we have serious heartburn with this, but we have to look at the full package before making any final recommendation," Deputy Defense Secretary John White said in an interview.
Senior Pentagon officials are waiting for Defense Secretary William J. Perry to return on Sunday from a weeklong trip to Europe to decide what to recommend to the White House. The Pentagon is not expected to send its findings to the White House until after the July 4 holiday, military officials said.
Meanwhile, a growing number of Senate and House Republicans, including some conservatives from Southern California, are warning Mr. Clinton not to disrupt a process that Congress established specifically to shield lawmakers from the painful task of closing bases in their districts.
"Rejection of the commission's recommendations for overt political reasons will raise serious questions about the integrity of the entire process," the House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, and Representative Floyd Spence, a South Carolina Republican who heads the House National Security Committee, said today in a letter to Mr. Clinton.
Commission members, who last week voted 6 to 2 to close McClellan, say reversing that decision is unlikely. "There's a good chance the President will send it back," said Joe Robles Jr., a retired Army major general who voted against McClellan. "But if I had to vote again I'd close it."
General Robles said that he and other commissioners were suspicious of Air Force claims that closing McClellan and another large maintenance depot, Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio, would hurt military readiness. Commissioners also said the Air Force overestimated costs and underestimated savings.
The panel's chairman, Alan Dixon, a former Democratic Senator from Illinois, left little doubt that the panel would be wary to alter the results of four months of analysis. "It's a prudent, sensible list, arrived at openly and fairly, and we're proud of our work," Mr. Dixon told reporters today.
Indeed, for the first time in the base-closing process, the panel proposed saving more money than the President recommended. The Administration's suggestions would save $19 billion over 20 years and the commission's list would save $19.3 billion. The panel's list would also eliminate about 50,000 additional civilian and military jobs that are directly or indirectly tied to the bases.
The President has until July 15 to accept the panel's recommendations or return the list to the panel citing his objections. If the White House were to reject the list, which has never happened before, the commission would have until Aug. 15 to make any changes.
Mr. Clinton would then have to accept or reject the entire package. But few Congressional or military officials expect Mr. Clinton to veto the recommendations from the last scheduled round of base closings. The Pentagon is counting on the savings to help buy new weapons and pay other bills. The panel did recommend another round of closings in 2001.
Aside from McClellan, the commission altered the Pentagon's list in several other ways, including closing Kelly and keeping open the Rome Laboratory in New York. But the California changes have stirred the loudest cries.
"This commission went bonkers," Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said in a telephone interview. "They were arrogant and not mindful of their obligation to look at cumulative economic impact."
As a result of the three earlier rounds of base closings, California has lost 22 bases and more than 200,000 jobs. As the largest state on the West Coast and beneficiary of the military buildup during World War II, California also had the most to give up.
But Mr. Dixon took issue that California was suffering more than any other state. In fact, he said, Alabama and Alaska had lost 0.4 percent of total jobs in the state through base closings. California, along with Texas, North Dakota and Connecticut, lost 0.3 percent of their jobs.

New Term for Shalikashvili
 CHICAGO, June 30 (Reuters) -- President Clinton today nominated Gen. John Shalikashvili to serve a second two-year term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, calling him a "shining symbol" of the United States armed forces.
The President said in a statement released during a visit here that General Shalikashvili, who became chairman in 1993, had provided "wise and reasoned counsel" and the "sound leadership needed to keep our military strong while shaping the armed forces for the 21st century."

HEADLINE: Mayor Loses Political Fray In Legislature

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 30

 BODY:
The 1995 legislative session ended shortly before dawn today after several demonstrations of the kind of hardball politics that have come to typify the arm-twisting, back-scratching and retaliation of Albany's annual race to recess. And the primary victim of this year's last-minute wrangling may be the Giuliani administration.
 In the final hours of the session, the Legislature passed bills, which Mr. Giuliani opposed, that would tie the city's hands in managing its Police Department while killing legislation coveted by the Mayor that would have provided property tax incentives for development in lower Manhattan. 
 The tax abatement bill died last night when the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Rensselaer County Republican, declined to submit it for a vote after the Democratic-led Assembly had passed it. Mr. Giuliani proposed the measure with great fanfare late last year in an effort to encourage development in lower Manhattan, an area beleaguered by aging buildings, declining rents and high vacancy rates.
 Legislators and lobbyists said today that the Manhattan development bill died not because of its merits -- it has broad bipartisan support -- but because of a bit of terrible political timing. It came to the Senate floor on a day when its chief sponsor, minority leader Martin Connor, a Democrat who represents sections of Brooklyn and lower Manhattan, had infuriated Mr. Bruno.
 Earlier in the day, Mr. Connor had informed Mr. Bruno that he would not deliver expected Democratic votes to help pass a resolution calling for a constitutional amendment on casino gambling. That sent Mr. Bruno scurrying in search of votes from his Republican colleagues, many of whom do not support casino gambling and voted for the resolution only to save Mr. Bruno from deep political embarrassment.
 The casino resolution passed, but Mr. Connor's audacity seemed to seal the fate of the lower Manhattan legislation. Mr. Connor said that when he called Mr. Bruno to tell him that he would not provide Democratic votes for casino gambling, Mr. Bruno snapped, "Well then, I'm not going to do lower Manhattan."
 Mr. Bruno denied making that comment. "It was in no way tied to the casinos," Mr. Bruno said in an interview. "We just need some time. We need more input. We need to take a closer look at the ramifications. I didn't really get a chance to talk to the Mayor about it."
 Mr. Bruno showed no such hesitation in allowing a vote on the police bills, which were pushed aggressively by politically influential police officers' unions, though he suggested he had not studied them in detail.
"You know, I'm not familiar that specifically with them," Mr. Bruno said. "I knew we were doing some things, but I can't tell you really what they were. It just seemed that some things should go on."
 One of the police bills would require the city to promote sergeants and lieutenants who have held investigative or organized crime assignments for at least 18 months. More than 600 officers would be promoted immediately at a cost of $1.4 million in the 1996 fiscal year and $4.2 million by 1999, according to city estimates.
 Another bill would specify that the detective bureau must consist of 70 percent third-grade detectives, the lowest level, 20 percent second-grade detectives and 10 percent first-grade detectives. The bill would require wholesale promotions of detectives at a cost of nearly $10 million in 1996.
 Yet another police bill that the Legislature passed earlier this week would remove the police commissioner from the final disposition of discipline cases, giving that authority to an independent arbitrator. Mr. Giuliani opposes all the police bills on the ground that they impose costs on the city without compensation and that they substitute the Legislature's judgment for the Police Department's. The Mayor called on Gov. George E. Pataki today to veto the bills, but the Governor said he had not yet decided what he would do.
 Business leaders in lower Manhattan said they still hoped that the Senate would enact the property tax abatements during an expected special session this fall. But they said the bill's failure last night could delay a number of significant development projects, including the Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street that Mr. Giuliani announced earlier this month.
 Developers, legislators and lobbyists said they found great irony in Mr. Bruno's decision to kill the bill. Few initiatives, they said, could be more Republican in philosophy than providing tax abatements for business development. Furthermore, they said, many of the developers who would have benefitted from the bill are significant contributors to Republican candidates.
 "I think it's unfortunate," said Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat who also represents lower Manhattan. "I think it was pure politics by the Senate side." Mr. Silver said the bill may have died because "Senator Bruno thought he was going to punish Marty Connor."

HEADLINE: Zhuzhou Journal;
On China's Overburdened Highway System, It's the Big Stall

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: ZHUZHOU, China

 BODY:
New York commuters who get steamed over traffic snarls might consider the plight of 24-year-old Zhou Hui and his two companions, who have been in traffic jams that last as long as three days.
Hanging out of the cab of his 10-ton truck, which was straining under the 14 tons of lumber draped over its backside, Mr. Zhou gazed up the line of traffic that stretched to the horizon in front of him and shook his head. 
 "From 12 o'clock last night until 8 o'clock this morning, we have not moved," Mr. Zhou said. "Look at us, our shirts are filthy, and we have no opportunity to wash. This is the pits."
With its enormous economic surge, China is straining the foundations of its 19th-century transportation system. Though road building is a national frenzy, China has fewer paved roads than Depression-era America. A national highway network remains a distant dream. It is faster to move cargo along the river system or ancient canals than to use the roads.
The burden on the highways is most apparent here, along the central highway of Hunan Province, which has become an extraordinary corridor of commerce that is opening southern China's internal market to Guangzhou, Hong Kong and the world.
Traffic on this stretch of the highway has been backed up more than 10 miles in both directions for weeks as the Hunan Province highway authority tries to put a new surface on a treacherous stretch of potholes, dips, cuts and trenches.
Mr. Zhou is one of three drivers who rotate shifts behind the wheel of the creaking lumber carrier. It will take them more than two days to cover the 240 miles from Jianghua in southern Hunan to the lumber mill in Changsha, the provincial capital.
That works out to less than five miles per hour. And they have to make the trip five to six times a month.
The long, tedious hours are punctuated by horrific collisions or furious fistfights.
Li Xinhua, 19, is one of the traffic policemen who is supposed to bring discipline to the chaos, where tempers can flare over the loss of time and money out there on the steaming pavement.
"The worst is when some of the drivers get so mad they come down out of their trucks and try to beat us," Officer Li said.
He talked as he commandeered the car of foreign travelers only too willing to use his authority to jump to the front of the line. It was Mr. Li's job to tell a policeman five miles ahead to stop the single lane of traffic that was moving south so the opposite lane could have a chance to start moving north again.
This method of alternating lanes was supposed to happen every 20 minutes, but the police have no walkie-talkies, so everything depends on word of mouth passed up the line, or on couriers like Officer Li.
Complicating matters this afternoon is that a truck carrying crushed rock has plowed into a cargo truck, igniting one vehicle's gasoline tank and creating a fire that has blocked both lanes, the one standing still and the one that was supposed to be moving.
One of the drivers did not survive the inferno and lay on the pavement, a charred corpse. Several hundred drivers had abandoned their vehicles and their torpor to observe the grisly diversion as firefighters and policemen scurried about their work.
The thousands of truck drivers sitting in line have created a captive market for entrepreneurial Chinese villagers who live along the highway. They have opened soda and ice cream stands, fast food shops, even brothels, to profit from the gridlock.
Young Chinese women in frilly dresses and bows in their hair decorate the doorways of every roadside restaurant, beckoning unshaven drivers to climb down and sample their home cooking.
But it can be risky to leave a truck unattended.
"The thieves come at night," Officer Li said. "We have caught them stealing pigs from the pig carriers and watermelons from the melon trucks. They will even try to take money out of the pockets of sleeping drivers."
Li Shaoyun, 22, has a boring factory job in Changsha, so four times a month he has been "borrowing" a truck from a state-owned company for the run to Guangzhou, where he can buy eight tons of watermelons for a third of a cent each and sell them in the Changsha market for nearly a penny each.
"Last year this road was so bad, you could only make a few miles a day," he said. His personal record for worst traffic jam is also three days.
He keeps his melon cargo covered or padlocked behind a grillwork that covers the rear bed, but still the thieves manage to pull a few free.
A thief who gets away in the middle of the night with a melon or two is likely to be seen the next morning peddling fresh watermelon slices from a bicycle to hungry truck drivers.
Echoing the lumber carrier, Mr. Li said, "This is the pits."

HEADLINE: Treasury Prices in Rebound In Light Pre-Holiday Trading

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices ended moderately higher yesterday, partly recovering from a plunge on Thursday, as traders unwound speculative investments ahead of the holiday weekend.
 Analysts tied little significance to the modest advance, which came after an early slide in prices. 
 Bond department desks were thinly staffed ahead of the Fourth of July holiday weekend, even though it was the last full trading day before Federal Reserve officials meet Wednesday to set monetary policy, ending weeks of speculation over whether they will cut interest rates to stimulate the economy.
 The price of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond, down in early trading, ended up 9/32 point, or $2.81 for $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, eased to 6.62 percent, from 6.64 percent late Thursday.
 On Thursday, the bond's price dropped by 127/32 points, its biggest daily decline since May 1994, after the Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes surged almost 20 percent in May. The news dashed hopes for an imminent cut in interest rates.
 Those hopes were further eroded yesterday. Factory orders rebounded 1.4 percent in May after three straight declines, the Government said. And the June consumer sentiment index as measured by the University of Michigan increased to 92.7, from 92.3.
 But other news yesterday seemed to conflict with the notion of an improving economy. The Commerce Department said gross domestic product grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1995, barely more than half the pace of the previous quarter. The first-quarter rate was unchanged from a month-old estimate.
 Market participants tied the late-day advance in bond prices to a reversal of speculative positions by traders who had bet on a decline in bond prices.
 The speculative trades exaggerated the price action in a lightly traded market. Activity ends early on Monday, the day before the holiday.
 Short-term Treasury securities ranged from 1/8 to 3/16 point higher and intermediate maturities ranged from 9/32 to 5/16 higher.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 5.54 as Selling At Last Minute Cuts Gains

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks ended yesterday's session with modest gains as a flurry of last-minute selling erased most of the day's advance.
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 5.54 at 4,556.10 after a late afternoon selloff pared gains of more than 30 points. 
 "They've had a great run," Steven Goldman, market strategist at Weeden & Company in Greenwich, Conn., said of the blue-chip stocks. "Some portfolio managers are locking in some profits to start the new quarter."
 Advancing issues led decliners by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume totaled 311.7 million shares, with a large portion changing hands in the last hour. That was just below the volume of 315.6 million shares that traded on Thursday.
 The American Stock Exchange's market value index climbed to a new high and closed for the first time above 500, gaining 3.81, to 500.19. The Amex reported the highest weekly trading volume for 1995 at 147.5 million shares and the highest-ever monthly volume at 539.3 million shares.
 Other market indexes posted gains as well, with the New York Stock Exchange composite index up 0.58, to 291.84, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 0.88, to 544.75, and the Nasdaq composite index up 6.64, to 933.45.
 Stocks headed higher in the morning as a series of mixed economic reports kept alive investors' hopes that the economy could continue to grow enough to support corporate earnings.
 The Commerce Department reported that the gross domestic product, the sum of all the goods and services produced, grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1995.
 That was unchanged from earlier estimates, but barely more than half the pace of expansion in the previous quarter, and the weakest performance in a year and a half.
 But, the department also reported that orders to factories rose 1.4 percent in May, recovering from three straight declines. The University of Michigan reported to clients that its consumer sentiment index rose to 92.7 in June from its 92.3 preliminary reading at midmonth.
 An index of economic activity by Chicago purchasing managers fell to 47.6 percent in May from 53.5 percent, but that was not enough to dissuade investors from the notion that the economy was in good shape. Investors also factored in a nearly 20 percent jump in new-home sales reported on Thursday.
 "Over the past two to three days, the economic data has suggested that while the economy has slowed, a recession is not likely," said Abby Joseph Cohen, market strategist at Goldman, Sachs. "The fundamentals are still constructive."
 Technology stocks started the day barreling higher but then backed off as investors took profits. On the Big Board, I.B.M. fell 1, to 96; Compaq rose 3/4, to 45 1/4, but Micron Technologies fell 1/8, to 55.
 In Nasdaq trading, Intel fell 1/2, to 635/16 , and Apple fell 13/16 , to 467/16 .
 The Dow industrials were buoyed by a good performance in cyclical stocks, which could be expected to continue performing well as long as the economy was still growing, Ms. Cohen said.
 Leading the 30 industrials higher were International Paper, up 2 1/2, to 85 3/4; Caterpillar, up 2, to 64 1/4; Allied Signal, up 1 7/8, to 44 1/2; Alcoa, up 1 5/8, to 50 1/8, and Sears, Roebuck, up 3/4, to 59 1/2.
 Bringing up the rear in the Dow 30 index were Boeing, which fell 1 7/8, to 62 5/8, after the aircraft maker announced that it would cut production on its 737 and 757 jets, and Exxon, which fell 1 3/8, to 70 5/8, as petroleum stocks gave up gains made earlier this week.
 Overseas stock markets ended mixed. In Tokyo the Nikkei average, overcoming four days of declines, added 10.23 points to close at 14,517.40. It was still down 747.78 from a week ago.

HEADLINE: After 114 Years, It's Payday;
Patience Is Rewarded Meagerly As Inflation Erodes 1881 Bonds

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It's been 114 years in coming, but there is good news for those who lent money to the Santa Fe railroad in 1881. They are about to be paid back. Checks for part of the loan will go out today. Lenders will have to be patient a little while longer, though, until October, to get the rest.
 The seemingly endless Santa Fe story illustrates almost everything that can go wrong for a lender, short of a complete failure to pay. Those who lent the money -- or perhaps their great-grandchildren -- are about to get dollars that are each worth less than seven 1881 cents. Along the way, the lenders have suffered through corporate reorganizations, fraudulent accounting and foolish business plans. They have been buffeted by volatile interest rates and by worries over credit quality. And they even lost their protection against inflation when Congress and the Supreme Court teamed up against them in the 1930's. 
 In short, the tale is a cautionary one for anyone thinking of lending money for the really long haul, as some modern-day investors did not long ago when they bought 100-year bonds from the Walt Disney Company. But it is also an affirmation of the longevity and stability of the American financial system that payment was made, even in watered-down form, so many years after a promise was given.
 The money being paid back now is for a debt dating to 1881 that ultimately was turned into two issues of 100-year bonds during the railway's 1895 reorganization. The first of those bonds, the one maturing today, was intended to be of lower quality, and the history of the prices it has fetched -- ranging from $285 to more than $1,300 for bonds with a face value of $1,000 -- provides a graphic description of the financial history of the last century. As it happens, the bonds are maturing after the company, now known as the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation, has agreed to be acquired by Burlington Northern Inc., ending its long tradition of independence.
 In 1881, it looked as if the bad days were behind the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad Company. It had seen some trying times in building its system in the sparsely settled Southwest, what with train robbers and gun battles between crews from the Santa Fe and a rival line trying to build in the same area. (The Santa Fe won the route thanks in part to its gunmen, led by Bat Masterson.) By 1881 the Santa Fe was earning good money. Further expansion seemed likely to bring in even higher profits.
 The public agreed by buying bonds that promised to pay 6 percent interest for 30 years. "We recommend these bonds as a first-class investment," wrote the two Boston investment houses pushing the bonds, Kidder, Peabody and Lee Higginson & Company. For a time, it looked as if they were right. Two years later, Charles Francis Adams, the Boston business leader and president of the Union Pacific Railroad, hailed the Santa Fe as "one of the most brilliantly successful" enterprises in the nation's history.
 But in only a few years, the Western railroad business looked very different. Building new lines cost more, and they brought in less new business, than had been expected. And as more roads were built, competition sometimes became ruinous. The average rate for hauling freight on the Santa Fe system fell 48 percent between 1880 and 1888. And passenger fares fell even further. A fare war in 1886 cut the cost of a ticket from Kansas City to San Francisco to $1, from $21.
 In 1889 came the first reorganization, converting a 30-year bond paying 6 percent interest into a 100-year bond, due in 1990, paying 4 percent. But that fix would not last. When depression came in 1893, the Santa Fe went into receivership, and quickly into scandal.
 Committees of bondholders in New York, Boston, London and Amsterdam -- Baring Securities had sold lots of Santa Fe paper in Europe -- hired an accountant to figure out what happened. He concluded that the railroad had lied in its financial statements, grossly overstating profits and the value of some assets. Not only had it paid millions in illegal rebates to shippers, which was bad enough, but it had treated those payments as an asset. And it had bought other lines that could not hope to earn enough to justify the purchase. Some of those lines had to be jettisoned, amid muttering that at least one was bought largely to bail out bad investments by Baring, which played a powerful role in running the road from 1889 to 1893.
 It was not until 1895 that new management came up with the second reorganization plan, and once again the bondholders suffered. Holders of the 100-year bond due in 1990 got $96.5 million, part of what they were owed, in a new 100-year bond, paying 4 percent and secured by a new first mortgage on the line; those bonds would mature on Oct. 1, 1995. And the rest of what was owed, $51.7 million, was put into a security called an adjustment bond. It is that bond that matures today.
 That bond, which was essentially crammed down the throats of the holders, also had a 4 percent coupon, but with a twist, since the architects of the reorganization were a lot more worried about the financial strength of the railroad than about the financial well-being of the investors. For the first five years, until 1900, the railroad was to pay the interest only if it felt it had sufficient earnings to make the payments. After that, it could not just forget about payments, but it could defer them, indefinitely if need be. The bond was issued in denominations of $500 and $1,000.
 When the new bond began trading in 1896, it rapidly became clear that the Santa Fe would not soon be able to pay any interest. The $1,000 bonds began trading at $425 and soon sold down to $285 amid fears that yet another reorganization was coming. In bond market lingo of a century later, it was viewed as a very low- quality junk bond.
 In fact, no interest was paid in 1896, but 3 percent was paid in 1897 and the full 4 percent was paid thereafter.
 The Santa Fe would survive every future financial panic, albeit not without scaring investors. After the stock market crashed in 1929, investors viewed the Santa Fe as quite a safe investment -- an earlier generation's junk was now viewed as among the bluest chips available.
 The bonds rose in value until 1931, when the adjustment bond almost sold for its full $1,000 face value. But then in 1932 the railroad saw profits plunge so far that it eliminated dividends on its common stock. It kept paying the bond interest, but the price sagged as low as $630, as investors decided that maybe the Santa Fe was a junk borrower after all. But business recovered, and with interest rates low, the bond sold for as much as $1,110 in 1936.
 Then, when recession came in 1938, the Santa Fe briefly appeared again to be in danger of going under. It deferred interest for four months on the bond, and the price plunged again, to $755.
 The 1896 low of $285 would endure as the all-time low for the bond, but it came close to being eclipsed 85 years later. In 1981 there was no worry that the Santa Fe would not meet its obligations, but a 4 percent coupon seemed very low. With interest rates soaring, the Santa Fe bond sagged to as little as $305. That was more than $1,000 below its highest price: $1,312.50 in 1946, the year when things looked rosiest. Rail profits then were pouring in after World War II, and interest rates were extraordinarily low. No one knew it at the time, but a 35-year bear market in bonds was beginning.
 Now, as the bond approaches payment at face value, or par, bondholders can think of what might have been. Had one Supreme Court justice gone the other way in 1935, the bond might be worth many times its face value.
 That is because these bonds, like virtually all others issued at the time, were gold bonds, payable in "gold coin of the United States of the present standard of weight and fineness, or its equivalent." The "present standard" in 1895 valued gold at $20.67 an ounce. At $385 an ounce, about the current price, that would make the bond worth $18,626.
 But in 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Congress declared such contracts invalid, in an effort to stimulate the economy by devaluing the currency. In 1935, the Supreme Court, voting 5 to 4, upheld that decision. The logic was that since a new law required Americans to turn in gold coins for paper money, paying them in gold coin would be meaningless, since they would have to surrender the coins immediately.
 Court fights would erupt over Santa Fe bonds in the 1980's, seeking to reverse that ruling on the ground that Americans had been allowed since the 1970's to own gold coins, but those fights were futile.
 Those who bought bonds in the 19th century had no idea that the gold clause would be invalidated. Nor could they foresee the inflation that was to become commonplace in this century. Consumer prices in 1895 were half what they were in 1800, according to Government estimates. A long-term chart of consumer prices showed increases in times of boom or war, followed by decreases during times of depression or moderate growth. Now a substantial decline in consumer prices is unthinkable.
 Given that, it is easy to understand why bondholders made what turned out to be a very bad bargain. It is less easy to understand why such confidence in the future returned, albeit briefly, in 1993, when several loans of longer than 30 years were made. Walt Disney, for example, sold 100-year bonds with a coupon of 7.55 percent. The company can pay back the bonds as early as 2023 if it thinks that rate is then too high. But if Disney does not want to buy back the bonds, the investors will have to hold on for the full 100 years or trade, of course, in the open market.
 It is doubtful that anyone who has owned the Santa Fe bonds for the past half-century or so would think the Disney bond was worth the risk. They have painfully learned that a dollar can lose most of its value over time, and that interest rates can fluctuate wildly. And earlier in their history, those bonds illustrated how credit quality can go from blue chip to disreputable junk, over and over.
 Those are lessons that seem obvious now. Perhaps Disney will be as solid a company in 2093 as it is now, just as the Santa Fe proved to be a longtime success in the railroad business. But will the dollar hold its value in the next century, as it did not in the last? The Disney bondholders can only hope.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up a Bit in Thin Trading Ahead of Weekend and Holiday

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar gained slightly yesterday as dealers sought to temper Thursday's selloff and cover their positions ahead of the pre-holiday weekend.
 The upward move served to correct the whipsaw action of previous days, when the currency market first drove the dollar skyward on Wednesday on news of the United States-Japan trade deal and then let it plunge Thursday on disappointment with the pact. 
 "It's just a modest correction," said Robert Lynch, currency analyst at MMS International. "The markets overshoot. You had an overshoot on the upside on Wednesday and an overshoot on the downside on Thursday."
 Caution was the predominant mood as dealers sought to cover their positions heading into the weekend. Many market participants will be taking Monday off as well as the July 4 holiday Tuesday.
 Trading was primarily by corporations needing to conduct currency transactions on the last day of the second quarter of 1995.
 "The number of participants was just tiny," said David Glowacki, senior trader at National Bank of Detroit. "Any movement was caused by whatever orders people had to do."
 In late New York trading, the dollar climbed to 1.3815 German marks, from 1.3800 late Thursday, and to 84.69 Japanese yen from 84.47 yen.
 By the end of a turbulent week, the dollar held to a narrow range, with the market focused on the major event ahead, the meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy making board on Wednesday and Thursday.
 Some analysts expected the Federal Open Market Committee to lower short-term interest rates to stimulate a slowing economy. In theory, such a move could weigh on the dollar by making American assets less attractive to overseas investors who buy large amounts of bonds.
 Other dealers speculated that a Fed move would not have a deleterious effect on the dollar.
 The dollar received a mild lift after a University of Michigan study showing consumer sentiment to be much higher than expected. That news, along with a report from purchasing mangers that suggested an economic slowdown, served to further cloud the outlook on interest rates.
 Dealers were also concerned about the prospects of central bank intervention in the event the dollar fell too quickly. On May 31, the Fed led a concerted effort that succeeded in driving the dollar higher by catching the market off guard.
 "The market should be very cautious about extending the dollar's move on the downside," said Steven Jury, dealer at the Union Bank of Switzerland.
 In other trade, the dollar slipped to 1.1495 Swiss francs, from 1.1460 late Thursday, and to $1.5945 to the British pound from $1.5755.
 The dollar also traded at $1.3725 to the Canadian dollar, down from $1.3757 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico to Get 2d Half of Its I.M.F. Aid Package

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 30

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund released the second half of its Mexican aid package today, saying that the Government's emergency stabilization effort had significantly improved the country's economic condition.
 About $2 billion of the remaining $10.7 billion in the international organization's assistance will be immediately available to Mexico. The rest will be set aside in five equal installments of about $1.7 billion from this August through August 1996. Mexico's situation will be under continuous review as the future payments are made. 
 The fund has already lent Mexico almost $8 billion.
 On Thursday, the United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said that Mexico's efforts at change since the peso was devalued in December had stabilized the economy considerably and that a second installment of $10 billion from the United States would be available, starting on Saturday.
 For weeks, Mexican officials have been stating their confidence that the additional money would be released because they were complying with all conditions of the $50 billion international bailout organized by the United States in March.
 Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said the money was being released because the peso had recovered, foreign reserves had risen, interest rates had fallen, the Mexican stock market had bounced back and the Government budget surplus had surpassed expectations.
 "There should be a return to economic growth in 1996 and beyond and a reduction in inflation to international levels," Mr. Camdessus said in a statement.
 Mr. Rubin said in Washington on Thursday that "Mexico's economic reform efforts have borne fruit."
 By raising taxes, cutting the federal budget and promptly paying all its obligations, the Mexican Government has eased fears that it would default on at least some of its debt.
 Nevertheless, the realignment of Mexico's economy has come at great cost to the Mexican people. Independent economists estimate that up to one million workers have lost their jobs since January. Inflation this year is expected to exceed 50 percent and even though interest rates on consumer credit have dropped to about 45 percent in recent weeks, the number of people who cannot pay back their loans continues to increase.
 Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, told business executives on Thursday that the economy probably shrank by 5 percent in the second quarter and that workers would not start to recover from the crisis until next year.

HEADLINE: Final U.S. Revision Confirms Growth Was Slow in Early '95

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Economic growth during the first quarter was the slowest in one and a half years, the Commerce Department said today in issuing a final revision of the data, but a rebound in factory orders during May pointed to a modest recovery.
 The Commerce Department said gross domestic product grew at a 2.7 percent annual rate in 1995's first three months, well below the pace of 5.1 percent in 1994's fourth quarter. The department's final revision of the first-quarter rate was unchanged from its initial revision a month ago. 
 In a separate report, the department said factory orders rose 1.4 percent in May after three consecutive monthly declines, including a 2.2 percent drop in April.
 Analysts said the second quarter, which ended today, would probably prove far more sluggish than the first three months. The economy may even have contracted, they said. Still, most of them said they did not see a recession on the horizon and expected at least a modest rebound by the end of the year.
 "Over all, we have sluggish growth," said Robert Dederick, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "We're getting extremely ambiguous data. The economy is not falling on its face, but it's been limping."
 The recent conflicting economic signals may pose a quandary for the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, which will meet for two days next week to discuss interest rate policy. Seeking to slow economic growth to a pace that could be sustained without inflation, the Fed engineered seven interest rate increases over a 12-month period that ended on Feb. 1. It has left rates unchanged since then.
 In today's report, the Commerce Department said consumer spending in the first quarter was a little weaker than previously estimated. But the downward revision was offset by higher net exports and business investment in durable goods.
 Inflation during the first quarter was slightly faster but still well within the moderate range. One measure of inflation tied to gross domestic product rose at a 3 percent rate in the first three months, compared with 2.6 percent in last year's fourth quarter.
 After-tax corporate profits increased 3.8 percent in the first quarter, up from 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter.
 Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of total economic output, tailed off sharply in the winter. It rose at a $14.3 billion rate in the first quarter, less than one-third as quickly as in 1994's final three months.
 Businesses increased inventories at a $51.1 billion annual rate in the first quarter compared with a $49.4 billion rise in the previous three months. Analysts have been debating whether a big buildup in inventories has led to a temporary economic lull or will continue to be a drag on the economy.
 Even though analysts believe economic growth slowed considerably in the second quarter, there have been hints of a recovery recently. On Thursday, the Government reported that sales of new homes in May rose by the biggest amount, 19.9 percent, in more than three years, while first-time claims for unemployment benefits unexpectedly fell by 28,000 in the latest reporting week, the biggest drop in nearly a year.
 Today, the Commerce Department said that May's 1.4 percent increase in orders to factories was the largest since orders rose 2 percent in December.
 Analysts had predicted the rebound after three consecutive months of decline, the first such decline since mid-1993.
 Excluding the volatile transportation component, factory orders were up 1.1 percent in May. By that measure, orders fell 1 percent in April.
 The backlog of unfilled orders was unchanged in May at $462.1 billion. The backlog is viewed as a measure of whether plants and the labor force are able to keep up with demand. Inventories in May rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $408.2 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Accord for Hong Kong's New Airport

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 30

 BODY:
Ending a four-year dispute, Britain and China agreed today on a financing plan for Hong Kong's new airport, clearing the last major hurdle for the $20.3 billion (United States) project.
 Officials also confirmed what had been widely expected for months, that the airport would not open on time two years from today, but rather in April 1998. 
 The bilateral dispute had been over financing plans for the new Chek Lap Kok Airport and a connecting rail line. Today's accord will enable two Hong Kong entities to borrow billions of dollars from banks or in the international bond market.
 "We've suffered like Job waiting for this," said C. Roger Moss, finance director of the Mass Transit Railway Corporation, which will now begin selling bonds to finance the project. "It will take us all of two and a half minutes to start issuing bonds."
 Borrowing may take longer for the Provisional Airport Authority. A bill that would turn it into a permanent public entity is still before Hong Kong's legislature and will require Chinese approval. Until that happens, the authority cannot borrow.
 Regarding China's remaining role in the process, Hamish Macleod, Hong Kong's Financial Secretary, said, "I can't give a precise answer."
 Chek Lap Kok, being built on reclaimed land off Lantau Island, to the west of Hong Kong Island, is one of the world's largest infrastructure projects. It had faced a cash crisis because of delays over the financing agreement.
 "Both sides have expressed their determination and confidence that the new airport and airport railway will proceed with all due speed to full completion as soon as possible," said the document agreed to by Britain and China. Britain will return Hong Kong to China in mid-1997.
 "The new airport will be substantially complete by mid-1997," Mr. Macleod said. Trial runs will be held and minor additions made until April 1998, he added. The airport railway will not be finished until June 1998, Mr. Macleod said.
 The financing agreement paves the way for the Provisional Airport Authority and the Mass Transit Railway, which operates Hong Kong's subway system, to borrow $23 billion (Hong Kong), or $2.97 billion (United States) for part of the airport and related infrastructure projects.
 Under the agreement, the Hong Kong Government will be able to inject equity into the railway company and the airport authority to offset cost overruns resulting from uncontrollable events. The Chinese negotiators also agreed to allow additional equity to be provided if exchange rates and interest rates fluctuate.
 Without such assurances, the borrowers would be forced to pay higher interest rates on their bonds or loans.
 The latest agreement is part of a broader accord reached in November under which the British and Chinese Governments set debt and equity levels for the airport project.
 Hong Kong has committed a total of $60.3 billion (Hong Kong) to the railway company and the airport authority. Last November, the countries agreed on how much each of the two entities would be allowed to borrow, but the actual authorization to issue bonds or arrange bank lending depended on the latest agreements.
 The negotiating teams also agreed today to grant franchises for Chek Lap Kok's air cargo services to Hong Kong Air Cargo Terminal Ltd. and Hong Kong Airport Services. Hong Kong Air Cargo is owned 25 percent by Jardine Matheson Holdings, a giant Hong Kong trading company whose support for political reform in Hong Kong has drawn criticism from China.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Negotiators from China and Britain, Zhao Jihua, left, and Hugh Davies, at a news conference in Hong Kong yesterday after signing long-awaited agreements for the colony's new $20.3 billion airport. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: The Irresponsible Superpower

BYLINE: By Patrick Smith; Patrick Smith, a former correspondent in Tokyo for the International Herald Tribune and The New Yorker, is writing a book about Japan.

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Conn.

 BODY:
The United States-Japan trade negotiations: The crisis builds. The brink is glimpsed. No, we're headed over the brink! But within hours of the deadline we're saved!
Trade representative Mickey Kantor exits with an exhausted but satisfied smile. The Japanese negotiator, Ryutaro Hashimoto, does not smile. 
 Correspondents covering the deal must work fast, for there are two full agreements to report. The American agreement is formidable: a turning point, a milestone, a breakthrough. The Japanese agreement suggests vaguely that "we will do our best."
This was the scene in Geneva last week when Washington and Tokyo averted a mess worth $6 billion in tariffs on Japanese automobile imports. But the whole business had a disheartening echo. Who agreed to what? Rarely has Japan demonstrated that it takes any such agreement seriously.
"All we can say at this moment is that the administration and the governing party will try to live up to the intentions announced in this agreement," said a Japanese official. What distinguishes his remark is its marvelous punch line: "Of course, in any democratic country intentions are not always realized."
That comment was made not last week but in 1990, when Washington and Tokyo concluded something called the Structural Impediments Initiative. This accord followed talks on textiles, steel, cars (of course), rice, baseball bats and construction projects. It coincided with negotiations over telephone equipment, beef, citrus, toy stores, computer chips and (of course) cars.
America registered some successes in these earlier agreements. The Japanese eat a little imported steak now, though they worry (as they should) about all the hormones. Perhaps a year from now Washington will be able to point to quantifiable improvements based on the accord just reached in Geneva. If American goals are met, our $36 billion deficit in automotive trade will be down to a mere $27 billion in three years -- in the absence of any increase in this deficit in the interim.
The larger point is missed. It's time for us to step back from a complicated 50-year friendship with Japan and to recognize that there is no short-term solution to the trade problem. We are stuck with huge export deficits for years to come. And to remain preoccupied with the statistics is to treat only a measure of our skewed relationship.
It is remarkable how easily Americans forget everything this country has done to create the Japan that befuddles us. We speak of Japan as if it intruded upon us out of nowhere -- as if it has acted quite independently of us since 1945.
This is part of the fog that rolled in with the cold war. Every important component of the Japanese economic machine was put in place by the end of the American occupation in 1952 -- often with the encouragement of the occupation authorities.
Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry? Up and running precisely one day before American troops reached Tokyo after the surrender. Targeted industries: ships, steel, cars? The policy of singling these out for development began in 1947. It was called "priority production" then. We encouraged the Japanese to win by diplomacy and industrial clout what it had lost in its nationalist adventure. The rest -- security, foreign policy -- would be left to us. This arrangement was cobbled together by Shigeru Yoshida, the Prime Minister who led the prewar political elite back to power in 1948, and Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who led the occupation.
Japan today is an irresponsible nation. It possesses power without knowing what to do with it. The cult of irresponsibility grew from the model by which Japan chose to modernize. But the Yoshida arrangement prolonged the problem by blocking the process by which Japan could have grown into the world citizen we now wish it was.
MacArthur made his best-known remark about the Japanese before the Senate in 1951. "They would be like a boy of 12," he said, "as compared with our development of 45 years." The comment stung, because it was true -- then. But we persist in our nation-of-12-year-olds attitude even now, as the Geneva agreement demonstrates. We try to order the Japanese about in a way that we never would with European allies, and they cooperate only with reluctance.
To solve our problems with the Japanese we must put a healthy distance between us. We gave Japan much after the war besides the time to work their economic miracle, which is no miracle at all. We imposed on them a democratic Constitution that barred them from war and a security treaty that put them under our protection. These are the pillars of our relationship. The truth we refuse to face is that these things will eventually have to change, for Japan must learn to act autonomously.
The Japanese are beginning to understand this. Last November, the Yomiuri Shimbun, the most conservative of the national dailies, published a draft of a new constitution "in hope of stirring national debate," as the headline read. Clearly, the country is restless within a set of constraints that made sense 50 years ago but is long outdated now.
These are daunting matters, but neither side can flinch from them much longer. Today the security treaty is good so long as it is not carried out. If it ever was -- if Americans began dying for Japan's protection in, say, North Korea -- this nation would be outraged and relations would be threatened. Has the treaty not become a dangerous anachronism?
When Mickey Kantor and Ryutaro Hashimoto stumbled into the light after their 11th-hour talks in Geneva, Mr. Kantor called the agreement "a significant step to fundamental change." In Tokyo, the line was different. "We didn't cave in," a trade official said, apparently gleeful.
The Japanese trade surplus is indefensible. Yet, paradoxically, Japan's ability to say no to its condescending big brother deserves applause. It is a small step on a long road toward a more realistic relationship that eventually will benefit both sides.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Supported Arts From the Start

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Bruce Ellis Fein (letter, June 25), in his rush to rebut Hillary Rodham Clinton's "Arts for Our Sake" (Op-Ed, June 21), forgot -- or was oblivious to -- the long history of United States Government support for art and artists, beginning nearly two centuries before the establishment of the National Endowment for the Arts. 
 Has he never walked through the majestic Capitol Rotunda and seen the huge paintings commissioned by Congress? Has he never seen the magnificent Capitol ceilings and wall paintings by the first full-time artist hired for life by the United States, Constantino Brumidi?
Has he never explored the basement of the Smithsonian Institution building containing a sculptured monstrosity ordered by Congress of a toga-clad but half-nude George Washington -- so inappropriate Congress wouldn't let it stay on the Capitol grounds?
Mr. Fein may not have visited many Federal courtrooms to see the murals paid for by the judiciary. Yes, a lot of people (mostly nonartists) mentioned in his letter "helped make our country great," but so did Thomas Hart Benton and Howard Chandler Christy and other creators of art works paid for by taxpayers long before the endowment.
Mr. Fein implied that our crime rate was lower and our economy healthier before the endowment. Was he around in the 1930's when the economy was so unhealthy that the Works Progress Administration could hire fine artists for the equivalent of beans and coffee to create some of our national art treasures?
 
CHARLES B. HOLSTEIN
Silver Spring, Md., June 26, 1995

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bolivia Sells Utility to U.S. Companies

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 30

 BODY:
Bolivia announced the sale of a controlling interest in its state electricity company to three American companies for $139.8 million, the first step of an ambitious program to transfer ownership of key industries to private hands.
 The Government agreed to sell a 50 percent stake in Empresa Nacional de Electricidad to Dominion Energy Inc., a unit of Dominion Resources Inc. of Richmond; Energy Initiative Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., and Constellation Energy, a unit of the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company. 
 Although the transaction was small by international standards, it was closely watched by investors because the utility was the first of six major Bolivian industries that will be put on the auction block this year and because of the novel way in which the deal was structured.
 Unlike traditional privatizations, in which a government sells full ownership of a company, Bolivia has devised a "capitalization" program in which investors agree to invest a specified sum of new capital. In return, they get a 50 percent share and management control. The other 50 percent of the company is put into a fund to provide a guaranteed pension for all Bolivians.
The idea is to encourage economic activity and create desperately needed jobs while building up a national retirement system.
 Although Bolivia adopted an economic stabilization plan in the mid-1980's that revamped its economy and reduced inflation to 8.5 percent from 24,000 percent, it is one of the poorest countries in Latin America, with 30 percent unemployment.
 The American companies submitted the highest of seven bids for the electric company, known as Ende. The selling price was substantially higher than the minimum of $99.1 million set by the Government, but far less than the $250 million that some analysts and Government officials had estimated the company to be worth.
 Even so, David R. Evert, a spokesman for the Ministry of Capitalization, which is overseeing the sale of state companies, said the Government was delighted. "The success of the electric company bodes very well for future capitalizations," he said. "I think this sends a message to the investment community that Bolivia is serious."
 Bolivia plans to sell shares in five other state companies this year involved in oil, telecommunications, railroads, airlines and smelting. Altogether, the transactions are expected to generate as much as $2 billion in investment capital.
 The capitalization program is the brainchild of President Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, a mining entrepreneur who was raised in the United States and became President two years ago. He devised the plan after opinion polls showed that Bolivians were generally opposed to traditional privatizations, which they equate with the loss of national independence and with corruption.
 "I would have preferred to sell all these companies through conventional privatizations and use the proceeds to balance the budget and finance social programs, but we were convinced that public opposition would have been too strong to allow us to go that route," Mr. Sanchez de Lozada said.
 Investment bankers and economists say the Bolivian program is attractive to investors because it not only gives them complete management control of the company but also lets them use all the money they invest to expand and modernize a company.
 But there are risks associated with capitalization. Not only is it an untested formula in an economically depressed nation of just seven million people, but also opposition to it has been growing from labor unions and opposition politicians.
 Some critics contend that it will destroy, not create, jobs, while others complain that the state could raise more money through conventional privatizations.
 The American buyers said they were attracted by Bolivia's internal demand for electricity, which is growing by 7 percent a year, and the potential to export gas and electricity to surrounding countries.
 "One of the big problems that companies face after they buy into a privatization is coming up with the money to expand and improve operations," said Ed Geehan, Constellation's manager of international projects. "This is not something we have to worry about."
 The capitalization program fell behind schedule recently as the Government struggled to approve new laws governing the newly capitalized industries and pension fund.
 Ende will be split into three power-generating units that will be operated separately, each by one of the three American buyers.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 18, 1995, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on July 1 about the announced sale of a 50 percent stake in Bolivia's state-owned electricity company to three United States companies referred incorrectly to the ownership of one company, Energy Initiatives Inc. It is a subsidiary of the General Public Utilities Corporation, not independent.

HEADLINE: IN LANGUAGE;
A Woman of a Certain Age

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

 BODY:
HOW OLD IS A woman of a certain age?
Only a Nosy Parker would try to find out. But the expression is becoming androgynous, and the age seems to be creeping upward. 
 Sidney Wade, a woman who lives in Gainesville, Fla., reports that she was complaining to a friend, Debora Greger, about a loss of hair: "My friend remarked that we, as women of a certain age, were prone to a number of peculiar developments. At first I was surprised by her use of the phrase to describe us (we are mildly ripening), remembering it from my more youthful days in France as an insulting kind of polite elocution but one that remains rather wonderful and precise."
Then Ms. Wade was stunned to see a headline in The New York Times "3 Explorers of a Certain Age, Scaling Mountains and More" about three men in their 80's. "Reeling, I reported this to Debora, who supposes that the phrase itself seems to have developed a pronounced middle-aged spread. Is this so? I hope not."
The phrase, in English, can be cited to 1754: "I could not help wishing," wrote an anonymous essayist in Connoisseur magazine, "that some middle term was invented between Miss and Mrs. to be adopted, at a certain age, by all females not inclined to matrimony." (This was two centuries pre-Ms.)
The certain age suggested spinsterhood; the poet Byron in 1817 wrote, "She was not old, nor young, nor at the years/Which certain people call a certain age,/Which yet the most uncertain age appears." Five years later, in a grumpier mood, he returned to the phrase: "A lady of a 'certain age,' which means Certainly aged." Charles Dickens picked it up in "Barnaby Rudge": "A very old house, perhaps as old as it claimed to be, and perhaps older, which will sometimes happen with houses of an uncertain, as with ladies of a certain, age."
The Oxford English Dictionary defined that sense of certain as "which it is not polite or necessary further to define." That was the sense meant by William Dean Howells when he wrote of "gentlemen approaching a certain weight." The special sense reverses the literal meaning of the word certain, which is "fixed, definite" (much as "I could care less" means "I could not care less").
The phrase was repopularized in a 1979 book by the psychotherapist Lillian B. Rubin, "Women of a Certain Age: The Midlife Search for Self," in which midlife spanned 35 to 54.
Reached in San Francisco, Dr. Rubin, whose book indicates she is now in her early 70's, was surprised to learn of the long English history of the phase because "it has a long history in French, where it refers to women of fortyish and thereabouts who are able to initiate boys and young men into the beauties of sexual encounters. The early use in English seems to be about spinsterhood, but the French meaning has nothing to do with marriage."
In French, the phrase has erotically or sexually charged overtones. "It comes from a society where sexuality is freer," Dr. Rubin notes, "and more understood as an important part of human life."
The phrase in French is femmes d'une certaine age. The term, however, can apply to either sex. Without the certain, the phrase un homme d'un age translates literally as "a man of an age" and is defined in the Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary as "a man of advanced years."
And now to the point: is that certain age getting older?
"When I wrote the book in 1979," Dr. Rubin says, "the 'women of a certain age' were in their late 30's and early 40's. I think that has changed with the baby boomers and the lengthening of the life span. I'd say the 'certain age' has now moved to the age of 50 or 55."
Look at it this way: late 30's or early 40's is no longer that "certain" age; it's moved up a decade. The good news is that 40 is still young, at least linguistically. That's how it seems to a language maven of a certain weight and getting long in the tooth.
Which brings us to long in the tooth, which I used in a political column in an unkind reference to vigorous Senator Bob Dole. (The first user was William Makepeace Thackeray in an 1852 novel: "She was lean, and yellow, and long in the tooth; all the red and white in all the toyshops of London could not make a beauty of her.") In my piece, I was impelled by wordmavenhood to give the derivation of the expression: "As horses age, their gums recede, making their teeth appear longer." My source was the Oxford English Dictionary: "displaying the roots of the teeth owing to the recession of the gums with increasing age; hence gen., old."
This folk wisdom about the illusion of tooth-lengthening was promptly challenged by Michael Brisbane McCrary, former Hong Kong polo player and now a squire in Hunter, N.Y.: "Horses actually do get 'long in the tooth.' It is not receding gums; their teeth continue to grow out (like beavers, and there is a word for it beginning with 'ex-') throughout their lives until the teeth actually fall out."
Mr. McCrary (his wife is Jane Buckle; her long-panted-for book, "How to Massage Your Dog," is scheduled for publication this fall) continues: "The growth of the horses' teeth is required because they would wear down in the process of eating in a natural setting. As the teeth grow out, lines show; this is how one usually tells the age of a horse. And this is the background to the phrase 'Don't look a gift horse in the mouth'; i.e., if it is a gift, don't ask how old it is."
That moved me to call the National Zoo. I don't call the Bronx Zoo anymore; any zoo that calls itself a "wildlife center" cannot be trusted. (A spokesman at our national zoological park, Mike Morgan, remembered me as the one who revealed the reason that pandas have reduplicating names like Ling-Ling and Hsing-Hsing they can't hear well and zoo keepers have to call them twice.)
It seems that Mr. McCrary could be right and all of us lexicographers could be wrong. "As horses age," noted Dr. Richard Montali, one of the National Zoo's veterinarians, "their teeth actually do continue to grow for some time. The incisors appear to look longer, but it's mainly because the angle of the teeth changes. Instead of perpendicular growth, the teeth angle out as they grow and wear."
Maybe the gums recede a little as the growing teeth angle out; that's why horses' teeth reveal their age. As a result of receiving this new information, and with deference to animal rights groups, I will no longer refer to old horses as being long in the tooth. They are horses of a certain age.
