HEADLINE: Coloring History Our Way

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger; David E. Sanger, formerly chief of The Times's Tokyo bureau, now covers economic policy from Washington.

 BODY:
A FEW MONTHS AGO, IT SEEMED THAT JAPAN AND AMERICA had finally figured out how to finesse the politics of this summer's anniversaries. For years, officials in Washington and Tokyo had puzzled over how to mark the atom bombing of Hiroshima and end of World War II without stirring the wrath of veterans in Nebraska or nationalists in Nagoya. After endless meetings, Japanese and American diplomats agreed on a strategy: No big V-J Day events, just an acknowledgment of the sacrifices on both sides. Then the focus should turn to the "global partnership" that diplomats like to talk about as a counterpoint to the constant bickering between the world's two largest economies.
Like most agreements between Japan and America these days, the details were left a little hazy. And, like most accords, this one is failing. 
 The United States turned out a postage stamp showing a mushroom cloud over Hiroshima, then withdrew it. Next, the two countries stumbled into their most vituperative economic dispute in decades. As Washington threatened an embargo on Japanese luxury cars, many in Tokyo recalled America's economic isolation of Japan in the 1930's -- which every Japanese schoolchild is still taught made Pearl Harbor inevitable. Meanwhile, Tokyo's effort to get Parliament to issue a vaguely worded apology for the terror Japan spread throughout Asia during the war turned into a fiasco. Right-wingers used the debate to repeat their claims that Japan had fought a "war of liberation" to free Asians from the yoke of Western rule.
After six years in Japan, I found none of this surprising: Japan's gyrations to avoid real discussion of its responsibility for the deaths of 20 million people is the stuff of innumerable stories for foreign correspondents. But I was unprepared for the treatment of history in my own country, at the Smithsonian Institution's just-opened exhibit of the Enola Gay, the bomber whose work was shown on the stamp. The lengthy and public arguments with American veterans groups over the exhibit's tone and content ended with a classically Japanese solution. Like similar displays in Japan's own war museums, the Smithsonian exhibit seems oddly suspended in a historical vacuum, long on hardware and short on explanations.
The Enola Gay is flying solo on the Mall in Washington, without any serious examination of whether the bomb was needed to force Japan to surrender, a question that is debated more seriously today, and with more compelling evidence, than at any time in postwar history. There is only a glimpse of the devastation and human suffering that the bomb left in its wake.
Any other approach, American veterans groups insist, would create a "moral equivalence" between Japan's expansionary horrors and America's efforts to stop them. The Smithsonian, declaring that it was impossible to honor those Americans who sacrificed so much while simultaneously conducting a dispassionate examination of the war's end, abandoned the chance to cast new light on a dark corner of history.
This is the real moral equivalence: We are matching the Japanese in historical amnesia, claiming, as they do, that the issues remain too divisive to explore, even 50 years later. The explanation is no more convincing coming from American museum curators than it is coming from Japanese politicians.
To be fair, the Smithsonian's first instinct was to examine the historical record. When organizers went to Japan several years ago to enlist Japanese help, they offered assurances that the exhibit would not celebrate Japan's devastation. They asked to borrow the eerie artifacts from the city's famed A-bomb museum: the stone steps of a bank building forever imprinted with the shadow of the poor soul who was sitting there at the moment of detonation, the watches that stopped as the atomic flash froze the moment of horror. And -- this is where the trouble began -- they asked the same questions Japanese themselves raise every year as the Aug. 6 anniversary approaches: Was the bomb truly dropped to save American lives that would have been lost in a bloody invasion? Or was the decision, as the Japanese insist, tinged with racism, or was it simply a desire to send a signal to the Soviet Union or -- as many Japanese believe -- to justify the billions spent building the bomb?
That exhibit, of course, never got off the computer screen. Veterans argued, with some merit, that the Smithsonian's scripts swallowed Tokyo's revisionist mythology, portraying Japan more as the victim than the aggressor. Repeated efforts to fix the tone only worsened the offenses. As pressures mounted, museum officials panicked. The exhibit was revised, then revised again. Congress held hearings. Martin Harwit, the museum's director, was forced to resign. Hiroshima officials, watching the winds shift so dramatically, said they would mount their own traveling counterexhibit in the United States, led by Hiroshima's Mayor.
A Smithsonian official put the museum's quandary succinctly: "The veterans want the exhibit to stop when the doors to the bomb bay opened. And that's where the Japanese want it to begin."
This is history by consensus, which is troubling enough. But the rationale for the final product is even more disturbing, because it echoes Japan's own justifications for its refusal to teach a new generation of Japanese the lessons of their country's disastrous past.
The originator of the "we must not dishonor the veterans" argument is Japan's Ministry of Education. Time and again, its officials have invoked this logic to explain why textbooks gloss over Japan's brutal, 35-year colonization of Korea or the Rape of Nanking. When a former Education Minister, Mayumi Moriyama, was asked why the country has battled in court for 30 years to keep a seemingly forthright textbook out of schoolchildren's hands, her description of the author was telling. "His interpretation is not a popular one," she said, as if that were the test of accuracy. "He is very isolated now. Few people are supporting him."
The Smithsonian's arguments also reminded me of those made by officials in the Shinjuku ward in Tokyo after some construction workers discovered a collection of human bones. The workers had stumbled on the site of the headquarters of the infamous Unit 731, which had conducted vivisection experiments on Chinese prisoners of war. The bones offered a rare window on the unit's activities -- exactly what the city was desperate to avoid. "There are many veterans who still live in this area," a ward official said to me, explaining the city's sudden lack of curiosity. "How will they feel if this is how we remember the war?"
Wars are ugly affairs, and it is no surprise that countries want to think that they fought with justice on their side. But does it honor American veterans to recall the decision to drop the bomb with the same absence of introspection that taints Japan's museum exhibits? Shown in historical isolation, the Enola Gay looks a bit like the kamikaze plane on display at the famed Yasukuni Shrine in Tokyo. The tiny craft is surrounded by the uniforms and letters left by hundreds of young kamikaze pilots, but there is no discussion of why they flew off to their deaths, no rationale offered other than loyalty to the Emperor.
It is museums like that one -- and there are many all over Japan -- that help explain the queasy feeling you get when you talk to Japanese university students about World War II, or the Persian Gulf war, or any other conflict. All war is bad, they are likely to tell you. But scratch beneath the platitudes, and you will quickly discover that the studied avoidance of discussion about the Government's decisions in the 1930's and 1940's has left a whole generation of Japanese incapable of having a debate about when it makes sense for a nation to use its military power. To defend its shores? To preserve its oil supplies? To assure the spread of democratic values? Only the rare student will engage in the discussion.
So perhaps the best argument for asking the obvious parallel questions about the bomb at the Smithsonian is that raising the issue in Washington is the only way to force the same question in Tokyo. "Gaiatsu," or foreign pressure, is often used to open up the Japanese market for citrus fruits or car parts, but it is even more effective at opening the market forunvarnished history. When the American media seized on the long illness, and death in 1989, of Emperor Hirohito to explore the question of whether he was a willing participant or a helpless bystander in the war effort, it freed Japanese television producers and newspaper editors to do the same.
The savviest Japanese historians manipulate this national trait to their advantage. The Government is still reeling from the exquisite work of Yoshiaki Yoshimi, a little-known history professor who cut through brazen official denials that the Japanese Imperial Army had kidnapped Korean women and forced them to provide sexual services to the front-line troops. He dug up documents in the military's own archives proving that the Army had ordered the stocking of the "comfort stations," as they were called, and released them just before Japan's Prime Minister traveled to South Korea in January 1993. There was a predictable outcry in Seoul and, eventually, a reluctant admission of the truth in Tokyo.
By the time I left Japan last summer, I saw a glimmer of hope that, despite the Government's best efforts, Yoshimi and a band of rebels like him were beginning to score broader victories. Last year, just as the Smithsonian debate was beginning, a new Mayor of Hiroshima, Takashi Hiraoka, opened a second museum, one that documented the city's role as a major military center and did not pretend that the war started on Aug. 6, 1945. "Some of us believe that when we think about the bomb, we should think about the war, too," he told me as we watched middle-aged Japanese drop in and look at the pictures in wonderment. "I had no idea," one woman said as she suddenly discovered why Hiroshima was a target.
As the Smithsonian debate proved, neither exhibits in museums nor hollow celebrations of the "global partnership" will convince Japan or America to see the war in anything close to the same light. But the anniversary is a rare and much-needed chance for Americans and Japanese to confront some of the suspicion and bitterness that still lurk beneath the surface of every trade dispute, every argument over Japan's responsibility to take a greater role in the world and every debate over whether the two largest economies will ever understand each other. Doing what Japan has done for too long -- reducing the war to a few Government-approved sound bites -- will make an ailing relationship only worse.

HEADLINE: Americans in a Land of Opportunity: Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
FOR GENERATIONS, AMERICAN ARTISTS heeded the call of Paris. First came the painters, Mary Cassatt and Winslow Homer among them, lured by the Impressionist movement of the late 19th century. Then it was the turn of writers, with Edith Wharton leading the way in the 1910's and Ernest Hemingway, Gertrude Stein, Ezra Pound and Scott Fitzgerald soon following.
By the 1930's, Josephine Baker was the toast of le tout Paris, and black American performers had found a home here. After World War II, Paris was where Henry Miller could get published, where James Baldwin felt free to live and write. Then, it seems, Paris stopped being an important port of call for American creators. 
 Today, the suggestion that France, or indeed anywhere in Europe, serves as a font of inspiration for American culture would prompt sniffs of contempt in the United States. Rather, the contrary is probably true. It is made-in-America popular culture that increasingly dominates the world. And, at least in film, European actors and directors covet the chance to seek fame and fortune in the United States.
Yet, for all that, Europe has not lost its attraction to American artists. It is just that today's pilgrims are less visible. In place of painters or writers looking for inspiration or romance, now it is those in the performing arts who trek here in search of work. The reason is simple. Painting and writing are solitary tasks, but music, opera, dance and theater all need support structures. And, thanks to generous state financing of the arts (as well as entrenched cultural traditions), Europe offers opportunities that simply can't be found in the United States.
In some cases, recognition back home has followed success overseas. William Christie, who has helped revive interest in Baroque music in the United States, was an unknown musician when he arrived in France two decades ago. Robert Wilson's work as a theater director was first acclaimed in France. William Forsythe's Frankfurt Ballet company has earned him a prominent place in dance. But many American performers in Europe no longer aspire to an American career. They have come to terms with "exile" in Europe because this is where a career is possible.
There is no American artistic community as such in Europe today, but the careers of four creative artists are in many ways fairly typical. Thomas Moser, 50, is an opera singer who lives in Vienna. Dee Dee Bridgewater, 45, is a jazz singer who has settled in Paris. Andy de Groat, 47, is a choreographer in residence in a Paris suburban theater. Joseph Mydell, 50, is an actor whose home is London. None is a household name in the United States. But all have flourishing European careers. And all feel vindicated by their decision to leave their native land to go in search of recognition and appreciation in Europe.
 
The Tenor
A Gamble That Paid Off
 Thomas Moser, a tenor, had good reason to feel satisfied earlier this year after the opening of the Theatre du Chatelet's production of Benjamin Britten's opera "Peter Grimes." The audience had acclaimed his performance in the title role, and Paris critics had singled him out for special praise. "He can be boorish and moving, sensitive and disturbing, brutal and dreamy, all with infinite talent," Le Figaro's critic wrote.
It was not Mr. Moser's first appearance on a Paris stage. But he had finally made his mark here. A physically imposing man with a gentle manner, he would probably be the first to describe his career as successful rather than spectacular. After early emphasis on Mozart and Rossini, though, he is being increasingly noticed as major European theaters ask him to diversify his repertory, not only to Britten but also to Berlioz and Wagner.
"At least 90 percent of what is interesting to me now is happening in Europe and not the United States," he said during a visit to Paris for "Peter Grimes."
The gamble of coming here 20 years ago has paid off. Having spent four years attached to a Navy band (and performing frequently in the Nixon White House), Mr. Moser, a former choir boy from Richmond, was almost 30 by the time he went professional.
"As an American," he recalled, "I had the dream that I was the one who would make a so-called American career." But reality soon intervened. He struggled to get auditions and, when he succeeded, "you had 250 people auditioning and 249 going home without work."
From Germany, though, friends kept telling him that good tenors were in demand. And after his teacher also urged him to try his luck in Europe, he found himself in Vienna in 1974. By the following year, he had a permanent job in the opera house at Graz, Austria, singing one opera after another. Two years later, he was taken on as a permanent member of the State Opera of Vienna.
"I went from a house where I was a star to a house where I was part of the inventory," he said with a laugh.
But his European career was well on its way. Fluent in German and French, he was soon singing on other European stages, often in Germany ("where every city of a certain size has an opera house," he noted) but also in France and Britain. For a while, though, he still yearned to "make it" in the United States. He made his American debut at the New York City Opera in 1979. But now, he said, "I feel absolutely at home here and rather strange in the United States."
In the future, he conceded, the trimming of many government arts budgets in Europe may reduce job openings in opera, but he is already firmly ensconced in Vienna, and he feels comfortable because his work is accepted.
"It's like when you go to a cocktail party and people say, 'What do you do?' and you say, 'I sing,' " he explained. "In America, you will find people saying, 'Yes, but how do you earn your money?' In Europe, it is a respected profession. Here they understand there really are people who earn their money singing."
 
The Club Singer
An Audience To Sing To
 Sitting cross-legged on the floor of her dressing room as she painted her fingernails green, Dee Dee Bridgewater recounted with glee how she came to be starring in "Cabaret" at the Mogador Theater in Paris.
"The director, Jerome Savary, called me last May and said, 'Cherie, I'd love you to play Sally Bowles,' " she recalled. "I said, 'You've got to be kidding! A black Sally Bowles?' He said it would make it more interesting. So I said, 'O.K., let's do it.' "
As it happens, a black, French-speaking Sally Bowles surprised no one in this city. Rather, it was seen as just another example of Ms. Bridgewater's versatility. Since she moved to France nine years ago, she has had her own radio and television shows, appeared on stage and sung at innumerable jazz festivals. But, perhaps most of all, she said, she has been able to capitalize on the French "fascination" with black entertainers and "on the Josephine Bakers and Sidney Bechets who came before me."
Moving to France, however, has meant more than commercial success. Ms. Bridgewater began singing professionally in the United States when she was an 18-year-old student at Michigan State University. Within a few years she concluded that her first love, jazz, was "not going to pay my bills." So, between playing small television, movie and theater roles, she turned to pop music. In 1986, while touring with a musical here, she discovered there was an audience for jazz in Europe, and so she decided to stay.
"Now I can live off my jazz," she said with satisfaction.
One reason is that cities and regions across Europe finance jazz festivals, while in France Ms. Bridgewater often performs in municipal "cultural houses" that also live off state subsidies.
"There are lots of grants for artists," she said. "I make enough money not to need one, but I might if I wanted to create a special work. So, yes, it's easier to work in Europe."
And is Europe also easier for black performers?
"I feel respected here," she said. "When I think of the States, I think black artist. When I think of Europe, I think artist; I don't think color."
As a jazz singer, though, she feels a special responsibility to her art form. "Without trying to sound presumptuous, I feel I am one of the better jazz singers," she said, "and I'm trying very hard to keep traditional jazz singing going, like Ella Fitzgerald, with the scatting and so on. This is our musical culture. It's our original music."
So this summer she is singing in clubs and jazz festivals in several American cities (today she is scheduled to perform at the Newport Jazz Festival in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.) Would she like to go home for good? She held up a finger now decorated with green nail polish and wagged it furiously.
"No, no, no," she said.
 
The Choreographer
Putting New York Far Behind
 It was not really Andy de Groat's decision to start coming to France, but in the end it was almost natural that he should stay here. Born in Paterson, N.J., he attended the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan, and, in 1967 at the age of 20, he joined Robert Wilson's troupe as a "moving actor." Starting in 1971, when Mr. Wilson triumphed at the Nancy Festival with its production of "Deaf Man's Glance," the troupe began returning to France every year. "By the time I left Wilson in 1976, my entire professional life had involved France," Mr. de Groat recalled.
He formed his own company, Andy de Groat and Dancers, and became its choreographer. While he struggled to make ends meet in New York, his troupe often found work at dance festivals in France. By the early 1980's, however, the trans-Atlantic commuting was getting him down.
"I was only going back to New York to collect unemployment," he said. "So I made the change."
He formed a new troupe, Red Notes, and effectively went native. "I asked for a grant from the French Government to make a new piece," he said, "and I've been getting grants from them every year since then."
Not surprisingly, he, like many other cultural exiles, is a great believer in government aid for the arts. His company's residence at the new opera house at Massy, just south of Paris, is backed by $200,000 per year in subsidies. In exchange, it performs regularly and organizes classes and workshops for local children. It also tours in France and beyond.
"Artists don't have to stay alive waiting tables here," Mr. de Groat said while rehearsing his dancers for two sequences in Mr. Wilson's production of Mozart's "Magic Flute" before its return to the Bastille Opera in the spring. Clearly, he does not miss the United States.
"I returned to New York last year for the first time in 10 years, mainly to see my friend Jerome Robbins rehearsing a new piece," he said. "But I've lost contact with most of my American friends. A lot of my friends in New York are dead."
In any event, he said, he finds the dance scene more exciting in Europe today. "I don't think success in New York is better than success in Europe," he said. "I think New York has lost something of its aura of being the arts capital of the world. That was in the 1970's and 1980's, but things have changed."
In contrast, he said, dance has developed enormously in France over the past 15 years, and this has enabled him to branch out from what he called his early "post-modern minimalist" style toward one that embraces both classical and experimental dance.
"I am now interested in all kinds of music and movement," he said, noting that his plans for the fall include the choreography for a new production of Stravinsky's "Rake's Progress" at the Lyons Opera. "I mix everything up. I use everything." French audiences seem to go along with it. "There is something about dancing that appeals to the intellectual side of the French," he said. "It makes it very rewarding to work here."
 
 
The Actor
Up From Segregation
 A long road took Joseph Mydell from a segregated high school in Savannah, Ga., in the mid-1960's to the stage of the Royal National Theater in London three decades later. But the actor vividly remembers how it all began.
"One of our black teachers played a recording of an Old Vic version of 'Macbeth,' and that was just it," he recalled, still stirred by the memory. "I was smitten."
Translating his dreams into an acting career took far longer. He went to college twice and moved on twice, and between occasional roles in black theater companies in New York and a tour sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts, he taught drama in Tougaloo, Miss., and in Savannah, his hometown.
"I finally decided I had to do something that showed my abilities," he said, "but there wasn't anything. So I wrote my own one-man show."
His chosen vehicle was Paul Lawrence Dunbar, a black American author of the late 19th century whose life and writings provided Mr. Mydell with rich material. "He was a dandy, he was a snob, he had an awful marriage, he was interesting, he was human, he was not politically correct," Mr. Mydell said.
In 1980, Mr. Mydell took the play to the Edinburgh Festival, where it won the Fringe Award for the best one-man show. With that, he decided to stay in Britain. He performed a series of small theater roles until, in 1986, he finally got his break: a two-year contract to perform six plays, with the Royal Shakespeare Company. "That was the beginning of what I knew could be my career," he said.
Since then, his Savannah accent now hidden behind the clipped English of a Shakespearean actor, things have gone well for him. He has done many television dramas, and last year he became the first American actor to win a coveted Laurence Olivier Award for his performance as Belize, the former drag queen, in the National Theater's production of "Angels in America, Part II: Perestroika," which had been a hit on Broadway in the 1993-94 season. This spring, he was again performing with the National Theater, this time in Christopher Hampton's "Alice's Adventures Under Ground."
"I never wanted to become an ex-pat," he said over coffee in his cramped apartment in Hackney, a run-down district in east London. "I always thought it was sad that James Baldwin, Richard Wright and others felt they had to leave. But I couldn't do what I'm doing in the United States. In the States, I was pushed into black roles, but here people aren't intimidated if you're bright and intelligent. If you want to do the kind of theater I want to do, this is the country."
If the right opportunity arose, he said, he would go home. But he is not optimistic.
"I haven't seen anything that has made me think, 'Oh, yes, I want to be there,' " he said. "And now it looks like they're trying to do away with the arts. Between right-wingers and political correctness, there won't be any imagination left in America." He stood up and stretched. "I am very pleased I came here," he said with a smile. "I think I'm about ready for my first 'Othello.' "

SECTION: Section 2; Page 22; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 874 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
When New York Was the New Place to Play

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein 

 BODY:
IT WAS THE BEST OF TIMES, IT WAS THE worst of times. Some concerts were so popular that tickets were scalped for $650. Legendary virtuosos made their way to New York, which was also the testing ground for aspiring performers. Grand concert halls were constructed, though some were harshly criticized for putting decoration above good acoustics. Critics lobbied for American composers and condemned the New York Philharmonic for its excessive love of European models. Some writers were astounded by the plentiful "trash" attracting inordinate public attention.
It was, in other words, a time very like the present. But this was New York in the 1850's, when the city was not yet a world-class metropolis and American musical culture was in its infancy. So everything was radically different, as if taking place in a parallel universe in which the language was the same but the meaning unfamiliar. 
 That, at any rate, is the impression given by a groundbreaking book to be published in September by the University of Chicago Press, recounting, in sometimes exhausting detail, the musical life of New York between 1850 and 1856. It is the second volume in Vera Brodsky Lawrence's "Strong on Music," a projected three-volume study of the New York music scene during the days of the music-loving lawyer George Templeton Strong, who kept extensive diaries until his death in 1875. The first volume of Ms. Lawrence's work, published in 1988 and covering the years 1836 to 1849, has just been published in paperback.
Scholarly attention is now turning back to the origins of American musical culture in an attempt to discover reasons for its current condition and overlooked prospects for its future. These volumes will provide a foundation for research in their resurrection of lost details: newspaper reviews, impresarios' declaration, the economic demands of an art form.
It lends perspective to find the young Verdi, in the new book, called the "Grand Maestro of the Mechanico-spasmodic school." And here is a rare glimpse of the piano before its American renaissance, from The New York Mirror on the occasion of Louis Moreau Gottschalk's New York debut in 1852: "Most people have been subjected to so much thrumming of the instrument at home that they become nervous when they see an artist preparing to attack them with it in public."
These were the years in which the soprano Jenny Lind was sold to the New York public by P. T. Barnum (to some surprisingly critical reviews, as Ms. Lawrence discovered); the Castle Garden theater was built near the Battery and subject to abominable odors from the new landfill ("We are quite of the opinion," wrote The New York Herald in 1854, "that it has militated against the interests of the opera"), and opera was given in blackface at Buckley's Ethiopian Opera House (including versions of Donizetti's "Lucia di Lammermoor" and Bellini's "Norma").
Strong, a wealthy lawyer whose father-in-law designed Gramercy Park, was often on the scene, attending concerts, reacting to rehearsals, holding "Mass meetings" at his home, in which friends might, for example, read through Mozart's Requiem. (It tends to "drag a little," he noted of the piece.) Ms. Lawrence calls his Pepys-like chronicle a "passport to a bygone world."
Here is how Strong reacted to Mendelssohn's "Italian" Symphony in an early New York performance: "A symphony, like an epic poem, is either very great or worthless. . . . Why should the Philharmonic Society bother itself to produce correctly this beautiful product of Mendelssohn's . . . when so many of the Philharmonic subscribers have but the vaguest notion of Beethoven's Symphonies in C minor, A and D, the 'Eroica' and 'Pastorale,' Mozart's in E flat and the 'Jupiter,' Weber's and Mendelssohn's great overtures, and so forth?"
MS. LAWRENCE, WHOSE SCHOLARLY devotion to this project is apparent in wry footnotes and asides, calls Strong's comment "a narrow, alas persistent, point of view indigenous to symphony subscribers through the ages."
In fact, Strong is just a loose peg for this collection of documents and opinions. Each year is represented first by his diaries, then by an extensive collection of reviews and commentary by contemporaries.
Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of this collection is the current timeliness of recurring themes: the raging arguments between defenders of High Art (the term was used) and lovers of sensation; between aggressive advocates of American composers and proud exponents of European Classicism; between critics who championed music that "appeals directly to the sympathies and appreciation of the people" and writers like Strong, who called a popular extravaganza "one of the grandest humbugs on record."
A great vitality pervades the documents of this period, in which most music is new and most arguments are fresh; musical life today seems tame by contrast and poorer by half. But the recurring, timeless themes provide great comfort, too: they are seen here setting in motion a constant counterpoint to American musical life. These issues of self-definition have accompanied American music for nearly 150 years, always leaving the way open for continued fractious debate and continued hopes for better times.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A Nathaniel Currier lithograph of Castle Garden in 1850, when the Swedish soprano Jenny Lind made her first appearance in the United States, and, right, a Mathew Brady daguerreotype of Lind. (New-York Historical Society; Library of Congress (inset)); George Templeton Strong--Music-loving lawyer.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Toxic Sites;
Fears of Future Liability Scuttle Many a Deal

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT started off as an all-too-common 90's story: A machine tool business went under, so its bank foreclosed and put its warehouse up for sale.
The warehouse was in good shape and in an accessible Connecticut location. But the bank wanted the property off its books, so offered it at a bargain-basement price. There was, however, a big problem: The warehouse had kept machine oil in vats, some of which had leaked. 
 "The cleanup would have been easy, but I couldn't get a soul to consider buying it," said Bruce P. Meyerson, senior director of Eastern Consolidated, a real estate investment bank. "Everyone is frightened of buying an environmental nightmare."
Concerns about leaky storage tanks, asbestos-laden buildings or other environmental problems are scuttling property sales at a growing rate. Many buyers, fearful of cleanup problems or liability suits, will not touch properties with the slightest environmental taint. And lenders are loath to provide funds for buyers who will take the risk.
Some lenders are still trying to unload environmentally problematic properties they took back in the recession. And most fear they will be forced by the courts to clean up sites they take back in the future.
"Predictability is critical for financial institutions, and they cannot predict which way the liability issue will go," said Frank L. Amoroso, the environmental law partner at Nixon, Hargrave, Devans & Doyle in Garden City. The result, said Richard D. Jones, a partner in the Hartford law firm Pepe & Hazard, is that "envirophobia is rampant among lenders."
The fears have hit the capital markets, too, said Carl Kane, managing director of the Ernst & Young Kenneth Leventhal Real Estate Group. The share prices of real estate investment trusts or of securitized mortgages -- mortgages that are pooled and sold as securities -- often plummet when they include tainted properties.
"Any risk that could have a deleterious impact on cash flow is of terrible concern to the rating agencies," Mr. Kane said.
Such fears have had a chilling effect on deals. More than 40 percent of commercial mortgage bankers polled by Environmental Warranty, an insurance company in West Hartford, said they had backed out of mortgage deals because of fears about contamination, and 87 percent said that such fears had delayed transactions. Nor were the fears specious: 70 percent said that environmental problems had turned up on properties on which they had arranged mortgages.
"Actual experiences and fear of such experiences play a huge role in what gets financed today and what doesn't," said Charles Perry, president of Environmental Warranty, which offers policies that pay off if environmental engineers miss something when they assess a site's cleanup needs.
ALMOST every mortgage broker has a horror tale to tell. Jerry Swartz, a principal at Pergolis Swartz Associates, said it had taken more than a year to get financing to build a Walgreen's drugstore in Mineola, L.I.; normally, it would have taken two months. A gas station had occupied the site, and the insurance company providing the financing asked for more assurances about liability before it would close the deal.
Lawyers say it is unlikely deals will speed up anytime soon. "The standard now is to ask for all environmental data, and then do an investigation," said Thomas E. McHugh, a real estate lawyer with Fulbright & Jaworski in Manhattan. "Even if you don't expect problems, you are not giving proper representation if you don't make sure."
But while environmental fears have slowed sales, they have not stopped them. Lenders are hankering to put loan money back into the market, and there are not enough pristine properties to go around.
"There are far too many dollars chasing far too little product," observed David B. Vance, president of KTR Environmental Services, a Manhattan consulting firm. "So people who once walked away from risk are now looking for ways to manage it."
Fidelity Bond & Mortgage, based in Blue Bell, Pa., recently arranged refinancing for a New York City office building that had asbestos-wrapped pipe in the basement. The owner agreed to sheathe the pipe and continually monitor the air quality around it.
"We wouldn't have touched this if the pipe was in a public area," said Peter R. Steier, a Fidelity senior vice president. "A few years ago we wouldn't have touched this at all."
Even renters are making compromises. The Educational Housing Corporation, a nonprofit provider of student housing, recently took a 15-year lease on the old George Washington Hotel, on Lexington Avenue and 23d Street. The corporation will check each room twice a year, and repaint it if existing lead paint has peeled or chipped.
"We just couldn't find another building in that area at that price," said Michael Myers, chairman of the brokerage Corporate Realty Partners, which handled the deal.
Bankers and investors have grown more savvy about environmental risks. They recognize that asbestos can be contained rather than removed, and that oil leaks that will quickly spread through sandy soil will not move far in clay-like soil. And they know that sellers will pay for site assessments.
Such assessments generally start with an overview of a site's past uses and environmental track record, and sometimes progress to soil and water sampling. They usually include estimates of cleanup costs. Some consultants -- Groundwater Technology of Norwood, Mass., was one of the first -- agree to stick to their cost estimates for a specific level of cleanup.
BUYERS also are insisting on what Mr. Jones calls "a steep fear discount." He recently handled a deal in which an investor paid $2 million for a $10 million mortgage note on a Connecticut office building. Why the low price? The bank discovered that the land below the building contained coal tars.
"No one knew if the coal tar was dangerous, or what it would cost to clean it," Mr. Jones said. "The investor was certain there was no problem, but the bank was afraid."
In fact, a growing number of investors are looking for tainted properties that they can buy for a fraction of what they would go for if they were clean. Some are betting that no problems will crop up; others are ready to clean the properties themselves.
Mr. Meyerson of Eastern Consolidated is currently negotiating the purchase of an asbestos-ridden office building in Atlanta that, he says, is selling for half of what it would cost if it were clean. "Our client is certain he can remove the asbestos for a lot less than the owner thinks," he said.
Entire businesses are forming around such certainties. Last November, six partners, all with backgrounds in either environmental consulting or law, formed LandBank, a Manhattan-based company, for the sole purpose of buying contaminated properties, cleaning them up and reselling them.
"So many properties are unsold or unused or unfinanced because of conditions that we knew could be treated," said Christopher Carpentieri, a LandBank principal.
LandBank is buying an old bus terminal on Jericho Turnpike in Floral Park, L.I., for $700,000. It is riddled with diesel fuel, solvents and gasoline, but LandBank figures it will cost less than $500,000 to clean it up. Mr. Carpentieri expects a shopping center developer would pay $2.4 million for the cleaned-up land.
The partners, who are using their own capital, have also picked up a small strip center with a leaky gas station in Wilmington, Del., and eight contaminated acres in Charleston, S. C., that Mr. Carpentieri thinks he can resell for an entertainment complex.
OTHER investors are hedging their bets with environmental assessment insurance, offered by Zurich, AIG, Environmental Warranty and a handful of other companies.
Such policies often tip the scales for Ahold Real Estate, which Royal Ahold, the huge Dutch food retailer, formed five years ago to develop shopping centers in the United States that would be anchored by Ahold-owned supermarkets. Edward J. Pabich, Ahold Real Estate's executive vice president, has opted out of many deals because of environmental uncertainties. Just last month, he passed on buying 10 acres of beautifully situated land in South Carolina because a leak from an adjacent gas station had migrated onto the property.
"Normally, when we're in doubt, we walk away," Mr. Pabich said.
But Ahold's supermarket executives are even more conservative than Mr. Pabich. He found some land in Willimantic, Conn., that seemed perfect for one of Ahold's Edwards Super Food Stores. It had once held a gas station, but records showed no spills.
"I was comfortable enough to buy it, but the people on the supermarket side were scared that something bad would turn up once we started building," Mr. Pabich said.
They struck a compromise. Ahold Real Estate bought the land and took out a three-year policy with Environmental Warranty that insured Ahold for the acquisition cost of the land, should any contaminants be found.
"This kind of coverage couldn't make me buy land near an oil refinery in Bayonne," said Mr. Pabich, who said he had taken similar policies on four other properties. "But for most of our sites, this provides sufficient comfort levels."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward J. Pabich of Ahold Real Estate at supermarket in Willimantic, Conn.; gas station had been on site. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF

BYLINE: By ROBERT W. STOCK 

 BODY:

Lawyers May Be Fined For Filing Frivolous Suits
The State Supreme Court took a serious view of frivolous law suits last week. It called upon the court system's Civil Practice Committee to come up with a new rule that could levy fines or other kinds of monetary penalties on lawyers found guilty of filing such suits. 
 Governor Whitman and many business leaders have complained that growing numbers of frivolous suits have overloaded court dockets and been a financial burden on the economy. Many lawyers have demurred. In fact, the majority of the lawyers and judges on the Civil Practice Committee had recommended simply the enforcement of existing standards to control the frivolous suits. The committee minority had plumped for monetary sanctions.
"I think such suits are relatively rare," said Harold A. Sherman of Warren Township, president of the state bar association, "but they do exist, so it's appropriate to do something about them." He warned, though, that any rule based on the Federal regulation could have "a chilling effect on new, cutting-edge kinds of litigation." He also said there was a potential for opposing lawyers to use the threat of a monetary penalty on each other "as a club."
 
Marching Through State, Thrift Buys Another Pharmacy
With the purchase last month of a pharmacy in Point Pleasant Beach, Thrift Drug of Pittsburgh is maintaining its fast-paced invasion of the New Jersey market, and company officials expect the acquisitions to continue. Thrift has bought 40 pharmacies in the state in the last two years, bringing its New Jersey total to 115. Rite Aid, based in Alexandria, Va., is the New Jersey leader.
In most cases, Thrift has sought out independently-owned pharmacies in New Jersey, rather than build new stores, said John Leibrick, manager of retail sales promotion. "In a market already filled with drug stores," he said, "it's often not practical to do new ones. It makes sense to go for established pharmacies with good real estate."
The Point Pharmacy -- now called Point Thrift -- on Arnold Avenue in Point Pleasant Beach is the company's latest acquisition. It has a total of 620 stores in 16 states.
 
Coming to State's Highways: Diesel Inspection Teams
Drivers of diesel trucks on New Jersey highways may soon be in for a surprise. Under legislation passed in Trenton last week, up to 10 teams of state police officers and Department of Motor Vehicle inspectors will start roaming the roads, pulling over diesel trucks that weigh five tons or more for inspection of their smoke emissions. The measure also calls for increased penalties for violators.
"There is a growing list of studies showing the negative health effects of diesel particles," said John C. Elston, administrator of pollution programs for the Department of Environmental Protection. Diesel buses and trucks account for about 10 percent of the miles driven in the state each day. The Department of Transportation would handle inspections of buses, most of them operated by New Jersey Transit.
The legislation also provides for the licensing of privately operated centers for testing diesel emissions; diesel vehicles registered in New Jerey would have to be inspected there.
 
Farmers Go High-Tech With the Jersey Tomato
There are many tomatoes grown in New Jersey, but only one "Jersey Tomato," and it will be picked for the first time this week. The trademark belongs to the New Jersey Tomato Council, a new cooperative of 21 farmers based in Cedarville in Cumberland County.
"In the past," said Robert J. Matarazzo, a spokesman for the council and a farmer in Belvidere, "we grew a great tasting and looking tomato, but we couldn't pack and ship so it looked and tasted like that on the supermarket shelf."
The council's members have put up $1,000 for each acre of tomatoes they grow. That plus borrowings plus some state funds -- $1 million in all -- has enabled the farmers to change their ways. A drip irrigation line is being used to feed plants nutrients based on daily laboratory analyses of their leaves. The Jersey Tomato is being grown on stakes to avoid ground diseases. It will be moved through the packing process in channels of water to prevent bruising. A computerized photo system will classify each tomato by size and color at the rate of 600 a minute, putting like with like. Chain stores like that kind of uniformity, Mr. Matarazzo said. ROBERT W. SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 4; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Places, Everyone

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
THE plan for the state's new arts center is to get people -- from the suburbs, from the cities -- off their couches and into the theater and the concert hall. Bring a center of their own, like Lincoln Center in scope, to people who don't want to schlep to New York City for culture.
And in Newark, a city that more readily conjures up images of carjackings than concertos. Backers of the $165 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center point out that the brownstone-and-cafe-lined neighborhood around Lincoln Center was once considered one of Manhattan's most dangerous. 
 In a time of nationwide cuts in arts budgets, when long-established arts groups are pleading for money, most of the New Jersey center's financing -- $154 million so far -- has been raised from government grants and loans and private donations. A steel skeleton is going up that will support the 2,750-seat concert hall for the New Jersey Symphony, among others; a 500-seat theater, shops and two restaurants.
Now, a year before the scheduled opening, the center's leaders have chosen the people who will figure out what to put on its stages.
In a ceremony a week ago, the arts center's board introduced its selections. The head programmer is Stephanie S. Hughley, 46, who produced the National Black Arts Festival in Atlanta; the associate is William W. Lockwood Jr., 57, currently of the McCarter Theater in Princeton. They start work in the fall.
Mr. Lockwood has had plenty of time to witness the effect a major arts center can have on real estate. For 27 years, he produced concerts and other programs at Lincoln Center, including Great Performers, Serious Fun and Mostly Mozart, the last of which is as much a part of New York City in the summer as gushing fire hydrants.
 Now he wants to do the same thing for his native state, where, as a Princeton undergraduate, he used his own savings to dabble in show business, bringing the Kingston Trio, the Weavers and Carl Sandburg to the campus to perform.
 "All roads lead through or to Newark," he said. "We have a clean slate. We hope to draw people seeking performances of all shapes and sizes. Rather than just watching TV or renting a movie, they'll have N.J.P.A.C."
 Ms. Hughley, too, talks of luring people out of the house and into the concert hall. She wants concerts and shows from the East and Africa as well as Europe and the Americas.
 "Our mission is to be multicultural," she said from Atlanta, where she is producer for arts and entertainment for the 1996 Olympic Games. "We want a place for New Jersey's artists of all nationalities."
 "I want to do classics," she said. "But when you talk about classicism, you don't just mean the West. Every culture has classics. I want people to have cultural experiences that are familiar and comfortable, of course. But I also want to push the borders. It's important to have a moment where the artist comes and touches you -- not just demonstrates in front of you. If you don't sit down and communicate with the audience, you don't change the way they think. You have to embrace different cultures. If you don't, the world won't change."
 Ms. Hughley is wrapping up the most international of programs, three years of choosing and producing dances, concerts and other entertainment to go with next summer's Olympics. She says she has traveled the world, seeking out little-known troupes.
 When she was younger, Ms. Hughley said, she knew she loved the arts, especially dance, but never imagined the arts would provide her with a living. She went to Kent State University and Antioch College, majoring in premedical studies, and, after college, was a medical technologist for a short time.
But more than science, she loved modern dance and ballet, which she had studied since 18, and eventually made her way to New York, dancing and helping out at the Alvin Ailey and Fred Benjamin dance companies. She found that her talents lay not in performing but in handing the details, making it possible for others to be on stage. She moved into theater, working on such Broadway shows as "Ain't Misbehavin'," "For Colored Girls" and "Bubbling Brown Sugar."
 "I did everything from payrolls to budgets, contracts to union stuff, box office to settlements, publicity, marketing," she said. "I was a different kind of manager, being an artist. Usually, it becomes us and them, actors versus management, but I was an artist, too."
 She did not, at first, want to leave New York for Atlanta, but her husband longed for his old home. There, in a city where the majority is black, she produced her biggest shows, the National Black Arts Festival, weeks of African and African-American arts and music with mock villages from African countries and the American South. Half a million people attended the festivals in 1988, 1990 and 1992.
 Like Ms. Hughley, Mr. Lockwood loved the arts -- in his case, music and theater -- in college but never dreamed he could support himself that way. But the shows he produced at the McCarter got him an introduction to and, after graduating, a job with a master producer, Sol Hurok.
 "He was a brilliant man, very difficult, autocratic, despotic," Mr. Lockwood said. "He knew this business. He had a canny sense of what would sell. Working for Hurok was experience you could not buy or get from any course or book."
 Though he is known for producing classical music concerts, Mr. Lockwood said he loves rock and pop. "I'm a dedicated Deadhead," he said of the Grateful Dead.
 The ultimate reward, he said of his profession of 30 years, is to stand in the back of a theater or concert hall and watch the communication establish itself between the stage and the people in the seats. "It's a viable connection, a chemistry," he said. "It doesn't always happen, but I'm very much aware of when it does."
 Rob Gibson, director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, said: "Stephanie is a real vision-oriented person. She's unassuming and very, very talented. She's pretty good with film, very good with music and extremely knowledgeable about dance and theater. She and Lockwood are an interesting tandem. Bill is really strong in music. He's excellent in marketing and a brilliant programmer, brilliant at selling tickets at the box office."
New Jersey's investors, officials from the state and from Newark city government and all who are working on the arts center, Arts hope, of course, that it will do for downtown Newark what Lincoln Center did for the West Side of Manhattan. But Mr. Lockwood and Ms. Hughley both say they do not want to try to duplicate Lincoln Center on the Passaic.
 "Obviously, people will always go to New York," Mr. Lockwood said. "But we think there's audience enough for all. It's logical that if we have a great performing arts institute, people will be interested in coming to Newark. Whether it's electronic music or the Dead or Bob Dylan, the Boston Symphony, Alvin Ailey, Liza Minnelli, we want to have whatever will bring people into the seats. We want to be responsive to what they want to see and hear, and we want to try and educate them, introduce them to new experiences, not just the tried and true."
Ms. Hughley said she wants more than stage performances. She wants the artists to go into schools and meet the audience.
 "I see this center as standing on the edge of the future," she said. "I love Pavarotti, but I want to know who the next Pavarotti is. I love symphonic music. I want to know who the Mozarts of today are."
 The New Jersey Performing Arts Center is due to open for the 1996-97 season. The open question is, will people go to downtown Newark, or stay there after work, to see shows? The center's backers say there are 4.5 million people living within 25 miles of it. To succeed, the center's directors have to allay fears of being in Newark downtown at night as well as overcome the habit of sliding a tape into the VCR.
 "Skeptics say this won't ever get off the ground," Mr. Lockwood said. "Come look. Looking at the steel superstructure, it's easy for the imagination to fill in the sides and the seats and see the orchestra pit. There's no reason why something serious like music and dance can't be entertainment, pure entertainment. It's pragmatic -- that's what will tear them away from their couches."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new program directors, William W. Lockwood Jr. and Stephanie S. Hughley, at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. (Steve J. Sherman)
 
Chronology: "From Idea to Reality, the Making of a Performing Arts Center"
December 1986 -- Gov. Thomas H. Kean hires C. W. Shaver & Company to recommend the type, size and location of a center that would meet current and future needs of the state's performing arts organizations.
July 1987 -- Governor Kean announces that the center will be in Newark.
June 1989 -- Lawrence P. Goldman is named president of the center.
September 1989 -- The U.S. Senate's Appropriations Committee approves $1.2 million for planning, design and site preparation.
November 1990 -- Barton Myers, architect, is selected to design the first phase of the center including restaurants, shops, a multipurpose theater and Theater Square, a public plaza.
February 1991 -- The master plan for the center's 12-acre site and a proposal to create a surrounding cultural district are unveiled.
January 1993 -- The Economic Recovery Fund, including $40 million for the center, wins approval from the New Jersey Legislature.
May 1994 -- A 212-piece mural created by 2,000 children in the state is dedicated. It will ring the construction site.
June 1995 -- Stephanie S. Hughley and William W. Lockwood Jr. are introduced as the artistic team responsible for programming.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Are the Bulls Headed For Europe Now?

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
HERE in Europe, it is often said that market trends are like the prevailing weather patterns: they blow from west to east. What is hot in America, the reasoning goes, eventually blows out over the Atlantic and arrives on the Continent some months later.
Now, with near unanimity, investment advisers are forecasting warm and sunny weather ahead for European stocks. 
 This year, American stocks have enjoyed their most impressive six-month run-up since 1987, giving investors an 18.6 percent bonanza. But now, with the combination of a weakening economy and low projected growth in corporate earnings, many analysts are wondering how much higher this market can go.
Not so in Europe. Here, strategists are predicting that a collection of economic conditions -- falling interest rates, a depressed dollar that should only go higher against European currencies and much stronger growth in corporate earnings -- will produce the world's best equities markets for the second half of 1995.
"By the end of November you will see a number of European markets at historic highs," said Thomas Tilse, chief equities strategist for the Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "The opportunities here far outweigh what you could get in the United States. It will be worth it for American investors to diversify."
To be sure, predicting market moves carries risks, and none of the big brokerage firms are recommending that investors pour all their assets into European stocks. They warn that if the German central bank decides not to lower rates or if the dollar fails to recover against the German mark, European stocks will underperform expectations. And there is the potential that the United States bull market will continue.
Morgan Stanley's global portfolio, for example, is still underweight in European stocks, though the firm has been increasing its recommended holdings recently.
It is not that Europe has been a laggard in the first half. While everyone has been watching the roaring bull market in the United States and the collapse of markets in Latin America and Japan, Europe's markets have quietly been a respectable second.
Measured in local currencies, for example, these stocks have risen 4.3 percent. But investors who sold dollars to buy overseas stocks on their own markets in, say, January did much better. Since currencies like the mark and Swiss franc rose in value against the dollar, American investors in these markets not only enjoyed the rise in these stocks in local currency terms but they also gained on the appreciation of those currencies against the dollar.
In dollar terms, European stocks rose 11.4 percent in the first half of the year, and two markets even outperformed American stocks: the Swiss market, which was up 22 percent, and the Finnish, which increased by 27 percent. Moreover, two other markets did almost as well as the American markets: the Netherlands, up 15.2 percent, and Belgium, up 15.4 percent.
This was all happening as stocks in the Pacific basin fell 7 percent in dollar terms, and emerging markets -- in countries like Argentina, Turkey and Brazil -- are off nearly 8 percent this year.
NOW, looking to the second half, many equities strategists are predicting that Europe and the United States will trade places at the top of the global markets.
They are urging their customers to shuffle their portfolios away from American stocks and into more European issues. UBS Global Research is recommending that clients increase their holdings of European stocks by almost 20 percent and reduce their North American portfolios by the same amount.
Goldman, Sachs is predicting that, in dollar terms, American stocks will rise 5.5 percent over the next 12 months, while there will be returns of 19.3 percent from Swedish stocks, 17.4 percent from Swiss stocks, 15.4 percent from German stocks and 12.2 percent from British stocks. The calculations are based on expected appreciation plus dividends and are hedged against a rising dollar.
This push-pull relationship between American and European markets underscores the importance of global diversification for American investors. Salomon Brothers calculates that someone who invested 100 percent in American stocks since January 1986 would have had an annual compounded rate of return of 10.4 percent. But if half of those holdings had been a mixture of European and Asian equities, the return would have been 11.7 percent. This means that a $100,000 investment made in January 1986 would be worth $167,214 more to the investor who diversified.
"Why should you invest in European equities? Because there is only one free lunch -- diversification," said Ralf Conen, an equities strategist in Frankfurt and London for Salomon Brothers. "A basket of international stocks plus American stocks clearly gives you a higher return."
But analysts warn that not all European markets will perform equally. Moreover, they say, in order to maximize their gains in Europe, American investors should both weigh the outlook for markets at home and take steps to protect their European investments should foreign currencies fall against the dollar.
In urging their clients to look to Europe for the rest of this year and into 1996, the analysts are largely betting that two things will happen: The Continent will continue to rise out of recession and the dollar will gain strength against European currencies.
While the American economy and corporate earnings were growing in 1992 and 1993, Europe was mired in its worst postwar recession. The European economy is tied to interest rates set by the powerful German central bank, and all of Europe suffered as the Bundesbank pushed up interest rates to economy-crushing levels to stanch the inflationary effects of vast new spending in the former East Germany.
Only last year did the European economy begin to grow as corporate profits exploded and earnings growth in the United States began to weaken.
Still, so far this year, European stock prices have been somewhat dampened by the rise of the German mark and other strong European currencies against the dollar. This is because these stronger currencies tend to make European exports more expensive and less competitive, thus dragging down earnings of export-oriented companies like Daimler-Benz. (At the same time, a weak dollar makes American exports less expensive abroad and thus more competitive, pushing up American corporate earnings.)
But the consensus here is that the dollar has bottomed out. Though it is now trading at just under 1.40 German marks, analysts say the dollar should recover to a range of 1.50 to 1.55 marks through the end of the year. This would turn the export picture -- and the markets -- around, depressing American corporate earnings and benefiting European companies.
And there is another factor at work, the analysts say: Even as the strong mark is beginning to dampen economic growth, it has reduced fears of inflation, creating an environment in which analysts expect the Bundesbank to lower rates later this summer. And as rates fall in Europe, that tends to push up stock prices, since dividend yields on stocks come closer to yields on bonds.
Of course, even in the rosiest outlook, not all European markets are likely to rise, and analysts tend to be divided on which will do better than the others.
Still, there is near unanimity that Italy, with high levels of debt and deep political instability, is not the place for big returns over the next months, and there are strong advocates for Swedish, Dutch, Swiss, German, British, even Spanish and French stocks.
Given an expected fall in interest rates, analysts tend to focus on markets with a high component of banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions. These companies hold large amounts of financial instruments on their balance sheets that rise in value when rates fall.
The Netherlands and Switzerland are on top of most lists, since both have a large number of financial institutions, like the ING Bank, the Dutch bank that recently bought the failed Barings Bank of Britain, and the Swiss Bank Corporation, Switzerland's second-largest bank, which struck a deal to buy the British merchant bank, S. G. Warburg.
Other European financial institutions that are on the buy list for major brokerage firms are Allianz, Germany's largest insurance company, and Commerzbank, the country's No. 3 bank.
The Netherlands and Switzerland are also characterized as having companies that are big in consumer products, which analysts say should benefit over the coming months, among them Philips, the Dutch consumer electronics company, and Roche, the Swiss pharmaceutical company.
Germany and Sweden are two other markets that are often lumped together because they have a high component of so-called cyclical stocks, companies whose earnings tend to rise strongly in the first part of an economic expansion and taper off as orders for their products diminish as the economy weakens.
If Europe was seen to be heading into a long recession, almost every brokerage would probably be issuing sell orders on German and Swedish stocks. But that is not the case. Some analysts are neutral, fearing the effects in Germany, for example, on the export earnings of its companies because of the strong German mark.
THAT point was driven home rudely last week, when Daimler-Benz announced that because of the high mark, particularly affecting its aerospace industry, it would report a "severe loss" in 1995. Daimler stock fell almost 7 percent on the news.
But many analysts like some German stocks. For example, Mr. Conen of Salomon Brothers describes Mannesmann A.G. as a "cash cow," because after several years of heavy investment to build the second German national cellular telephone system, it will begin reaping the benefits this year of large revenue inflows.
Much against the grain of other investment advisers, Mr. Conen is pushing Daimler stock, despite the shock of last week. He is predicting that the new Mercedes E-series car introduced just last week will meet enormous demand and that Daimler will start to benefit from a rising dollar and could be very profitable.
"All the worst things are now coming together, creating a lot of sentiment against Daimler," Mr. Conen said. "Into that weakness I would be a buyer, because fear breeds opportunity."
The Union Bank of Switzerland's Global Research also has Mannesmann on its buy list, as well as Hoechst A.G., the giant German chemical and pharmaceutical company.
Just as there is division over German stocks, there is also a divergence over Swedish stocks. Mark Howdle, head of European Equity Strategy at UBS, says Sweden, along with Italy and Germany, are among the markets the firm predicts will turn in the weakest performances.
However, at Commerzbank, analysts say the Swedish market is greatly undervalued, especially since the Government has taken measures to bring big deficits down. Mr. Tilse at Commerzbank sees the market jumping more than 21 percent in local currency terms over the next six months.
Goldman, Sachs also ranks Sweden among the most attractive markets worldwide, predicting a similar market increase, and saying that the country's pulp and paper industry is particularly attractive.
France and Spain are often lumped with Italy and referred to as the Club Med countries, with traditionally weak currencies, a tendency to devaluation and therefore highly sensitive to movements in interest rates. These countries' markets tend to get hurt more than their neighbors when interest rates rise, since to defend the value of their currencies, local central banks have to push up interest rates more than in Germany, thus hurting economic growth and corporate earnings.
But once rates begin to fall the bounce effect on corporate earnings is faster and bigger than in the hard-currency countries like the Netherlands, Austria and Germany. Thus it is not surprising that Spain, and to a lesser extent France, turn up on the positive list at major firms.
Brent Janssen, European stock analyst for UBS, noted that based on price/earnings ratios, Spanish stocks were selling at near historic lows relative to returns on bonds, offering investors bargain prices and a good chance for appreciation.
Moreover, political uncertainty over whether Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, will have to step down from office before the 1996 elections has diminished and is making for a more stable investment climate. Commerzbank sees Spanish stocks rising 11.4 percent in local currency by year end.
In France, there is not as much optimism, primarily because the new President, Jacques Chirac, has proposed large new taxes to finance ambitious programs to reduce unemployment. Analysts warn that even though French stocks are cheap relative to bond prices, it will be a while before the political climate settles down.
Still, there are some stock recommendations on French shares, such as AXA, the large French insurance company, and Societe Generale, the country's second-largest bank, and in the consumer area, L'Oreal, the cosmetic company.
Finally, the British market is in favor with many analysts, although they recommend that investors wait to see if Prime Minister John Major wins next month's Conservative leadership fight.
Britain's economic cycle is more advanced than that in continental Europe and more closely tied to the American economy. But it may get the best of both worlds, benefiting from falling rates and slower but continued growth in Europe.
Moreover, British stocks are offering some of Europe's best values, said Richard G. Davidson, European equities strategist for Morgan Stanley in London, paying, on average, 4.5 percent in dividends, compared with 3.5 percent in all of Europe.
Also, prices relative to earnings are low compared with other European markets. P/E's on projected 1995 results are now 12.8 percent in Britain, compared with 13.5 percent for all of Europe.
Several of the country's banks, like National Westminster, are currently on buy lists, as are some of its telecommunications companies, like Vodaphone and Cable and Wireless.
"We started the year with a negative view on Europe, but we changed that around mid-April," Mr. Davidson said. "And I am still quite happy to hold more European equities."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Remember Growing Pains?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
This bull market may not be the best ever, but it is one of the most painless.
The exciting news for American stock owners is that in the first half of 1995 share prices advanced across the board, with the Standard & Poor's composite up 18.6 percent, not including dividends. But the most remarkable aspect of that is the smooth way in which it happened. 
 Only twice so far in 1995 has has the S.& P. 500 fallen more than 1 percent in a day, with the second one being last Monday.
We went looking through history and found that such an absence of bad days is truly extraordinary, particularly in a period when prices are leaping. It is a cliche that a bull market climbs a wall of worries, and those fears are usually manifest in occasional bad days.
The last time the S.& P. did better than in this year's first half was in the first half of 1987, when the index rose 25.5 percent. A wonderful performance (to be ruined, to be sure, by the subsequent crash) but one in which the index had 14 bad days.
The first half of 1986 was also great for shareholders, with the S.& P. up by 18.7 percent, but that performance was marred by 12 bad days.
What gives? Part of the answer is that there is no hot new trading technique to roil markets. In the 1970's, there was block trading by institutions, and in the 1980's there were index arbitrage and other forms of program trading. For a time, other traders found it hard to deal with both, and there were sometimes big moves brought on by such strategies that had nothing to do with investors' fundamental outlooks on the economy. Now, markets have adjusted.
But what this really represents is a new confidence in American investors. Stocks, the academics and the sales brochures tell us, are the best long-term investment over any period. So if you are investing for the long haul, for retirement or for the kids' college education, you should buy stocks and forget about it. Let a mutual fund manager handle the details of what stocks to own. Since the recovery from the 1987 crash, mutual fund investors are more likely to buy than to sell in response to bad days.
Stock mutual funds now have more than $1 trillion in assets -- ten times what they had a decade ago -- and fund managers keep less in cash than at any time since the 1970's. That is because they too believe that stocks are wonderful long-term investments, and because what they fear most is being out of stocks when they zoom. So while fund managers are quite willing to dump a stock if bad news hits, they immediately buy something else, pushing up prices of other stocks and keeping the market from enduring really bad days.
If you accept that stocks are always the best investment, then there is no point in looking at such traditional indicators as the dividend payout ratio, now at its lowest point ever. The gospel of the time is that market timing is stupid and hopeless.
The closest thing to the current attitude of "you never need to sell the stock market" came in the early 1970's, when the era of "one-decision stocks" sent the Nifty 50 growth stocks into the stratosphere. The theory was that such stocks were destined to grow forever, so they need never be sold. The full year of 1972 saw only six bad days in the stock market, the lowest for any year in the past three decades.
In 1973, long after value-oriented analysts had thrown up their hands in dismay, the worst bear market since the 1930's got underway. Perhaps the lesson is that gains without pain are destined to wane.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Funds With a Continental Flair

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
A SIZZLING year in 1993 put European stock funds on the map. The number of funds in the group nearly doubled, to 43, soon afterward.
If this year's returns continue apace, as the pundits are suggesting, look for the group's ranks to swell again next year. 
 European stock funds have returned 12 percent on average in the first half of 1995, following a measly increase of less than 2 percent last year. And the hot streak is far from over, predicted E. Andrew Lohmeier, an analyst with Morningstar Inc., the funds research firm in Chicago. "Trailing five-year returns are still pretty anemic" on the Europe funds, he said. For the five years ended in May, the Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 11.4 percent annually, while Europe stock funds gained only 4.7 percent.
Europe has been mostly in a recession since 1990, when German interest rates moved up to cover the high costs of reunification. In fact, Europe stock funds have had only one good year since 1989. That was 1993, when they gained 26.9 percent on average, thanks to a combination of lower interest rates and investor expectations of an economic recovery the following year. But the recovery mostly fizzled in 1994.
Once again, talk of economic expansion is in the air, perhaps signaling a good time to buy. Europe stock funds provide international exposure -- frequently a goal for long-term investors -- with little of the volatility of developing countries, Mr. Lohmeier said.
Despite overall disappointments, a few pockets in Europe performed relatively well last year. Funds that invest in small companies led the pack -- DFA Continental Small Company Fund was ranked second among the 43 funds. Other leaders had big holdings in smaller countries like Ireland, Finland and Sweden.
Both trends have reversed this year. DFA Continental Small Company has slipped to 37th place, as large company stocks have outpaced smaller ones. And funds invested in Germany and the other big markets have grabbed the lead.
Mr. Lohmeier favors two funds sold without a sales charge, T. Rowe Price European Stock and the Vanguard International Index-European, each of which has been around at least five years. Among funds with sales charges, he recommends Putnam Europe Growth and Pioneer Europe, with 5.75 percent levies.
Exchange rates have played a big part in fund gains so far this year. Countries whose currencies are closely linked to the German mark profited the most, as the mark appreciated against the dollar. As the dollar declines, the value of Americans' investments abroad rises.
If the dollar picks up, American investors in the Europe funds should be protected because the vast majority of the funds hedge against currency risk. In hindsight, the funds have hedged too much over the last four or five years, Mr. Lohmeier said, damping their returns. Notable funds that do not hedge are the two DFA funds and the Vanguard European index fund.
Because currency rates are notoriously difficult to forecast -- much like interest rates -- investors waiting for the dollar to recover could be on the sidelines years hence.
