HEADLINE: A New Kind of Suburbia Arises Out of the New Jersey Farmlands

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, N.J.

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, fields of corn, barley and wheat stretched for hundreds of acres in all directions from the crossing of South Middlebush Road and Claremont Road here in southern Somerset County. But in the last decade, the cropland has vanished. Now the area is filled with 2,600 new single-family homes, garden apartments and town houses.
To city dwellers and even residents of the older, close-in suburbs, these new outlying developments, like the Wynnefield Village town houses and garden apartments, seem isolated. 
 Wrong, says one of Wynnefield Village's new settlers, Jim Menke, 36-year-old president of an engineering company based in Hillside, N.J., near Newark, that designs pharmaceutical equipment. "This is the center point," Mr. Menke said. "You're an hour from the Jersey Shore, 42 miles from the center of Manhattan; you're next door to Princeton, two hours from the Poconos and an hour and a half outside Philly."
In the last decade, Mr. Menke and tens of thousands of others like him have poured into hundreds of new housing developments scattered across the farmlands and meadows of six northern and central New Jersey counties, Somerset, Morris, Hunterdon, Middlesex, Monmouth and Ocean. The Census Bureau estimates that since 1990, the six counties have accounted for two-thirds of the population growth in New Jersey, or 114,800 of the state's 173,000 increase.
Mr. Menke's new neighbors include hundreds of young couples in their 20's and 30's and families with preschoolers. Though urban dwellers think of them in terms of their distance from New York City or Philadelphia, they do not see themselves that way, and do not typically work in those two cities nor spend a great deal of their leisure time there. Indeed, at the time they bought, more than twice as many of the people in Mr. Menke's subdivision worked in Somerset or neighboring Middlesex as in New York City.
These outer suburban counties are changing the face of central New Jersey, challenging the decades-old reign of the four post-World War II suburban boom counties closest to Manhattan -- Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic -- as the state's most powerful population center and its economic heartland.
In 1980, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic had nearly 563,000 more residents than the six upstarts. Now their edge has tumbled to just fewer than 80,000, at 2,622,000 to 2,542,300, according to census estimates.
In terms of new jobs, the six outer suburbs have outpaced the four inner suburbs by a wide margin since 1982, according to a 1994 study of non-government jobs by James W. Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca of Rutgers University.
"We've reinvented the geography of the New Jersey economy," said Dr. Hughes, associate dean at the Rutgers School of Planning and Public Policy.
In 1989, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Passaic had nearly 167,000 more jobs than Morris, Somerset, Hunterdon, Middlesex, Monmouth and Ocean. The lead of the four older suburban counties fell to about 61,000 (987,000 to 926,000) by September 1993, the last year the state's county-by-county job figures were available, the study said.
And if not for the arrival of 91,000 immigrants from overseas in the four inner suburban counties, there would have been severe population losses there.
Years ago in the four older counties, most jobs sprouted along railroad corridors and older state highways, like 3, 4, 1 and 9.
Job growth in the six surging counties in the 1970's and 80's depended on new offices built on cheap farmland and woodlands made accessible by interstate highways 78, 287 and 80, and the Garden State Parkway, Dr. Hughes said.
The 400 town houses and garden apartments of Wynnefield Village make up the newest section of a sprawling development, Society Hill at Somerset, which looms from the fields about a 10-minute drive down South Middlebush Road from Exit 6 along Interstate 287. Cars are critical to the jobs and life styles of most residents.
The project's developer, the K. Hovnanian Companies, New Jersey's busiest housing contractor, priced the two- and three-bedroom homes in Wynnefield Village, now three years old, from $106,950 to $138,950, hoping to attract young, first-time home buyers, and the strategy seems to have worked. A majority of the 200 or so buyers who answered a K. Hovnanian survey said they had been renters under 40 with no children and family incomes under $60,000 a year. Most came to Wynnefield Village from Somerset or neighboring Middlesex County. The next biggest batch came from New York City -- 12 from Brooklyn, 11 from Manhattan and 8 from Staten Island.
At the time they bought, 86 worked in Somerset or Middlesex, 42 in New York City and the others in counties across northern and central New Jersey.
Michael and Michelle Redfern were among the earliest buyers in Wynnefield Village. "For now, this is perfect for us," Mr. Redfern said. He works as a manager for a company that packages liquid pharmaceuticals. His office is only 15 minutes away, in Dayton, N.J. "By Exit 8A on the turnpike," he said.
Overwhelmingly, the new jobs in offices and headquarters campuses on or near the interstates are white-collar professional, including engineering, administrative, pharmaceutical, telecommunications, high technology, information processing, accounting and law, he added.
Public transportation and reliance on jobs in Manhattan are alien to most workers in the six surging counties. The 1990 census found that about 5 percent of workers in the six counties, or 61,236, worked in Manhattan, as opposed to 11.5 percent, or about 146,000, in the other four.
That affects the way residents see the world. Speaking about the convenience of this area, Kevin Kendall, who lives on deLeon Circle with his wife, Eileen, and their two young children, first said, "It's local to Princeton." Before moving here from Bergen County, Mr. Kendall, 33, worked in the Inspector General's office in New York City's Human Resources Administration. Since then, he has become an insurance adjuster, based in Philadelphia.
Wynnefield Village's settlers say they enjoy the community pool and tennis courts, the block parties, the bus trips to Atlantic City and the pick-up basketball and football games on Sunday mornings.
Sal Monaco, 68, came from Carnarsie a couple of years ago after finishing 36 years of work in a Brooklyn factory that produced molasses and brown sugar. He misses the old neighborhood stores and the rumble of the subway. But Mr. Monaco said his new home in Society Hill at Somerset has pluses, too.
"I feel safer here," he said. "There's no hangouts, there's no noise and there's no kids taking dope and breaking windows. I'm at the age where I don't need teen-agers around."
Growth brings problems, too, of course. According to the 1990 census, at least 80 percent of the workers in each of the six outer suburban counties drove alone to work or took a car pool, producing heavy reliance on the interstates and state highways that helped create, and disperse, all the new jobs since 1982. Usually, they also produce bumper-to-bumper rush-hour crawls.
Years ago, Franklin Township was a secluded farming town of 50 square miles, with a tiny urban corner bordering New Brunswick on the northeast, a few historic hamlets on the Delaware and Raritan Canal along its western border and vast fields and woodlands in the middle. But between 1980 and 1990, its population grew to nearly 43,000 from 31,350.
A small piece of Interstate 287, including Exit 6, crosses its northern tip now. New motels and offices, including one for AT&T and another for Merrill Lynch, are tucked next to the exit. Wherever Bob Puskas goes he sees cars. Mr. Puskas is the last dairy farmer on South Middlebush Road. Years ago, he had the narrow two-lane road pretty much to himself. Now he refuses to take his equipment onto South Middlebush or herd his 40 Holsteins across it before 9:30 in the morning or after 3 in the afternoon.

HEADLINE: Job Insecurity: A special report.;
In New Work World, Employers Call All the Shots

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, July 2

 BODY:
Not so long ago, American workers would suffer the sting of a recession by losing jobs or having their hours or wages reduced. They responded by taking part-time work, signing with temp agencies and just making do -- at least until the economy revived. Then they would pour back to work, their wages rising as employers competed for their services.
Not anymore. Recent reports suggest that the economy is starting to sputter after perking along for the four years since the last recession. But whatever the economy's prospects, the latest stretch of growth shows that for all but professionals, executives, new college graduates, and the most skilled blue-collar workers, many problems that workers faced only in bad times have become fixtures in all times: Some wages are still falling, people must be ready to work 12-hour shifts and 6-day weeks, and no job is for keeps. 
 "The difference between today's economy and a recession is anyone can get a job who wants one; it just depends on what you call a job," said Gary Galloway of Tarrant County Junior College here, who oversees retraining for aircraft workers laid off by the Lockheed Martin Corporation.
Of 124 million people who were working in May, 8 million -- 2.2 million more than a decade ago -- moonlighted, or held two or more jobs simultaneously. Of 22 million part-timers, 4.5 million wanted full-time work and could not get it. The number of temporary workers has tripled in a decade to 2.1 million in May. And the average hourly wage, in terms of what people can buy with it, has been falling since 1973.
Three factors -- weakening unions, foreign competition and automation -- are undermining workplace verities, like annual salary increases and regular promotions, on which most Americans counted and from which they charted their future.
These factors are well entrenched in the widely diversified economy of Fort Worth. Unemployment in the city last month was 5.9 percent, just above the national rate of 5.7 percent. The area is awash with big service, restaurant and retail store employers. The corpses of old businesses and bunting of newcomers line mall-encrusted highways.
Like many northern cities, Fort Worth and neighboring Arlington have a mix of unionized manufacturing industries that pay $30,000 to more than $50,000 a year, well above the $23,000 average for American workers, and new, largely nonunion industries -- electronics and telecommunications -- that typically pay half the old industry wages.
But here, as nationally, the old industries are contracting. Fifteen years ago, factories in the area provided 25 percent of all the jobs; the figure is 16 percent today, in line with the decline nationwide. Last week, General Motors Corporation said it would eliminate 1,200 jobs in October at an automobile plant in Arlington, leaving about 2,000 jobs. Lockheed Martin has chopped its work force from 32,000 to 13,000 since 1990.
What has emerged for most people here, -- as for most other Americans -- is a new and unstable work world in which they feel that the employer can call all the shots.
"Before, looking for a job meant you were looking for someone who was looking for you," said Earl Davis Jr., a 48-year-old divorced father of three from Fort Worth who lost his $49,000-a-year job with Lockheed in 1993 after a Pentagon budget cut. "Now you have to go out and convince someone that you've got something no one else has."
Low-wage workers say they feel like yo-yos, yanked from part-time work to full-time work and back, from the day shift one week to the lobster shift the next.
For the average worker with a high school diploma or a little college, wages that would rise with the economy are not budging. In factories, high-paid assembly-line jobs keep disappearing as though the recession never ended, and it has become harder to find a job paying even $8 an hour, or $16,000 a year.
For the jobs that are available, employers insist on applicants with experience -- even when the skills required could be learned quickly, like stocking store shelves and cleaning motel rooms. They make no commitments to the people they hire, however. Indeed, since the late 80's, employers have been using temporary help agencies like spigots, bringing temporary workers in when business heats up and pulling the plug on them when it cools.
 
Searching
Wage Illusions Meet New Realities
 As workers' job security has evaporated, so has their bargaining power -- their ability to ask for more money, more vacation time, more health benefits. Across the nation, and across industries, employees perceive that they are more vulnerable to dismissal now than in the past.
Mr. Davis, for example, said he thought he had broad and readily marketable management experience from Lockheed, where he was a mid-level executive, and from an earlier job at a shipbuilder.
But he said no one had been willing to take him on for even half his old salary. So, while grinding out resumes and job applications, Mr. Davis makes ends meet with a part-time job delivering and installing computers to a computer store's customers for $20 a trip.
Even if Mr. Davis lands a regular job, he can probably forget about the periodic raises that once came automatically to lift his living standard. From $9.66 six years ago, just before the recession, the average hourly wage has increased to the current $11.40. But the increase was an illusion; inflation outpaced it, so workers cannot buy as much as they once did for their wages. And now, since the recession's end, even the illusion of rising wages is withering.
"From my perspective," said Chuck Reed, who owns a Minute Man temporary help agency in Arlington, "wages have been frozen for the last four years."
But as employers freeze wages, they demand more experience. "Nothing is unskilled any longer," Mr. Reed said. "Even digging ditches. Employers want someone who's been digging ditches. They want a mechanic who's operated this type of machine to operate this type of machine. They want a janitor for a health care facility who's been a janitor in a health care facility."
Darlyne Stewart, a job counselor in the Texas Employment Commission's office in Arlington, is witnessing both phenomena. Consulting her computerized list of job offers from local employers, she noted: "Here's one from a manufacturing company. They make plastics. In April last year, they wanted a trainee assembler for $5.75 to $6.05 and no experience. Now they want one for $5.75 with three months' experience."
Another company is seeking a worker to load trucks and make deliveries. It offered $9.49 for the job last June, $9.79 in October and $9.49 again this month.
 
Disappearing
Automation Hits At Skilled Jobs
 In Fort Worth, people closest to the job market suspect that the continuous march of automation, first in factories, now in ever-more computerized offices and shops, is the main culprit undermining the job market. Automation has struck hardest at the middle range of the wage scale, jobs paying $8 to $14 an hour: those of skilled clerks, some assembly-line workers and machine operators.
"We're not seeing as many of those jobs, and they have been the slowest to come back," said Michael Wallace, the manager of a state employment commission office in Fort Worth. "The competition for them is really fierce."
What remains is an oversupply of semiskilled workers who must settle for low-skilled, low-wage jobs, like running convenience store cash registers and waiting tables, that do not lend themselves to automation. Demand for those workers has strengthened with the economy, but the wages -- $4.50 to $6 an hour, not much above the Federal minimum wage of $4.25 -- will not lift most one-worker families out of poverty.
Mary Bryant, for example, a 38-year-old single mother with a 6-month-old son, Dylan, says $9 an hour, or $18,000 a year, is the threshold she must meet to stay off charity and welfare. It is just enough, she said, to let her move out of her son's godparents' house, rent an apartment and pay the $65 weekly cost of child care.
"I just can't take less than that," Ms. Bryant said. "It's not going to benefit my son to get a job where I know I'm going to starve."
Her credentials would seem to qualify her for the pay she wants. She has two years of college and more than 10 years of experience in clerical jobs with banks.
A month ago she lost a $9-an-hour clerical job for a retail map store because the business was failing. Then two weeks ago she found another $9-an-hour, full-time job as a clerk with a mortgage company.
But she has also found that whatever her skills and experience, this job market can take her or leave her. "The day before I was to go to work," she said, "I got an infection in my lymph nodes." She was scared because she had only recently suffered from cancer, and had had a hysterectomy.
"I asked my new bosses if they could hold the job one extra day," she said. "They couldn't."
 
Coping
Worker Flexibility, By Choice or Not
 Ms. Bryant, at least, can still vie for a regular, full-time job paying an adequate wage. Ben Almond, 30, says he is trapped under a "paper ceiling" -- with no college diploma or other credentials testifying to his expertise as a health-care aide.
Clean cut and eager looking, Mr. Almond has two sons, ages 3 and 6; his wife stays home to care for them. He has a full-time job as a therapeutic recreation technician at a rehabilitation hospital and earns $6.79 an hour -- close to $960 a month -- helping patients with their exercises and playing games with them.
"In late February," he said, "the patient count went down. Everything revolves around the number of patients. So they moved me from full time to part time, meaning they would call me as needed.
"Then, they called me back in late April for three days a week. They wanted me to do central supply in the morning and do recreation technician in the afternoon."
Soon after, he was shifted to five days. "But the second week they said, 'Well, we're going to have to cut you back to five-and-a-half hours on Sundays,' " Mr. Almond recalled. "The guy said, 'It's nothing personal. Just a function of money.' "
For most workers, an often fruitful route into a permanent job is the temporary help agency, which has displaced the old Main Street employment agency.
Temporary agencies hire workers, pay their wages and dispatch them to regular employers for jobs that often become "temp-to-perm" trial runs. The employer typically takes three months to a year to size up a worker, then offers her a permanent job or sends her back to her real employer, the agency.
The number of temporary workers, some 2.1 million, seems minuscule in the work force of 124 million. But millions more workers have passed through the agencies into permanent jobs.
Six years ago, Ms. Crossett of the Texas Employment Commission said there were 51 temporary help agencies in Fort Worth and Arlington employing 4,937 workers. By late last year, she said, 154 agencies had 15,528 workers on their rolls.
"It's really a revolution," said Gary Burtless, a labor economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "Essentially, many employers have given up the idea they're going to screen employees and let temp agencies do the screening."
For all its turmoil, the job market has mellowed for at least one group of Americans. Carolyn Ulrickson, the director of career services at Texas Christian University here, said that after several lean years, offers flowed freely and starting salaries rose for this year's crop of college graduates.
Yet for these workers, too, employers are fussier, Ms. Ulrickson said. "I can remember back in the early 80's, I.B.M. would hire 6,000 graduates a year and Rockwell International 6,000," Ms. Ulrickson said. "Texaco used to schedule recruiting visits here three years in advance."
Today, she said, many employers send out only one recruiter or two from offices closest to the university, rather than pay for trips from headquarters. "And we're lucky if they call three weeks in advance," she said.
Few of these employers commit to lifetime careers, she said. They have applied to hiring practices their "just-in-time" method of inventory control, buying supplies the instant they are needed rather than stocking up on them.
Often, too, these veteran employers now use temporary help agencies. As Ms. Ulrickson explained, "They tell the agency, 'We have a project and we need four accountants. Show us some new graduates.' "

HEADLINE: AIDS Group Urges a Plan On Medicines

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
A Federal advisory group has urged the Government to provide drug companies with tax credits and protection against competition to accelerate development of new medicines for AIDS.
The pharmaceutical industry anticipates such limited profits that it is rapidly abandoning research on new AIDS drugs, the National Task Force on AIDS Drug Development said on Thursday. Except for new drugs called protease inhibitors, now in clinical trials, the pipeline is mostly empty, the group said. 
 "This is a major threat," said Peter Staley of the Treatment Action Group, an advocacy organization. He said the situation involves not just cash-strapped small firms, but larger companies that "simply are dropping AIDS when they do economic calculations of what research to pursue."
Dr. Daniel Hoth of Cell Genesys Inc. said that companies could not spend millions researching drugs to treat acquired immune deficiency syndrome unless the medicines hold the potential for big profits at a time when investment in drugs by the Government and Wall Street is lagging. "The investment environment is chilly to hostile with respect to investing in AIDS drugs," Dr. Hoth told the task force.
The task force, composed of patients, drug makers and government and private scientists, spent a year studying how to speed development of new AIDS drugs. Currently, there are only four.
On Thursday the panel forwarded its recommendations to the Clinton Administration. Here are some of its proposals:
*Offer a 50 percent tax credit for all clinical research into potential drugs for AIDS and the human immunodeficiency virus.
*Give several years of market exclusivity to all H.I.V. and AIDS treatments. AIDS drugs once automatically got seven years of exclusivity under a law to promote treatments for rare diseases, but too many Americans now have AIDS for it to qualify any longer as a rare or "orphan disease."
*Add an extra six months of exclusivity for drugs that are prepared in special infant formulations and are proven safe. Most AIDS drugs have a "lousy" track record of being studied for their effects in children, said Dr. David A. Kessler, the head of the Food and Drug Administration.
*Offer a 50 percent tax credit for studying additional uses for approved AIDS drugs.
The task force also won a pledge from the F.D.A. to issue written guidelines about exactly when it would approve a drug based on just one test in humans.
The agency normally requires more data, but has made exceptions for drugs to treat life-threatening diseases. But so few companies know this exception exists that they spend valuable time pursuing more trials.

HEADLINE: Malnutrition Hits Many Elderly

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Despite America's reputation for plenty, 25 percent of people age 65 or older may suffer from some form of malnutrition, experts say.
One half of elderly hospital patients are malnourished, as are two in five nursing home residents. Sixteen percent of all older people consume fewer than 1,000 calories a day. 
 Poverty is an obvious and common cause, but the condition is pervasive even among those who are not poor, the experts say.
"Too often people just focus on economics," said Deborah Clark, staff director of the Nutrition Screening Initiative, a research group lobbying doctors to routinely screen their patients for nutrition. "They think poor people don't have the money to get the right foods.
"That's a risk factor, but we're seeing it regardless of income because of things like medications, oral health, mental health and functional status."
Few doctors are trained to recognize malnutrition, despite knowing that well-nourished elderly people become ill less often, recover from illnesses and injuries quicker and are less expensive to treat, said Julie Stauss, a member of the American Dietetic Association's government affairs team.
"When we say malnutrition we don't mean our typical definition of malnutrition, like a starving child in a third world country," Ms. Stauss said. "You could look at someone and not know that they're malnourished. But since they are malnourished, that puts them at higher risk for additional disease and complications."
Advocates for the elderly want doctors and other health care providers to check their patients' nutritional status as routinely as they check their blood pressure. An American Dietetic Association study showed that for every dollar spent on nutrition screening and intervention, at least $3.25 in medical costs are saved.
Health care workers can gauge nutritional levels accurately by using one of several different questionnaires that ask about a person's eating habits, illnesses, medications, weight, alcohol consumption and social habits.

HEADLINE: Japanese Do Buy American: By Mail and a Lot Cheaper

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 2

 BODY:
Gathered outside a college classroom, Sayaka Fujimoto and six of her friends tore open their packages from the United States, and to the astonishment of their male friends who were watching, pulled out $1,133 worth of Victoria's Secret lingerie.
"We're going to have a sleep-over and wear everything -- like a fashion show," said Miss Fujimoto, a 20-year-old college student who often orders clothes through the mail along with her friends. 
 In Japan, Miss Fujimoto and her friends are part of a growing consumer rebellion, fighting sky-high prices with an American custom: mail orders.
If the recent trade dispute has given the impression that American goods are being held at bay, take a look at the near-doubling in the last year of American imports arriving in Japan by mail. Clothing and camping equipment, fishing tackle and cosmetics are here in record quantities. So are bicycles, musical instruments, even a small helicopter.
In a country where economic indexes all seem to be dropping -- stock prices, property prices, even sales at supermarkets -- mail orders from the United States are soaring.
American companies send hundreds of thousands of catalogues across the Pacific, and Japanese read them as if they were hot suspense novels, keeping them in office drawers for furtive browsing at dull moments. Indeed, mail-order shopping has become a blossoming American success story in Japan.
By conservative estimates, mail orders from the United States this year will total $750 million.
From its headquarters in Freeport, Me., L. L. Bean sends thousands of catalogues to consumers throughout Japan, now Bean's largest foreign market. Sales last year reached $100 million, up 66 percent from 1993.
The volume of packages has swelled so that the United States Postal Service, which handles much of the express mail, dispatched a delegation to Tokyo to improve coordination.
"The mail-order business is very, very promising these days," said Kiyotomo Sakuma, president of Eddie Bauer Japan Inc., whose sporty and casual clothing has become well known in this country.
The rise of the yen, which makes dollar-priced goods cheaper, has helped, and there is also a growing craze to buy what is considered the American look: the preppie at school, the camper in the wilderness, the fly-fisher on a rowboat, the healthy biker.
The Japanese seem to have a little more leisure time these days, and when Japanese think of leisure, their thoughts turn to the United States. Fortunately for American-mail order companies, Japanese are meticulous at getting the sporting look perfect, even if they can't sometimes enjoy the sport.
In Japan, lakes and rivers are so crowded that fishermen, with their eight-pocket jackets and spanking-new tackle boxes, end up sitting on the banks so close together that their rods bump and their lines tangle. And while families may buy American camping gear, the tents can end up pitched in the front yard where the children play.
Some Japanese are captivated by the novelty of buying by mail and avoiding the discomfort of shopping in Tokyo's crowded commercial areas.
They are also able to import small quantities of products like cosmetics or pharmaceuticals, favorite items that are difficult to find at home.
American auto makers and other industries complain that while Japanese tariffs are low, the nation's complex distribution system is a formidable barrier to entry. But catalogue sellers are able to turn that to their advantage, bypassing usual distribution channels. One result is that they enjoy a greater price advantage than in most other nations.
The Japanese mail- and package-delivery system is efficient and, by this country's standards, inexpensive -- although still twice as costly as in the United States. And as Japanese trade negotiators love to say, the average tariff on manufactured goods is only 2.2 percent, lower than in the United States.
Would-be catalogue-sellers still face some of the obstacles that bother the Big Three auto companies, for Japanese consumers are more brand- and quality-conscious than Americans. Instead of simply ordering something because it is cheap, Japanese want to buy from a company that has a reputation for quality.
Inside Tokyo's international post office, which handles most overseas mail, the floors are covered with mail-order parcels, stacked in ceiling-high piles. The overwhelming majority of labels are American: L. L. Bean, Lands' End and REI, to name a few.
The international post office had to hire new employees and clear a new floor to accommodate the increasing number of giant mail sacks, which increased from about 400 a day last year from the whole world to an average recently of 900 sacks just from the United States. Postal officials say that most of this, by volume, is mail-order merchandise, equivalent to about 50,000 pounds each day.
For the moment, it is such a freshly budding business -- the more prevalent domestic mail-order business accounts for 2 to 3 percent of retail sales -- that the Government does not publish statistics on the industry.
Nor does it separate mail-order purchases from other imports into Japan. But some industry experts say that the mail-order business could expand this year to three million packages, up from 2.6 million last year.
A Japanese mail order typically runs about $250, roughly twice an order in the United States. But both the value and the physical size of the orders appear to be increasing. These days, the packages may contain tents, folding bicycles or something even more surprising.
Earlier this year, the Subaru World Trading Company Ltd., which sometimes assists mail-order customers with difficult requests, helped Japanese consumers bring in a small helicopter, a motorboat, a canoe and several harps by express mail. Yet, as with other companies, most of the mail ordering through Subaru, where sales have quadrupled in the last year, consists of clothing for women and children.
The popularity of American catalogues is notable, given that the mail-order business has had to overcome obstacles that included a seedy reputation.
"Japanese mail-order companies used to be thought of as down-market, and people used to buy things like socks, nylons, underwear and sexually related things like sex toys and adult videos," said Sawako Takahashi, a spokeswoman at Lands' End in Tokyo. "You couldn't trust the quality. If you bought nylons, you could only wear them once, but they were so cheap you didn't care."
Still, with Japan's inefficient, costly producers raising prices from high to outrageous, consumers are increasingly abandoning that old distaste for mail-order merchandise.
There are other problems, born of distance or unfamiliarity. Many Japanese consumers complain that American sizes are too large, that they cannot touch or feel the fabrics and other merchandise, or that they cannot read the English in the catalogues. So several American companies, like L. L. Bean and Eddie Bauer, a unit of Spiegel, have opened complementary store outlets, even if this means that customers try on the clothes and run home to order by catalogue at cheaper prices.
Lands' End, Eddie Bauer and other companies have also set up Japanese-language mail-order operations, sending out catalogs in Japanese and American-made merchandise from warehouses in Japan. Sales at those operations seem to be buoyant, even though the same goods may be 20 percent to 70 percent more expensive than in the United States. Others, like L. L. Bean and REI, rely on English-language catalogues, but insert Japanese order forms.
These days, mail-order companies in the United States can send their merchandise by plane to arrive at homes in Japan within 5 to 10 days at a moderate cost. Purchasers do have to pay duty, but even with these extra costs the American merchandise is significantly cheaper than Japanese goods are. But with duty, returns can be messy, and getting the Government to refund a duty payment can be a real chore.
And even avid mail-order purchasers are known to complain about the quality of American goods.
"With products imported from America sometimes, the buttonholes are not sewn very well so they come apart," said Kaori Morozumi, a 33-year-old jewelry designer who spends up to $1,000 on mail-order goods several times a year. "There are deficiencies that Japanese products just wouldn't have."

HEADLINE: Cartoonists See a Future That's No Joking Matter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, June 30

 BODY:
Ted Rall, mop-headed antiestablishment political cartoonist, has abundant talent, a 1,400-drawing portfolio, seven years' experience, the acclaim of peers and the approval of newspaper editors who, every so often, print his work. What he lacks is someone who will hire him full-time.
"People have been telling me I'll find a job for seven years now," he said, sprawled glumly on a sofa at the downtown Stouffer's here. "I'm not going to find a job. There are no jobs." 
 No wonder the nation's editorial cartoonists look a bit drawn. In their hearts, they say, they are brilliant and incisive social analysts whose savage wit can change the very course of current events. They also confess to "wildly inflated egos," as one of them put it.
Taken as a whole, however, they fear they are becoming the buggy-whip makers of American journalism, accessorizers to a business -- newspapers -- that is the industry's horse-drawn carriage. And they are beginning to look at new venues like the Internet.
At the annual meeting of the Association of American Editorial Cartoonists here recently, the president, Signe Wilkinson, counted 168 members, some 120 of whom were employed by daily newspapers. Cartoonists for six dailies are losing their outlets: those at the Evening Sun of Baltimore; the St. Petersburg Times; the Houston Post; the Chicago Tribune; the Providence Journal, and the Seattle Times.
Some of these newspapers, such as the Tribune, simply decided that full-time cartoonists were an expensive frill in an era of rising newsprint costs and bottom-line publishers. Others, like the Post and the Evening Sun -- themselves vanished, killed by dwindling readership and growing electronic competition.
"There are a lot of papers left that do back up their cartoonists, and I hope they'll be the model," said Ms. Wilkinson, a Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist at the Philadelphia Daily News. "Maybe what's happening is that we're weeding the weaker newspapers out."
Maybe. When the Providence papers merged the Bulletin into the morning Journal earlier this year, the publisher elected to end the contract of the Journal's cartoonist "for essentially economic reasons," said Robert Whitcomb, the editorial page editor of the surviving paper, the Journal-Bulletin. Mr. Whitcomb said the paper chose to plow more money into local news coverage and to buy cartoons from features suppliers known as syndicates.
But editorial cartoonists, a prickly lot, tend to take it more personally. "We're seen as one of the fringe elements of newspapers," said Rob Rogers, a cartoonist who moved to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette when the city's other paper, the Press, ceased publishing. "So when something has to be cut, who's first in the food chain?"
Truth be told, however, the economics of the business are working against the cartoonists. Established artists, mostly at big papers, get an increasing share of their income from the syndicates, which bundle their works into packages that are sold to virtually all papers and magazines of consequence. This allows local papers to get a well-known name and style for their opinion pages. On a price-per-cartoon basis, local artists simply cannot compete.
"If an editor can get Walt Handelsman and Steve Kelley for ten bucks a week, why would he pay $70,000 a year for a guy in his hometown?" asked Mr. Handelsman, a cartoonist at the New Orleans Times-Picayune.
Mr. Handelsman was, of course, speaking rhetorically; both he and Mr. Kelley, a syndicated cartoonist at the San Diego Union-Tribune, grouse that that syndicates have given newspaper editorial pages all the spice and variety of shopping malls. One outcome is that some artists like Mr. Rall now break into the business not through newspapers, but by syndicating their own work.
But the ultimate result, the cartoonists say, is that the remaining local artists have had to scramble to make themselves indispensable, or at least less offensive, to their bosses. Some say cartoonists are under greater pressure to pull their punches, so as not to offend advertisers or the publisher's golf partners; this year's cartoonists' convention included a display of some 30 cartoons that never made it to press, and a Golden Spike award for the best example of such censorship.
Others are trying to survive by branching into computer media. Mr. Rall signs his E-mail address to each cartoon he syndicates, and reports "a terrific response" from readers and a steady, if small income from readers seeking reprints. Mr. Rall also has a site on the World Wide Web called Tool User Comics (http:/ /www.tooluser.com).
Larry Wright, a cartoonist at the Detroit News, is designing the newspaper's new site on the Internet with editorial cartoons as a regular feature. He has come to believe that is the wave of the future, and that "flat, dead-tree" cartooning -- his words for two-dimensional newspaper art -- will dwindle in importance. The News site will encourage readers to talk back by E-mail.
Eventually, he predicts, editorial cartoons will be computer-animated -- The Simpsons, after all, is the work of a political cartoonist who could not break into mainstream newspapers. "Why not?" he said. "If the technology's there, why shouldn't a cartoonist change his thinking about the concept of a cartoon? Why wouldn't he stop thinking of starting with flat cartoons and then trying to animate them, and just begin with animation?"

HEADLINE: A CLOSER LOOK;
Where the Rent-Stabilized Rental Units Are.

 BODY:
More than a million rental units in the city are regulated by either rent-control or rent-stabilization programs.
 
Rent control applies to about 100,000 pre-war apartments. Tenants have no leases, and rent increases are limited to 7.5 percent a year. When a tenant moves or dies, a landlord may raise the rent to nearly the market value, and the aprtment becomes rent stabilized.
 
Rent stabilization applies to about 900,000 post-war units. A state board ties rent increases roughly to inflation and to the landlord's maintenance costs.
Last week the Rent Guidelines Board approved increases of 2 percent for one-year leases and 4 percent for four-year leases for all of the city's 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments.

HEADLINE: George Elbert, 83; Wrote of Cooking And Indoor Plants

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
George A. Elbert, who collaborated with his wife, Virginie, on a score of cookbooks and books about indoor plants, died on Thursday in the New York University Medical Center. He was 83 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
The cause was congestive heart failure, Mrs. Elbert said. 
 Mr. and Mrs. Elbert's books were published from 1968 to 1991. Almost all of the books were illustrated with photographs taken by the couple.
Joan Lee Faust, the garden writer for The New York Times, wrote in a review of the couple's 1973 book "Fun With Terrarium Gardening," "Their pleasures are conveyed in the many novel ideas for plants to grow and containers to grow them in."
The couple's other books include "Foliage Plants for Decorating Indoors" (Timber Press, 1989), "Dolci: The Fabulous Desserts of Italy" (1987, Simon & Schuster) and "Down-Island Caribbean Cookery" (1991, Simon & Schuster).
Mr. Elbert also wrote about cooking and indoor plants for magazines including Ladies Home Journal, Gourmet, Horticulture, Houseplant Magazine and Woman's Day. And he wrote articles, on the same topics, for The New York Times.
The Elberts also helped to found the Indoor Gardening Society.
Mr. Elbert was born in Manhattan, the son of August and Blanche Elbert, and grew up in New Rochelle, N.Y. After graduating from a boarding school in Zurich, he received a degree in economics from the University of Heidelberg.
He worked for three decades as a New York-based importer and exporter of chemicals, successively for his father, in partnership with his brother Edwin, and with other associates. He also traded on the New York Produce Exchange.
In addition to his wife, the former Virginie Fowler, he is survived by a daughter, Suzanne, of Washington, and a grandson.

HEADLINE: South Africa Lifts Bank Rate

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
South Africa's central bank has raised its bank rate by one percentage point, to 15 percent, to counter inflation, the bank's governor said last week.
The bank rate is the rate at which the South African Reserve Bank makes loans to banks. By raising the rate -- the third increase since a new Government was elected in April 1994 -- the central bank hopes to slow the economy to contain inflation while allowing enough growth to finance its reconstruction program. 
 "It's very positive for the market and it needed to be done," said Dave Wright, vice president of fixed income at Smith Borkum Hare Inc. in New York.
The South African rand rose against the dollar on the news.

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Paradise Enow?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Generations of American visitors have fallen in love with Italy. It offered what home so often did not: beauty, passion, history, sensuality in food and clothes and life. With their revolving governments, Italians might not order their politics as efficiently as we did; but they knew how to live.
What few of us noticed, in our romance, was that postwar Italy carried off an economic miracle. It made itself the world's fifth-largest industrial economy. And it did that, handling the resulting social strains without compromising individual liberty. 
 Now the country is going through a political transformation just as dramatic as the economic. For three years magistrates have been exposing corrupt links between business and politics. As a result, the political parties that ran things for 50 years have simply disappeared. In the present Parliament, elected last year, three-quarters of the members have never held office before.
The figures may make Rome sound like today's Washington, with its legions of radical Republicans new to office; but the two are entirely different. Italian politics is not driven by ideological zealotry. The challenge, and the fascination of it, is of another character.
In those decades of short-lived governments -- 54 of them since 1945 -- the Italian state grew fat and lazy. The political parties, working with one another in successive arrangements, lived by the art of the indecisive deal. The bureaucracy grew ever more arrogant and inefficient.
The state ducked hard financial problems by borrowing. When governments have an average life of nine months, it is easy to avoid responsibility and say to yourself that those who come after us will pay.
Italy's national debt today is 25 percent more than its annual gross domestic product. That is twice as much as the target set by the European Union. Unless Italy brings its debt down, it may find itself relegated to a second tier of the E.U.
The country's current economic performance is terrific. Inflation is declining, and Italy had the biggest rise in industrial production last year of any developed country. But the good news does not dispel alarm about the overhanging shadows of debt and bloated government.
To deal with the problems Italy now has a government of a kind virtually unknown elsewhere, one led by nonpolitical technicians. The Prime Minister, Lamberto Dini, used to be director general of the Bank of Italy.
Mr. Dini has made a good start on the financial challenge. The budget deficit is coming down sharply. He is pushing legislation to reform the national pension scheme so that it no longer promises pie in the sky. Experts say the reform is not strong enough but at least is a start -- which is more than some other European countries can say.
In fact, the Dini Government has been so effective that some people are tempted to think the country would run better without politicians. But in the long run, and not very long, the really tough changes that are needed can only be made if they have the democratic legitimacy of political choice. That means an election.
An election could lead to more decisiveness in government than Italy is used to. Whenever it comes, voters will have a choice between two main blocs, center-right and center-left, instead of the myriad parties of the old system.
But one significant party is staying out of the blocs. That is the Northern League, which stands for ending subsidies to poorer regions. When I asked its leader, Umberto Bossi, where he would throw his weight after the next election, he said, "We can work with either the moderate left or the moderate right." He hopes, that is, to be the balance of power -- which would probably mean old-style government by deal.
In the end, Italians may want a more efficient state -- but not at the price of changing the special qualities of the way they live. In a referendum last month they rejected a proposal to expand shopping hours, making shopkeepers stay open longer. I asked the leader of the center-left, Romano Prodi, about that. He is an apostle of competition and efficiency, but he said:
"We don't want cities like yours, in which nobody walks! You can't be doctrinaire [about efficiency]. You need small shops. In Bologna we work like mad. But we are a gregarious people -- we like to walk, to talk, to relax."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
The Root of Devils' Unrest Is Unwritten Promise in '82

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
From the day he became the New Jersey Devils' owner in 1982, John McMullen believes, he was deceived by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. Now that he admits erring in relocating the former Colorado Rockies to his home state, he is seeking to create the legal right to relocate to Nashville.
"They don't give a damn about us," he said recently, referring to the authority. "Aren't I entitled to break even?" He said that the Devils' Stanley Cup-winning season added a $2 million loss to his $18 million deficit. 
 McMullen's fight for radically new personal economics at Byrne Meadowlands Arena led last week to declaring twice that he would terminate his lease, first in 1997, and then this Thursday. The authority swiftly sued the team to prevent the termination and keep the team from moving.
In what may indicate progress in talks held since last Thursday, lawyers for the team and the authority have agreed to postpone the Devils' termination notice for a week, as well as a hearing that was scheduled before Judge Peter Ciolino of Superior Court in Hackensack, N.J., at 9 A.M. today, said Joel Kobert, the authority's general counsel.
"Everyone is encouraged and they'll keep talking this week," he said yesterday.
The landlord-tenant imbroglio, rooted in what McMullen says was an oral promise of a perpetually packed arena, reached a boil last December when the authority suspended the team's lease during the National Hockey League lockout, a maneuver that the team insists was designed to deprive it of luxury suite revenue.
But McMullen has always pointed to this promise in 1982:
"The authority has continually and repeatedly represented that the authority would deliver a base of 19,000 fans at the arena," the team charged in court papers filed Friday. The Devils have "lost millions of dollars" because of that unfulfilled, albeit unwritten, promise. "I was promised 19,000 fans and they never gave us a chance to produce them," McMullen said.
Although the authority has granted two rounds of concessions since 1986 -- which it values at $33 million when fully realized by 2002 -- the team has never felt they were enough. At various times, McMullen has suggested running the arena, creating a cable sports network for Devils and Nets games and, most important, adding new luxury boxes to the arena's complement of 29.
"We found it was architecturally sound to build 48 more," said McMullen, a naval engineer and architect, "but even if that happened, it wouldn't compare to the new arenas."
To understand the Devils' financial underperformance at Byrne Arena, he said, one must visit the Fleet Center, the Bruins' new home, which has 104 suites. But McMullen said the ancient Boston Garden was a better deal for the Bruins than Byrne Arena is for the Devils.
The advent of new arenas from which teams receive the lion's share of revenues and the alleged long-term mistreatment by the authority have now led McMullen into open battle. The authority has responded by accusing McMullen of concocting 13 defaults in the lease as a subterfuge to take Nashville's sweetheart deal.
Whatever McMullen's strategy, he omitted public relations. He sent his first notice of default to the authority hours before the Devils' June 25 Stanley Cup victory. And just hours before its victory parade Wednesday, the team filed its second notice. The authority swiftly announced the action in a news release, rankling McMullen. Then the authority promptly sued the team.
While last week's rush of negotiations may indicate that the war of paperwork aggression is largely hard-line posturing, the talks cannot mask the palpable anger the Devils feel about their 13-year tenancy at the Meadowlands.
"The authority has treated Meadowlanders shabbily for years," the team said in court papers, referring to its corporate name. "Meadowlanders does contend that it should not be forced to remain yoked to the authority's continuing bad faith and contractual defaults."
Twice, the Devils alleged, authority officials advised the team to leave if it did not like life at Byrne Arena. In a March 1994 meeting described in an affidavit by Lou Lamoriello, the Devils president, he referred to the authority's chairman, Michael Francis, saying, "Mr. Francis went so far as to say that Dr. McMullen 'was the last person that [he could] help' because Dr. McMullen had supported Governor Whitman in her political campaign." Later, Lamoriello quoted Francis as saying, " 'Well, maybe you have to leave.' " He quoted Robert E. Mulcahy, the authority's president, as making a similar statement.
The Devils ridiculed the authority's argument that the loss of the Devils to Nashville would cause irreparable economic and psychological harm.
The authority "indicts itself by arguing that the relocation of a professional sports franchise violates the rights of the general public," the Devils charged, citing the migration of the Nets, the Giants and the Jets to New Jersey, and its wooing the Yankees to leave the Bronx. "Simply put, the authority has never acted as if it believes the arguments it is now making."
The Devils' position found backing in a poll published yesterday in The Record of Hackensack, which found that 68 percent of those surveyed in Bergen and Passaic counties opposed using tax money to keep the Devils in New Jersey, and 51 percent said it mattered little to keep the team in the Garden State.
Although she has said she would do what is prudent to keep the team from leaving, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has stopped short at throwing money at the Devils.
The Devils said that talks aimed at reaching "an alternative agreement," presumably with Nashville, were justified because the authority has not resolved the 13 defaults that have allegedly deprived them of $11 million.
It would be "imprudent for Meadowlanders not to engage in such negotiations with the authority and/ or others given that the agreement may terminate in a week," the team said. It added that the authority "should not be permitted to rummage about in the alleged negotiations" because the dispute is not about relocation, but who breached whom.
The authority said it has remedied all 13 alleged defaults. But in his affidavit, Mulcahy said the defaults "are nothing more than a pretext designed to allow the defendant to remove the Devils from the state of New Jersey." The Devils, he said, breached the lease by talking to Nashville.
Nashville Mayor Philip Bredesen said last week that he had met twice with McMullen last fall about moving the team, but backed off when he felt that McMullen still had a valid lease. McMullen has never admitted to talking to Bredesen, who said Lamoriello accompanied McMullen on one of the visits. "It's nobody's business when we went to Nashville," Lamoriello recently said.
In describing the Devils' "poorly concealed attempt to bring hockey to the home of the Grand Ole Opry," the authority said that "if the Devils were not seeking to play its games elsewhere and were instead simply trying to resolve their differences with the authority, McMullen would have unambiguously proclaimed that the team would be returning to New Jersey."
It added the Devils "have allowed their negotiations with Nashville officials to become public in an effort to render the authority short-handed" and "exhibited an embarrassing lack of proper business demeanor, good faith and sincerity."

HEADLINE: CUNY Restructures for a Fiscal Crisis That Doesn't Exist;
College, a Privilege

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a graduate of CUNY (Brooklyn College), I support the tightening of remedial education at the four-year colleges (news article, June 27). It is a necessary step to attempt to balance the system's budget. 
 A college education should be available to everyone. But it is a privilege to be earned through academic achievement, not a basic right granted through special favors.
CUNY's solution strikes the appropriate balance. Remedial classes should be available, but students should not be able to endlessly fail and repeat the same low-level courses. Ideally, remedial education should be completed in high school. When that is not the case, night school or community college is more appropriate.
This is an example for the city and society of the type of balance needed to maintain the opportunities opened in the 1960's while meeting the tougher educational and economic challenges of the 90's and the next century.
 
NOACH DEAR
City Council Member, 44th Dist.
Brooklyn, June 27, 1995

HEADLINE: For the Young, It's Looking Like a Jobless Summer;
The Hunt for Work Is Taking On an Air of Futility as Openings Grow Scarcer

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Around the Queens housing complex where 17-year-old Cynthia Roman lives, the search for a summer job has taken on a depressing air of futility.
For weeks, Ms. Roman has been applying for jobs at retail outlets around the city, but no one calls with an offer. "If I don't find one, I'll just hang around the projects -- broke, hot and thirsty," she said. 
 Some teen-agers in her neighborhood, she said, have already become frustrated enough to consider shoplifting popular labeled clothing -- Nautica, Polo and Hilfiger -- from department stores in Manhattan and selling it on the streets. "There's a lot of pressure in New York to have money and have things," she said. "Without jobs this summer, it's going to be more kids in the streets doing crime."
In New York City and throughout the region, the demand for summer jobs is outweighing the supply. In New York City alone, about 55,000 youths applied for the 35,000 minimum-wage jobs that begin this week in libraries, hospitals, parks and recreations centers through the city-administered Summer Youth Employment Program.
Last summer, the unemployment rate for those between the ages of 16 to 19 in New York City was 29.4 percent. In New York State, it was 18.6 percent, and in New Jersey 16 percent. This summer will most likely be worse, according to economists and labor market professionals.
"The economy was moving ahead last year," said John Wieting, the Bureau of Labor Statistic's regional commissioner. "This year it's flattening. It's not a great job market."
At the same time, Federally funded jobs are drying up. In 1992, New York City received enough money through the Federal Job Training Partnership Act to provide 52,000 jobs; in 1993, the number dropped to 47,000, and last year it was down to 35,000. This year the figure is 32,000 -- augmented by an additional 3,000 jobs financed by the city. But Congress has eliminated financing for the program in 1996, leaving its future in doubt. Nationwide, the Federal Government finances 615,000 jobs through the job training program.
Summer jobs in the private sector have also declined. In 1993, New York City's largest private summer-jobs program, sponsored by the New York City Partnership, hired 36,000 youths. Last year, the partnership, an organization of local chief executives and leaders of universities, nonprofit and civic groups, could offer only 20,000 summer jobs.
Officials at Jobs for Youth in New York City can attest to the shortage. Of 100 college students who are enrolled in one of its summer jobs programs, only 20 have found work. In another program, half of the 400 students enrolled have not been placed.
"We're turning to the private sector to pick up the slack, but it doesn't seem to be happening as much as we'd like," said Linda McLaughlin, an employment specialist at Jobs for Youth. "One of the trends we've found is that students are settling, they're lowering their standards. High school kids are getting shut out of a lot of jobs because college kids are taking the jobs they normally would get. College kids are performing menial task like stuffing envelopes, filing or cleaning up."
For many, like Colleen Clark, a junior at Cornell University, the search for work has been full of frustration. "Every time I go to apply for a job, there are these people in their 30's who are there applying," said Ms. Clark, a 20-year-old Queens resident. "No one wants to hire me because I'm only going to be at home until August. They want someone with experience, but I'm in school all year long."
To be sure, many students are finding summer jobs, and one of the bright spots is tourism. The weak dollar is attracting foreign visitors and increasing the demand at places that count on youth helpers in the summer, like tour companies, parks and museums.
Through the Academy of Travel and Tourism, a partnership between private companies and six public schools, more than 100 students who just completed 11th grade have found jobs on tour buses, in hotels, gifts shops and travel agencies. "We've placed every eligible student in the program this year," said Richard Graziano, director of the eight-year-old effort to prepare high school students for careers in the tourism industry. Mr. Graziano warned that a possible hotel strike in the city could drastically alter things. "We don't want to send kids across the picket lines," he said.
On Long Island, where tourism is strong, Gary Huth, a market analyst for the New York State Department of Labor, said it should be a good summer for jobs near the beach. "We got an early jump on the season this year with the U.S. Open Golf Tournament, which was played in the Hamptons," Mr. Huth said. "That gave a nice boost to the economy and a lot of early job opportunities. But whether that left employers kind of flush and ready to hire more remains to be seen."
Though many of her friends are having a tough time finding jobs, Michele Borg, who lives in the village of Bayville, L.I., on Long Island Sound, is working for the third summer in a row at Marine West, a boating and marine supply store in Syosset, L.I. Ms. Borg, a 21-year-old senior at Muhlenberg College in Allentown, Pa., said she was originally able to land her job because she comes from a family that spends a lot of time sailing and she has taken a number of sailing and boating safety courses. Now, Marine West hires her each summer, she said, because "they want people with experience."
Some students who do not have work experience have been savvy enough to learn how to enhance their marketability. They start their searches early, develop contacts, attend job fairs and even volunteer to gain experience. Volunteering can be tough for a student who needs to save for school, but it beats sitting around all summer and it often leads to decent positions that pay, many say.
Kerwin Lawrence, 20, of Brooklyn, a junior at St. John's University, said he was earning a competitive salary this summer as an intern in the marketing department of the accounting firm of Deloitte & Touche. His first two jobs, he said, were as a volunteer at Coney Island Hospital and Bellevue Hospital Center. "Employers see volunteer work as an asset," Mr. Lawrence said.
Carolyn Serrano, another summer intern at the accounting firm, has been aggressively pursued by would-be employers. A 20-year-old junior at Pace University, Ms. Serrano left her job in the finance department at the Henri Bendel store to accept a similar job at Deloitte & Touche. Henri Bendel has asked her to come back and work part-time when school resumes, and although some of Ms. Serrano's classmates have found summer jobs, "they're all jealous of me because they wanted to work at a big firm, too," she said.
However, the size of the company is irrelevant for many unemployed youths. For Ms. Roman, the young Queens resident, a summer job will mean an escape from her housing project, where she said most teenagers are thus far spending the summer "sitting outside on the benches, drinking, whatever."
Ms. Roman, a senior at Fashion Industries High School in Manhattan, said she thought she would be able to parlay the experience she gained last fall working part-time at Toys 'R' Us into a full-time retail job this summer. She has applied at The Gap, Foot Locker, Modell's and Sloan's.
With her asymmetrical haircut, a nose ring, and pristine high-top white tennis shoes, Ms. Roman said she thinks store managers "stereotype" her when she walks through the door. "I think they have this image thing," she said. "They want you to dress and look a certain way. After I fill out the application, no one ever calls back."
Complicating matters for job-seeking teen-agers like herself, she said, is the plight of her 21-year-old brother. Married, with a year-old baby and another on the way, he is struggling to support his family by working full time at McDonald's, she said. "Older people like my brother work at Mickey D's now, so even they don't have jobs available," she said.

HEADLINE: F.B.I. Reveals A Man's Plan To Blow Up A Courthouse

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash., July 1

 BODY:
Federal agents say that they have uncovered a plot to use a fertilizer bomb to destroy the United States Courthouse here, but that the conspiracy appears to have no connection to the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.
According to newly released court documents, the Federal Bureau of Investigation learned about the Spokane plot from an informer eight days after the April 19 Oklahoma City blast, which killed 167 people and injured more than 400. 
 The suspect was identified in the documents as Darwin Michael Gray, 27, of Spokane, an unemployed insulation installer.
According to a confidential Washington State Patrol intelligence bulletin, circulated to police agencies throughout the state, Mr. Gray stole blueprints of the courthouse while working for a company that installed insulation in the building. The company later dismissed him, but declined to say why.
The F.B.I. informer, who is not identified in the court papers, told the authorities about the blueprints and said Mr. Gray had detonated practice fertilizer bombs before the Oklahoma City explosion.
Federal employees familiar with the investigation, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the practice devices were exploded in a rural area of Pend Oreille County in northeastern Washington.
After the F.B.I. learned of the plot on April 27, the General Services Administration, which manages the Spokane building, installed portable concrete barriers on the courthouse plaza to keep vehicles away. The G.S.A. and the United States Marshals Service, which provides security for five Federal judges in the building, also hired additional building guards.
The case was given high priority, Federal officials said, because the suspect has ties to the white supremacy group, Aryan Nations, based in nearby Hayden Lake, Idaho.
Mr. Gray is an acquaintance of Randall C. Weaver, a white separatist who now lives in Iowa, and a stepbrother of Kevin Harris of Republic, Wash., the authorities say. Mr. Weaver and Mr. Harris were involved in a standoff with the authorities in August 1992 after Federal marshals went to Mr. Weaver's mountaintop cabin on Ruby Ridge, Idaho, to arrest him on charges of selling sawed-off shotguns to an informer for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
Mr. Gray was a visible and vocal opponent of the Federal agents at Ruby Ridge. At the start of the confrontation a Federal marshal and Mr. Weaver's 14-year-old son, Sammy, were killed. The next day an F.B.I. sniper mistakenly shot and killed Mr. Weaver's wife, Vickie. After a 10-day siege Mr. Weaver surrendered, but was subsequently exonerated on conspiracy charges.
Agents who investigated the Weaver case are based in the Federal building and courthouse in Spokane's downtown business district.
Mr. Gray has not been charged in the bombing plot, but remains in the Spokane County Jail without bond on Federal drug and firearms charges.
He was arrested on May 5 by A.T.F. agents who found firearms and 43 marijuana plants growing in the basement of his home here.
The agents did not find bomb-making chemicals or components, but they did seize three bomb-making publications, including one about homemade detonators, according to court documents.
"It remains an open investigation at this point," said Assistant United States Attorney Earl Hicks.
Mr. Gray has declined requests for interviews. His court-appointed lawyer denies that he was involved in a bombing scheme.
The court documents were sealed and kept from public inspection until Thursday, when Federal prosecutors had to return to court after Mr. Gray sought release from jail.
Mr. Hicks argued successfully that Mr. Gray posed a risk of flight and was a danger to the community, and that he should remain in jail without bail until his trial on the marijuana charges in mid-July.
The court documents say the F.B.I. "received information from a concerned citizen that Darwin Michael Gray and another individual were involved in the manufacture and testing of destructive devices, more specifically, fertilizer bombs."
They also say the informer reported that Mr. Gray and David Plunkett of Clayton, Wash., near Spokane, had been detonating "progressively larger fertilizer bombs at an unknown location in the woods for approximately one and one-half months" before April 27.
In an interview with Federal agents on May 5, the court documents say, Mr. Gray admitted he had used fertilizer and other explosives in the past, but only "for stump removal."
Mr. Plunkett said he knew nothing about Mr. Gray's activities, the documents say. Efforts to reach Mr. Plunkett were unsuccessful.

HEADLINE: Economist Is Said to Enter A Six-Month Drug Program

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Lawrence A. Kudlow, the former Wall Street economist, went to Minneapolis yesterday to check into a long-term, residential drug treatment program at Hazelden Foundation, his wife, Judith, said.
Mr. Kudlow, 47, agreed to undergo the six-month Hazelden program, where Kitty Dukakis, Eric Clapton and other well-known people have sought help, after three shorter treatments in the last two and half years for cocaine and alcohol habits, his wife said yesterday. 
 Fifteen months ago, Mr. Kudlow made a highly public confession of his drug problem shortly after he was forced to resign as chief economist at Bear Stearns. He also made a fresh career start as a conservative political commentator for television and magazines and said he believed that he had overcome his addiction.
But over the weekend, court papers filed by Mrs. Kudlow indicated that he may have lost his battle against cocaine. In a filing on Thursday, she petitioned the New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan for a divorce and an order to prevent Mr. Kudlow from tapping their Bear Stearn's retirement account to pay for a weeks-long cocaine binge. "The defendant will use such money to buy cocaine," she stated in an affidavit, "and in so doing will likely suffer a fatal overdose and will dissipate the only remaining liquid marital assets."
Mr. Kudlow could not be reached for comment yesterday. A Hazelden spokesman said the treatment center could not say whether or not a patient had checked in because of Federal regulations.
Mr. Kudlow's apparent setback comes a time when he appeared to have turned his career around. After losing his $800,000-a-year Wall Street job, Mr. Kudlow landed quickly on his feet. His disclosure of cocaine problems in an interview with The New York Times prompted an outpouring of sympathy. He landed a consulting position at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
And Mr. Kudlow, who was President Ronald Reagan's budget director and considered one of the brighter lights in the New York Republican Party, regained his political footing. He became economics editor of the conservative magazine National Review and started dispensing political advice again, sharing a platform with Gov. Christine Whitman of New Jersey. Indeed, Mr. Kudlow had urged her to cut taxes sharply, an issue that helped sweep her into office.
As recently as several weeks ago, Mr. Kudlow seemed to have regained his former professional stature. He shared a dais last month with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, when he addressed New York's financial elite. A few weeks earlier, Mr. Kudlow was appointed by Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing under President George Bush, to a commission to study how best to cut taxes. Always immaculately dressed and ready with a clever line, Mr. Kudlow seemed always to be racing between television studios and from speech to speech.
There were occasional signs of stress: the client presentation at Montgomery Securities that he missed or missed deadlines at the National Review. In the end, the occasional slip turned into something far more frightening.
"He had slips but he was sober for big intervals," Mrs. Kudlow said in a telephone interview. "He was doing everything. He was going to A.A. He was going to church. He was seeing his counselor. He was determined to overcome this, but it just overpowered him."
According to Mrs. Kudlow, her husband initially resisted the idea of long-term treatment, which is expensive, disruptive and almost impossible to hide, even though two monthlong and one weeklong treatment program had not been enough. Instead, he turned more to drugs.
In the end, she said she decided to act. Mrs. Kudlow, a former press secretary for the Department of Justice and now a painter, said she did not intend to end her marriage to Mr. Kudlow. The divorce action, she said, was a legal device to keep him from using the money to buy more cocaine. As it turned out, she added, it also helped convince Mr. Kudlow that he had to take drastic measures.
"It came down to saving his life," she said. "I have no intention of divorcing him, but I had to take a hard line."
What happens now? Mrs. Kudlow said she looks forward to life together with him but a very different one from the fast-paced, high profile existence the couple shared in Manhattan. She said in the affidavit that she planned to sell their apartments to pay for Mr. Kudlow's treatment and to begin a new life outside of New York City with her husband.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Group Bids To Build U.S. Rockets
The European consortium Arianespace is bidding with Alliant Techsystems of Minneapolis on a $2 billion contract to design a new family of rockets for the Air Force. 
 The group is responding to the Pentagon's willingness to allow its rocket makers to seek foreign technology and partners if it results in lower costs and more reliability. The bid could open a market to Arianespace now dominated by Lockheed Martin, which has also bid on the project. [Page 46.]
 
Economic Reports Mixed
Consumer spending rose a surprising seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, while personal income fell two-tenths of 1 percent. Construction spending fell 1.5 percent in May, and the National Association of Purchasing Management said its manufacturing index slipped in June. [49.]
 
The reports renewed hope on Wall Street that the Fed would cut interest rates, sending stocks up in abbreviated pre-holiday trading. The Dow industrials rose 29.05 points, to 4,585.15. Gaining issues exceeded decliners by 1,172 to 854 on extremely thin volume of 117.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange [51.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed, with the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rising to 6.63 percent, from 6.62 percent. [49.]
 
Auto Sales Down in June
G.M. said its vehicle sales fell 3.9 percent in the United States last month. Over all, the eight companies reporting June sales said sales fell 5.1 percent, to 582,889 units. [49.]
 
Protein Design Shares Drop
Shares in Protein Design Labs lost one-third of their value after the company's announcement late Friday that its lead drug had failed in advanced clinical trials. [48.]
 
New Troubles for Economist
Lawrence A. Kudlow, the former Wall Street economist, will check into a residential drug treatment program, his wife said. [48.]
 
Plan May Save Air Base Jobs
The Pentagon is preparing to recommend the White House reject a plan by the commission on military-base closings that work at McClellan Air Force Base, near Sacramento, be transferred out of California. [1.]
 
Growth in Eastern Europe
The Szczecin shipyard in northern Poland has moved from bankruptcy in 1991 to a ranking among the world's top dozen, becoming a model for Eastern Europe. The region's economy is growing -- by 3 percent in 1994 and an estimated 4 percent this year. [1.]
 
AT&T in Printing Venture
Moving to grab a share of the growing market for computer-controlled printing, AT&T has announced agreements with six printing and software companies to use its new Network Demand Printing service. [48.]
 
Tobacco Papers on Internet
The University of California at San Francisco said it would publish hundreds of documents over the Internet showing that the tobacco industry concealed its knowledge of the addictive nature of nicotine. [9.]
 
A Squeeze on Free Trade
Though President Clinton's credentials as a free-trader seem substantial, his actions against Japan and other countries may tarnish his record. And Washington's recent refusal to participate in a global pact on financial services represents a potentially serious threat to a new world trading system. News Analysis. [47.]
 
The spirit of free trade is growing in Latin America, and the United States, eager to expand business with the region, played host to trade ministers from around the Americas in Denver last weekend. [47.]
 
Electric Car Compromise
In a move that could significantly delay the introduction of electric cars, Massachusetts said it would postpone requiring auto makers to build electric cars until two years after any manufacturer builds one that meets a set of criteria on performance and criteria. [8.]
