HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
More Open Latin Borders Mirror Region's Freer Markets

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 3

 BODY:
Latin America's free-trade mood, though overshadowed by the Mexican financial crisis and war between Peru and Ecuador, is expansive, reflected best perhaps by the new express lanes at Brazil's international airports.
With cursory nods, the police wave through thousands of passport bearers from the nations of Mercosul, the common market of the South -- Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay. 
 Jets that shuttle hourly between Sao Paulo and Buenos Aires carried 1.3 million passengers last year, twice as many as four years earlier. In 1994, four times as many business executives from Mercosul countries visited Brazil as did executives from the United States.
Eager to take advantage of Latin America's move toward free trade, United States officials played host in Denver last weekend to 33 trade ministers from the Americas. Officials from the United States, Canada, Mexico and Chile agreed to meet in Mexico City on July 25 to start negotiating Chile's entrance into an expanded version of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
And raising hopes that Chile would join the group early next year, Republican Congressional leaders indicated last week that they would work with the White House to win approval of "fast track" authority for negotiating an agreement with the Chileans.
"The three amigos have become four amigos, or at least we hope so by the end of the year," Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in Denver. "We have made a marvelous start to establishing a free-trade area for the Americas."
Looking beyond Chile, the trade ministers agreed to start working on the creation, by 2005, of a hemisphere-wide customs union, the Free Trade Area of the Americas.
Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, lecturing doubters among 1,000 business executives in attendance, said that United States exports to Latin America had doubled since 1989, now nearly reaching the level of those with Europe. This year, the United States expects a $2 billion trade surplus with Brazil -- one of its few significant trade surpluses worldwide.
By 2010, officials in Washington calculate, the United States will export more to Latin America than to Europe and Japan combined.
While all the negotiations are expected to take years, two essential building blocks for a Western Hemisphere trade zone are taking shape -- Latin American multinational corporations and regional free-trade groups.
Cross-border financial ventures are increasingly routine. In recent deals, for instance, an Ecuadorean bank bought a Colombian bank, a Colombian bank bought a Venezuelan bank, and a Chilean bank bought a Bolivian bank.
Mauro Saccomani Moreira, export manager of Tintas Renner S.A., Brazil's largest paint company, championed the use of joint ventures. "In many countries it is difficult to participate in markets by sending paint from Brazil," he said, so Renner adopted joint-venture tactics. Now with local partners, the company has paint factories in Argentina, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay.
Renner is one of 300 Brazilian companies now operating in Argentina, and in Brazil, there are 100 Argentine companies. Chile, a leader in Latin American multinationals, has 170 companies in Argentina and dozens in Peru.
Provida, Chile's largest private pension fund, has invested in funds in Peru and Colombia, and is entering Bolivia, El Salvador and Guatemala.
Telecomunicaciones de Chile, that country's largest private phone company, has invested in telephone companies in Argentina, Colombia, Peru and Venezuela, and is considering investments in Bolivia, Brazil, Ecuador and Paraguay.
Over all, intra-Latin trade has grown to 25 percent of the region's total, from 10 percent a decade ago. With this surge, business leaders are pressing their governments to allow private companies to improve roads and communication. Copying the Mercosul system of express passport lanes, the five nations of the Andean Pact -- Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela -- later this year plan to introduce a regional passport, the Andean Migration Card.
As Brazilian trade with Argentina runs at five times the 1990 level, Brazil is reviewing 14 proposals from construction companies to link the two nations, the largest in South America.
"Mercosul will develop faster than Nafta in the next few years," Henry A. Kissinger, the former American Secretary of State, predicted in Sao Paulo in April, after a visit to Buenos Aires. "My impression was that the Argentines believed that their future and Brazil's future are closely linked."
Mercosul, which has been in full operation only since Jan. 1, has created its own constituency. Early in the year, Brazilian businesses with investments in Argentina created Grupo Brasil, a lobby dedicated to defending the free-trade pact against protectionist attacks.
Not everyone has prospered in every respect. After three years of trade surpluses with Argentina, Brazil is veering toward a deficit this year as high as $1 billion. Indeed, two weeks ago, O Globo, Rio's largest-selling daily newspaper, carried an article headlined "Mercosul Trade Accord Damages Brazil."
Mercosul encountered its first major crisis in mid-June, Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, decided to halve his country's car imports for the second half of this year. President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina objected, saying that auto-import quotas violated Mercosul agreements, and he threatened to boycott a regional meeting of heads of state in Sao Paulo. After negotiations, Mr. Cardoso exempted Argentina from the import quotas and gave both sides until mid-July to negotiate a solution.
"We don't want any restriction that wounds Mercosul," the Brazilian leader said. "The bulk of the car imports come from Europe and not from Argentina."
Predicting that the United States would move slowly to extend the North American trade agreement south, Brazilian diplomats are working overtime to hammer out accords with the other countries of South America.
"Our intention is to conclude talks with Chile by November," Jose Artur Denot Medeiros, Brazil's principal trade negotiator, said today by phone from Montevideo, Uruguay. "A breakthrough with Chile would accelerate talks with the others."
Bolivia and Venezuela are also eager to negotiate duty-free trade status with Mercosul, which would hasten the Andean Pact's drift into what Brazilians are informally calling Safta -- the South American Free Trade Association.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Pullback

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: PARIS, July 3

 BODY:
President Clinton's credentials as a free-trader seemed substantial. But now he is in danger of tarnishing his record.
Mr. Clinton enthusiastically supported the world trade liberalization talks that concluded last year under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and the creation of its successor, the World Trade Organization. 
 The year before, after initial hesitation, he pushed through the North American Free Trade Agreement, and the President now hopes to extend it beyond Mexico and Canada, to nations of South America, beginning with Chile. Beyond that, he endorses a Pacific Basin free-trade zone and has not ruled out a a free-trade area encompassing North America and Europe.
But in quarreling with Japan over access to its automotive market, the Clinton Administration threatened to impose sanctions, bypassing the World Trade Organization's new arbitration machinery.
More recently, the United States pulled out of global talks aimed at lowering cross-border barriers to companies engaged in financial services, and today it announced that it would investigate charges by Eastman Kodak that its rival, Fuji Photo Film, had conspired to deny it access to the Japanese market.
The auto dispute was settled by the two nations last week, and even if the United States had imposed sanctions, Japan would have taken the matter to the World Trade Organization. But Washington's refusal to participate in a global pact on financial services represents a potentially more serious threat to the new world trading system.
The Clinton Administration says it will not open the American market to all financial-services companies seeking entry unless fast-growing Asian and Latin American economies offer greater access to their own markets to American banks, insurance companies and brokerage firms. It is thus opting out of the first attempt to write global rules for one part of the $1-trillion-a-year market in internationally traded services.
According to Sir Leon Brittan, the European Union's chief trade official, the proposed accord would cover nine-tenths of international banking, insurance and securities business, which in turn represents 5 percent of the world's economic output.
Moreover, as Renato Ruggiero, the World Trade Organization's Director General, noted last week, the United States was largely responsible for pushing financial services toward the top of the trade agenda.
"U.S. policy makers introduced the subject onto the international agenda for two reasons," Mr. Ruggiero said. "They knew that the services sector could provide the bulk of economic growth and new employment, and they believed open markets and multilateral disciplines would insure this growth."
Washington, though, fears that it would lose leverage over emerging economies if it opened its market before they had liberalized their own. So it plans to offer access only to countries that agree to reciprocal arrangements.
The European Union argues that this negotiating strategy is flawed because developing nations do not want access yet to the American market. They are still building their financial industries and prefer protection to deregulation, particularly in the wake of debacles like the Mexican financial crisis and the demise of the investment bank Barings.
As Sir Leon said last week, "There just isn't a line of Malaysian bankers waiting to get into Montana."
Moreover, by offering to negotiate special-access deals with individual countries, the Clinton Administration is undermining a pillar of the postwar trading system known as most-favored-nation status, which holds that any trading privilege given one nation is extended to others in good standing.
The 15 countries of the European Union are now struggling to prevent the emerging liberalization package from falling apart as nations withdraw concessions they were prepared to make before the United States pulled back.
At the end of this month, the Europeans will try to persuade wavering countries to undertake a trial liberalization agreement for a limited period. But to bring the United States back into the fold without a loss of face, the Europeans will have to persuade the developing economies to improve their offers of access, not just maintain market access at current levels.
This provides an opportunity as well as a challenge, as the European Union dreams of forging a common foreign policy, even if it has not had much luck thus far in doing so.
In his own way, President Clinton has given the Europeans a chance to maintain free trade in financial services and to help pull the United States back from its latest flirtation with protectionism. And that would be quite a coup.

HEADLINE: Stocks Advance Sharply, With Dow Up by 29.05

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Wall Street stocks rose strongly in abbreviated trading yesterday as new signs of weak economic growth fostered hopes of an interest rate cut in the final session before Federal Reserve policy makers meet tomorrow.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 29.05 points to end at 4,585.15 in a shortened pre-holiday session. Gaining issues exceeded decliners by 1,172 to 854 on extremely thin volume of 117.9 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange, compared with 311.7 million Friday. 
 The Nasdaq index rose 1.08, to 934.53, and the American Stock Exchange index added 1.28, to 501.47.
Stock markets will be closed today for Independence Day.
Investors, focusing on the meeting tomorrow and Thursday of the Federal Reserve's policy-setting Federal Open Markets Committee, saw economic reports issued yesterday as pushing the Fed toward reducing interest rates to keep the economy from sinking into recession.
"There is a good chance the Fed will ease rates," said Tony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal Lyon & Ross.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index fell in June to a level many analysts consider recessionary. The report showed a second consecutive monthly slowdown in manufacturing despite continued slow growth in the overall economy.
Separately, the Government said construction spending in May fell 1.5 percent, far steeper than the one-tenth of 1 percent fall economists had been expecting and the biggest monthly decline since May 1991.
At the same time, it said personal income fell two-tenths of 1 percent, while spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, suggesting economic growth will remain slow in the coming months.
"The data is somewhat constructive toward the hope that we will see a decline in rates on Thursday," said Joseph Barthel, director of investment strategy at Fahnestock & Company.
"The $64,000 question is, 'Does the Fed want more time?' It's a possibility knowing the way Greenspan has operated over the years. It is possible he does something small." The reference was to Alan Greenspan the Federal Reserve Board chairman.
Mr. Dwyer said there was a 50-50 chance of a quarter to half a percentage point easing in rates after the committee meets. "I think that it will come out that they will," he said.
But Alfred Goldman, technical analyst at A. G. Edwards & Sons, said confidence in an interest rate cut had been somewhat dampened over recent weeks by mixed economic data. But that would still support stocks, he hinted.
"If we don't have a cut this week, it will be positive because we will have something in front of us," he said.
Among individual issues, the Argosy Gaming Company jumped 3 3/4, to 16 5/8, on the Nasdaq after the company's joint venture, which includes a unit of Conseco Inc., was issued a certificate of suitability to operate a riverboat casino in Lawrenceburg, Ind.
Protein Design Labs Inc. shares dropped 6 7/8, to 13 7/8, on the Nasdaq after the company and its partner, Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., part of Roche Holding, said a study showed its Zenapax drug was ineffective in preventing disease after bone marrow transplants. However, analysts said the company had ample cash and other products.
Eastman Kodak rose up 1 3/4, to 62 3/8, in heavy volume of more than 550,000 shares after the Clinton Administration said it would investigate the company's claims that Fuji Photo had conspired to deprive it of Japanese market share.
Boeing, which said over the weekend that it was cutting production of two aircraft, was down 1, to 61 5/8, in heavy Big Board volume of more than 812,000 shares
On the Nasdaq, Microsoft rose 9/16 , to 9015/16 , in heavy volume of more than one million shares. The company said it would continue its stock repurchase program in the 1996 fiscal year, and there were rumors that the company was studying how to unbundle software for its planned on-line service from its forthcoming Windows 95 program in case the Justice Department took antitrust action.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 2.34 points, to 547.09. The Big Board's composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.15, to 292.99. The average share rose 14 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of the New York Stock Exchange, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 5,367.031, up 18.258, or 0.34 percent.

HEADLINE: Change-Minded Voters of '94 Find That Unease Remains

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., July 3

 BODY:
The Republican tide last year swept across no state more forcefully than this sprawling one, and it was unwittingly fueled by voters like 46-year-old Michael Henderson.
Traditionally, Mr. Henderson supported Republicans and Democrats alike. But last year, he and his fellow Tennesseans saw to it that the state's two Senate seats and the governorship turned Republican. 
 "I wanted a change in what politicians were doing," said Mr. Henderson, a high school chemistry teacher who put his expertise to good use on Sunday selling fireworks at a local shopping mall. "I didn't know the whole country felt the same way. I was shocked that I voted the way most Americans were feeling."
And how are they feeling now, eight months after disgruntled voters delivered one of the most dramatic Election Day verdicts in decades? In nearly 50 random interviews over the weekend in this fast-growing patch of central Tennessee -- from the Murfreesboro town square to the golf course to the ballpark to the watermelon stands -- voters who helped bring about the enormous political upheaval said they were hopeful but very cautious.
Except for the most devoted partisans, these voters said they were not convinced that the ascendancy of Republicans would be a panacea -- or that it would last. Few were ready to pronounce the Republican takeover of Tennessee's highest offices -- and of the Congress -- a success or a failure. If anything, many said, cleaning house is good for the Republic. But despite passage of a budget-balancing bill last week and an assortment of Republican proposals, most said it was far too early to determine if the party's sweep would bring about the fundamental change that voters talked about last November.
"Would I vote strictly Republican again?" Mr. Henderson asked himself. "Not necessarily." He said he was worried about the speed with which Republicans were moving to cut the budget and restrict abortions. "They're going just a little too far, too fast," he said.
Specifically, several voters said they were disturbed by how Republicans scuttled the nomination of a Nashville obstetrician-gynecologist, Dr. Henry W. Foster Jr., as Surgeon General. "The ultra-conservatives were against him," said Susan Louthin, 33, a homemaker who is a Republican.
But Kim Stalvey, 42, a contractor who was remodeling a restaurant in downtown Murfreesboro, said fast action was why he abandoned the Democrats and voted Republican last year. Citing the House Republicans' promise to act on the 10-point Contract With America in the first 100 days, he said: "I liked the way they set up the 100 days, stuck to it and made some things happen. That's unusual in Washington."
Still, many voters here were reluctant to heap such praise on the new majority that they helped install. Rawls Ray, 50, a computer operator, said: "There's still a lot of distrust among the voters. If you have the right Democrat out there next time, I'll vote for him."
In fact, a large proportion of those interviewed, including Republicans, said they were uneasy with what they described as extremist behavior coming from Capitol Hill.
Jeff Sweatt, 28, a supervisor at United Parcel Service, said he backed Republicans last year but worried that Speaker Newt Gingrich had "gone too far to the right." He said he was relieved that a Democrat was still in the White House "for checks and balances."
Another who voted for Republicans, 34-year-old Joel Beckham, a city golf course superintendent, had more good than bad to say about what his decision wrought. "I'm not crazy about everything that the Republicans are doing, but we are seeing more accountability for what's going on," Mr. Beckham said. "But if these guys can't get it done it will go right back to the Democrats."
He and his wife, Jackie, 30, who is expecting their first child, said they were concerned that Republicans seemed fixated on opposing abortion. "They push the pro-life issue too much," said Mrs. Beckham, a secretary at an insurance company.
"I wouldn't want to be associated with an abortion," Mr. Beckham said. "But I'm not one to say whether that's right or wrong for someone else, either."
The Republicans' electoral successes here last year were all the more stunning given that they were not touched off by a sluggish economy; in fact, the economy has been doing fairly well. That may explain why many more voters said crime -- not the economy -- was the issue of most concern to them.
Murfreesboro, 33 miles southeast of Nashville, has transformed itself from a small farming town to one of the fastest growing sections of the state, due in part to the construction in recent years of nearby automobile plants by Nissan and General Motors' Saturn subsidiary. Newcomers as well as many of the longtime residents are turning more and more to the Republican Party. A Democrat, Representative Bart Gordon, was elected to a sixth term in this district last year, but with only 51 percent of the vote.
One after another, voters responded first with a chuckle, then a shaking of the head, when asked about Mr. Gingrich. More often than not, they said they were uncomfortable with his tone and style but were at a loss to cite specifics.
"He scares me," said Doug Rhodes, a 52-year-old farmer who voted Republican last year. "It's all right to go a little bit conservative, but you don't want to drop off."
While Mr. Gingrich has often overshadowed President Clinton in news coverage since November, three voters did not know who he is.
"Huh, what is that?" replied Wanda Underwood, a 38-year-old Democrat on disability, when asked about Mr. Gingrich. She went on to speak knowledgeably about her disappointment over the failure of Mr. Clinton's health care proposal.
Asked the same question while he was watching his daughter play baseball, Chuck Lawson, 33, a machinist, said: "Who? I'm lost."
"He's the one on television all the time," his wife, Theresa, a secretary, interjected, looking up from a novel about a serial killer.
Mr. Lawson was still puzzled. Even so, he said he voted last year "right down the Republican line," adding, "That's the way the N.R.A. told me to vote in my magazine."
Mark Moore, 35, a registered nurse and longtime Democrat, said he regretted that he "succumbed to the anti-Washington movement," when he voted last year for the two Republicans -- Fred D. Thompson and Bill Frist -- who won Senate seats without ever having held elective office. And he said he resisted supporting Don Sundquist, who was elected Governor, because he had been a member of Congress.
"The Christian Coalition and the insurgency of the religious right frightens me," Mr. Moore said. And noting that Mr. Frist backed the doomed nomination of Dr. Foster while Mr. Thompson did not, he added, "Frist has shown himself to be a moderate, but Thompson has moved to the right extreme."
Indeed, some Democrats in Tennessee in recent days have urged Dr. Foster to challenge Mr. Thompson when he runs for a full six-year Senate term next year.
According to a Mason-Dixon poll of regular Tennessee voters that was conducted in May, 62 percent rated Mr. Thompson's performance as excellent or good, while Governor Sundquist received a 54 percent rating and Senator Frist only a 46 percent rating.
Many voters said they were disappointed in Mr. Clinton, who in 1992 captured Tennessee with 47 percent of the vote. His biggest hope to hang on to the state next year, according to some Democrats here, may be the good will many voters feel toward a native son, Vice President Al Gore.
"I'll vote for Clinton -- I don't like what they're doing to Medicare or what they're doing to the education bill, or what they're doing to the older people," said Helen Whitworth, 47, a kindergarten teacher, referring to the Republicans. "But you know it would be even better if Gore would run. Oh, I just love that family."
Many voters also spoke highly of another Tennessean, former Gov. Lamar Alexander, a Republican Presidential candidate.
But Mr. Clinton can claim some converts. Joe Dillon, a 42-year-old contractor, voted for George Bush in 1992 but has changed his tune. "I was scared to death of Clinton," he said, appropriating the same words many voters use for Mr. Gingrich. "I thought that he may be a little bit too radical."
But the soft-spoken Mr. Dillon said the recent spate of national traumas had brought out the Presidential bearing of Mr. Clinton. "With the hurricanes and the bombings, we've heard more out of him and seen him do more," he said. "I don't see anyone we're going to run against him that's going to do anything better for the country."

HEADLINE: David H. Sawyer Dies at 59; Innovator in Political Strategy

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
David H. Sawyer, a pioneer in the field of political consulting that burgeoned in the 1970's and 1980's as party machines lost their clout in choosing electoral candidates, died on Sunday in New York Hospital. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan.
He had been under treatment for several weeks for a brain tumor, his family said. 
 By 1988, Mr. Sawyer's clients included four Senators, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, John D. Rockefeller 4th, Edward M. Kennedy and John Glenn, six Governors as well as leading politicians in the Philippines and Israel.
One notable turnaround engineered by his firm, D. H. Sawyer & Associates (later the Sawyer-Miller Group) was in the 1987 gubernatorial primary in Kentucky, where his client, Wallace Wilkinson, started out with about 5 percent in the polls and went on to win against two strong contenders.
Mr. Sawyer based his strategy then and later on polling studies of the electorate. In the case of Kentucky voters, both major opponents of Mr. Wilkinson had advocated tax increases and attacked each other bitterly. In place of higher taxes, the Sawyer-Wilkinson strategy advocated a state lottery.
In a 1984 interview for the Inc. Publishing Company, Mr. Sawyer defined his work this way: "I don't manipulate voters, because I can't -- they're too sophisticated. I'm much more interested in the nature of communication itself. How do you create a dialogue with the electorate? How do you control the dynamic of the campaign? Set the agenda for discussion? Answer an opponent's charges? Those are my issues. You have to get way inside a campaign before you can resolve them, too."
A Democrat, Mr. Sawyer worked only for Democratic candidates, but he had no problem dispensing advice to big corporate clients, including Coca-Cola, Apple Computer, Goldman Sachs, Time Warner and Resorts International.
Colleagues, headed by Scott Miller, bought out Mr. Sawyer's ownership interest in his firm, which had a staff of 40, in 1993. In that same year he opened a political-economic consulting firm called the G.7 Group. By this time there were more than 200 political consulting firms across the country and more than 3,000 people working in the field.
David Haskell Sawyer was born June 13, 1936, in Boston. After earning a bachelor of arts degree at Princeton University in 1959, he made documentary films, working in the cinema verite genre with Frederick Wiseman and Richard Leacock. One film dealt with rural poverty in Maine. Another feature, "Other Voices," about mental health patients, was nominated in 1970 for an Academy Award for best documentary. He was drawn into political consulting in the early 1970's in Illinois, where he did some film work for an elected official.
He is survived by his wife, the former Nell Michel; a son, Luke, and two stepsons, Andrew and Gavin McFarland, all of New York; his mother, Mrs. Edward Brewer of Hartford; a brother, Edward of Cleveland, and a sister, Penny Sawyer, of New York.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Assess Kodak's Case Against Fuji

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
In what is shaping up as the next focus of trade friction with Japan, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would investigate charges by the Eastman Kodak Company that its rival Fuji Photo Film had conspired to deny it fair access to the Japanese market over the last 20 years.
The American move, made less than a week after the two countries pulled back from the brink of sanctions and settled a bitter automotive-trade dispute, was based on a 275-page complaint filed by Kodak in mid-May, contending that the Japanese Government had helped Fuji create an anticompetitive market, costing it $5.6 billion in sales. 
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said in a brief written statement announcing his decision to mount an investigation that "American manufacturers of photographic film and paper should be able to compete on a fair basis in the Japanese market, just as Japanese firms can here." He acted under a provision of American trade law known in official shorthand as Section 301.
"It is critical that U.S. firms achieve full access to Japan's market, a market roughly comparable in size to that of the U.S," Mr. Kantor added.
Kodak, which began selling its products in Japan more than 100 years ago, said in its complaint that it held less than 9 percent of the Japanese market last year, far below the nearly 45 percent it holds in other foreign countries.
"All we're asking for is for the Japanese to enforce their own laws," said Alan W. Wolff, a former deputy United States trade representative, who directed the team that Kodak assembled at the Washington office of the law firm Dewey Ballantine to conduct its study.
Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. said in response that it regretted the American decision to initiate a Section 301 action, rather than dealing with Kodak's charges "through more constructive channels" in Japan or at the new World Trade Organization in Geneva.
It called its American rival's complaint "a heavy-handed attempt to shift the blame for Kodak's own poor business decisions in Japan from Kodak to the Japanese photographic industry and the Japanese Government."
Fuji said Kodak's trade complaint "relied almost exclusively on statements from various publications which are taken out of context, mischaracterized or inaccurate."
The Clinton Administration, which waited until the very end of the 45-day period within which to proceed with an investigation or deny the company Government help, seemed eager to prolong the harmony that concluded the automotive negotiations.
Playing down the immediate effect of today's decision, which had been widely expected, officials held no news briefing, and Mr. Kantor was unavailable to elaborate on his statement.
The United States now has up to one year to assess Kodak's charges and to seek a satisfactory market-access agreement with Japan. If this fails, the Administration could impose tariffs or other sanctions, as it had threatened with automobiles and auto parts.
The Japanese Embassy in Washington offered no response today to the American decision.
While the language of this new disagreement was subdued, specialists said it did not mean that the Kodak-Fuji dispute lacked the potential to become a full-scale trade battle with threats of high American tariffs. Indeed, Washington might find the film dispute a handy enforcement weapon, should it find that Japan was not fully living up to its commitments on automotive trade.
Specialists also said that Kodak's charges would also be closely watched as a guide in creating rules for the World Trade Organization to address problems of competition, a subject discussed at last month's economic summit meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
The basic charge by Kodak, the American photographic industry leader based in Rochester, is that in the 1970's, when formal postwar restrictions were about to end, the Japanese Government joined with Fuji to head off Kodak's possible domination of the market and to preserve the market for the Japanese company.
Kodak cited as "countermeasures" that had impeded it for two decades a system of exclusive distribution relationships, artificially high prices that subsidized Fuji's research, "a complex clandestine system of cash payments to financially strapped wholesalers and retailers," and interlocking trade associations committed to price stability and avoidance of competition.
A restrictive market, dominated by Fuji and four main distributors, "remains in place today with the complicity of the Japanese Government," Kodak contended in its complaint, filed on May 18.
It said that these impediments, involving both film and photographic paper, had cost it billions of dollars in revenue and allowed Fuji to build a $10 billion reserve that enabled it to dump products on the American market. Fuji, Kodak continued, was "fundamentally altering the global competitive balance" between the two companies.
Despite these asserted barriers, Kodak has been more successful in Japan than many other American companies, having invested heavily and tailored products specifically to Japanese taste.
Its latter-day aggressiveness results from the decision of George M. C. Fisher, its chairman since late in 1993, to pursue a strategy that succeeded in opening the Japanese market when he headed the electronics company Motorola.

HEADLINE: Dead-End Jobs? Not for These Three

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 3

 BODY:
Mark Ishaya was a toddler in Baghdad when his father died and his mother abandoned the family. He was a child laborer in a Lebanese oil filter factory when Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas massacred co-workers as he hid in a cabinet.
Zdenka Bulic was 21 when she emigrated from Bosnia nine years ago, frustrated at the career roadblocks she faced as a Croat. David Nunez left his home in Mexico at the age of 16 in search of higher wages. 
 All three have ended up in management jobs at the McDonald's restaurant on Peterson Avenue on Chicago's north side, overseeing the 50 other immigrants on a staff of 55.
Their achievement testifies to the energy and talent of immigrants who use "burger flipping" jobs that most Americans deride as dead ends to lift themselves to modest prosperity and many of the trappings of middle-class American life.
Their success also reflects the effectiveness of systems that McDonald's and other fast-food chains have been forced to develop to integrate into their work forces vast numbers of low-skill workers, whether they be immigrants or American citizens.
More than 1 out of every 8 Americans now working -- at least 20 million people -- have worked in a McDonald's since Ray Kroc opened his first McDonald's hamburger stand 40 years ago in the Chicago suburb of Des Plaines.
Behind that number is a corporate strategy of using armies of part-time workers. In addition, hourly pay for McDonald's crew members is typically only a bit higher than the $4.25 minimum wage and fringe benefits are meager. Employees leave so frequently that this year McDonald's and its franchisees, which employ more than 500,000 workers in the United States and Canada, will have to hire well over that number of new employees to stay fully staffed.
But there is an upside to this upheaval. The leading fast-food chains have been forced to concentrate more than other businesses on designing their jobs and training programs with an eye toward quickly adapting large numbers of raw recruits from diverse backgrounds, including those with little or no experience speaking English. And turnover, plus the industry's relentless expansion, gives quick learners a rapid shot at management.
Training programs at Peterson Avenue start with McDonald's-supplied videotapes, in either English or Spanish, ranging from general topics like methods of dealing with customer complaints to the specifics of operating different kinds equipment. Written manuals repeat much of the information. In addition, experienced employees designated as crew trainers work shoulder-to-shoulder with new hires.
The management track starts with introductory weeklong operations and management courses for assistant managers taught at regional training centers. Those promoted to second assistant become eligible for the Intermediate Operations Course, focusing on recruitment and retention of workers and advanced decision-making problems, and an equipment-maintenance and technology course.
First assistant managers, who have already received up to 2,000 hours of training, become eligible to attend the two-week Advanced Operations Course at Hamburger University, the company's national training center in Oak Brook, Ill. Managers also take review courses and specialized offerings, such as courses on career development for women, blacks and Hispanics.
Nowhere has the McDonald's system worked better for immigrants than at the Peterson Avenue restaurant, one of six franchises owned by a retired contractor, Ralph Wright, and his wife, Marilyn, an immigrant from Croatia. Native-born Americans rarely make up more than a handful of the employees there. And these days it's Mr. Ishaya, Ms. Bulic and Mr. Nunez who are among the role models.
 
Mark Ishaya
Mark Ishaya's psychological ties to his perilous childhood remain strong. He dreams of returning to Baghdad some day to visit the grave of his father, who died when he was 2 years old. The memories are vivid of the flight with his grandparents and sister by car, camel and foot to Lebanon when he was 6 and from Lebanon to Greece nearly three years later when Palestinian and Syrian attacks engulfed their Christian community.
By the time Mr. Ishaya took the suggestion of some friends and applied to work with them at a McDonald's, the habit of hard work to help support one's family was already engrained. Then 15, he lied about his age to obtain more hours.
"I was made manager of a McDonald's within months of graduating from high school," Mr. Ishaya said. "There I was, an 18-year-old, running a $1 million operation."
Mr. Ishaya, now 31, was transferred to the McDonald's on Peterson Avenue within two years. He soon fashioned the branch into a frequent winner of performance awards from both the company and neighborhood trade groups. In 1993 he was promoted to a job supervising the restaurant on Peterson Avenue and two others, with a salary he describes as "about $45,000." The fringe benefits include health care and a leased 1995 Ford Explorer.
One of the first lessons McDonald's taught Mr. Ishaya was that he was not as shy as he once thought. "After you deal with thousands of people of every race day-in, day-out, your personality changes," he said.
Mr. Ishaya said McDonald's had taught him enough about machinery and building systems to do most of the work refurbishing a two-apartment building he bought and then sold. He also picked up the basics of American financial controls, inventory management and marketing strategies. Above all, he learned a respect for employees and customers that he said was foreign to the Middle East.
Asked to explain, he cited a case in which a manager under him covered up the fact that a batch of Chicken McNuggets had been sitting too long, setting back the timer to make it look as if they were fresher than they were. Mr. Ishaya briskly ordered new McNuggets and removed the old ones. Then he took the manager aside, told him to taste the old McNuggets, and inquired whether he would be happy to pay for them if he were a customer. The typical restaurant in his homeland, Mr. Ishaya said, would have neither rigid quality controls nor a policy of teaching wayward employees instead of just berating them.
"I'm not gifted," Mr. Ishaya said. "But McDonald's put me through a lot of classes and I really practiced what I learned. I believe I could do anything now."
 
Zdenka Bulic
Bosnia had not yet plunged into civil war when Zdenka Bulic, now 30, came to Chicago to attend a relative's wedding, live with her cousin, Judy, for a year and perhaps go to school. Her parents both worked at an airplane factory and her family enjoyed a middle-class life. But it was already apparent that she would never be given a shot in Muslim-dominated Mostar at teaching math and science, her dream job.
In retrospect, it is no surprise that Judy promptly took her to work at McDonald's: Judy's sister is Marilyn Wright. Ms. Bulic was initially assigned to grillwork and began picking up Spanish from fellow crew members before she learned any English. Like everyone else in the Wrights' stores, she goes by her first name (pronounced iz-den-ka). It is so frequently mispronounced that she wants to change it to Pam when she applies for American citizenship next year.
"That's what some of my regular customers decided to call me when I first started serving," she laughed.
As Mr. Ishaya's successor as store manager at Peterson Avenue, Ms. Bulic arrives at 4 A.M. every fourth day to meet the McDonald's delivery truck and by 5 A.M. the rest of the time. She sometimes leaves as early as 3 P.M., but often gets caught up chatting with employees or customers.
"The concept of 100 percent customer satisfaction was new to me," said Ms. Bulic, who had worked briefly in a restaurant in Mostar before coming to the United States. "At home, we never even say 'please' or 'thank you' to customers."
The other eye-opener, she said, was the emphasis on teamwork. "The system is so organized and responsibilities are so broken out that it makes the role of teamwork clear," she said. "I had no clue about how much goes into it when I started."
Ms. Bulic, who now earns about $35,000 annually, has piled up such all-American assets as a Chevy Beretta and a small two-bedroom home in Elk Grove, Ill. Her main hobby is tending the house's huge garden, which includes plants contributed by some of her customers.
She recently completed the company's advanced course on store operation at Hamburger University. She is studying computers but her career dream these days is to graduate from the Wrights' chain into a job as a McDonald's field consultant advising other restaurant managers.
 
David Nunez
David Nunez, now 32, never had trouble finding work in his native Michoacan, a state just west of Mexico City. By the time he was 17, he had been laboring for more than a decade making construction materials or clothing to help his parents and six siblings make ends meet.
"I wanted something better," he said, recounting in halting English how he left in 1979 to join two older brothers who preceded him to Chicago.
On the recommendation of a friend, he left his first job here as a busboy at an upscale restaurant to clean tables and mop floors at McDonald's. Willingness to work rather than raw ambition has lifted him to his current job as first assistant manager at Peterson Avenue under Ms. Bulic.
It took two years before Mr. Nunez made the move from cleaning into the kitchen, and even then it came only after prodding from Mr. Wright to try it. He quit in 1982 when his closest friend left Chicago for a job in Texas tending vegetables and flowers and urged him to come along. A year later, he drifted back to Mexico, and in 1985 he got married.
Returning to Chicago with his new wife, Maria, he called Marilyn Wright and was offered a kitchen job. That lasted two more years but his wife, who was homesick, returned to Mexico with their infant daughter, and after four months he followed her. He came back to Chicago for good in 1988, this time getting a machine maintenance job with the Wrights and an eventual promotion into customer service.
"The first time they asked me to consider going into management, I said no because it's too much responsibility," Mr. Nunez said. But in 1990, when he was asked again and, assured there would be others double checking everything and backing him up, he agreed. The extra money helped reunite him with his wife and three children.
Mr. Nunez earns about $25,000. He frets about weaknesses in his English and people-management skills but has begun to entertain the notion that he could someday run Peterson Avenue. "I would never have gotten this far outside the McDonald's system," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Flat in Thin Trading, With Interest Rate Cut Expected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most leading currencies yesterday as expectations grew that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates this week.
Still, trading was very thin yesterday ahead of the Fourth of July holiday, with few traders willing to establish big positions on the dollar before the Fed meeting. 
 Many analysts expect Fed policy makers will cut rates when they meet tomorrow and Thursday because the economy is slowing to a pace at which recession is a danger. Lower interest rates often hurt the dollar by making dollar-denominated deposits less attractive.
"It won't be a surprise if we see them cut a quarter of a percentage point," said Jeffrey Yu, senior currency dealer at Sanwa Bank in New York. If the Fed does trim rates, "the first reaction will be selling the dollar," Mr. Yu said.
Some traders said the Fed would wait for more evidence that the economy was slowing before reversing course and cutting rates.
"I don't think there'll be any change in rates," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. He and other traders said they would scrutinize Friday's report on United States employment in June for clues to the state of the economy and the outlook for interest rates.
Even if the Fed leaves rates unchanged, the dollar is likely to remain under pressure because speculation about rate cuts will persist beyond this week's meeting, traders said.
In New York yesterday, the dollar slipped to 1.3799 German marks from 1.3817 marks on Friday. The dollar rose to 84.74 yen from 84.69 yen.
While financial markets will be open today in Asia and Europe, foreign-exchange trading will still be light because of the holiday in the United States.
In other trading, the British pound was little changed as traders waited to see how Prime Minister John Major will fare in today's Conservative Party leadership election.
If Mr. Major fails to win enough votes, a second vote will follow. A country's currency often suffers when there is government turmoil.
The pound was last quoted at 2.2050 marks, little changed from 2.2025 marks on Friday. Against the dollar, the pound edged up to $1.5980, from $1.5940 on Friday.

HEADLINE: Workers' Benefits Cost More, but Less So

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
After spiraling upward for years, the cost of employee benefits is flattening out.
The soaring costs of health care -- the biggest and fastest of the runaway horses -- have been growing at a slower rate. Workers' compensation claims have been reined in. And the buoyant stock market, by producing substantial gains on investments, has allowed corporations to meet their pension obligations with only minimal extra contributions. 
 Although some analysts think this may prove a blip rather than a trend, strong evidence of a turning point came in a recent Labor Department report. Benefit costs, which account for nearly 20 percent of total compensation, edged up a scant two-tenths of 1 percent in the first three months of 1995, according to the report. This was the smallest quarterly rise since 1987. Measured against the comparable period a year earlier, benefit costs rose 2.9 percent, the smallest such increase since the first quarter of 1987 and the second smallest since the calculations were first made in 1979.
"Something big is going on," said Frank B. McArdle, manager of the Washington research group at Hewitt Associates. "This is not a flash in the pan."
Even hard-pressed small companies are feeling better about benefit costs. A poll by the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents some half-million establishments, found only about 10 percent now think that the cost of health care and workers' compensation insurance is their No. 1 problem. That is down from a peak of 14 percent in the early 1990's, according to William J. Dennis, a researcher for the group.
Still, not all economists are as sanguine as Mr. McArdle. Some doubt that the recent trend will last; others question whether workers will benefit even if costs remain under control.
In theory, if employers do not have to pay as much for benefits, they should be in a better position to raise workers' pay -- which has scarcely kept up with inflation for more than a decade.
But some economists argue that whatever extra amount workers receive, it is likely to end up being used to shoulder more of their health care costs.
The experience of Martin G. Imbach Inc., a family owned marine contractor in Baltimore, illustrates both the change and some aspects of the debate. Imbach, which has about 60 employees, has moved forcefully over the years to contain health and workers' compensation costs that had begun to threaten its survival.
In 1989, it began to pay its own health insurance claims, instead of paying Blue Cross and Blue Shield to do so, saving costs of about 20 percent over five years. Then, in 1993, Imbach had employees pay 25 percent of the health costs.
In addition to these savings -- which Stuart McGeady, the company's vice president and treasurer, said kept Imbach from dropping its health coverage -- the company bargained aggressively with hospitals and clinics for the best deal.
"We told them: 'Don't give us the off-the-street rate. We want the same rate as your best client,' " Mr. McGeady said. His approach worked.
Such efforts by hundreds of thousands of companies like Imbach have helped chop health care inflation to 3.5 percent in a three-month period through May, from a peak of 9.6 percent in 1990.
Of course, workers who bear costs formerly paid by their employers may find it can takes considerable time to get even -- much less ahead -- from related wage increases.
"It was seen as a small pay cut," Mr. McGeady acknowledged. "But all things being equal, they saw it as an adjustment that has had to be made in difficult times."
Kirk Ridgell, a 35-year-old mechanic and equipment operator for Imbach, said that by and large, workers did not object to the cost shifting, considering the company's financial constraints. "You don't miss it because you never see it," he said.
He said the main complaint was that single employees pay the same $15 a week as those with large families.
"That was the biggest thing that I heard," said Mr. Ridgell, who has two children and a third on the way. "Those guys were saying, 'Why should I pay the same amount as somebody that's got five kids when it's just me?' "
In order to save on health care costs, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said, some employers have switched their workers to health maintenance organizations or coverage with higher deductibles. In other cases, health costs have been lowered by the one-time expedient of reclassifying workers as independent contractors.
Another factor that has been holding down the cost of fringe benefits has been a lengthening of the workweek as employers, unwilling to hire new workers until they could be sure that the economic recovery had taken hold, have simply demanded more overtime work.
"You get free benefit costs for those extra hours," observed Sylvester J. Schieber, director of research at Watson Wyatt, a benefits consultant.
Yet fringe-benefit costs could be contained for some time without workers seeing any gains in their paychecks, argued John Zalusky, a senior economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. who specializes in wages and industrial relations.
Mr. Reich, commenting on recent data showing real wages skidded 2.3 percent over the last year, was similarly skeptical. "One would expect that with health benefits and the cost of health care declining, employers could afford to put more money into wages," he said. But instead, "wages and benefits appear to be falling at the same time."
An argument over who gains from the slowing costs of benefits might be premature, some analysts say, arguing that the relief may not be permanent. Some say it is largely a delayed reaction to the 1990-91 recession and will not last if the economy continues to advance.
"In times of recession, people buy fewer goods and services, including health care" and 401(k) plans, said William S. Custer, a Washington researcher specializing in benefits. "Four years is about right for this to work through the insurance market" and show up as lower costs.
Another factor that may have only temporarily held down benefit costs was the Clinton Administration's health care proposal, now defunct. During the debate, the health industry held down costs in order to help ease political pressure for sweeping change.
Still, many analysts say some of the new-found restraint will remain, buttressed perhaps by legislation working its way through the House that would put small businesses on equal footing with major companies by allowing them to band together to offer a common, self-insured health plan.
Much of this would involve managed care, predicted Alan Mertz, chief of staff to Harris W. Fawell, an Illinois Republican who is the legislation's chief sponsor.
Only 46 percent of workers in companies with fewer than 10 people on the payroll have employer-provided health insurance, while 80 percent of workers in companies with at least 1,000 employees are covered, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute.
Another sign of lower pressure on benefits, one reflecting the intense competition now found in much of health care, is a dramatic slowing of pay increases for private-sector hospital workers.
Hopeful as he is for the immediate future, even Mr. McArdle of Hewitt Associates is not sure the present trend will last forever. "It's a positive signal," he said, "but it's not persuasive that costs are under control for the longer term."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Small companies like Martin G. Imbach Inc., a marine contractor in Baltimore, have been aggressive in limiting employee benefit costs. As Imbach increased its employees' share of health costs, Stuart McGeady, the company's vice president and treasurer, said, the workers "saw it as an adjustment that has had to be made in difficult times." (Marty Katz for The New York Times) (pg. 50)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities End Mixed In Light Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday after several economic reports produced no surprises. Trading was light in the shortened session.
While many traders were off yesterday ahead of the Fourth of July holiday, the session still had the potential to be volatile after the turmoil of last week. On Thursday, Treasury prices fell sharply after the May new-home sales report showed expected strength in the economy. The report raised fears that the Federal Reserve would not, as expected, reduce short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets tomorrow. On Friday, Treasury prices seesawed on expectations, later confirmed, that the Chicago purchasing managers' survey would show weakness, which helped the case for a Fed rate cut. 
 But the data released yesterday contained few surprises for the market. The Commerce Department reported that personal income fell two-tenths of 1 percent in May, meeting expectations. Spending for the month was up seven-tenths of 1 percent, only slightly stronger than an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent that had been expected.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its index of overall manufacturing conditions slipped to 45.7 last month from 46.1 in May. And while the number still suggests a contracting manufacturing economy, the drop was not as steep as the 45.2 some analysts had expected.
Construction spending fell 1.5 percent in May to an annual rate of $514.7 billion, restrained by decreased expenditures on single-family homes, the Commerce Deparment report showed. In April, construction spending, which was originally reported as rising four-tenths of 1 percent, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in a revision by the agency. Analysts said it was the largest monthly decline for construction spending in four years.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist with CS First Boston, said that all the reports were close to expectations, with the exception of construction spending, which came in weak.
The price of the 30-year bond slipped 6/32 , to 11227/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 6.63 percent, from 6.62 percent on Friday. The market closed early yesterday, at 2 P.M., and will be closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday.
Also yesterday, the Treasury held its regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills, and the sale went better than expected. Some traders had feared that with so many people out yesterday that there might not be enough buyers. The average rate at auction for a three-month bill was 5.53 percent, up from 5.35 percent last week. For a six-month bill, the average rate was 5.46 percent, up from 5.34 percent last week. Both rates were the highest since June 12.
When traders return tomorrow, their attention will be turned to the Fed's meeting. Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said the national purchasing managers' data yesterday "might give the Fed some manuvering room should it decide to ease rates, only because the number indicated a further slowing in the economy."
"I think the Fed will ease 25 to 50 basis points," Mr. Dwyer said. "It's simple to see that the market has priced in an easing. And the Fed is unlikely to do anything that the market hasn't already anticipated."
Following are the results of that Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Rise in Consumer Spending May Rule Out Fed Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Spending by consumers showed unexpected strength in May, the Government reported today, suggesting that an interest rate cut might not be necessary to give the economy a lift.
Consumer spending rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, considerably faster than April's increase of one-tenth of 1 percent, even as incomes dropped for the first time since January 1994, the Commerce Department said. 
 "The message is that the consumer should not be written off as dead," said Carl Palash, chief economist with MCM Moneywatch in New York. "It argues against a Fed easing."
Analysts said the spending rise was the key figure among a number of economic statistics released today, the last batch of reports before the start of a two-day meeting by the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. At the meeting, which begins Wednesday, officials will decide whether an interest rate cut is needed to keep the economy from falling into a recession.
Despite the spending rise, there was plenty of evidence of economic weakness today that could be used by Fed policy makers to argue for a rate cut. For example, the Commerce Department reported that personal income fell two-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first decline in nearly one and a half years, after having risen a revised one-tenth of 1 percent in April. For the year so far, monthly income growth has averaged only three-tenths of 1 percent, half the rate of six-tenths of 1 percent in the corresponding period last year.
The agency also reported that construction spending fell 1.5 percent during May, the largest drop in four years, restrained by declining expenditures on single-family homes.
Meanwhile, data released by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated the manufacturing slowdown continued in June. The industry group's index of overall manufacturing conditions slipped to 45.7 last month from 46.1 in May. Before May, the index had increased for 20 consecutive months.
"This throws a mixed bag at the Fed," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at Commonwealth Bank of Australia in New York.
Many economists expect the Fed to ease credit at some point this summer, even if it does not do so this week. "I think the Fed's going to ease," said Raymond Stone, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. The May increase in consumer spending was still relatively low, he said. "I don't think that would stop them from easing."
Other analysts, however, said the Fed chairman Alan Greenspan's concern about inflation would likely lead him to argue against an immediate cut. "The sway of the numbers is toward continued slow growth in the economy, with consumer spending speeding up in the second half," said Gary Ciminero, chief economist with Fleet Financial in Providence, R.I.
Today's Commerce Department report showed that after adjustment for inflation, consumer spending rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May. Disposable income, or the money left over after taxes, increased seven-tenths of 1 percent.

LENGTH: 769 words

HEADLINE: Parks in Peril

 BODY:
This is the time of year when Americans begin flocking to their national parks. Some will find what they were looking for: vistas of spectacular beauty, hours of restorative silence. But others may find themselves wondering whether they have traded one rat race for another. The national parks contain most of America's greatest scenic wonders. They also suffer from the urban nuisances vacationers had hoped to leave behind: traffic jams, noise, dirty air and garbage.
There is, as Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico notes, "trouble in paradise." If past experience is any guide, for example, there will be gridlock today in Yosemite. By one estimate, the Grand Canyon alone needs $350 million to repair roads, sewers and water systems. Many of the park system's 22,000 historic buildings, as any visitor to Ellis Island can confirm, are simply falling apart. 
 Human overload is the most visible culprit. Nationwide attendance at the Park Service's 368 separate units is expected to reach 270 million this year, 300 million by the turn of the century. But the real culprit is Congress. In the past 20 years, it has established more than 80 new parks while refusing to give the Interior Department's Park Service enough money to do its job. The service's $1.5 billion annual budget barely covers operating costs. The result is an estimated $6 billion repair and construction backlog.
Congress is responsible for cleaning up the mess it created. The question is how. Not surprisingly, given Washington's anti-environmental, budget-conscious mood, the most popular option is to trim back the system itself. A bill before the House would direct the Interior Department to review all parks and determine which ones are "nationally significant." At that point, a special commission would decide which parks should get the ax and then present its list to Congress.
The proposal excludes 54 "major" national parks but leaves open for review more than 300 monuments, historic sites, scenic trails, urban parks and assorted recreation areas.
On its surface, this bill, co-sponsored by Joel Hefley, Republican of Colorado, and Bruce Vento, Democrat of Minnesota, has an appealing simplicity. The park system definitely includes substandard sites -- what Mr. Hefley calls "pork parks," shoe-horned into the system to enhance local economies and the careers of the politicians who sponsored them. Get rid of these, Mr. Hefley argues, and we will have more money to spend on the "crown jewels" like Yellowstone and the Grand Canyon.
In the end, though, this is an unnecessarily messy and potentially dangerous approach to the problem. Mr. Vento says that Congress will vote on each recommendation "on its merits." But a more likely scenario is that the proposed closings will be lumped together in one omnibus "closings" bill, threatening valuable wilderness along with mediocre sites that do not belong in the system.
A more positive approach to rescuing the parks is contained in two other bills confronting the Senate and House. One would overhaul entrance fees, which are ridiculously low. The average entrance fee is $3, less than half the cost of a ticket to "Batman Forever." A carload of people can explore Yellowstone for a whole week for only $10 -- the same price they would have paid in 1916. Doubling entrance fees, a not unreasonable proposition, could generate an extra $100 million for the parks.
The second bill would end the sweetheart contracts awarded years ago to the companies that run the lodges, souvenir shops and other facilities inside the parks. In 1993, concessions generated gross revenues of $657 million but returned only $18.7 million -- 2.8 per cent -- to the Federal Treasury. The bill would mandate competitive bidding for these lucrative enterprises, giving the Park Service a bigger cut of the proceeds and generating $60 million more for long-neglected repairs.
Both measures were well on their way to approval when time ran out on the 103d Congress last December. There is now in place a vastly different Congress, more inclined to budgetary parsimony than environmental stewardship. Its basic philosophy is that to save the patient we have to cut off an arm here, a leg there.
That is the wrong way to go. The right way is to provide the park system with enough resources not just to survive but to renew itself. The language in the original mandate establishing the Park Service was unambiguous. The national parks should be left "unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations." Congress wrote that language, and Congress needs to honor it now.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
$20 Billion Thriller

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Spent weekend reading great yarn of international intrigue reaching into high places, very high. Stakes of billions of dollars, manipulation of governments, that kind of thing. Bit long -- 748 pages -- but moves right along; highly recommended.
Only two things may spoil reader enjoyment. Perpetrators win and justice is not done -- that's one. 
 The other is that since this story is all true and the money your own, it can leave you with a heavy awareness that you have been taken for a ride economically, morally and politically by the Administration and Congress you put in office.
In fact you are still on it -- a ride for which Americans had to gamble $20 billion of taxpayer money without ever being asked if they wanted to get on board.
The narrative, chronology and documentation are all in this story -- a report put out by Senator Alfonse D'Amato, as head of the Senate Banking Committee, about the Clinton Administration's $20 billion loan to Mexico. It is the result of under noticed committee hearings and months of staff research.
The reason given for the loan was to prop up a staggering Mexico because any default on loans would end foreign investment in all developing countries. That was malarkey then and is malarkier now.
The real reason was to rescue American and Mexican investors who had thrown their money into the craps game of high-interest Mexican Government bonds. They saw their money disappearing. So they got the U.S. to make the loan that would turn their risks into a guaranteed return -- in American money. Some lighthearted day ask for the same deal on your own investments in America.
Congress went along with the loan without a vote or debate.
From the beginning the issue seemed to me not so much the Mexican Government and its failures, but the conduct of the U.S. Government. For a year before the loan was ordered, on Jan. 31, 1995, top Treasury officials and President Clinton were telling us how great things were going economically in Mexico.
Didn't they know the truth, which they revealed only at the time of the loan, that Mexico was heading to disaster? Who knew what? When?
The answer given here in several columns was gathered from available information. It was a cover-up to prevent Congressional defeat of the North American Free Trade Agreement, to bolster the Mexican and U.S. administrations in upcoming elections in both countries, and to protect the major speculators.
Now the report puts reality beyond discussion: It was indeed a cover-up. Scores of internal documents show that from February 1994, while the Administration was shilling for the Mexican "miracle," its top officials knew that Mexico was in big economic trouble. Documents show that they had information from their own statistics, from what Mexicans told them privately and from the C.I.A.
The report puts chief responsibility for the charade on Under Secretary Larry Summers. But obviously the Treasury Secretary, then Lloyd Bentsen, knew. If they knew, so did the White House.
Epilogue: The burden of the whole Mexican-American mess falls on ordinary citizens in both countries. In Mexico, one million workers have lost their jobs and inflation is expected to reach 50 percent this year.
For the U.S., according to the report, trade with Mexico has gone from an American surplus to a deficit that may reach $15 billion this year. The beneficiaries are Mexican, American and international companies that are increasing their exports of cheaper Mexican-made goods.
The decision of Congress to go along, for fear of taking responsibility, was a historic example of cowardice hiding behind bipartisanship.
When the first $10 billion was turned over to Mexico, the U.S. said no more would be needed this year. Now Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin says the second $10 billion is available to Mexico immediately.
Senator D'Amato asks for a fight against that second $10 billion, since the loan is a betrayal of Americans' trust in their Government.
Senator Robert Dole recently put to entertainment executives a question every adult must face sooner or later. Now it faces all members of Congress who permitted the betrayal: "Is this what you intend to accomplish with your careers?"

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Shell Decides Not to Develop Iran Oilfields

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that it had decided not to bid against Total S.A. for the development of Iran's offshore Sirri oil and gas fields.
A two-company contest was expected after President Clinton of the United States forced the Conoco Inc. division of Du Pont on March 15 to withdraw from the Sirri project and later banned all United States companies from buying or selling Iranian oil. 
 Julian Barnes, a spokesman for the British-Dutch oil company, said Shell had expressed interest in the Iranian oilfields after Conoco had withdrawn, but there were no current plans for an agreement.
Higher costs from equipment suppliers and subcontractors dealing with Iranian oil projects, as a result of the United States embargo, could have forced Shell to rethink its initial proposal, which had envisaged production starting in late 1996 or early 1997, according to the Middle East Economic Survey, a Cyprus-based newsletter.
"By and large, then, it can be said that it was the indirect effects of the United States embargo on the commercial execution of the contract terms which prompted Shell to bow out, rather than the direct political impact of the embargo itself," the newsletter said.
Combined crude output from the Sirri-A and Sirri-E fields would start at 70,000 barrels a day, rising to 120,000 barrels a day by the turn of the century, the Middle East survey has previously reported, citing estimates from the National Iranian Oil Company. Exports would be processed by existing facilities on Sirri Island after some modifications.
Shell's withdrawal leaves Total S.A. of France as the front-runner for the Sirri project.

HEADLINE: Supply Exceeds Demand for Ph.D.'s in Many Science Fields

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
THE holder of a doctoral degree in science or engineering would probably make a better taxi driver or bank teller than someone without a Ph.D. But if a newly minted doctor of science is hoping for a permanent, full-time job in his or her specialty, there is a 1-in-4 chance of being disappointed, according to a recent survey.
As if that were not bad enough news for young scientists, the authors of the report have concluded that increased government spending for scientific research, even if it were granted, would eventually make the job situation even worse. 
 The survey, supported in part by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation and by Federal funds, was conducted by the Institute for Higher Education Research at Stanford University and the Rand Corporation, a Santa Monica, Calif., research institution with traditional ties to the Defense Department.
The study, which covered 13 science and engineering fields, 210 doctorate-granting institutions and more than 1,000 educational institutions that employ people with doctorates, was led by two economists, Dr. William F. Massy at Stanford and Dr. Charles A. Goldman at Rand, assisted by two graduate students, Marc Chun and Beryle Hsiao. They concluded that "universities in the United States are producing about 25 percent more doctorates in science and engineering fields than the United States economy can afford."
The group experimented with mathematical models designed to predict the effects of changes in conditions, and concluded that increasing government funding for scientific research would actually exacerbate the glut of Ph.D.'s in the long run.
By increasing research funding, Dr. Massy said, "the whole system will be expanding and people will get the kinds of jobs they were trained for.
"However," he adds, "as soon as you stop increasing it and go back to a steady state -- not a decrease -- all of a sudden the underemployment comes back. In fact, it comes back worse than it was before because the whole system has scaled up."
Professors whose research projects depend on cheap, competent help from a constant supply of graduate students are among the main offenders, they said, and it is time for university administrators and professors to throttle back the flow of graduate students passing through the educational system into very uncertain careers.
Surprisingly, the overproduction of Ph.D. degrees seems to be highest in computer science at present. The surplus of doctoral computer science degrees currently awarded over the number of those who get desirable jobs in their field is 50.3 percent, Dr. Massy said. (This figure does not represent an actual unemployment rate of 50.3 percent, but merely the current estimated imbalance between supply and demand.)
The job situation in other branches of science and engineering is better, the study found, but surpluses of supply over demand are still large; for example, 31.5 percent for physics, chemistry and mathematics; 26 percent for chemical engineering; 44 percent for mechanical engineering, and 23 percent for geological sciences. The survey found that demand actually exceeds current supplies of new Ph.D. holders in psychology, but Dr. Massy said the probable reason is that doctoral-level psychologists are often siphoned off into clinical jobs not included under the heading of science and engineering.
The findings of the new study closely parallel those of several recent studies by other academic and professional groups.
A task force created by the American Chemical Society and headed by Dr. David K. Lavallee, provost at City College of New York, reported in May that its preliminary findings "indicate an annual oversupply of chemistry Ph.D.'s in the work force of between 250 and 400."
The overall unemployment rate for chemists is low, only about 2.5 percent. But substantial numbers of chemists recently awarded Ph.D.'s are unable to find permanent, full-time chemical research jobs. Many therefore accept postdoctoral academic appointments as teaching or research assistants, usually for two years at a time with relatively low pay and little chance for permanent employment.
The chemical society task force calculated that if a postdoctoral appointment persisting for more than four years is considered unacceptable, 12.5 percent of recent Ph.D.'s are either unemployed or stuck in undesirable temporary jobs. If the desirable cutoff is assumed to be anything more than three years in a postdoctoral job, the percentage rises to 19.5.
To some extent, the gloomy job prospects for aspiring scientists have already affected the degree-granting institutions of the nation.
A recent report by the education and employment statistics division of the American Institute of Physics said that the number of first-year physics graduate students has dropped by 6 percent for the second consecutive year; about 2,900 students entered physics graduate programs in 1993-94, down from 3,300 in 1991-92.
Some universities have announced their intention to hold down enrollment in physics, and one, James Madison University in Harrisonburg, Va., has announced that beginning with the coming semester, it will no longer offer a physics major program at all. The contracts of the university's 10 tenured physics faculty members will be terminated in August 1996.
The outlook for young mathematicians also looks bleak. A survey by the American Mathematical Society of the 1,125 recipients of doctoral degrees in mathematics from July 1, 1990, to June 30, 1991, found "an alarming 12 percent of this population to be unemployed and seeking employment." This rate, according to Dr. Donald E. McClure, professor of applied mathematics at Brown University, was more than twice as high as for the previous year's crop of Ph.D.'s.
Holders of doctorates are not alone in facing the slump in scientific and engineering jobs. A survey by the National Science Foundation published this year concluded that the 1993 job market for recent college graduates in the sciences and engineering was significantly worse than it was in the late 1980's.
Dr. Goldman of Rand said in an interview that it had been "surprisingly difficult" to get reliable statistics on the sizes of university faculties in scientific and engineering disciplines, or on the rate at which academic positions become open, and that many sources of data had to be compared to calculate estimates.
Most science students tend to regard their professors as role models in research careers. But instead of becoming tenured faculty members like their teachers, many end up with temporary postdoctoral jobs or worse.
In a recent satirical essay published by the journal Nature, the British physicist and humorist David Jones chided television programs that "take up science on the absurd pretense that science is fun."
"In fact," he wrote, "there is no demand for scientists, as shown by their low salaries and dismal career prospects." Dr. Jones's tongue-in-cheek advice was to have a student float stock to pay for his studies, and let market forces shape his career.
"Suppose he wants to study physics," Dr. Jones wrote. "If the market feels him to be a rotten physicist, or reckons there are too many physicists already, he will find it hard to raise capital. His shareholders will steer him toward classics, advertising studies or wherever they see the best future returns."
Dr. Massy took a more sober view. Asked what he would advise children of his own who might be considering earning Ph.D. degrees in science, Dr. Massy replied: "I'd tell them, first of all, that they should not expect, as a matter of course, to be able to replicate the kinds of careers that their mentors have had, or that I have had. The job market is just too competitive to have any expectation of that. They might be very fortunate and achieve it, but the odds are against it.
"Having said that, if they have a true, deep and abiding interest in research, they certainly could give it a try," he added. "It's a wonderful career, if you achieve success. And if you have a deep interest in teaching, as some doctoral students do, this might not be a bad time, if they select their institution carefully.
"I think there will be renewed interest in the profession of teaching as opposed to the profession of research," Dr. Massey said.
