HEADLINE: MILITARY OFFICIALS SEEK WAY TO SAVE JOBS IN CALIFORNIA

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Pentagon officials have crafted a plan with members of the independent commission on the closing of military bases that they hope will save thousands of jobs at a California Air Force base and political face for President Clinton.
After intense negotiations over the weekend involving the commission, the military and the White House, the Pentagon is preparing to recommend that the President reject the panel's suggestion that 11,000 jobs at McClellan Air Force Base be transferred out of state. 
 Under the proposal, Mr. Clinton would ask the eight-member panel to reconsider the recommendations it made last month but only on the narrowest grounds. He would be most likely not to challenge the decision to close McClellan, but would ask that it be left to the Pentagon to decide which bases or private contractors will be awarded the work now done there.
Panel members had directed the Air Force to move the communications electronics work at McClellan to the Tobyhanna Army Depot in Pennsylvania.
Many details are still unfinished and the discussions are still under way, but the Pentagon's preference would be the approach adopted with another large maintenance depot, Kelly Air Force Base near San Antonio, where the panel left it to the Pentagon to decide where the work should be awarded. Under the compromise plan, President Clinton would ask for the same flexibility, offering hope that some or all of McClellan's military and civilian jobs could stay in California with private contractors.
If the commission approves this proposal, which the Pentagon could send to the White House as early as Wednesday, Mr. Clinton could claim credit for saving jobs in a state that is crucial to his 1996 campaign hopes. The President could also deflect Republican criticism that he is tampering with the integrity of the base-closing process by saying that what is fair for Texas is fair for California.
Mr. Clinton can suggest changes in the panel's recommendations, but he and Congress must approve or reject the list in its entirety.
"There is some hope for a resolution," Alan Dixon, a former Democratic senator from Illinois who is the commission chairman, said in a telephone interview. He declined to comment further.
Another panel member, who had joined Mr. Dixon in the 6-to-2 vote to close McClellan and spoke on the condition of anonymity, said of the proposed Pentagon recommendation: "I'd go along with that. But that's about as much as we're willing to compromise."
But it was unclear whether the plan goes as far as Californians or some senior White House political operatives would like. "It's something that sounds like it might have promise, but we'll have to see the analysis that supports it," said a senior Administration official.
Since the proposal would not guarantee McClellan's jobs would stay in California, the plan drew sharp protest today from California's two Democratic Senators, who have lobbied the President to reject the panel's recommendations as harmful to national security and California's suffering economy.
"It seems very timid and very strange, and it's not acceptable to me," Senator Barbara Boxer said in a telephone interview.
A spokesman for Senator Dianne Feinstein, Seth Oster, said, "Senator Feinstein does not see how this idea would make any sense at all. The Senator believes the only idea that makes sense is for the President to reject this list outright. There are simply too many jobs at stake in California."
The three previous rounds of base closings, in 1988, 1991 and 1993, resulted in the loss of 26,421 civilian jobs at California installations, according to the Pentagon. But Senator Boxer has said that as many as 200,000 jobs directly or indirectly tied to the bases would be lost.
In addition to losing McClellan in this latest round, the panel would also strip California of the Naval Shipyard at Long Beach, which employs 3,500 civilians, and the Army port in Oakland, which has 670 civilian workers.
Defense Department analysts have vainly struggled to find sufficient credible reasons to reject the panel's suggestions on Kelly and McClellan on the basis of cost or military value.
But if the base must close, the next best solution for the state would be to keep most of the work in Northern California, even at the base, to be done by contractors at lower costs.
The idea of shifting military maintenance work to the private sector has strong appeal for senior Pentagon officials. An independent commission looking for ways to streamline the military recommended such a plan in May. The head of that panel became the new Deputy Defense Secretary, John P. White, whose first tough task has been coordinating the Pentagon's response to the base-closing commission's list.
Under the legislation governing base closings, the President has until July 15 to accept the panel's recommendations or return the list to the panel citing his objections. If the White House rejects the list, which has never happened before, the commission will have until Aug. 15 to make any changes.
Mr. Clinton would then have to accept or reject the entire package. He could not tinker with its parts. If he accepts, the President will send the package on to Congress for an up-or-down vote on the recommendations in their entirety.
But few Congressional and military officials believe Mr. Clinton or lawmakers would dare to reject this last scheduled round of base closings. The Pentagon is counting on the more than $6 billion in annual savings to buy new weapons, pay salaries and insure proper training.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 8, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A map on Tuesday showing the military bases with the biggest job losses from actual or potential closings located the Alameda Naval Air Station incorrectly. It is in the San Francisco Bay area, not in Southern California.

HEADLINE: In a Change of Policy, and Heart, Colleges Join Fight Against Inflated Grades

BYLINE: By DAVIDSON GOLDIN 

 BODY:
A year after Stanford University and Dartmouth College announced changes in their grading policies designed to stem a 30-year trend of grade inflation, a number of other elite colleges say they are considering making high grades the exception rather than the rule.
At Dartmouth, where the average grade increased last year to a B-plus from a B in 1973, transcripts now include not only grades, but also their context -- the class size and class average. 
 Dartmouth's registrar, Thomas Bickel, said the new grade reporting policy seemed to be encouraging professors to grade more harshly. At the end of the winter semester, grades were down from last year.
Stanford's new policy will bring back the F for the first time in a quarter century, beginning this fall, and will prohibit students from dropping classes late in a semester, a common practice to avoid low grades. Currently at Stanford, 90 percent of all letter grades are A's or B's. The goal is to return the center to C, for average work, and B, for good work.
Ramon Saldivar, Stanford's dean, predicted that Stanford's new grading policies would spark "a slow downward trend that will probably be noticeable in two to three years."
Deans at Cornell University, Columbia University and the University of Pennsylvania said their institutions were likely to follow Dartmouth's lead. The deans said that because getting an A was no longer necessarily indicative of superior achievement, their goal was to provide graduate schools and employers with a way to compare students.
"We feel that providing additional information will allow the readers of transcripts to have a better idea what grades really mean," said Kathryn Youtrakis, the associate dean of Columbia College. "For example, if a student scores a B-minus in one of our chemistry courses if the average grade in the course is a C, knowing that average grade gives you a lot more information about that student."
Even institutions that are not considering drastic changes in either their grading policies or their transcripts, like Harvard and Princeton Universities, said they are reminding professors that high grades should be awarded sparingly.
According to information provided by more than half a dozen leading colleges and universities, grades rose significantly in the late 1960's and early 1970's, leveled off in the mid-70's to mid-80's and began to rise again in the late 1980's. Institutions compiled their grading patterns in different ways, making it difficult to compare individual colleges. The bottom line is that professors award about twice as many A's as they did 30 years ago and less than half as many C's.
At Cornell, the percentage of A's doubled, to 36 percent of all grades in 1994 from 18 percent in 1965, while the number of C's dropped to 12 percent from 40 percent.
At Princeton in that time period, A's rose to 41.2 percent from 16.9 percent, with C's dropping to 9.4 percent from 19.6 percent.
At Harvard, the average grade has risen to an A-minus/B-plus from a B/B-minus in 1965, with more than 40 percent of all grades in the A range.
Institutions also report an increasing disparity in grades between humanities courses and science courses. At Penn, for example, average course grades range from an A-minus/B-plus in small humanities classes to B/B-minus in large natural science classes. That is prompting concern not just about grade inflation, but also about grade fairness.
Kent Peterman, Penn's associate dean for academic affairs, attributed the discrepancy to differences in the ways science and the humanities are taught. He said humanities classes are generally small, allowing students and professors a greater opportunity to develop personal relationships, and grading is based on writing assignments that can be revised or rewritten. Science classes, on the other hand, tend to be larger and generally award grades based on one-time exams.
Even while many institutions are seeking to make sure transcripts include a student's entire academic record, including both the proud and the not-so-proud, Brown University remains intent on making transcripts reflect only achievement. Any grade below a C does not appear on transcripts, and students are permitted to withdraw from classes at any point in the semester. Only 20 percent of a class, however, can graduate with honors.
"When you send in your resume, do you put down all the jobs you applied for that you didn't get?" said Sheila Blumstein, Brown's dean. "A Brown transcript is a record of a student's academic accomplishments."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fuji Complaint by Kodak Shrugged Off in Japan
To officials at Eastman Kodak, perhaps, their complaint charging Fuji Photo Film and the Japanese Government with conspiring to block Kodak's entry into the Japanese photographic market might be as clear as a well-focused snapshot. But in Japan, the case seems more blurry than that. 
 On Monday, the United States said it would investigate charges by Kodak that it had been denied fair access to the Japanese market. Yesterday, Fuji and Japanese officials dismissed Kodak as a sour-grapes loser and ruled out negotiations on the dispute. Japanese retailers said that when prices are the same, consumers just prefer Fuji. [Page D4.]
 
'Apollo 13' Provides Hollywood Lift
A strong debut for the film "Apollo 13" helped provide Hollywood's best five-day box-office weekend, the Exhibitor Relations Company estimated. It said the top 50 films took in as much as $150 million in ticket sales over the Fourth of July weekend that began on Friday, surpassing the previous $140 million set over the Thanksgiving weekend of 1992. [D7.]
 
Building a Bigger Military Budget
For the first time in more than a decade, the budget being prepared by Congress locks in military spending at levels higher than even the Pentagon requested and comes close to ending the post-cold-war decline in arms spending. The Clinton Administration and some outside experts say the Republican spending plans are stuffed with throwbacks to the era of a Soviet threat. Republicans and conservative Democrats say they are not increasing the Pentagon's budget in real terms, just slowing its cutback. [A1.]
 
British Markets Rise on Major Vote
British stocks and bonds rose yesterday ahead of a key vote on Prime Minister John Major's continued leadership of the governing Conservative Party; the pound advanced after his victory. [D6.]
 
Hong Kong Plans for China's Rule
Signs of Britain's waning colonial presence are more apparent in Hong Kong, as is the shadow of China, the territory's master-in-waiting. But Hong Kong has long since ceased to be economically independent of China. There are more than 2,000 mainland Chinese companies in Hong Kong with an estimated $25 billion in investments. And two-thirds of the 207,000 registered foreign investors on the mainland are Hong Kong companies. [A1.]
 
Saying Goodbye to Bumpy Flights
The spirit of adventure that comes with flying in a small plane is fading as the nation's commuter carriers upgrade to larger turboprop aircraft. Business Travel. [D2.]
 
New York's Corporate Benefits
Even as the New York City and State governments slash spending for schools and social services, they are providing hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks and other benefits to big businesses, including some of the nation's largest corporations. [A1.]
 
Behind Microsoft's Stock Moves
Many top Microsoft executives seem eager to sell shares of the software giant as the introduction of its Windows 95 operating system nears. And as the stock price has soared, the company has cut back on repurchases of its stock. Does that mean that Microsoft insiders have turned bearish after the big price run-up? Not necessarily. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D6.]
 
$6 Million and a Dream
Looking for clues on lottery numbers? A flashy new $6 million national ad campaign, featuring a wisecracking parrot, intends to promote Lotto World, a tiny, two-year-old magazine, into a broad-circulation publication built on lottery hopes. Advertising. [D7.]
 
Of Ice Rinks and Energy
A California entrepreneur understands that business, like hockey, is about playing the angles. The angles were his knowledge of cogeneration power production, the local utility's obligation to pay him for this power, and a city's willingness to grant tax breaks to help revitalize a blighted area. The result is a $66 million power plant with two Olympic-size hockey rinks, a fitness center, a swimming pool and a restaurant. [D2.]

HEADLINE: British Stocks and Bonds Gain as Major Retains His Leadership

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
British stocks and bonds rose yesterday ahead of a key vote on Prime Minister John Major's continued leadership of the governing Conservative Party, and the pound advanced following news of his victory.
Financial markets in the United States were closed for the Fourth of July holiday. Elsewhere, European and Asian markets were generally higher. Germany's main stock index rose 1 percent, led by utilities and chemicals, amid hopes that a slowing American economy would hasten cuts in global interest rates. 
 The London Stock Exchange closed before votes were counted in Mr. Major's move to wrest back control of his Conservative Party. He defeated a challenger for the party's top post, which also carries the prime ministership.
A win by Mr. Major was seen as benefiting British assets by reducing the risk of an early general election that could lead to a change in government and its economic policies.
"The market's been preoccupied with the idea that Major's going to win the vote," Fred Yearly, a trader at Paribas Capital Markets Ltd. said. "That's helped support stocks."
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100 Index rose 25.50 points, or 0.77 percent, to 3349.20, led by gains in British Telecommunications, British Petroleum and Tesco P.L.C.
The yield on the benchmark 10-year Government bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, was last quoted at 8.42 percent, compared with 8.45 percent on Monday.
The British pound rose against major currencies after Mr. Major won the leadership election, strongly beating his challenger, John Redwood. A country's currency often suffers when its leadership is in question.
"Sterling is taking the news quite well," said Chris Turner, director of currency strategy at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. "It was a better result than people expected."
The pound rose to 2.2105 German marks from 2.2051 marks, where it was quoted before the results of the election were announced at about 5:20 P.M. London time.
The pound rose against the dollar as well. It was last at $1.5991, up from $1.5970 before the results, and up from $1.5978 in London on Monday.
The dollar rose against the mark after Mr. Major's victory. Many traders sold marks for dollars, then sold those dollars for pounds to try to take advantage of the British currency's gains. The dollar rose to 1.3823 marks from 1.3800 marks in London late yesterday.
The rise in the German market came on the eve of a meeting by the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee, which will decide whether recent signs of economic weakness will permit a cut in American interest rates.
In Frankfurt, the DAX Index of 30 electronically traded stocks rose 10.45 points, or half of 1 percent, to close at 2,110.13. The index was pulled higher by gains in Siemens, Deutsche Bank and Mannesmann.
The prospect of lower United States rates lifted stocks in Germany as traders reasoned that a cut would give Germany the leeway to lower its own rates.
Early today in Japan, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was trading higher. At the midday break, the Nikkei was up 74.70 points, or 0.51 percent, at 14,830.44. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 270.33 points.

HEADLINE: Temple U.'s Dispute With Philadelphia Stalls a Giant Sports Complex

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 2

 BODY:
On a Saturday afternoon in June 1994, Temple University's executive vice president, James S. White, was in his office putting the finishing touches on testimony he was to give before the City Council two days later.
After several years of land acquisitions, engineering studies and negotiations with business and civic groups, the university appeared close to breaking ground on an $80 million sports arena and business complex for the blighted inner-city neighborhood surrounding Temple. Only a few routine city ordinances were still needed, and the mood in Mr. White's office, as he recalled, "was real high." 
 Then the telephone rang. The caller, a lobbyist hired by Temple to sell city officials on the project, relayed some unsettling information.
"The message was from the City Council president that I was to include in my testimony a commitment to finance a $5 million housing program," Mr. White said recently. "I had never heard of anything like this. Everything went rapidly downhill."
Since that day, the complex, the largest development proposed in many years for the hard-bitten streets of North Philadelphia, has been stalled by a standoff between city and university officials. And the complex, known as the Apollo of Temple, has become a lightning rod for a debate over the extent of responsibility that a powerful university has to its neighbors.
The standoff has pulled in the State Legislature and the Governor and has prompted Temple to threaten to move more of its operations to the suburbs. The dispute has also underscored the detrimental effects of a long, acrimonious rift between two of the city's most dominant leaders: Temple's president, Peter J. Liacouras, and the City Council president, John F. Street, a Temple law school graduate whose district includes the 111-year-old public university.
After negotiations over the last year, the university and the city have agreed that Temple will provide the $5 million to rehabilitate housing in the neighborhood, raising the total price tag of the project to $85 million. But the sides remain at loggerheads over who should control the housing fund, the university or a neighborhood group.
Despite the promise of more than 400 construction jobs and some permanent jobs for local residents, Mr. Street has led the opposition to Temple's request for the zoning variance. He is demanding that the $5 million for the housing program be given to an autonomous neighborhood-controlled development group.
"We get the housing under the terms we want and Temple will get the zoning," Mr. Street said in a recent interview.
Temple officials insist they must maintain authority over the housing fund, since university trustees would raise the money.
They also express concern about a pattern of misuse of money by nonprofit community development corporations in the city, like that the City Council has proposed in the Temple neighborhood. The officials also assert that Mr. Street wants to control the patronage that the housing fund would provide.
Temple has offered to have a board dominated by neighborhood representatives administer the day-to-day use of the fund, while the university would retain the right to audits and financial reports.
 
Raising the Stakes By Defying Council
The Apollo would include a 11,000-seat sports and convocation complex, a 12-screen movie theater, stores and a restaurant with live jazz. Temple received $33 million from the state toward the project, and the rest of the money would come from private donations. University trustees have raised about $21 million so far.
Temple officials have enlisted the help of the university's most famous graduate, the entertainer Bill Cosby, to advertise the project in the local media. In an interview, Mr. Cosby, a native of northeast Philadelphia, said that the dispute "making Philadelphia look silly" and that "people in other cities are laughing."
In an effort to get around the City Council, the university sought special authority from the State Legislature to build the Apollo without the city's approval, raising the ire of Mayor Edward G. Rendell and other municipal officials. The Legislature approved a bill that would exempt the university from city zoning ordinances, and Gov. Tom Ridge, a Republican, signed the measure on Friday.
City officials contend that zoning is a local issue and say they will fight the exemption in court, if necessary.
Part of the problem is that community leaders, business owners, Temple administrators and faculty members and city officials have different views on how to achieve and maintain a healthy, attractive neighborhood.
Thomas Marino, a professor at the Temple medical school, said, "The Apollo just happens to be a focal point for a much larger discussion about what the university and North Philadelphia are going to look like in 10 years."
Many faculty members argue that Temple's role as the community's primary employer, and its record of providing social services, health care and police protection to city residents are unappreciated in the neighborhood.They say the university's resources are stretched too thin to develop a project that includes such significant largesse for the neighborhood.
Faced with a $16 million budget gap, Temple announced in recent weeks the layoffs of 85 administrators and cut 55 faculty positions. It has also eliminated some graduate programs, shut down its public television station and closed a day-care center.
"We have to be a good citizen," said Roland Lipka, president of the faculty senate, which represents the university's 1,500 faculty members, "but the question is, How good a citizen should we be?"
 
Neighborhood In Need of Lift
The Cecil B. Moore Avenue area, which borders the southwest end of campus where the Apollo would be built, looks like a neighborhood suspended between death and resurrection.
The $5 million contribution from Temple would be part of a $25 million effort to revive the area with 400 new houses and 100 renovated ones for low- and moderate-income owners. The city would raise the additional money.
"They move our people out," said Paula Taylor, president of the Jefferson Manor Community Development Corporation, and an ally of Mr. Street. "They believe this is Temple Town, not that they are our neighbors in northeast Philadelphia."
If the university tries to begin construction without reaching an agreement on the housing program, Ms. Taylor warned, "we are committed to laying our bodies down to stop them."
For their part, Temple's administrators say the Apollo is a necessary investment. With the 18-to-24-year-old population on a steady decline in the city, the university must draw more students from surrounding counties.
Twenty years ago, 80 percent of Temple's students were Philadelphia residents; now, 40 percent are. Enrollment has dropped 7 percent to 30,300, and there are fears of crime in the neighborhood. Two months ago, a Temple undergraduate was killed at a cash machine a block from the campus.
In a letter to Mayor Rendell, Mr. Liacouras, the university's president, warned that if the Apollo project was canceled, Temple's trustees would have to consider "the downsizing of Temple in Philadelphia and the movement of programs to the suburbs."
Such a move would severely alter the face of education in the city, given Temple's traditional role as a sort of city college that educates a wide variety of local residents.
Temple already has about 2,000 students at its suburban campus in Ambler, Pa., where the university owns 184 acres. Mr. Liacourcas said Temple would be forced to refocus on the suburbs for future projects if it could not build in the city.
In Philadelphia, he added, "nothing will work unless we have the neighborhood improve cooperatively."
 
2 Personalities In Conflict
But cooperation has not been possible between Mr. Liacouras and Mr. Street, who were once close friends.
When Mr. Street had difficulty getting into Temple University's law school, a program for disadvantaged students started by Mr. Liacouras, who was then dean of the law school, helped Mr. Street gain admittance in 1972. In 1980, when Mr. Liacouras ran unsuccessfully for the United States Senate, Mr. Street campaigned on his behalf, endorsing him as "the guy who gave me a chance."
In 1984, the friendship fell apart when information about Mr. Street's defaulted student loan debt were disclosed to the press and Mr. Liacouras was reported to be the source. He said he was not the source of the disclosures. Mr. Street refuses to discuss the matter. The two men have not talked since.
In an interview in his office, Mr. Liacouras pulled from his desk a black and white photograph taken in 1982, on the occasion of his being named Temple's president. In the photo, Mr. Street is kissing the cheek of Mr. Liacouras's mother, Stella.
Gazing at the photo, Mr. Liacouras said, "I wish this wasn't viewed as personal, but it partly is."
Mr. Street feels differently. "I don't ever have to talk to him," he said in a telephone interview. "Why do I need to talk to him?"
He pointed out that they communicate through intermediaries and letters. "This is business," he said.
Time is running out, as construction costs continue to rise and benefactors get cold feet. And the City Council has recessed until September without taking action.
Probably no one is as frustrated with the dispute as is John Chaney, Temple's venerable basketball coach. Known for his winning teams and acerbic tongue, Mr. Chaney said that the 3,900-seat basketball arena and the condition of the surrounding neighborhood gave other coaches an advantage in recruiting.
Mr. Chaney said he had a solution: "that Temple pack it up, move to the suburbs, and leave a hole in the ground and a statue of the Mayor and the Council president holding hands, together again."

HEADLINE: Lower Budgets Don't Cut Flow Of Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
At a time when the New York City and State governments are cutting sharply into spending for schools and social services for the poor, they are providing hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks and other benefits to big businesses, including some of the nation's largest corporations.
The Pataki and Giuliani administrations say the tax breaks, which have gone to such corporatons as ABC and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the Wall Street brokerage concern, are part of a long-term strategy to shore up the local economy by keeping big employers from leaving New York. In other states, they say, such enticements abound. 
 But a growing number of critics, including elected officials, economists and urban planners, question whether a strategy of broadening tax breaks to business makes sense while cities and states are doing some of the most far-reaching budget cutting in decades, affecting virtually every government service from education to garbage collection.
In Connecticut, for example, which has attracted more than 25 major Manhattan companies over the last 20 years, the appetite for extending large-scale corporate tax breaks has cooled under Gov. John G. Rowland, a conservative Republican who took office in January.
"The new administration is placing greater emphasis on the overall business environment, not on assisting specific companies," said Joseph Cohen, a spokesman for the Connecticut Economic Development Department.
Over the last 18 months, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has approved 11 deals to give $348 million in sales tax breaks to a variety of companies. Although the arrangements were negotiated by the city, they include concessions from the state and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which gives the city's Economic Development Corporation the power to act in its stead on such matters.
These incentives are part of a long menu of tax breaks, low interest financing, energy subsidies and other benefits that have been expanded under Mayor Giuliani, despite challenges from the State Comptroller and several City Council members.
"There is this silly debate, fueled by left-wing critics, over whether you have a choice about whether to extend these benefits," said John S. Dyson, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. "If you want to keep jobs, you don't."
Similarly, in Albany the administration of Gov. George E. Pataki has agreed to give I.B.M., which was threatenting to move out of state, an extraordinarily rich package of incentives, including $75 million in state-financed, low-interest loans to build a new headquarters in Westchester County. The state also agreed to lease vacant I.B.M. buildings in Kingston, East Fishkill and Binghamton, and to transfer more than 2,000 state data processing jobs to those buildings.

Fierce Competition To Keep Businesses
With other cities and states offering similar deals to prevent departures of manufacturing plants, office complexes and sports teams, a fierce national competition has broken out. But in recent years, with the costs of such enticements, some states have started to back away.
"When firms ultimately do leave, their parting words are that the streets are filthy and the schools are bad," said Elliot Sclar, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University. "Government should get back to providing government services."
Though the present administrations in New York have expanded these economic development programs, they were not the first to embrace them. Starting in the early 1980's, New York City responded to an exodus of companies to Connecticut and New Jersey by offering property tax breaks and other subsidies.
Among the beneficiaries under the adminisration of Mayor David N. Dinkins were CBS, Morgan Stanley and The New York Times, which was given $21.5 million in tax credits, grants and purchase options from the city for a new printing plant in College Point, Queens. The long-term tax breaks for the companies were intended to keep them from moving operations out of the city.
"Bear in mind that companies don't need to be here," said Clay Lifflander, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which has negotiated the biggest corporate deals under Mayor Giuliani. "I think that if you ask for a long-term commitment, you should give them something in return."
Last year, hundreds of New York City companies, from small merchants to the nation's top investment firms, benefited from the city's largesse. In property tax breaks, city records show that businesses received $301.8 million in subsidies last year, far above any previous year.
The largest source of subsidies, accounting for $147.9 million of the 1994 property tax breaks, is the Industrial and Commercial Incentive program, which has been available since 1981 to companies and real estate developers who build, move to or expand above 96th Street in Manhattan or in the other four boroughs.
That program was broadened gradually in the 1980's, and, at Mayor Giuliani's behest, was expanded again in a Council vote called shortly after 2 A.M. on June 22 after a full day of action on budget issues. Under the new rules, developers who build "smart buildings," which are highly computerized and climate-controlled, qualify for property tax breaks if the buildings are between 23d and 59th Streets in Manhattan.
The Mayor also won Council support for a package of tax breaks for companies and developers below Chambers Street, but those need approval from the State Legislature.
"This is a giveaway to the real estate industry," said Councilman Stephen DiBrienza.
Mr. Dyson said the city must offer such subsidies to compete with the rising number of governments trying to lure businesses away. "There isn't a day that goes by when I don't hear about some mayor, governor or foreign official in this town trying to lure a company away," he said.
Already, New Jersey, a tough competitor for New York City business, has begun to raise the stakes in the competition. "It is becoming a more competitive world," said Alan J. Steinberg, assistant commissioner of New Jersey's Commerce and Economic Development Department. He said his agency and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman would give the State Legislature a proposal to offer large companies that move to or expand in New Jersey long-term reductions in sales and corporate income taxes.
Much of the controversy in New York has been set off by the circumstances surrounding many of the richest incentive packages. For the most part, the tax breaks and other incentives have been negotiated behind closed doors without public input, approval by the City Council or the Legislature. And a handful of the beneficiaries are political supporters of the Mayor and the Governor.
Two of them, CS First Boston and Donaldson, Lufkin, were among the biggest corporate donors to Mr. Giuliani's 1993 mayoral campaign. More than 20 executives of Donaldson, which received $29.5 million in long-term tax breaks in September 1994, combined to contribute $39,880. Executives of First Boston, which got $50.5 million in city tax breaks in January, contributed $21,850.
One business organization that stands out in lobbying is the New York Mercantile Exchange, which received the largest corporate retention package under Mayor Giuliani and now plans a new headquarters and trading floor in Battery Park City. That deal includes $129 million in cash from the city and $58 million in other city and state benefits.
The package, announced by the Mayor last September, provoked opposition by many officials before it was approved by the City Council and the City Comptroller in recent months. At the same time, the exchange's City Hall lobbying expenses, recorded by the City Clerk, jumped to $28,939 in the first three months of this year, from $13,200 in the last three months of 1994 and $9,800 the preceding three months.
In Albany, Governor Pataki's chief economic adviser and corporate negotiator, Charles A. Gargano, was the top fund-raiser for his campaign, responsible in that job for seeking support from companies and individuals alike.
"When these corporate benefits are negotiated behind closed doors, they almost inevitably lead to the impression of an incestuous relationship between government officials and big business," said Stephen Moore, chief economist for the Reason Institute, a conservative California research organization that has analyzed the increased use of tax breaks to attract and retain corporations across the nation.

Making Sure Promises Are Kept
When giving large tax breaks, the city and state governments have sometimes been lax in insuring that companies live up to their promises not to relocate jobs.
Last month, the New York State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, said an audit by his staff found "no evidence" that New York City "actually monitored employment levels."
The focus of Mr. McCall's audit was the the city's Industrial Development Agency, which provides low-interest financing to companies through the sale of tax-free municipal bonds. Determining which companies qualify, and assuring that they meet employment requirements, is the Economic Development Corporation's responsibility.
The Comptroller's staff examined the hiring and employment levels of 12 companies among 124 business organizations receiving low-interest loans between July 1988 and June 1993. It said seven had failed to meet their employment objectives.
Earlier this year, Mr. Giuliani learned that both First Boston and Donaldson Lufkin were planning to cut hundreds of New York City jobs in their trading and public finance departments. The city's agreement with the companies did not include potential layoffs in those departments.
In May, the Mayor announced that he was freezing a $6.4 million package of tax breaks extended a year earlier to the Republic National Bank of New York. Republic, which had promised to keep 2,400 workers in the city, had instead announced layoffs in the city of 850 employees.
Late last month, aides to the Mayor said the Republic deal was dead.
City officials say they have toughened the rules to make sure companies do not renege on their commitments. "We have put teeth into the process that never existed before," Mr. Dyson said.
He said each benefits package negotiated with a company contains provisions that it keep a minimum level of employment, subject to some flexibility in economic downturns, and that anytime a company failed to live up to its commitments, its benefits would be canceled.
Other provisions, not yet tested, Mr. Dyson said, would require a company that blatantly violates its commitments to the city -- particularly by moving workers somewhere else -- to reimburse the city for its tax breaks or other benefits.

HEADLINE: The Anti-Tax Man Cometh

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

 BODY:
Individual income taxes, Irwin A. Schiff tells everyone who will listen, are voluntary, but almost everyone pays because politicians have enacted complicated laws to trick people into thinking they must pay.
The view might sound absurd, and Mr. Schiff used to be cursed at when he voiced it. But some Americans are taking it seriously. 
 The works of Mr. Schiff are now widely cited in the literature of tax protesters and right-wing organizations challenging the legitimacy of the Federal Government. Over the years, he has been a frequent guest on talk shows around the country, having discussed the issue with Larry King, Tom Snyder and, in the New York area, Bob Grant.
He says he has sold 30,000 copies of his latest self-published book, "The Federal Mafia," and more than 67,000 copies of his 1982 book, "How Anyone Can Stop Paying Income Taxes." And, in recent weeks, an Internet site devoted to taxes has been dominated by arguments over Mr. Schiff's idea, now advanced by a variety of his followers, that no law makes individuals or corporations liable to pay income taxes.
Mr. Schiff preaches that "a compulsory income tax would violate" the Constitution despite the 16th Amendment, and so the Internal Revenue Code "was written to make paying income taxes appear mandatory."
"The Government succeeded in doing this," he contends, "by tricking the public into believing that those enforcement provisions of the code that apply to other, nonvoluntary taxes -- like alcohol and tobacco taxes -- also apply to income taxes when in fact they do not."
At age 67, tanned and exuding confidence that he has uncovered the greatest hoax of all time, Mr. Schiff says he is finding a sharp change in public reaction to his theories.
"Ten or 15 years ago I was called a Communist," Mr. Schiff said in an interview last month. "People who called in would say if you don't like America, leave it. Tomorrow I will be on nationwide radio for three hours telling people the same things and I won't get one negative call."
And he didn't. Nor did anyone attack his views on several other programs in the days that followed.
Mr. Schiff's grass-roots challenge to the legitimacy of the Internal Revenue Service is so far mostly words. He has won no big legal battles in his crusade and has spent more than three years in prison after losing a couple. The I.R.S. brushes off Mr. Schiff and his followers as sadly misguided pests.
Yet even people who ridicule his interpretations of tax law say Mr. Schiff is tapping into a deepening well of popular resentment. His books are widely cited by a melange of groups, many calling themselves patriots of various stripes. "A belief that the income tax is invalid or illegal is a fundamental belief among Christian Patriot groups," said Jonathan Mozzochi of the Coalition for Human Dignity in Portland, Ore., which tracks such organizations.
But Mr. Schiff's anti-tax message is also making its way into the mainstream. "His argument appeals to people whose economic situation has peaked and are desperately looking around for some way to improve their situation," said Richard D. Adams, an assistant professor of auditing at the University of Baltimore who frequently jousts on the Internet with advocates of the idea that income taxes are voluntary.
Indeed, the tax revolt may be more widespread than the I.R.S. lets on. While it reported only 160 open criminal investigations of tax protesters as of last fall, an agency official testified in the trial of an anti-tax activist last year that "hundreds of thousands of people" directly challenge the legal authority of the I.R.S. by filing protest returns or asserting a constitutional right not to file.
The reasons for the change of heart are complicated. Beyond economic factors, one might be the collapse of Communism, a force that had rallied Americans behind the Federal Government against a foreign enemy. Another is a belief that the Government is mostly wasteful and inefficient.
"There has been a dramatic loss of public support for the income tax," said Michael J. Graetz, a professor at Yale Law School and former Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for tax policy in the Bush Administration. "The anti-tax movement extends far deeper than Mr. Schiff and his believers."
In fact, there are many proposals in Washington to scrap income taxes in favor of a flat tax, a national sales tax, a value-added tax or some other plan, all promoted with a promise that most people will pay less.
Mr. Schiff's journey to the libertarian fringe of the tax-protest movement was a long one. In his youth in New Haven, he says, he absorbed the leftist politics of his father, a carpenter and self-described Socialist.
"I was very pro-Roosevelt," he said.
Then, in his mid-20's, he went through a crushing disillusionment. Running the state election campaign of a friend, he was shocked by what he regarded as the moral crassness of politicians. "I never heard them say, 'We will do this to help people,' " he recalled. "They said, 'We will get this guy this job and that guy a contract,' and I realized government is just a business people get into to benefit themselves. From that point on, I listened closely to politicians and I realized that they lied."
Despite that experience, he led a fairly conventional middle-class existence in Connecticut through the 1960's and early 70's, raising a family and running a company he formed to administer health plans for doctors.
He wrote his first book, "The Biggest Con," in 1976 to expose what he viewed as the Federal Government's deceitful ways, including how departing from the gold standard would spur inflation and higher taxes. As time went by, he became more interested in tax issues, inspired by a businesswoman who refused to withhold income taxes from her workers' paychecks. "I wondered at how she had the courage to do what she did," he said.
Ultimately, he took a similar step. In 1974, he quit paying Federal income taxes, prompting a long legal battle that resulted in his imprisonment twice in the 1980's for a total of four years. By the time he got out in 1993, he had sold his business and gotten a divorce.
This year, Mr. Schiff moved to Las Vegas and rented a $730-a-month, two-bedroom apartment that is decorated with plaques and trophies that he has won as an amateur magician. But he spends most of his time on the road, selling books and videotapes and preaching his anti-tax gospel at seminars and on talk shows. He has his own weekly broadcast here.
He carries a cellular phone but says he has no bank account, using cash or credit cards to pay his bills, because he figures the I.R.S. would seize the money as payment toward the $1.2 million in back taxes that it contends he still owes. Already, the agency has confiscated $220,000 in royalties from his 1982 book, "How Anyone Can Stop Paying Income Taxes."
Mr. Schiff is as close to an intellectual light as anybody in the movement against the income tax. His confidence and seeming mastery of the most arcane details of tax law make him a hit with some people. "People respond to Irwin because he is a genuine guy and he has court cases and laws he cites to back up everything he says," said Jamian White, co-host of the nationally syndicated "Birdwell and White" program on Talk America Radio Network, on which Mr. Schiff was a guest last month.
Timothy L. Deaton, who with his wife runs a tiny computer repair and programming business in Shelbyville, Ind., listened to lectures by Mr. Schiff last October, then paid $385 for his collection of books and tapes and started reading tax court cases in the local law library.
"After my studying I'm convinced that Irwin is right, that there is no law that says you have to pay income taxes," he said. Last year, the Deatons paid the I.R.S. $25,900 toward income taxes for the year, but then filed a return reporting no income for 1994, adopting Mr. Schiff's argument that wages are not income under the law. The I.R.S. then refunded the $25,900.
A spokesman for the I.R.S. declined comment on the Deatons' tax return, but said the agency's policy was to withhold refunds from taxpayers who file returns claiming zero incomes. The spokesman, Steve Pyrek, said the I.R.S. typically did not begin auditing returns until 18 months after they were filed and that recovery of refunds issued in error might take several years.
William Cohan, a lawyer in Encinitas, Calif., who defends tax protesters, calls the notion that individuals are not liable to pay income taxes "loony." But Mr. Cohan said the I.R.S. made it possible for people like Mr. Schiff to flourish because it uses the term "voluntary compliance" on its Form 1040 instruction booklets for taxpayers.
I.R.S. officials say Mr. Schiff reaches his conclusions by selective reading of the law. And Margaret Milner Richardson, the I.R.S. commissioner, said that in I.R.S. usage, the term "voluntary compliance" referred to filling out tax forms, not to paying taxes.
In an interview, Mr. Schiff compared himself to two dissidents in the former Soviet Union. "Sharansky went to jail! Solzhenitsyn went to jail!" he said. "Repressive regimes always send people who speak the truth to prison."

HEADLINE: Fed Rate Step Won't Ignore Bond Market

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Speculation has been building for weeks about whether signs of an economic slowdown will lead Federal Reserve policy makers to reduce short-term interest rates when they meet here Wednesday and Thursday. But the key question before the central bank's officials may lie in how well financial markets would withstand a decision not to cut.
The Federal Reserve prizes its independence from Wall Street and from the White House: "No one forces our hand," a Fed Governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said in an interview last week. Still, the Fed's leaders take many of their cues from the bond market. 
 Prevailing interest rates for Treasury bills, notes and bonds with a maturity of up to five years are now less than the Fed's 6 percent target for overnight loans. And while rates have bounced back slightly over the last two weeks following signs that the economy might be less weak than previously thought, the persistent gap between market rates and the Fed-controlled interest rate suggests that many investors still believe the Fed will have to cut rates this summer, and possibly this week. Having already adjusted to lower rates, markets might slump if the Fed does not follow through.
What remains unclear is whether the concern by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, about the health of financial markets will exceed his worries that a premature rate reduction could feed inflation later if, as he has predicted, the economy bounces back by the end of this year. And a rate cut on Wednesday or Thursday could prove embarrassing to the Federal Reserve if unemployment figures for June, scheduled for release on Friday, show a rebound in the economy.
The Federal Reserve is scheduled to receive an advance copy of the June unemployment figures, but not until late Thursday afternoon. By then, its policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee will likely have adjourned.
Fed officials are fond of reminding listeners that their shifts in short-term interest rates affect spending and investment decisions -- and therefore economic growth -- with a lag of six months to two years. Yet a quarter of a percentage point reduction in short-term interest rates -- the scenario most commonly cited now by economists -- would make little difference for the economy, but could have a big and immediate effect on financial markets.
Top Fed officials, including Mr. Greenspan, have been feeling the pressure for a reduction in short-term interest rates this summer. Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, noted in an interview last month that soaring stock and bond prices, and the accompanying fall in long-term interest rates, have partly counteracted weakness elsewhere in the economy.
The scattered signs of economic health in the last two weeks seem to have reflected lower interest rates in financial markets. For example, the Commerce Department announced on June 29 that sales of new homes had soared 19.9 percent in May, when mortgage rates were falling steeply in lock-step with interest rates in the bond market.
The conflicting pressures on the central bank have opened fissures within the committee, with Mr. Blinder expressing more concern about the economy than Republican appointees like Mr. Greenspan and Edward W. Kelley Jr., another governor. When Mr. Greenspan conducted his usual informal poll of the committee members ahead of this week's meeting, Mr. Blinder was said to have pressed him for lower rates and warned that he might dissent if this did not happen.
Mr. Greenspan noted during a speech in New York on June 20 that, "Of one thing I am certain -- our Federal Open Market Committee meeting in a couple of weeks will be most engaging."
For all these reasons, cautious experts are forgoing predictions about this week's meeting. "It's a very close call," said Lyle E. Gramley, a former Federal Reserve Board governor. "I think this is going to be a meeting at which reasonable people can differ."
The American stock and bond markets are also no longer the only financial markets that are important to the Federal Reserve. Mr. Greenspan said in his New York speech that every central banker has to set policy these days with an eye to the huge sums of money flowing across national borders these days, which can swamp even the best-planned economic strategy.
A reduction in interest rates now could cause the already weak dollar to fall further by reducing the returns in short-term interest rates here. As a result, even Wall Street economists who want lower rates are saying that the Fed should cut only the Federal Funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, and not the discount rate, which the Fed charges banks for short-term loans.
The Federal Funds rate, currently 6 percent, is much more important for the economy than the discount rate, which is currently 5.25 percent. Banks borrow very little money at the discount rate these days because the Fed discourages them from doing so. But the discount rate has remained an important symbol of the stance of American monetary policy, particularly for traders in foreign countries where the discount rate is still more important.
As a result, Sung W. Sohn, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation, a bank holding company in Minneapolis, predicted this week that the Federal Open Market Committee would probably cut "the Federal Funds rate by half a point but leave the discount rate alone to keep the dollar from sliding."
But Mr. Sohn's prediction of even a half-point cut this week puts him in a minority. Some economists predict that the Federal Open Market Committee will give Mr. Greenspan explicit authority to cut short-term interest rates at his discretion at any time before the committee's next meeting on Aug. 22.
Still other economists, looking at this week's meeting, take the view of Paul L. Kasriel, vice president and monetary economist at the Northern Trust Company, a Chicago bank.
"I am predicting a quarter percent cut in the Federal Funds rate and no change in the discount rate," he said. "The Fed is not really sure how much it will need to lower the funds rate now, so it's probing."

HEADLINE: A Rough Year For Farmers Appears Likely

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 4

 BODY:
Cold, wet spring weather across much of the Midwest, followed by a searing dry spell in early June, has set the table for what could be a rough year for many farmers. An average or even slightly better than average grain and soybean harvest is still possible, analysts say, but shortfalls seem more likely.
Problems with this year's crop already are translating into higher prices for livestock feed, costlier ingredients for food and beverage companies and higher prices for industrial consumers of agricultural products. Little of the expense has filtered through to consumers, but that could change if continued weather problems hamper the current harvest of winter wheat and the progress of crops planted this spring. 
 "We're in nail-biting time," said John McMillan, who follows agribusiness for Prudential Securities. "The margin for error is low."
The high risk of poor harvests is particularly worrying because worldwide corn and wheat supplies began the year near historic lows when measured against how much is being consumed. With less in reserve, every new hint that harvest projections will have to be lowered makes buyers more nervous. As more of them purchase futures contracts to lock in the price they will pay for crops they need next month, or even next year, prices for both the futures and the grain currently being sold spike upward.
"What we've seen so far will raise consumer food prices by a half a percent to 1 percent, to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent," said Paul Prentice, president of Farm Sector Economics Inc., a Colorado Springs consulting firm. "But if corn got to $3 a bushel and stayed there, the rate of food inflation could double to between 5 percent and 6 percent."
That impact would come primarily from the effect of higher feed costs on poultry, pigs and beef. Higher feed prices can initially drive meat prices down as animals that become too expensive to feed are killed, adding to supplies. But once those animals are gone, supplies tend to tighten, sending prices up.
Price increases are already pinching profits for many agribusinesses. The stock prices of food producers like Tyson Foods Inc. and Archer-Daniels-Midland have slumped as analysts pare earnings estimates. Many smaller competitors have been even harder hit. Last week, a large ethanol plant in Southpoint, Ohio, owned by Ashland Oil and three minority partners, said that it would shut down and lay off 182 workers because it could not sell ethanol and its byproduct, a feed additive for cattle, at a high enough price to cover the cost of corn.
The outlook got even bleaker on Friday when a Government report cut estimates of the number of acres of corn farmers managed to plant to 72 million, well under the average estimate by analysts of 73.4 million. Corn futures prices rose sharply that day in heavy trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, and analysts said the price could continue to move up in coming weeks. Traders around the world use the Board of Trade contracts as the benchmark for virtually all other corn sales.
Wheat prices, up more than 30 percent since March, to their highest levels since the 1970's, have climbed even more sharply. They could well head still higher if more storms hit the winter wheat harvest, which is currently working its way north through Oklahoma and Kansas. Winter wheat accounts for more than three-quarters of the United States crop. The projected total crop this year is 69.4 million acres, well below what analysts had earlier expected. Poor quality is also a major concern.
The weather has been better further north, but the wet, cold spring delayed planting of spring wheat in that region making it less likely that American farmers can contribute much this year to lessening the tight worldwide supply outlook.
"The question worrying us now is whether this price rise is a blip, a plateau, or a rising curve," said Mark Dirkes, a spokesman for the Interstate Bakeries Corporation in Kansas City, a leading producer of breads and cakes.
The hardest hit corn growing regions are in the southern half of the Corn Belt, including Missouri and the southern portions of Iowa, Illinois and Indiana. Unlike the floods of 1993, where the worst of the weather damage occurred after crops were planted, this year's problem was simply getting into the fields in the prime planting period of late April and early May.
"I've never seen anything like it in 22 years in the business," said Bill Shaw, the district representative in northeastern Missouri for Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., the country's largest corn seed company. Over 80 percent of the Pioneer seed sold for early planting in Mr. Shaw's district was returned. Some was exchanged for soybeans or strains of corn bred to mature more quickly. But, Mr. Shaw estimated, about 50 percent of the land that farmers in the region originally intended for corn never got planted.
The lost acreage in the southern part of the Corn Belt might have had less impact on the corn market if farmers in other regions had not set aside 7.5 percent of the land they would normally have devoted to corn. The Government ruled last fall that farmers had to make such a set-aside to remain eligible for crop subsidies. It feared that a bumper crop like that harvested last year would create an oversupply. That would sink prices and increase the sums the Department of Agriculture would owe farmers under the subsidy program.
Looking ahead, farmers and customers alike are now most concerned about the more than 70 million acres that did get planted. Much of the planting took place weeks behind schedule and in poor conditions. The old adage that corn is "knee high on the fourth of July" is true in many areas this year; unfortunately, it is also woefully out-of-date when applied to modern strains that are expected to be waist high at this point.
The crop has come along nicely in the past two weeks but the portions planted in wet ground have poor root structures. That corn is more susceptible than usual to damage from insects and the high winds of passing thunderstorms. And late planted fields will begin the pollination process that creates grain inside the ear in late July or August instead of early this month. Later pollination brings higher risks of heat and dry weather than can reduce the number of kernels per ear.
The late planting also leaves less time for the corn to mature before harvest. "If we have an early frost, we're toast," said William Biederman, vice president for research at Allendale Inc., an agricultural consulting firm.
The soybean crop is also late and likely to produce poor yields in many areas. Because stocks are relatively high though, and farmers may have switched as much as a million acres they originally intended for corn into beans, price pressures have been more moderate.

HEADLINE: Indian Politics Derail a Big Power Project

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, July 4

 BODY:
A few months ago, it seemed like an ideal match. On one side was India, now open to foreign investment but starved of the electrical power needed for economic growth. On the other was a consortium of major American companies with a contract to invest nearly $3 billion in an advanced power plant outside Bombay.
When paperwork on the contract was completed in January, the consortium, led by the Enron Corporation of Houston, a big natural-gas supplier, was the jewel in the crown of a budding new business relationship between India and the United States. 
 Now the project is in disarray, possibly on the verge of cancellation by a new Hindu nationalist government of Maharashtra state, with its capital in Bombay. Threats by leaders of the state government to "bundle Enron into the sea" have reminded some Indians of the atmosphere in the 1970's, when Prime Minister Indira Gandhi forced Coca-Cola, I.B.M. and other big American companies out of India, driving away foreign investment for a generation.
The attack on the current project is based on accusations that the Americans obtained unduly favorable terms from the national Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao that will translate into onerous rates for Indians, an assertion that the parties to the deal deny. Critics have also noted that the contract was awarded without competitive bidding, a break with the tight rules that govern public contracts in India.
For the American companies, and for foreign investors in general, the attack underscores the uncertainty of doing business in developing nations. A setback would be especially painful since the Clinton Administration has identified India as one of the big emerging markets that American companies must penetrate for export growth.
For Prime Minister Rao, who must call a national election by next spring, the attack is a challenge with a strong political subtext: He has built his record largely on an ambitious program of economic change, with a more open environment for foreign investors as a centerpiece.
Indians who have backed these changes fear that a collapse of the Enron deal could set off a chain reaction, with other foreign investors pulling out -- leaving India, one of Asia's poorest nations, to fall still further behind its neighbors. Finance Minister Manmohan Singh, the architect of the changes, has called the Enron project a litmus test for the entire economic effort.
Amid the tide of good feelings that prevailed last year, the Enron project was lauded as an example of all that American investment could accomplish in India. The project, with the General Electric Company's GE Capital unit and Bechtel Enterprises as minority partners, was to be by far India's largest single foreign investment, with $990 million for the first, diesel-fueled phase of the power plant, to be completed in 1997, and a further $2 billion for a second, gas-fueled phase, with the details to be negotiated later.
India needs few things more than electric power. With chronic power shortages that regularly paralyze factories, offices, hospitals and trains, India's state-owned electrical utilities have been the butt of recriminations for years. Under its program of economic reforms, the New Delhi Government has plans to increase total power output by half by the end of the decade, with 60 percent of the increase to come from foreign-built plants.
If India seemed poised to gain from the Enron deal, so too did American companies, many of which had focused on India, with its nearly 900 million people, as a market that could not be missed. During a visit earlier this year by the United States Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, American officials boasted that, in India at least, American companies had stolen a march on Japan, which has led investment elsewhere in Asia.
Now, despite the controversy, Enron's engineers have forged ahead at the power-plant site on the rocky Arabian Sea coast 100 miles south of Bombay. Work stopped for a time in May, when demonstrators attacked the site, slightly injuring three Americans and wrecking vehicles. Since then, the Dabhol Power Corporation, the Indian-registered company founded by the American partners, has laid foundations for the generating plant and begun work on other facilities.
But soon the Maharashtra government, a coalition of two Hindu nationalist parties, will begin a review of the deal it ordered after ousting the Congress Party in an election in March. The nationalists' victory followed a campaign in which they accused the Congress Party officials of guaranteeing windfall profits for the Americans, and of accepting kickbacks. No evidence has been offered to support that allegation.
Still, the nationalists struck deep chords in India's psyche. Gopinath Munde, Maharashtra state's deputy chief minister, told election rallies that the American companies were offering nothing India could not accomplish on its own and that Enron's profits would be paid "on the backs of India's poor."
The criticism has spurred a noisy debate across the country, with a torrent of articles in newspapers and magazines, some defending the Enron deal and many more decrying it. "India's status will be enhanced, not lowered, if it tells the world that it is no pushover, no banana republic ready to accept an atrocious deal," a commentary in the influential Times of India said.
The main Hindu nationalist party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, known as the B.J.P., has shown signs of using Enron as a trial balloon for a national campaign next year that would make a big issue of charges that the Rao Government had "sold out" India to foreign interests. The Maharashtra coalition is composed of the B.J.P. and an extreme Hindu nationalist group, the Shiv Sena.
In the last week, Enron executives have prepared for the worst. "I'm in grief," Rebecca Mark, the 40-year-old president of the Enron Development Corporation, the subsidiary that concluded the deal, told reporters in Europe. Ms. Mark spoke after Indian newspapers said a Maharashtra review committee headed by Mr. Munde would condemn the Enron project and recommend that it be canceled without compensation.
Diplomats at the United States Embassy here have been ordered to say nothing to exacerbate the situation. But privately, they say that at least two big American companies have put negotiations for major Indian investments on hold. Other Western embassies report a similar cooling among foreign companies.
"Since the days of the East India Company, Indians have always been suspicious of foreign companies," a Western diplomat said. "It's too tempting a target for the nationalists to leave alone."
Hopes for saving the project appear to depend mainly on a last-minute reversal by the Maharashtra leaders, prompted perhaps by hints from Enron and its partners that they could use an arbitration clause in the contract, providing for settlement of disputes in London, to sue for compensation. Enron executives have suggested that claims could exceed $100 million, but at the urging of the United States Ambassador, Frank G. Wisner, the company has toned down some of its tough talk.
Behind the scenes, Enron executives and American diplomats have met with the New Delhi Government, hoping that, if all else fails, Mr. Rao will use power given the central Government in the contract to block cancellation of the deal.
When Enron's negotiations faltered last year, Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary led a succession of Clinton Administration officials to India and persuaded Prime Minister Rao to approve guarantees that New Delhi would pay for the power generated by eight foreign-built power plants, including Enron's, if India's state electricity boards, notorious for their corruption and inefficiency, failed to pay.
One solution suggested by officials in India's power ministry is for New Delhi to compensate Enron and its partners if the project is canceled, and to recoup the money from the subsidies it regularly pays to Maharashtra. Another possibility is that the Rao Government take over the project and transfer it to another state with chronic power shortages, possibly the eastern state of Orissa.
But for the moment, attention is focused on the risks of the Enron dispute torpedoing India's prospects of attracting other foreign investments, including an estimated $50 billion urgently needed to build more power plants, as well as to improve battered ports and roads. Overall investments have been painfully slow, with less than $2 billion coming in last year, a fraction of the amounts foreign companies are investing elsewhere in Asia.
Those who say that Enron and its partners have been given overly generous terms focus on a provision in the contract that guarantees a minimum return on investment of 16 percent, rising to a potential 30 percent if the Enron plant operates at close to its full 2,015-megawatt capacity. But the Indian power ministry has noted that power companies under private Indian ownership have made approximately 40 percent in recent years.
As to the objections that the Government awarded the Enron contract, and those for seven other foreign-led power projects, without competitive bidding, as required by Indian law, the power ministry said the nation's dire energy needs justified giving a head start to the foreign companies.
Ms. Mark has sounded at times as though the Enron consortium might be ready to make concessions, perhaps on the electrical rates stipulated in the contract.
"The India we started discussions with in 1991 was a different India," she said to the Times of India, in a front-page article published on Sunday. "We went there when no one wanted to go. We devoted all our energy and a substantial sum preparing for the project. It was done in a spirit of solidarity with India, not in a self-serving way."

HEADLINE: Camden Aquarium Changes Lures;
Forget the Local Color, Brighter Fish May Attract Visitors

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J.

 BODY:
For years the accepted wisdom about the mad public love for fish under glass meant that anybody could build an aquarium, and people would turn out in the millions. Then the New Jersey state aquarium tampered with the formula by specializing in local fish.
There are a lot of brown fish in New Jersey waters. Brown flounder. Brown cod. Even much of the water is dun. The aquarium almost single-handedly brought down the national statistics for aquarium attendance and worse, it failed to prove the engine of redevelopment envisioned for this impoverished city across the Delaware River from Philadelphia. 
 "I mean, fish in New Jersey are not very interesting, they are kind of drab looking," Wanda M. Bullion, a librarian in the Camden schools, said. "The Nintendo generation wants color, excitement -- you have to get their attention."
This weekend, the aquarium started trying to do exactly that.
Cries of "Shark! Shark!" and "EEEwwwww, look at the eel!" resonated through the aquarium, reopened on Saturday after BRC Imagination Arts, a theme park design company based in California, spent six months and $3.75
 
million remodeling the inside. The "Made in New Jersey" label is all but banished. Caribbean and ocean exploration have arrived.
There are crimson and gold Spanish logfish, purple Creole wrasses and French angelfish striped in blue. Everything from squawking macaws to mariachi bands to piped-in undersea noises to coral reefs is meant to transport visitors to an exotic realm.
"People go to aquariums because they want to see cool fish with neat stripes and neon colors and eyes bulging out of the sides of their head," said Jane Ballentine, director of public affairs for the American Zoo and Aquarium Association.
Although the aquarium's long-term appeal remains untested, the changes do seem to be drumming up renewed interest, with 16,029 visitors over the four-day holiday, compared with 12,617 for the same period last year.
Originally New Jersey legislators wanted to draw on the experience of cities like Boston and Baltimore, where aquariums helped transform decaying downtown sections into thriving tourist meccas. They sought a similar change for Camden, a city of 85,000 that still has a 22 percent unemployment rate and a national reputation for things like the 1991 pre-Halloween pyromania when vandals torched 120 empty buildings.
A 1985 study for building the aquarium anticipated it might draw as much as $500 million in further investment, but only about a third materialized. A 25,000-seat amphitheater, a garage and a corporate building have been completed, while the Delaware River Port Authority is putting up another office tower and a restaurant.
One problem was a poor economy. Dr. Judith L. Wellington, the aquarium president, said the average tourist in neighboring Philadelphia visits the Liberty Bell and then leaves, so the aquarium relies heavily on local visitors. Sitting there alone, the aquarium could not overcome Camden's reputation as a good place to get your car stolen. The locale, even with a $4 ferry from Philadelphia, and the unadorned exhibits did not attract the crowds that would encourage new shops and restaurants.
Aquarium advocates generally blame the state legislators who balked at the original price tag of $53 million in taxpayers' money and had to be mollified with a promise that the exhibits would glorify New Jersey. When it was finished, the state leased the 100-acre site for $1 a year to a nonprofit management corporation, the New Jersey Academy for Aquatic Sciences.
Things went swimmingly at first. In the first 10 months of operation in 1992, 1.1 million people showed up. But they did not come back, forcing cutbacks in staff and hours. By 1994, only 511,000 people came and membership plunged to about 8,000 from a high of 19,000.
It was the first such dramatic drop in the nation, according to the American Zoo and Aquarium Association, which has acquired 18 new members over the last 25 years, most since 1990. The crowds at its 26 member aquariums peaked at almost 35.5 million in 1993. Then in 1994 the number fell to 34.9 million.
The New Jersey aquarium did attract something of a marketer's dream -- with an average family income of more than $60,000 -- but the exhibits were deemed too passive. The Maritime Center in Norwalk, Conn., with a record of 482,000 visitors over the last 12 months, also features local marine life, but its exhibits invite children to touch shellfish, build Lego dams and navigate boats.
In Camden, many of the "natural habitats" were not exactly crowd pleasers. A New Jersey jetty exhibit meant a lot of dark water and a few rocks highlighted by a glimmer of movement. The outer walls were unfinished concrete, and walking from tank to tank was as compelling as meandering from exit to exit on the New Jersey Turnpike.
"Before our kids were chasing ahead of us to get out, but this time they seem transfixed," Barbara A. Shively, from Allentown, Pa, said.
The difference in the remodeled aquarium, officially the Thomas H. Kean New Jersey State Aquarium, starts in the front lobby, dominated by a seven-foot-high replica of the jaws of a 50-foot Megalodon shark, mounted with real fossilized teeth.
There are more sharks to touch, and visitors can play with a 12-foot shark statue whose every inch is an interactive exhibit. They can move its dorsal fin with a wheel, inventory the debris in its stomach or lift flaps on its tail that answer questions like, "How are sharks like birds?" (Some lay eggs.)
In the once static hallway that held the 150 New Jersey fish, the exhibits literally leap off the walls as the garish coral and other underwater motifs were incorporated into the oddly shaped walls around the tanks.
The New Jersey fish were not filleted. A few tanks are newly disguised within rainbow-hued satellite maps of local waterways. Most of the fish were recast as anonymous background players in the massive main tank.
Referred to by museum staff as the "Big Wow," the main tank used to be the first thing visitors saw and was known for its reflected view of the Philadelphia skyline. Now it is the finale.
At 760,000 gallons, it holds enough water for one person to shower for 40 years. It has a population of about 2,000, including Bob the sea turtle, whose jaw marks are visible on some fish, and two dozen well-fed, crowd-pleasing sharks. Well, mostly crowd pleasing. A toddler set into a bubble window that gives viewers the sensation of sitting in the tank ran screaming from the room when a shark, jaws gaping, whizzed by his nose.
While scores of the new exhibits are much more hands on, the aquarium also evidently thinks adults wouldn't mind more than just fish.
A woman named Monica Rodrigo introduced a troupe of South American dancers who performed under the new fish mobile and shimmering blue lights of the main rotunda.
"The couples dance separately doing frenetic and erotic movements which are based on jumps, falls, chases and confrontations between man and woman," she said, explaining that the dance was called the mapole after a fish from the waters off Colombia. "The dancers' moves imitate the movements of this fish."
There were no dances named after New Jersey fish.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The encounters were many between children and fish at the New Jersey aquarium, which opened over the weekend in Camden after a remodeling. Local fish, authentic but drab, have been replaced by tropical crowd pleasers. (Photographs by Dith Pran/The New York Times)
