SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 728 words

HEADLINE: Jockeying for Block Grants

 BODY:
The Republicans act like they want to chop the last four words from President Clinton's pledge to "end welfare as we know it." They propose doing away entirely with the 60-year-old entitlement that guarantees Federal and state money for poor mothers. Instead, the Republicans want Washington to turn fixed pots of money, called block grants, over to states to spend on the poor, or slash to inconsequence, as they please.
The block grants are being sold as a solution to the Federal deficit and a deterrent to out-of-wedlock births. Washington would no longer spend more money every time state welfare rolls swell. Nor could teen-agers count on government to help pay the cost of raising children. But the G.O.P. is fast learning that block grants are no magic elixir. The proposal has stalled in the Senate in a battle among states over how to allocate the block grant money. 
 The challenge is to find a formula that simultaneously satisfies states that are rich or poor, fast or slow growing. The G.O.P.'s insistence that Federal welfare spending fall over the next seven years makes the task of allocating a shrinking resource all the more politically daunting.
The House has passed a welfare bill that sets block grants to each state at, roughly, the amount Washington is currently providing to their welfare programs. But when Sun Belt senators took a hard look, they bolted because their states currently get far less Federal money than do Northern states. That is because the South puts up far less money per poor child than the North, and Federal contributions are tied to the amount a state spends on its own. So the Sun Belt senators devised a different formula that would move toward equalizing Federal spending per poor child -- dramatically shifting Federal money out of New York and into Mississippi and other Southern states. Federal welfare spending in New York could fall by half.
All of the Republican block grant proposals pose a grave danger to the poor because the G.O.P. will not insist that states maintain their own contributions at current levels. That leaves them the option of cutting back their own welfare spending entirely. States will be under tremendous pressure to cut spending on the poor to save money in these tight financial times and to drive the poor elsewhere.
To make matter worse, Senate conservatives are flirting with turning food stamps -- an entitlement the House left in place and that is paid for entirely by Washington -- into a block grant. The impact would be catastrophic, according to estimates by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal think tank. Under current law, when recession hits and welfare rolls rise, Mississippi spends only about $25 per month of its own money to support an additional family on welfare and food stamps, with Washington picking up the rest of the tab. But with block grants, Washington would not spend an extra dime as welfare rolls rise -- leaving Mississippi to cough up, at current benefit levels, an extra $400. New York now spends about $235 of its money to add a family to welfare and food stamps, the balance coming from Washington. Under block grants, New York would have to spend an extra $685 to support families at current benefit levels. So when recession hits, fiscally strapped states would be apt to gut services or deny eligibility to millions of needy families.
The G.O.P. might resolve the North-South feud by devising a complicated formula that took account of current Federal spending but also spent more in states with low benefit levels or fast-growing poverty rolls. But there is a problem. If the Republicans refuse to spend more money, then the money directed to the South will have to come out of the coffers of states in the North. The likely result is further political gridlock.
Even without the feuding, block grants would be an unprincipled reform. Welfare should be provided from Washington, not state and local governments. That is the only way to insure that states set benefits at compassionate levels, rather than ramping down benefits to drive the poor into someone else's lap. Now the Republicans are finding that this unprincipled reform is also politically intractable. It is probably asking too much for the G.O.P. to back down. The only hope is that whatever formula they choose takes account of people in need.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Half A Loaf

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In trying to determine whether the latest U.S.-Japan trade accord on autos is a good deal or a bad one, I'm reminded of what Chairman Mao reportedly said when asked what he thought of the French Revolution: "It's too soon to tell."
To be sure, it is troubling to note how happy the Japanese are with this deal. Any deal Japan is happy with is a deal the U.S. should worry about. Japan is a country with structurally closed markets and a $130 billion global trade surplus. If your negotiating outcome with Japan is "I'm O.K., you're O.K.," then you're probably not O.K. 
 But then, it's not surprising Japanese officials would try to put the best public face on this deal. What is more indicative is what the U.S. car manufacturers are saying in private. Detroit's executives are chronic complainers and they have an enormous stake in opening the Japanese market. What they are saying is that as a result of this deal they will sell more cars and parts to Japan. But, what they are also saying is that this deal, while it wedged the door open for them, has not fundamentally changed the Japanese system, which limits showroom space for U.S. cars and restricts the sale of U.S. auto parts. That's why their bottom line is: this deal creates the opportunity for a stream of new sales to Japan, but certainly not a flood. It's worth supporting, but not celebrating.
If that's the case, what lessons can be drawn from this partial victory?
1. Pain works, and more pain works better. Whatever the U.S. got out of these negotiations came because it credibly threatened Japanese auto companies with real pain, in real time, involving real money -- 100 percent tariffs on every luxury car they sell in the U.S. American officials really don't know how to influence decision making in Tokyo. But Toyota does. Mitsubishi does. Squeeze them hard enough and they will get the right message to the right Japanese bureaucrat.
2. The Clinton Administration put an enormous nine-month effort into organizing that pain. It was the trade equivalent of firing the guns of Navarone. But when you finally fire the big guns, you're supposed to sink the fleet -- you're supposed to fundamentally alter Japan's closed system of interlocking companies. This deal took only the first steps toward that end.
But Washington is not likely to threaten to fire the big guns again soon. It's too unsettling. So how does it keep inflicting pain on Japan to open other closed markets? The only way is to work more effectively with the Europeans, and other open-market Asian countries, to line them up against Japan and create more leverage. The Europeans and Asians share America's frustration with Japan's closed markets, but not its unilateral tactics. Washington has to find a way to work with them in every world organization to relentlessly expose Japan's protectionist practices and to enlist the full force of international opinion against Tokyo.
3. If America is to fully harvest even the limited promises Japan made in this latest deal, it must staff the U.S. embassy in Tokyo with fewer cold war political officers and security types and more Japanese-speaking commercial experts who can follow the Japanese auto market to verify whether Tokyo is living up to its commitments. Right now the Tokyo embassy does not have nearly enough staff to monitor this agreement in proportion to the pressure Washington put on to achieve it and in proportion to the stakes involved in making it work. As the Japanese say: "Shinyo suru ga kakunin suru" -- trust but verify.
4. For now the Japanese have us over a barrel. Either their economy is so weak that they say "How can we compromise?" or their economy is so strong that they say "Why should we compromise?" That vicious cycle will only be broken when Japan redefines its own interests. That is, when it shifts from a nation obsessed with protecting its producers to a nation more concerned with protecting its consumers -- giving them the lower prices and the range of choices that come with real open markets. It's just like arms control with the Soviets. We really only saw a huge reduction in nuclear weapons after Mikhail Gorbachev took office and decided to shift Moscow's relationship with the U.S. from one of adversaries to one of strategic partners.
When might that happen with Japan? Sooner, one hopes, than it took Mao to make up his mind about the French Revolution.

HEADLINE: Clean Water: A Midstream Approach

BYLINE: By Sherwood Boehlert; Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York, is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Water Resources and Environment.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Within the year, the 104th Congress may rewrite the Clean Water Act, the Superfund program, the Endangered Species Act, the Safe Drinking Water Act and portions of the Clean Air Act. In short, it may redesign the entire framework of environmental protection that has been developed over the past 25 years.
That could have salutary results. The laws need to be redrafted to prune red tape, cut back the natural accretion of bureaucracy and, most important, reflect the findings of the latest scientific and economic research. Unfortunately, Congress seems poised to leap far beyond such level-headed revision and instead reverse more than two decades of environmental progress. 
 The vote last month in the House to dilute the Clean Water Act demonstrated what an uphill battle it is to put together a coalition for sensible reform. But the vote also indicated that moderates still could carry the day as the debate over environmental protection moves forward.
Part of the problem is that the terms of debate are being set by those at the ends of the spectrum. On one side are environmental absolutists, who often sound as if they view the restoration of Eden as a reasonable interim goal for environmental policy. On the other is an increasingly strident conservative vanguard, which believes (to update Barry Goldwater) that extremism in the defense of libertarianism is no vice and moderation in the pursuit of deregulation is no virtue.
Both sides grossly misread the desires of a pragmatic and often ambivalent electorate. The absolutists choose to ignore the voters' growing suspicion of the Federal Government and, in the abstract, of regulation. But the libertarians fail to see that the voters still expect the Federal Government to guarantee them a cleaner environment. And, polls show, the vast majority even want the Government to do more to achieve that end.
What is to be done? Congress can satisfy the voters, protect the environment and maintain the nation's ability to compete in the world economy, if its environmental policy is guided by three fundamental moderate principles:
Repeal is not reform. Environmental law can be improved without eliminating the provisions that have made it so effective. This principle has often been honored only in the breach by the current Congress.
For example, in the name of "reform," the clean water bill that passed the House repealed the entire program that limits discharges of polluted storm water -- even though storm water runoff is responsible for more than 25 percent of damage to water quality in the United States.
Was repeal necessary to eliminate the flaws in current law? Absolutely not. An exemption for small communities and small businesses, which contribute little to the problem, could have eased the burden of regulation without threatening water quality.
Instead, the House used a guillotine to cure a headache -- giving aid and comfort to the environmental absolutists by making credible their claim that "reform" is merely a euphemism for backsliding.
States have a role. Centralizing all decision-making, as the environmental absolutists desire, is a recipe for an anti-regulatory backlash. Giving the states a greater role in environmental policy -- the power to carry out Federal law by granting permits for the use of wetlands, for example -- reduces red tape and insures that regulators understand local conditions.
On the other hand, environmental policy cannot simply be delegated to the states, as the libertarians pretend. Air and water recognize no state boundaries. Supporters of the House bill repeatedly said that Maryland could protect the Chesapeake Bay without Federal regulation if the state was genuinely concerned about its recreation and fishing industries. But Maryland would have no way to stop polluted water originating in Virginia or Pennsylvania.
Regulation should be based on science. Scientific research should not be viewed as suspect simply because its findings may be politically uncomfortable. During the House debate on the Clean Water Act, however, proponents of the "reform" bill attacked a report on wetlands issued by the National Academy of Sciences because it inconveniently offered a scientific definition of wetlands that would have required the bill's proponents to preserve far more acreage than they wished. Yet wetlands follow the laws of nature, not the laws of Congress.
At the other end of the spectrum, the absolutists have not helped the cause of science either, sometimes clinging to outdated scientific findings and forecasts if they can be used to paint a picture of looming environmental catastrophe.
A bipartisan coalition is beginning to form around these principles, despite the polarization in Washington and the lobbying clout of the libertarians and their allies.
During the clean water debate, the moderate coalition was able to block the repeal of the program that protects coastal areas from pollution carried by runoff -- preventing untold billions of dollars in damage to beaches and fishing areas. And though a moderate version of the entire bill lost, it drew 184 votes, far more than anyone had predicted.
The moderate effort was truly bipartisan. It was led by Republicans, with significant support from members of both parties. Speaker Newt Gingrich, incidentally, encouraged Republicans to air their differences.
We have demonstrated that moderates in both parties can work together. If we continue to do so, the public may yet get what it wants -- effective environmental protection that does not unduly burden business or individuals.

HEADLINE: SPECIAL OLYMPICS;
Running the Offense, When to Run Is Enough

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, July 4

 BODY:
Tomas Murray lost his right basketball shoe but hardly a step as he stopped to retrieve the shoe, slipped it back on and then stole the ball from the player he was guarding.
Those rapid-fire movements during a game held to assess talent at the Special Olympics World Games last Saturday would have evoked cheers at any basketball game. But in this instance, they elicited a roar, because Murray has only one leg and, without a prosthesis, runs up and down the court on that one appendage. 
 Not only that, but the 20-year-old Murray, who usually plays point guard, is one of the best players on the Panamanian basketball team. In an assemblage of athletes who perform wondrous achievements in spite of their varying levels of mental retardation and, in some cases, physical disability, Murray is perhaps the most remarkable.
"He's amazing, absolutely amazing," said Jim Reynolds, the boys' varsity basketball coach at Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven and commissioner of the basketball competition, which has drawn 608 male and female players from 44 nations. "He does things that a lot of two-legged players can't do."
In a sport where balance is important, a one-legged player would seem to be at an almost impossible disadvantage. But the 5-foot-4-inch, 180-pound Murray rarely loses his balance, as he demonstrated while playing forward in a game between Panama and the Dominican Republic this afternoon at Quinnipiac College in nearby Hamden.
"It's hard to believe, but Tomas hardly ever falls down," said Troadio Fernandez, the director of the Panamanian delegation to the games, which run through next Sunday. "He's a very good passer, sets good picks and screens and is the team's best 3-point shooter."
Murray, a fiery and aggressive player, did fall down today, three times in all, once after shooting a 3-pointer. But over all he acquitted himself well as Panama was routed by a far superior Dominican Republic team, 85-52, after having won its opening-round game against a New Mexico team made up entirely of Navajos. Playing a little more than half of the 30-minute game, he made 1 of 5 shots, on a layup in the second half. Murray also dazzled the crowd of about 300 with a behind-the-back pass. And unlike many of his teammates, he never turned the ball over as he quickly hopped about the court.
What makes Murray's dexterity and agility on the court even more notable is that, off the court, he walks with crutches, because he does not have a prosthesis for his left leg.
Murray, who is from the Panamanian province of Bocas del Toro near the Costa Rican border, lost his left leg at the hip at the age of 7 when he was hit by a train. But his disability did not keep him from developing into an all-round athlete, who plays baseball, volleyball and American-style football, in addition to basketball in a regular league in Panama.
Why doesn't he use a prosthetic device, he was asked. "Because of economic conditions," he said through an interpreter, referring to his family's financial situation. "I had two -- one when I was small, and another from 13 to 16 -- which I outgrew."
Even when he used an artificial leg, though, Murray said he usually played without it. A third prosthesis is awaiting the young Panamanian when he returns home. "The club that sponsored my trip is giving me the leg, and I will wear it," said Murray, whose degree of mental retardation is slight and who hopes to study engineering at the university level in Panama. "But I won't use it to play basketball."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tomas Murray, who lost his left leg when he was 7, played basketball for Panama's Special Olympics team yesterday against the Dominican Republic. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
An American Manifesto for a Desirable Future

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

THE NEXT AMERICAN NATION
The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution
By Michael Lind
436 pages. The Free Press. $25
 Excepting the immodest few who run for top public office, not many observers of the passing scene would have the audacity to present their ideas for the collective American future as a "manifesto." It is a measure of his boldness that Michael Lind does just that. 
"The Next American Nation," he writes, is "the first manifesto of American liberal nationalism," which, in essence, is a prescription for prosperity and justice based on what Mr. Lind calls "cultural fusion and genetic amalgamation not just of white immigrant groups but of Americans of all races." Moreover, he writes, only liberal nationalism, by contrast with other, either liberal or conservative counter-manifestoes, "can lead to an America in which you and your descendants would want to live."
If you say that yours is the only way to a radiant future, you'd better be good. Fortunately, Mr. Lind is very good. "The Next American Nation" is a brash, refreshingly unorthodox, always interesting performance by a young man (he is just 32) who defies the usual political categories of left and right, liberal and conservative.
This is not to say that Mr. Lind's book is always compelling or even that it is convincing more than half of the time. It is often both tendentious and dreamy, based too much on pure thought and not enough on any experience with the way the world actually works. Just about every element of Mr. Lind's description of the current national plight and in his prescriptions for the future is debatable. Still, even when he is utopian or dogmatic, Mr. Lind saves himself by his obvious intelligence. His book is one of the best -- certainly it is the most visionary, the most forward-looking -- in the growing library of works on the American identity, multiculturalism and the future.
"The Next American Nation" is organized around what might be called two disavowals. The first concerns the dominant vogue of multiculturalism, which Mr. Lind treats as an unmitigated calamity. He is an enemy of racial preferences, affirmative action and racial labeling, the elimination of which he cites as liberal nationalism's "one nonnegotiable demand."
The second disavowal is of what Mr. Lind variously calls "the plutocracy," the "white overclass" or the "oligarchy," which, he argues, has throughout American history struck a series of grand compromises, all of them aimed at maintaining its ascendancy in American life. His analysis is unabashedly based on economic interest with little room left for other factors, such as idealism or principle. In the first American Republic, the "Anglo-American nation," the compromise was between North and South to keep blacks in bondage. The Second American Republic, what Mr. Lind calls "Euro-America," saw the bargain struck between the oligarcy and the white working class to keep blacks out.
This leads to Mr. Lind's highly critical portrayal of multiculturalism, which he declares "a repellent and failed regime," though not for the reasons normally cited by the critics of such things as racial preferences and the cult of ethnic and sexual authenticity. Conservatives have warned that these practices will lead to separatism, lowered standards and Balkanization. Mr. Lind avers, by contrast, that multiculturalism has become the basis for a new grand and highly conservative compromise. The white overclass has used racial labeling to buy supremacy by co-opting token numbers of blacks and other minority group members and giving them overclass status, leaving the vast majority untouched and unhelped. The real danger, Mr. Lind argues, is not Balkanization but Brazilianization, "a high-tech feudal anarchy, featuring an archipelago of privileged whites in an ocean of white, black and brown poverty."
Throughout much of this, Mr. Lind, swept up perhaps in the grandeur of his vision, engages in overblown descriptions of the current national plight, his constant use of such words as "plutocracy" and "reactionary" summoning up images of a banana republic rather than the world's most prosperous and socially mobile democracy. Multicultural America is, he says, "plutocracy tempered by tokenism," which is a fine turn of phrase, but it does not disguise the author's approach, which could be called overstatement tempered by intelligence.
His notion that such approaches as affirmative action represents a kind of invisible hand of oligarchic power has an old-left pamphleteer's ring to it, but is it true? Mr. Lind, to take one of many possible examples, calls "our castelike educational system" the "final redoubt of oligarchy." His critique of preferences for the sons and daughters of alumni as affirmative action for the rich is compelling. But in 1993, the entering class at Harvard was more than 50 percent Jewish, Asian, black and Hispanic, while at Stanford, Berkeley and many other places those figures were even higher. Something more far-reaching than token gestures by the white overclass seems to be involved.
Mr. Lind's specific proposals for the future demonstrate the same blend of boldness and dubiousness as does much of his analysis. On the one hand, he brilliantly describes the elements of a common American culture. On the other, he lays out a vast government program involving an "unsubtle, crude, old-fashioned redistribution of wealth, through taxation and public spending." In other words, it's the kind of program that the common American culture, if the last election is any indication, has lately been repudiating, and that, by contrast with, say, Scandinavia, it has always repudiated. Mr. Lind would limit immigration, impose a social tax on goods imported from third-world countries (to protect American labor) and engineer an array of programs -- the "ideal would be 'maximum feasible paternalism,' " he writes -- to change the "culture of poverty" at the root of American misery.
Every one of these suggestions raises questions, as does one of Mr. Lind's main articles of faith, which is that in a regime of liberal nationalism "formerly accepted inequities become intolerable." Still, despite its weaknesses and implausibilites, "The Next American Nation" deserves the appellation that Mr. Lind, a bit immodestly, gave it. It is a manifesto, and it deserves serious thought.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Lind (Sigrid Estrada/The Free Press)

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE famous pianist and sometime Polish statesman Ignace Jan Paderewski liked zinfandel.
On the eve of World War I and at the height of his fame as an artist, he bought a 2,000-acre property, Rancho San Ignacio, near Paso Robles, in San Luis Obispo County, on the central coast of California. Ten years later, after he had served a term as Prime Minister of the Polish state created by the Treaty of Versailles and had made a triumphant return to the concert stage, he planted a zinfandel vineyard at his California property. When the vines matured, the wine was made for him by the nearby York Mountain Winery, then, as now, one of the best-known wineries between Los Angeles and San Francisco. 
 The central coast, and especially the Paso Robles area, has always lived in the shadow of the better-known wine regions of Napa, Sonoma and Mendocino Counties, 250 miles to the north. While grape growing and winemaking around Paso Robles (pronounced PAH-so ROE-bulls) are still not as intense as in the northern coast counties, growth in the last 20 years has been considerable.
The number of cabernet sauvignon acres there has increased from about 33 in 1971 to more than 2,600 this year, and the chardonnay area has gone from 29 acres to about 2,500 in the same period. Zinfandel, Paderewski's choice, is the second most important red-wine grape, with about 1,500 acres planted now, up from not quite 300 barely 25 years ago.
Winemaking in the area began at Mission San Miguel in 1797 and became significant in the last half of the 19th century, when immigrants who had come to California for the gold rush moved into the Salinas Valley to take up farming.
Prohibition, however, almost destroyed the wine business in the region. Most of the wineries in the Paso Robles viticultural area -- there are about 25 -- date from the early 1980's. Creston Vineyards, the Eberle Winery and the Martin Brothers Winery are three whose labels are likely to be seen outside the area.
Paso Robles and York Mountain are the two designated American Viticultural Areas in San Luis Obispo County. Paso Robles is an inland valley, desertlike and hot; York Mountain's location, only seven miles from the Pacific and with elevations of 1,600 to 1,800 feet, is maritime, with lots of fog and rain.
Paso Robles is cabernet and zinfandel country; York Mountain has become a source for top-quality pinot noir. Merlot from Paso Robles and from York Mountain has been quite successful. The region produces some fine chardonnay, but much of it goes into commercial wines made by large-volume wineries.
York Mountain Winery, the only winery in the York Mountain viticultural area, was founded by Henry York in 1882.
It has five acres of its own vines but purchases most of its grapes from warmer, sunnier California climes. Most of York Mountain's wines are sold at the winery to tourists on their way to or from the William Randolph Hearst castle, San Simeon, on the coast.
Few of the wineries in Paso Robles are well known outside California, except to a few connoisseurs who will kill to get a case of Peachy Canyon Winery's zinfandel or Wild Horse Winery's pinot noir.
The biggest Paso Robles winery in the region is Meridian Vineyards, just west of the town, on Route 46. Meridian owns some 500 acres around the winery and another 3,000 acres to the south, in Santa Barbara County. Current production is about 100,000 cases a year, but it regularly crushes enough grapes for 10 times that much wine. Meridian is owned by the Swiss food giant Nestle, which also owns Beringer Brothers, in the Napa Valley, among other wineries. And so much of the juice produced at Meridian travels north to Beringer, where it becomes wine sold under the Napa Ridge label. (Meridian was originally a Napa label established by Chuck Ortman. But in 1988, when Nestle bought the Estrella River Winery in Paso Robles and hired Mr. Ortman to run it, the company also bought the Meridian name and bestowed it on the Paso Robles property.)
At Peachy Canyon, also in Paso Robles, zinfandel is king. In defiance of the basic laws of economics, the owner, Doug Beckett, insists he will keep both production and prices low. So far, the winery has produced only a couple of thousand cases a year and, according to plan, will never go above 3,000. After the great succsss of the 1989 and 1990 vintages, customers have been lining up.
Wild Horse Winery, in Templeton, a town south of Paso Robles that is part of its viticultural area, is best known for its pinot noir, made mostly from grapes from vineyards further to the south in the Edna Valley and Santa Barbara County, among other areas. One pinot noir from Wild Horse was a blend of grapes from six Santa Barbara County vineyards.
The blending of grapes from different vineyards seems more prevalent in central and south-central California than it is north of San Francisco. While north coast winemakers eagerly seek out grapes and wine from these more southerly areas, they tend not to blend them. Around Paso Robles, however, wineries and growers seem quite content to work among themselves to achieve what they want in winemaking.
 
Tastings
Edmeades Vineyards Zinfandel (Zeni Vineyard), Mendocino County, 1993. About $20.
Twenty dollars for a zinfandel? For most zinfandels, no. For some, yes. This is one of them. Mendocino County, and particularly the Anderson Valley, is great zinfandel country, as this wine illustrates. It's a big-bodied wine with a deep, garnet red color. The taste is intense, and the flavors are concentrated. The wine has power and a long, lingering finish. The oak is a bit forward, but let's face it, oak is where the action is these days. Keep the wine around a couple of years and the oak will blend in. But who's going to keep it around that long?

HEADLINE: Traffic Moves Surprisingly Well In New Jersey Despite Toll Strike

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 4

 BODY:
The combination of a toll collectors' strike and hundreds of thousands of holiday motorists was widely expected to bring congestion of historic proportions to New Jersey's busiest highways today, but into the evening hours things were surprisingly smooth, with traffic problems less than on many other holidays.
By 10 P.M., highway authorities reported no major trouble spots related to the strike on the New Jersey Turnpike and a "sickout" at the Garden State Parkway, and officials at both the turnpike and the parkway said regular employees were returning to their posts. Traffic was moderate and moving steadily in most places, and the authorities said any delays were caused by the normal tie-ups that come on a holiday, no matter who is operating the tollbooths. 
 It was not clear this evening whether the smooth flow of traffic was a result of advance warnings of the labor disputes, which could have prompted some travelers to begin returning home early. At 1 P.M. today, there was a four-mile backup on the parkway south of the Outerbridge Crossing near Perth Amboy, but it was not clear whether that was related to an accident or to the job action.
Turnpike and parkway officials said they expected the staffing of the tollbooths for the Wednesday morning rush hour to be normal.
Highway officials said they were handling the 600,000 cars that travel the turnpike on a holiday, and the hundreds of thousands more that travel the parkway, with no major problems. But the same could not be said for labor negotiations. At the New Jersey Turnpike Authority, labor and management traded complaints about each other's handling of the strike, while the New Jersey Highway Authority, which oversees the parkway, successfully petitioned a state judge to order workers back to the job.
Although union toll collectors were calling in all day to say that they would return to work for the 10 P.M. shift, neither highway authority had any plans late today to return to the bargaining table to resolve the contract disputes that led to the job actions.
A New Jersey Superior Court Judge, Yolanda Ciccone, ordered toll collectors to return to the Garden State Parkway about 2 P.M. today after 80 workers out of 100 scheduled to work the morning shift called in sick after contract negotiations with the authority broke down.
Lewis B. Thurston 3d, the parkway's executive director, said the judge's order ended the job action at the parkway immediately, although he added that the highway was operating smoothly with temporary workers operating the tollbooths. He said the union employees would be allowed to fill their normal shift if they reported for work on time.
The situation was reversed at the New Jersey Turnpike, where toll collectors tried to return to work late Monday night after a state court judge ordered them to end their strike, but were told to go home by supervisors at the toll plazas.
The union representing the 800 striking turnpike toll collectors, Local 194 of the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, said all union employees reported for work on time Monday night to comply with the judge's orders. After being turned away at their job sites, workers from today's 6 A.M. shift picketed many toll plazas, waving signs that declared the turnpike management had locked them out.
"We came in at 6 o'clock, and they escorted us out," said Mike Ruvolo, a toll collector at Exit 10 near Edison. "They told us to leave. We showed up in good faith to work, and they won't let us work. If they were going to do that, what did they get the injunction for?"
Roger Nutt, executive director of the turnpike authority, said the union workers were turned away on the shifts that started at 6 A.M. and 2 P.M. today because the authority had already contracted with temporary replacements to fill the slots. He said the authority needed to know how many workers would report for duty well before the start of the shift, and the union did not provide enough notice that the workers would return.
"We need to put a work force in place that we can count on to operate the turnpike," Mr. Nutt said this morning. "You can't run a turnpike without knowing who is going to be there until five minutes before they show up."
In a decision that outraged union leaders, Mr. Nutt said the union employees had to notify their supervisors that they would be at work at least five hours before their first shift. That meant that employees reporting for work at 10:30 P.M. tonight had to call in by 5:30 P.M.
The authority said that employees who did not report as required could be subject to fines or termination. But James Robinson, a turnpike spokesman, said that as of 7:30 tonight all 105 employees scheduled for the shift had called in to say they would report to work.
Nevertheless, people trying for a slot as replacement workers again filled turnpike headquarters in East Brunswick throughout the day. Most were attracted by the possibility of an extra paycheck to help with their bills.
"I just got layed off two weeks ago," said Earl Wilson, a heavy equipment operator from Jamesburg, N.J. "I've got a wife and two kids. Unemployment is not enough. I'm just looking for a paycheck."
The turnpike, which was forced by the strike to allow motorists to travel the highway free between 6:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Monday and again between 10:30 P.M. Monday and 6 A.M. today, estimated it lost about $300,000 in tolls. The parkway, which receives 70 percent of its tolls with automated collection machines, said revenues were not affected by the job action.
Union officials said today that the labor disputes were caused by the Whitman administration's desire to get tough on unions. "It is the whole basis for what is going on," said Frank Forst, a union negotiator.
But officials at both the turnpike and the parkway said the labor disputes were over contract issues and not state labor policy.
"This is a local turnpike issue," Mr. Nutt, the turnpike director said. He said the turnpike, which consistently operates in the red, must reduce its overtime costs. He said the authority paid $10 million in overtime last year while paying about $45 million in total salaries.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, attending a bill-signing ceremony in Milltown today, said it was unfair for public employees to receive better benefits and wages than private-sector workers. The Governor said the priority throughout the dispute was to keep the highways open.

HEADLINE: Engineer's Ice Plant Helps Power County

BYLINE: By DEAN NELSON 

DATELINE: ESCONDIDO, Calif.

 BODY:
In this northern region of San Diego County, residents are accustomed to heat, horses and avocado orchards. But now they are getting used to an incongruous addition -- a complex that creates electricity, steam and hockey rinks.
Therein lies the tale of a power entrepreneur who understands that business, like hockey, is about playing the angles. In this case the angles were his technical knowledge of cogeneration power production, the local utility's begrudging obligation to pay him a juicy premium for this power, and Escondido's willingness to grant him tax breaks if he helps revitalize a blighted area. 
 The result is Icefloe, a $66.4 million power plant with two Olympic-size hockey rinks, a fitness center, a swimming pool and a restaurant. Paul Gerst, 67, an electrical power engineer who has built cogeneration plants around the country for others, built his own after studying industries that would combine well with a cogeneration plant producing nearly 50 megawatts of power. Several plants provide for ice-making businesses or refrigerated storage. He chose a skating rink.
Cogeneration plants create electricity and then, with waste heat, provide additional energy for something nearby. In this case it provides energy for which other ice rinks in the area pay $13,000 a month.
Mr. Gerst said he decided to build an ice rink because "I didn't want to have to truck in a tomato or a turnip, slice it, package it, then truck it out again. The idea of an ice rink sounded good because the ice doesn't go anywhere."
But the real revenue for Mr. Gerst is in the 30-year contract his privately held Arroyo Energy Company has with the San Diego Gas and Electric Company. The utility, under the 1978 Public Utility Regulatory Policy Act, is required to buy the electricity he produces. He obtained the contract in 1985 when utility prices were considerably higher than they are now.
San Diego Gas pays 5.38 cents a kilowatt hour to Mr. Gerst, according to the utility, and it recently submitted a rate of 3.12 cents to the Public Utilities Commission for similar contracts in 1996. Mr. Gerst's rate, 72 percent higher than next year's proposed rate, was based on projections a decade ago that utility prices would skyrocket. They did not.
The utility was so reluctant to honor the contract with Mr. Gerst that Mr. Gerst sued and the utility settled.
"Mr. Gerst is a canny investor who took full advantage of a regulatory mistake where rates were set too high," said Greg Barnes, assistant general counsel for San Diego Gas.
Mr. Gerst took advantage of Federal and other Government benefits by building the power plant and the rink in an enterprise zone. The city, with a population 120,000, has seen rapid growth in the last 20 years, creating unsightly areas for the city to remedy.
Escondido officials deferred the collection of property tax from Icefloe, spread a $1.2 million sewer connection charge over 30 years, and moved road and bridge work in the area to the top of the city's public works list to help accommodate Mr. Gerst.
More important, an enterprise-zone project allows the consolidation of the multiple design, planning and public hearings that, in California, can drag on for years.
Mr. Gerst feels that the combination of power plants and hockey rinks is good enough to repeat elsewhere in Southern California.
He financed the complex largely through California Alternative Energy Funding bonds, and said that on the first day of operation his income exceeded his operating expenses.
Predictably, the local utility hopes Mr. Gerst will be satisfied with the complex he has.
San Diego Gas buys 59 percent of its electricity from suppliers, and customers already pay rates 30 percent higher than the national average. The law requiring purchases from cogeneration providers at a locked-in rate for 30 years limits the utility's ability to get lower rates, and works against the idea of a free market, Mr. Barnes said.
"We're delighted to buy power from cogeneration providers, but not when the arrangement is just a subsidy to certain suppliers," he said.
And while the utility thinks Mr. Gerst is a smart entrepreneur, Mr. Barnes said Mr. Gerst was too smart to build any more Icefloes.
"If he looks at the economics of today, he won't do it," Mr. Barnes said.
At that, Mr. Gerst simply smiles. He has plans for five more.
"Anything is possible when you're clever," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cogeneration plants create electricity and then, with waste heat, provide additional energy for something nearby. In the case of a plant built by Paul Gerst in Escondido, Calif., that something was an ice rink. (Robert Burroughs for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: An Educator Who Passionately Believes the Poor Can Succeed

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

 BODY:
In confronting the vast problems of Newark's schools, Beverly Hall is armed with 25 years of experience in urban education, strong leadership skills and -- most important -- a passionate belief in the ability of poor students to succeed, friends and colleagues say.
"Dr. Hall is a perfect example of an administrator who has demonstrated that in fact, all children can learn," Dr. Lester Young, Superintendent of District 13 in New York City, said yesterday. 
 Dr. Hall, New York's Deputy Chancellor for Instruction, will take up her new position as the Acting Superintendent of the Newark school system on July 17. Her first order of business will be to prepare for the opening of school, she said.
"We have to send a clear message in September that this is not business as usual," she said, "that indeed this process has made the beginning of school smoother, that there will be supplies, that there will be materials, there will be textbooks, the facilities will be in better order than they have been in the past."
Dr. Hall was born in Jamaica and came to the United States to pursue her education. She holds bachelor's and master's degrees from Brooklyn College and a doctorate in educational urban policy and administration from Fordham University.
She began her career as an English teacher in Brooklyn and in 1983, she became principal of Public School 282 in the borough. Under her leadership, math and reading scores at the school rose and the school was cited by the state Education Department in 1990 as 1 of 10 "schools that work" in New York City.
In 1992, she became Superintendent of Community School District 27 in Queens, the second largest district in the city system. While there, she involved teachers, parents and community members in a yearlong effort to restructure the middle schools by creating smaller, more personal environments.
Dr. Hall has called middle schools a weak link in the educational chain where too many children lose ground that they will be unable to make up in high school. She took those ideas with her when Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines appointed her the Deputy Chancellor for Instruction in 1994 and helped shape a citywide middle school restructuring that was credited with helping to improve reading and math scores this spring.
She also helped implement Mr. Cortines's plan to raise math and science standards for all students, regardless of race or economic background. "I believe that schools can work for urban students," she said. "I have demonstrated in my own career that if you hold high standards, you have high expectations, then schools can make the difference in a student's life."
Her departure from the New York system comes three weeks after Mr. Cortines announced his resignation and may be the start of an exodus of top educators who were brought into the central system by Mr. Cortines. When asked if she would have left the system had Mr. Cortines not resigned, Dr. Hall declined to answer directly.
"Certainly his leaving played a part in my deliberations to come to Newark," she said. "I went to be his deputy because I believed in his vision for the New York schools."
In a statement, Mr. Cortines praised Dr. Hall as a powerful advocate for quality education. "Dr. Hall has all the right tools for the job of improving Newark's schools: commitment to high standards, deep understanding of urban education and great ability as an administrator," he said.
Dr. Hall said that being an outsider in the Newark system will be a benefit, especially in rooting out the nepotism that has plagued the schools. She expects resistance.
"Whenever you go into a situation with such a mandate you will have some resistance because there are people with a vested interest in the status quo," she said.

She signed the latest installment of her 30 percent income tax cut, she wrenched one state labor contract to a settlement on terms highly favorable to the state, and then finessed a holiday strike. A basic issue in the labor strife on the New Jersey Turnpike is management's continuing campaign to cut overtime pay. [B6.]

HEADLINE: As Affirmative Action Ebbs, A Sense of Uncertainty Rises

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

 BODY:
Eddie Graham senses changes in the air, and he is angry and disillusioned.
"A lot of blacks have gotten to where they are because of affirmative action," said Mr. Graham, a 37-year-old black lawyer, as he stood on a street corner in Philadelphia last week. "For them to say now it's time to end it, that's really a disservice to our younger generation that's coming along." 
 Rich Romano also feels that things are changing, and it makes him hopeful.
"Affirmative action and even welfare, at the beginning, was a great idea, but it got out of hand," said Mr. Romano, 39, a white firefighter in Philadelphia's blue-collar Mayfair neighborhood. "Now it's gotten to be some kind of entitlement. Everybody thinks they're entitled to everything. No one wants to work hard anymore."
Nearly three decades after a series of long hot summers in Los Angeles, Newark, Detroit and other cities helped usher in a commitment to using race-based programs to improve the lives of blacks, talk of race once again fills the muggy air.
But this time the talk is how the 30-year edifice of race-based programs is crumbling -- and some say, along with it, the 30-year commitment to achieving racial equality.
In recent weeks the Supreme Court has issued decisions making it harder to justify giving minorities and women preferences in the awarding of Federal contracts, and harder to draw legislative districts with a majority of minority voters.
In May, the Court let stand a lower court decision halting a University of Maryland program that gave scholarships exclusively to black students. The Court also struck down a school desegregation plan for Kansas City that required Missouri to spend money to attract white students from the suburbs to predominantly black schools in the city.
Meanwhile, the Clinton Administration is re-evaluating Federal affirmative action programs while some lawmakers, including Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, are drafting legislation intended to end special considerations of race in Federal programs.
And a ballot initiative in California to halt the use of racial preferences in hiring, college admissions and contracting is widely expected to be approved next November.
In interviews with politicians, academics, legal experts and ordinary citizens over the long Fourth of July weekend, it became clear that there is a palpable sense of the nation's hurtling toward a future yet to be defined.
"It's the end of an era," said Constance Horner, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution and a member of the United States Civil Rights Commission. "What tells us that this is the end of an era is that all branches of government -- the courts, the Congress, the White House, even the state legislatures -- are actively engaged in the same process, and that's a rare event in American politics."
 
Looking Ahead And Gazing Back
But even as they look ahead, supporters and opponents of race-based programs have their gazes fixed on different points in the past. Critics of racial preferences envision a future rooted in what they say is a return to the roots of the civil rights movement and to virtues espoused by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
"It is a positive shift in that it de-emphasizes race in the way we do our national business, and that is healthy for all ethnic groups," said Joe Gelman, campaign manager for the California Civil Rights Initiative, the ballot measure that would end affirmative action programs in California.
"It is consistent with the principles upon which the civil rights movement originally stood," he added, "and it is certainly consistent with the speech given by Dr. King on the Mall in 1963, when he talked about a society judging people on the content of their character rather than the color of their skin."
But supporters of affirmative action say such sentiments pervert Dr. King's message. They look even further into the past -- to 1877, when Federal troops were pulled out of the South, signaling the end of Reconstruction and the resurgence of white supremacy.
"We are at the end of a second Reconstruction," said Janette Wilson, a black lawyer and former executive director of Operation PUSH, a Chicago-based civil rights organizaiton. "The recent decisions say that the Supreme Court has joined together with the Newt Gingrich faction of Congress, and war is being declared on African-Americans and poor people economically, academically and now politically."
 
Impact on Politics And the Economy
Some people were able to move beyond the visceral reactions that often accompany any discussion of race. They wondered how the changes would affect political and business institutions.
Many expressed a belief that pressure would be put on blacks to revitalize a civil rights movement that they said had grown complacent, and to organize politically to hold on to gains that had been won in the Federal courts and by executive fiat but that now had to be protected in legislatures.
Wade Henderson, legislative director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said that raising black voter participation was the way to counter the Court decisions, the new mood in Congress and what he called President Clinton's hesitancy about strongly backing affirmative action. In 1994, 37 percent of the blacks who were eligible to vote cast ballots, down from 39.2 percent in 1990.
"If we do not increase our voter participation rate beyond 37 percent, then we will have failed," Mr. Henderson said. "It will be hard for us to complain that we have been locked out of the political process if we fail to seize the initiative and energize our voters."
And while analogies to the end of Reconstruction and a return to Jim Crow policies abounded, some blacks noted a striking difference from that era: The policies of the last 30 years have helped create a level of black political and economic power that is unprecedented.
"If you look at the data compared to 30 to 40 years ago, there has been a stunning increase in the number of middle-class blacks and the number of blacks going to college or to business or trade schools," said Hugh B. Price, executive director of the National Urban League. "Our talent bank is exponentially fuller than it was 20 or 30 years ago."
The Supreme Court decision limiting a state's ability to draw majority black or Hispanic election districts will also put strains on the Democratic Party, some experts say.
Many white Democrats have felt that the drawing of majority black districts has packed the party's most loyal voters into a few districts, leaving adjacent white districts more vulnerable to Republicans. But while carving up these majority black districts and spreading their voters around may help white Democrats, it will be fiercely resisted by many black politicians.
"If blacks in the legislature perceive that they are being weakened through this process, they could link up with Republicans," said Merle Black, a political science professor at Emory University in Atlanta.
Some experts said the new times would increase pressure on conservatives to develop policies that would help blacks to advance.
Clint Bolick, vice president of litigation of the Institute for Justice, a conservative public interest group that has fought affirmative action programs, said, "The opponents of racial preferences are going to be challenged by people who say, 'O.K, you don't like preferences, what's your solution?' "
Others said that without affirmative action, conservatives might need a new rallying point.
"What is going to happen three or four years from now?" asked Raphael Sonenshein, a professor of political science at California State University at Fullerton. "What does it mean for conservative forces that have used these policies for 25 to 30 years to run against -- what will they be left with? It is like the end of the cold war for the conservatives."
And some noted that Government-required hiring and promotion programs based on race have made the Government an arbiter between corporations, which want to set their own hiring standards, and minorities, who want more jobs. Without such programs, corporations might become vulnerable to heightened black demands backed by protests or consumer boycotts.
"The question is not whether you have goals," said Lawrence Z. Lorber, a Washington lawyer who represents corporations in civil rights matters. "The question is, who sets the goals?"
 
A Fear of Extremism In a Growing Void
Some people express fears that as the nation sorts through its new direction on racial matters, voices of moderation and conciliation may be drowned out by those most ready to tap into black and white anger.
"The pessimist in me senses that we are heading to some kind of social conflagration," said Lani Guinier, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of Law whose nomination to head the civil rights division of the Justice Department was withdrawn by Mr. Clinton in June 1993 after she came under fire from conservatives.
"The leadership vacuum from both the Supreme Court and the political institutions is creating a void," Ms. Guinier said. "Nature abhors a vacuum, and into that vacuum may move the most extreme voices on each side."
For most blacks, and also some whites, the current shift has its roots in economic dislocations. With per-capita incomes stagnating and corporations trimming their work forces, racial preferences are difficult to sustain.
Perhaps because of, or in addition to, economic insecurities, the current mood also seems to reflect a diminution of the white guilt upon which the edifice of race-based programs was built.
"For a long time, white males were afraid to say anything at all about this," said Frederick R. Lynch, associate professor of government at Claremont McKenna College in California. "They didn't want to be called racists, wimps or whiners."
He added: "Affirmative action was a sacred cow. If you even raise a criticism or a question, suddenly the conversation would change to, 'How's the weather?' '
 
A Generational Gap Among Whites
There also seem to be generational differences among whites in how they view the push to end affirmative action. Those born during the baby boom after World War II, who remember crusading blacks fighting segregation, seem more sympathetic. Younger whites, to whom Jim Crow laws are something out of dusty history books, are less so.
As they sat in front of a Philadelphia skyscraper during their lunch hour, David Springer, 53, and Gerald Littrell, 31, two white elevator repairmen, both criticized affirmative action. But they differed on how quickly to end it.
"There are some people who could use that little leg up to get started," Mr. Springer said. "I don't honestly believe we're on an absolutely level playing field yet. If you go halfway between what you had before and what they're proposing, I'd feel fairly comfortable. You're not going to jam people down other people's throats. But you should use it wisely and not just as a blanket policy."
Mr. Littrell would have nothing to do with such gradualism.
"I think it was good in its day, but I think the field's a lot more even now," Mr. Littrell said. "There's a lot less racism, at least at our level. I don't know about higher up. So I don't think any race should get too many advantages. I think people of my generation and the younger generation feel that racism isn't that big a deal anymore."

HEADLINE: Comptroller Sues to Block Pataki Pension Fund Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 5

 BODY:
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall filed suit today to prevent Gov. George E. Pataki from using money in a special pension fund to balance the state budget, a move that could open a $110 million hole in the spending plan.
The fund in question was created in 1970 to augment the pensions of retired state and local workers whose benefits had been eroded by inflation. But the Legislature never touched the money until last month, when it authorized Mr. Pataki to use $110 million of the $360 million account to help close a projected budget shortfall of nearly $5 billion. 
 Mr. McCall, who manages both the special fund and the state pension system, challenged that move in State Supreme Court in Albany today as an "illegal, unconstitutional and unconscionable" raid on the pension fund.
"The pension fund exists for the main and only purpose of providing benefits to retirees," Mr. McCall, a Democrat, said in a news conference. "It is not a slush fund that the state should look to every time it's in trouble to balance the budget."
As the trustee of the pension system, Mr. McCall might have been able to block the pension plan administratively. But he filed suit because he wanted the force of a court ruling behind him. Mr. McCall said his suit is based on legal arguments similar to those he successfully employed two years ago to block a different plan by the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to use pension funds to balance the budget.
At a news conference in New York City, the Republican Governor said Mr. McCall's suit was politically motivated. Mr. McCall is considering running for Governor in 1998. Later in the day, Mr. Pataki's press secretary defended the legality of the plan, saying that while the $110 million would not be used to pay for new increases in pension benefits, it would compensate the state for the cost of past pension increases.
"The legislation is perfectly consistent with the purpose of the fund, which is to supplement pensions," said the spokesman, Robert J. Bellafiore.
But Mr. McCall said: "They are simply postponing to the future obligations they have to face up to this year. If we let them get away with this, if they get an inch this year, they'll want a mile next year."
The pension plan was part of the $63.5 billion budget enacted by the Legislature on June 7. In that spending plan, the Legislature authorized use of $110 million of the pension fund to help close the projected budget gap -- part of $900 million in "one-shots," or nonrecurring revenues, used to balance the spending plan.
The budget also authorized a new pension-payment increase for 402,000 retired teachers and other state and local government workers, starting on Sept. 1. Pension funds totaling $130 million would be used to cover that increase.
The remaining $130 million of the pension fund is to be given to local governments to reduce their pension costs.
Had the Legislature not dipped into the $360 million fund this year, Mr. McCall said, the fund could have financed the new pension increase for 10 years at no additional cost to the state or most local governments. But, he added, the Governor's plan would deplete the special pension fund by 1997, possibly forcing state and local governments to cut other spending to finance the enhanced pension benefits.
The special fund will not cover New York City's increased pension costs, which will be $100 million a year starting in 1997.
Mr. McCall did not offer any suggestions on how the state should close the $110 million hole his suit would create if it is successful. The Legislature and Mr. Pataki fought a bitter battle over other proposed budget cuts earlier this year, and finding an additional $110 million in reductions could prove difficult.
Even before filing his suit, Mr. McCall said he believes the state budget is precariously balanced and could unravel later this year, requiring new cuts.
Mr. Bellafiore countered that Mr. McCall was "trying to have it both ways here." The Governor's press secretary added: "He says he is supporting supplementing pensions, but he won't and can't tell you how he will finance it."
The budget also includes the caveat that if the pension plan is challenged in court, the pension increase will be postponed until the suit is resolved. Under the plan, if the state loses the suit, the pension increase will be delayed one year until Sept. 1, 1997.
Saying that the Legislature included that delay mechanism purely to discourage him from filing suit, Mr. McCall said his suit also asks the Supreme Court to prevent any delays in the scheduled pension increase.
It is not clear why the special pension fund was left untouched during its first 24 years of existence. Mr. McCall said the Legislature allocated $70 million to the fund in the early 1970's, then left it alone. Interest payments over the past two decades allowed the fund to grow to $360 million, and Mr. McCall said he thought it was possible that the lawmakers simply forgot that the fund was there -- until this year.
The Comptroller also said he met last week with Gerald Levin, the president of Time Warner Inc., to express his concerns about the company's role in producing rock and rap music with violent lyrics. The state pension system owns 2.6 million shares in Time Warner worth about $106 million.
Mr. McCall said he made no specific demands on Mr. Levin. But he declined to rule out the possibility of selling the state's holdings in Time Warner if the company did not take measures to deal with the concerns about lyrics.

HEADLINE: Iraq Admits It Produced Germ Arsenal

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 5

 BODY:
Iraq has admitted for the first time that it produced offensive biological weapons in 1989-90, on the eve of the war in the Persian Gulf, the chairman of a United Nations inspection commission told the Security Council in a letter today.
The chairman, Rolf Ekeus, told the Council that the Iraqis admitted in a meeting Saturday in Baghdad that they had produced "large quantities" of two deadly biological agents, the bacteria that cause botulism and anthrax. Iraqis maintain that the toxic agents were later destroyed. 
 The admission, which followed four years of denials that Iraq had a secret biological weapons program, will set back by a significant amount of time any hope Iraq may have of an early lifting of sanctions prohibiting the sale of oil.
The sanctions, which first went into effect after the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, were scheduled for a periodic review on July 11. As part of a cease-fire agreement in April 1991, after the war, Iraq agreed to destroy or account for all its weapons of mass destruction in return for a lifting of the oil embargo.
"It is important that Iraq has finally admitted what it was denying only a week ago: that it had an offensive biological weapons program," Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative said after the letter was circulated in the Security Council today. "This admission demonstrates again that the Council can get results when it is firm and consistent in demanding Iraqi compliance."
The Iraqis, who claimed to have destroyed the biological weapons they produced by October 1990, as the gulf war approached, will have a month to give the United Nations Special Commission, headed by Mr. Ekeus, a Swedish diplomat, full details of the program from start to finish. Diplomats and officials remain skeptical of assertions that all the toxic agents were destroyed.
When the Iraqi report is received, a process of verification will begin. United Nations officials could not guess today how long that might take.
For several years, the inspection commission has played a cat-and-mouse-game with Iraq, forcing admissions on nuclear, missile, chemical and now biological weapons by amassing evidence independently and confronting the Iraqis with it. In April, the commission announced that 17 tons of an imported growth medium that could be used to produce biological agents were unaccounted for, and that the quantities imported were far too large for medicinal or pharmaceutical use.
Mr. Ekeus told the Council that Iraqi officials told him on Saturday in an oral briefing that research on germ warfare began in 1985 at Muthanna, where Iraq also produced chemical weapons.
Research was moved to Salman Pak in 1986 and, in mid-1988, it was decided to begin production of the two agents -- Clostridium botulinum and Bacillus anthracis -- at Al Hakam. United Nations officials say that Iraq rigorously rejected suspicions that biological weapons were being produced, and even took reporters to Al Hakam to demonstrate their innocence.
"This is an important step the Government of Iraq has taken," Charles Duelfler, deputy chairman of the commission, said today.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Out of South Africa, Progress

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 1

 BODY:
At the turn of the century, Cecil Rhodes, one of this country's early statesmen-tycoons, dreamed of building a railroad from Cape Town to Cairo. He never realized his vision.
Succeeding where Rhodes fell short, a South African entrepreneur, Hans Harwinkels, is linking the far corners of the continent with microwave signals instead of steel. In little more than two years, he has built a pay-for-view satellite-television empire whose programming is beamed from South Africa to Egypt and 40 countries in between. 
 "African countries have been liberalizing their markets, and this has allowed us to push north, east and west with pretty good speed," said Mr. Harwinkels, chief executive officer of the entertainment broadcaster Multichoice.
Multichoice has a lot of company. With apartheid dead, South Africa's pent-up entrepreneurial energy is exploding all over Africa. South African industry is rushing in to build railroads in Zaire, sink mines in Ghana, put up hotels in Kenya and provide the entire continent with enough jets and telephone lines to help revitalize its sagging economy. South African trade with the rest of Africa is booming, with exports up 50 percent in two years to nearly $2.5 billion in 1994 and imports tripling to $664 million from $220 million. South Africa's expanding presence is displacing much of the economic and cultural influence long wielded by France and the United States.
Economists say the trend is accelerating, with important implications for the future of a continent that many in the West have written off as hopelessly poor and corrupt.
"Our politicians may not have fully grasped this, but for our business people it is fully realized that the rest of Africa is our hinterland," said Erich Leistner, an economist at the Africa Institute in Pretoria, a private research group. "Already, 25 percent of our manufactured goods go to our neighbors. We are going to become more and more involved, from railways to airlines, from mining and water supply to power, and the politics will just have to follow."
To some, it is ironic that post-apartheid South Africa's impact on the rest of the continent is more economic than political. When President Nelson Mandela took power last year, some supporters abroad expected him to become a bold force for political change, denouncing human-rights abuses and promoting democratic movements elsewhere in Africa. Instead, he has kept a low profile, making it clear South Africa does not want to play big brother to its neighbors.
The emissaries of South African capitalism, by contrast, seem to be everywhere. Representatives of South Africa's huge mining industry are crowding the hotels of West African capitals in a race to tap rich new mineral markets.
The mining companies are prospecting for deposits and contracts in Zaire, Burkina Faso, Guinea, Mali and several other countries in West Africa. Just last month, for example, the Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Company announced it was teaming up with a Ghanaian mining company to take over a formerly Soviet-run gold, silver and platinum mine at Kalana, in southern Mali. Companies in other industries are also extending their reach:
*South African hotel companies are investing in tourism ventures in Kenya, Tanzania and other East African countries. Protea Hotels has taken over ownership or management of 82 hotels in 11 countries as far afield as Tanzania and Egypt. "We began discussions in some of these countries as long as six years ago, when there was still a lot of distrust of us," said Otto Stehlik, executive chairman of the company. "Now we have a good laugh about the way we talked to each other."
*South African Airways has begun hiring out management, maintenance and supply services to airlines in Tanzania and Uganda and has opened discussions with others in Malawi, Namibia and Zambia. And South African airplane brokers are selling used aircraft all over the continent to African carriers too poor to buy new jets.
*South African telephone companies are bidding to overhaul national networks with new fiber optic lines or cellular systems. NZ Telecoms Ltd. has been modernizing phone services in Botswana, for example, and Telkom is prospecting for contracts in several countries.
*The electricity company Eskom is rehabilitating the power grids of Mozambique, Angola and Lesotho, and has plans to integrate them with South Africa's electrical network.
*South Africa Railways is working to upgrade the ports of Beira and Maputo in Mozambique to relieve congestion in South Africa's major seaport at Durban.
*South African Breweries last year bought half of Tanzania's formerly state-owned breweries and is building a bottling plant in that country.
One measure of all the commercial activity is the runaway success of Air Afrique's new route linking Johannesburg and Abidjan, capital of the West African nation of the Ivory Coast. After less than a year in service, the flights have higher occupancy rates than the Abidjan-Paris or Abidjan-New York connections.
Most African countries seem to be heartily welcoming South Africa's commercial invasion, coming as it does in the face of flagging interest in the West. Several governments have even begun to advertise their World Bank-mandated privatizations of state companies in South African newspapers, hoping to find bidders in the continent's most powerful economy.
South African businesses take a homey approach in negotiating with African governments: though large by African standards, they argue, they are less threatening than the American and European multinationals. And their headquarters are nearby in case of trouble.
"We want local partners and build joint ventures, and the word has been spreading in Africa that we are good people to do business with," said Mr. Harwinkels of Multichoice. For France, the former colonial power that has maintained the strongest ties to the continent, all this reeks of a plot by the English-speaking business world to supplant it in Africa. The French newsletter Lettre d'Afrique recently warned of "increasingly aggressive financial, industrial and commercial competition, in particular by Anglo-Saxons and Japanese, in league with South African firms."
Indeed, nowhere has South Africa's penetration of new markets in Africa been as spectacular as in French-speaking Zaire, formerly ruled by Belgium. As Western companies have withdrawn from Zaire in exasperation over its corruption and chaos, South African concerns have moved in, seeing its mineral wealth and huge needs for new roads and railways as economic stepping stones to the rest of the continent.
Pointing to a map of central Africa in his office, the eyes of Jan van Deventer, South Africa's Ambassador to Zaire, light up as he speaks, Rhodes-like, of South African companies restoring the Lubumbashi-to-Kananga line in Zaire, a project under way, and of building lines linking that line with the towns of Kalemie and Kindu, a project under consideration.
Taken together, these undertakings would link South Africa by modern rail with every country of the continent as far north as Tanzania, replacing costly truck routes and slow-moving lake barges.
Big South African mining companies are also moving into Zaire. Since De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. got involved in a diamond-mining project known as Birim River in Ghana 14 months ago, production has soared 55 percent. Other mining companies are hoping to resuscitate Zaire's dying copper industry, once the world's largest. The Anglo American Corporation of South Africa said it was considering taking a major stake in the Tinke Fugurume copper mine in southern Zaire. And an international consortium that includes Anglo American, the Engelhard Corporation of the United States, Fimalac of France and Swipco of Switzerland is reportedly negotiating to take control of Zaire's state-owned Gecamines, once the world's largest copper and cobalt mine.
South African companies are also eyeing Zaire's huge hydroelectric potential.
Mr. van Deventer, the South African Ambassador, sees almost limitless opportunity in Zaire and the rest of sub-Sahara Africa. "You are talking about being able to get South African consumer goods to African markets, where there is a strong demand for them, and evacuating African minerals to South African markets, where we have considerable expertise," he said.
"If you've been to Kasai you could cry to see that they don't grow much of anything in some of the best farmlands in the continent," he said. "If Zaire could get its logging industry going, we could take quite a bit of that production. But first you have to be able to get there."
But for South Africa to take full advantage of opportunities like these, experts in regional affairs say, it will have to begin engaging the rest of Africa politically far more than it has done so far.
Under Mr. Mandela, South Africa has shied away from peace-keeping tasks in places like Angola and Rwanda, hoping to avoid being cast in the role of savior. Critics of this approach say that as much as they can understand a desire to avoid becoming the bearer of all of Africa's burdens, Mr. Mandela should use his immense prestige to foster stability and democratic change in Africa.
Of Africa's leaders, only Zimbabwe's President, Robert Mugabe, has been received here on a state visit. And earlier this year, officials in many African countries were surprised when South Africa declined to join the African Development Bank, a regional lending institution.
Although President Mandela made a brief stopover in Nigeria last year to plea for the release of the jailed winner of elections there, Moshood K. Abiola, his Government has been mostly quiet about the political crisis there and in Zaire.
"High-profile people like Mandela should be spending as much time in African capitals as in Europe and America," said Tom Lodge, a political scientist at the University of Witswatersrand. "At the end of the day, we are not going to get much from Washington, or Paris or London. This is where the future lies."
