HEADLINE: Budget Battles Undercut U.S. Information Effort

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
When President Eisenhower created the United States Information Agency in 1953, it was the darling of conservatives, a powerful megaphone to undermine Communism around the world.
But with Communism on the run and the cold war over, conservative Republicans are now fighting a different war: the budget war, and the information agency could become one of its victims. 
 The House voted last month to eliminate the 9,000-employee agency and have the State Department absorb its operations. The Senate is expected to do the same next week.
"The agency was founded to counter the most pervasive propaganda organization the world has ever known -- the Communists," said Brent Scowcroft, who was President Bush's national security adviser. "But we no longer have that problem, so things like the Voice of America are no longer necessary. There are higher priorities for spending our money." The U.S.I.A. oversees the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe.
Seeing the U.S.I.A.'s $1.3-billion budget as a fat target, several Congressional subcommittees are also seeking to cut off financing of its main activities: broadcasting and educational exchanges. The agency sponsors the Fulbright scholarship program and oversees foreign exchanges of thousands of other students and academics.
The agency runs libraries in 130 countries, provides information to foreign journalists and sends 1,000 experts overseas each year on cultural missions. In recent months, the agency sent Betty Friedan to China to discuss feminism and the poet Philip Levine to Spain to give readings and lectures.
While many conservatives have kind words for agency activities, they nonetheless see them as luxuries today. They point to activities like a conference on "civic education" that brought together 400 Eastern European officials and intellectuals in Prague to discuss how to consolidate democracy. The agency is also sponsoring a $129,000 program in which a dozen Palestinians and Israelis will meet at an Ohio college for six weeks to study how to teach English and how to get along with each other.
"A lot of these are very good programs, but we're $5 trillion in the hole, so we have to start doing things in a different way," said Representative Sam Brownback, the Kansas Republican who is a prime sponsor of the Congressional effort to abolish the agency.
Mr. Brownback insists that the private sector should take over the educational exchanges, Radio Free Europe and the Voice of America. But he is so eager to undermine Communism in Cuba and China that he says Washington should continue broadcasting to those countries.
Joseph Duffey, director of the United States Information Agency, asserts that conservatives are taking a myopic view of the role the agency can now play. Its broadcasts may no longer be needed to spread democratic ideas to the former Soviet Union, he says, but they are still vital for such countries as Iran, Iraq, Cuba, China and the former Yugoslavia.
In Mr. Duffey's view, the agency has another role: to show foreigners this country beyond "Pulp Fiction," gangsta rap music, the O. J. Simpson trial and news clips of European tourists murdered in Miami.
"Every advanced democracy in the world has an institution that seeks to convey information about its policies, its values and its national life," Mr. Duffey said.
"I think we are very poorly served by the international mass media when it comes to explaining our national way of life," he said. "And commercial films don't convey much of what I want the world to understand about America."
Opponents suggest that the U.S.I.A. broadcasts are superfluous when CNN is being beamed around the world, and the Internet is reaching into the former Soviet bloc and the Arab world.
But agency officials vehemently disagree. "For people who live in hotels around the world and speak English, CNN is great," said Geoffrey Cowan, director of Voice of America. "But most people don't live in hotels and don't speak English. That's where we come in. We broadcast in 47 languages."
U.S.I.A. officials contend that it will be a disaster if the State Department absorbs their responsibilities because its behind-the-scenes style will clash with and ultimately cripple the agency's role of having Americans communicate in a public, uninhibited way with foreigners to explain what is happening in America.
Mr. Duffey's hope is that his agency will be rescued by a Presidential veto and subsequent negotiations between the White House and Congress. His aides predict that Congressional opposition might be weakened by some conservative Republicans who are having second thoughts.
Indeed, the agency recently received much-needed support from Jack Kemp, the former Housing Secretary, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former delegate to the United Nations. They sent a letter to Republican leaders saying it was "disheartening and astonishing" that many lawmakers were seeking to abolish the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe.
"This stream of information and analysis is crucial to listeners seeking to build democratic societies and free market economies on their own," they wrote.

HEADLINE: Delay in Assistance to Mexico Is Sought by Dole and D'Amato

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
Two Republican senators called on Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin today to delay further financial assistance to Mexico.
"We are not aware of any emergencies or contingencies that would justify the release of additional U.S. funds," said a letter from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. "The Administration should articulate a clear and compelling justification." 
 The letter was released after markets in Mexico had closed. Earlier, the leading Mexican stock index surged 121.84 points, or 5.58 percent, to 2,306.30, its highest level since reaching 2,354.24 on Jan. 2.
Analysts in Mexico City said investors were heartened by lower interest rates and by President Ernesto Zedillo's remarks that the economy was beginning to recover from the shock it suffered after the peso was devalued on Dec. 20.
Since the financial crisis began, the United States and others have agreed to provide Mexico with loans and guarantees totaling $52.8 billion.
The United States has already contributed the first half of its $20 billion loan and loan guarantee commitment. Last week, Mr. Rubin said the United States would release another $2.5 billion this week.
Mr. Rubin also said the International Monetary Fund will provide an additional $2 billion to Mexico as part of a standby credit agreement.
In their letter, the senators said, "Before the Administration contemplates the release of any additional U.S. funds, we urge you to exhaust other available sources," like the I.M.F.
In exchange for the international assistance, Mexico has agreed to allow the United States a measure of control over the nation's estimated $7 billion in annual income from oil exports, and has embarked on a plan to sell state-owned industries.

HEADLINE: Packard Bell Selling NEC A Big Stake

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 5

 BODY:
Linking the leading personal computer vendors in the United States and Japan, the NEC Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy nearly 20 percent of Packard Bell Electronics Inc. for $170 million.
The relationship gives a crucial financial infusion to Packard Bell, which is privately held. The Sacramento, Calif., company has surged to the lead of the American personal computer market largely by selling machines through mass merchants like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Sears, Roebuck & Company, but has grown at a pace that would be hard to sustain without outside investors. 
 NEC, meanwhile, is seeking to fortify its position in the Japanese market, where its dominance has been threatened recently by I.B.M. and the Compaq Computer Corporation. It also intends to expand its presence in non-Japanese markets, where its performance in personal computers has not been very strong.
NEC and Packard Bell said they would form a wide-ranging alliance that would include supplying components to each other, as well as joint purchases of computerparts, joint product development and manufacturing and the use of each other's marketing channels.
The agreement, to be completed by the end of August, is one of the first major Japanese investments in an American high-technology company since the Japanese economy soured three years ago. Many Japanese companies got burned in the 1980's by expensive investments in American technology companies that failed to live up to expectations.
The purchase will provide needed cash for Packard Bell, which surpassed the three longstanding leaders of the American computer market -- Compaq, Apple Computer Inc. and I.B.M. -- by selling the most personal computers in the United States since the last quarter of 1994, according to the International Data Corporation, a market research firm.
The company, which specializes in selling to consumers rather than corporations, will also be able to more readily obtain NEC components like memory chips, CD-ROM drives, liquid-crystal display screens and circuits for displaying three-dimensional images on the screen. Some of these components, particularly memory chips, are now in short supply because of strong growth of PC sales throughout the industry.
"Packard Bell wants to ally ourselves with a strong corporate partner with complementary strengths that will help us bring a new level of technology to the market, allow Packard Bell to maintain its leadership position and help Packard Bell expand into other markets," Brent Cohen, the company's chief operating officer, said at a news conference here.
For Packard Bell, the alliance promises some of the same benefits that a smaller rival, AST Research Inc., hoped to receive by selling a stake in itself to Samsung, the huge Korean manufacturer.
In 1994, Packard Bell and NEC were, respectively, the fourth- and fifth-largest suppliers of personal computers in the world. The two companies will pool their purchasing of some components, forming a huge buying group with estimated combined shipments of 7.3 million PC's this year. Microprocessors, like those made by the Intel Corporation or Intel clone makers, are among the prime components that Packard Bell and NEC cannot supply themselves.
Joint purchases with Packard Bell would help NEC, which has seen its competitiveness hurt by the strong yen, to cut its costs and better compete with the American companies that have invaded the Japanese PC market.
Steven Myers, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities in Tokyo, said that if NEC could save $50 a computer through the joint parts procurement, it would save $165 million on this year's estimated shipments of 3.3 million machines. That alone would recoup NEC's investment in Packard Bell.
Many aspects about exactly how the companies will cooperate have not been decided or were not disclosed. Moreover, NEC will not be able to realize the full benefit of joint procurement with Packard Bell because the computers NEC sells in Japan use proprietary technology that does not conform to the world personal-computer standard.
Packard Bell was founded in 1986 by three entrepreneurs from Israel who acquired the rights to the name of a defunct American consumer electronics company from Teledyne Inc. The company said that its revenue in the 1994 fiscal year was $2.8 billion and that it was profitable. As a private company, Packard Bell does not disclose specific figures for its profit or losses.
"The implication of this is that Packard Bell is not making money hand over fist," Mr. Myers, the analyst, said.
NEC said it would buy newly issued shares of Packard Bell amounting to a 19.99 percent stake, just below the 20 percent threshold at which it would have to consider the American company a subsidiary. While NEC said this was done to preserve Packard Bell's independence, it could also mean that NEC does not want to have to incorporate Packard Bell's financial results in its consolidated financial reports.
Groupe Bull, the French computer company, acquired 19.9 percent of Packard Bell in 1993, reportedly for about $75 million. NEC owns a 17 percent stake in Groupe Bull. Bull, which owns Zenith Data Systems in the United States, said today that it would invest $30 million more in Packard Bell to keep its stake at 19.9 percent.
NEC has long controlled more than half of Japan's personal computer market with its 9800 series of machines, which does not conform to the I.B.M.-compatible standard prevalent in the rest of the world.
But now, all other Japanese companies that once had their own unique designs have come to support the I.B.M. standard, forming a united front that is winning customers from NEC. Moreover, American companies such as Apple, I.B.M., Compaq and the Dell Computer Corporation, helped by the weakness of the dollar against the yen, have made strong gains. Last year, the American companies controlled about one-third of the Japanese market, according to International Data.
The result is that the NEC's share of the market in its home country dropped to 43.2 percent, the research firm said. But the overall Japanese market is growing rapidly -- it is expected to reach 5 million units this year, up from 3.4 million in 1994 -- so NEC's sales continue to grow.
The alliance with Packard Bell heightened speculation that NEC might plan to abandon its unique system and move to I.B.M. compatibility. Were NEC to do that, it would be able to import low-cost machines from Packard Bell to sell in Japan. But NEC officials denied that.
Packard Bell, which has concentrated mainly on the American market, also sells computers in Latin America and Europe. It has had only a limited presence in Japan but had been planning to expand here.
But Mr. Cohen, the chief operating officer, said Packard Bell would "honor and respect NEC's business activities in Japan." This and other comments seemed to suggest that in return for the cash infusion Packard Bell would forgo trying to become another low-priced American competitor to NEC in Japan.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Value Is Little Changed In Advance of Fed Rate Decision

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed yesterday in cautious trading as Federal Reserve policy makers met to consider interest-rate changes.
"It's steady because people are mixed in their views about what the Fed will do," said Charles Spence, director of currency sales at Standard Chartered Bank in New York. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 1.3794 German marks yesterday from 1.3799 marks on Monday. It edged up to 84.85 Japanese yen from 84.74 yen. Financial markets in the United States were closed on Tuesday because of the Fourth of July holiday.
A number of economists expect the Fed to lower short-term interest rates after the meeting of its rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee ends today. Lower interest rates typically hurt the dollar by making dollar-denominated investments less attractive.
But other analysts say that recent economic reports have shown enough strength to keep the Federal Reserve from lowering rates now.
"Views about the Fed are mixed all the way across the board," said Graham Broyd, currency-sales manager at National Westminster Bank in New York. "I think the most likely scenario is that the Fed won't cut rates at the meeting, but will give Greenspan authority to cut rates" before the next rate-setting meeting on Aug. 22, he said, referring to Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman.
While Mr. Broyd said a rate cut would hurt the dollar, Mr. Spence of Standard Chartered disagreed. Seven interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve in the 12 months ending in February did little to bolster the dollar, Mr. Spence noted. He said there was no reason why a rate cut should now depress the dollar.
In other currency trading yesterday, the British pound stumbled after Prime Minister John Major's redesignation on Tuesday as leader of the Conservative Party failed to quell concern about intraparty turmoil. Political instability often depresses a nation's currency.
Although he beat back a challenge from the right wing of his party, Mr. Major still faces problems, analysts said. "It is clear there is a divisive split within the party over policy," Mr. Broyd of NatWest said.
The pound, which rose sharply on Tuesday in European trading in anticipation of the Tory Party vote, declined yesterday against the mark and the dollar. It fell to 2.2025 marks, from 2.2105 marks in London on Tuesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.5960, down from $1.5980 on Monday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Dollar General has been giving investors a bang for their buck.

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane 

 BODY:
IF it ain't broke, don't fix it is just how the management of the Dollar General Corporation is proceeding as it continues to open more small, low-price stores, focusing on small-town America.
Wall Street apparently likes what it sees, with many security analysts rating the company, which transferred to the New York Stock Exchange in February, as a buy. The stock has been moving upward recently, notching a number of new highs. 
 "The format is simple and consistent," said Steven J. Schuster, an analyst for the First Manhattan Company. "The stores are only about 6,000 square feet, they carry only about 2,500 items and about half of them cost a buck."
Otto F. Grote, an analyst for Derby Securities, added: "Dollar General has come to understand better than any other retailer how to sell to customers who are really strapped for cash. Not only do they know how to price their product, but they also know how to cost it out."
Dollar General, based in Nashville, had sales last year of nearly $1.5 billion and operates a chain of almost 2,200 neighborhood stores in 24 states, with most of them in strip shopping centers in the Southeast and Midwest. Its merchandise is generally sold at discounted prices to what Tom Tashjian, an analyst for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, characterized as largely minimum-wage laborers, the elderly and people receiving some sort of government-sponsored income subsidy.
"Their target market is being ignored by most other retailers," he said. "They are very focused on a finite number of consumers they want to serve."
The company announced record profits of $1.07 a share in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, a 49 percent increase from the previous 12 months. Earnings also ran at a fast pace in the first quarter of the current fiscal year -- historically the least profitable after the strong Christmas sales period -- by rising 22 percent, to 17 cents a share.
Analysts are forecasting double-digit same-store gains for the next two to three years. As a result, their average earnings estimate is $1.32 a share in the year ending Jan. 31, 1996, and $1.66 a share in the year ending Jan. 31, 1997, according to the First Call Corporation, which tabulates this information. "They've had impressive numbers, particularly in light of what is going on in the economy," Mr. Tashjian said. "The founding family still manages this company and is focused upon well-prepared growth."
Dollar General intends to open about 300 new stores in the 1996 fiscal year. Most of the products in its stores sell for $10 or less, with even-dollar pricing the norm.
"The company has a very strong connection with its customers, who don't have a lot of shopping alternatives," Mr. Schuster said. "The average Dollar General customer tends to have less disposable income than the average Wal-Mart or Kmart customer. So they sell a lot of basic commodity consumables like soap and shampoo."
At yesterday's closing price of $30.75, near its high of $33, Dollar General is selling at a price-earnings ratio of 23.3, based on estimated earnings in this fiscal year. That multiple is at a 38 percent premium to the 16.9 current price-earnings ratio of the general market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's average of 500 stocks.
"My target price is 50 to 60," Mr. Grote said. "I think they will continue to do well in this environment."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Real College Champions

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
IF graduating is the premise justifying so-called student-athletes at America's colleges, too many athletes are not students at our institutions of what is apparently higher perspiration, not higher learning.
By itself, that is hardly news. Virtually a century ago educators discovered that, no matter how unstudious the student, a tradition of winning teams in leather helmets translated to a tradition of ticket-buyers and alumni contributions. 
 Winning teams in sneakers created a similar devotion of dollars. Television fees would further rationalize the thirst for triumph that often quenched the thirst for learning.
For all the scandals in college sports, information on individual students is considered too up close and personal to be tracked.
But the colleges can't hide now that the National Collegiate Athletic Association has issued graduation rates at its 302 Division I schools for all the freshman students and student-athletes (men and women) who entered college in the 1988-89 school year.
Some colleges' rates are distinguished. Some are disgraceful. Most are disheartening.
Extenuating factors were ignored in the survey. No breakdown of courses was presented, either pre-med or pre-unemployed. No breakdown of sports was documented, either football or field hockey.
No asterisk is allowed for transfer students with good grades. It's strictly how many entered college for the 1988-89 school year and how many graduated.
But the numbers indicate which colleges are participating in true college sports and which are operating campus pro sports; the numbers reflect which schools are winning with students who graduate.
Based on its graduation numbers, Penn State (77 percent student-athletes, 79 percent all students) deserved to be the top-ranked football team last season, not Nebraska (59 percent student-athletes, 48 percent all students).
Of basketball's Final Four teams, North Carolina had the best rates (76 percent student-athletes, 85 percent all students).
The champion, U.C.L.A., had 56 and 77, Arkansas had 39 and 41; Oklahoma State 38 and 40.
Three colleges graduated 100 percent of their student-athletes in that freshman class: Fairfield, Siena and Oral Roberts. But each had a small number of student-athletes. Of the larger schools, Providence's 98 percent graduation rate of student-athletes was first, followed by Colgate 93, Bucknell 92, Lehigh 91, Duke 90 and Holy Cross 90.
At the bottom of the student-athlete rates were Chicago State and Prairie View, each with a dismal 18 percent, followed by Texas Pan-American at 22, University of Nevada-Las Vegas 23, Texas Southern 23 and Tennessee State 23.
Ivy League schools drew a 0 in the student-athlete graduation rates because they don't grant athletic scholarships per se. But five Ivy League schools dominated the graduation rates among all students.
Harvard was first with 97 percent, followed by Yale with 96, Princeton 95, Bucknell 95, Virginia 94, Duke 94, Brown 94, Dartmouth 94, Fairfield 94, Stanford 93, Notre Dame 93, Holy Cross 93, Cornell 92, Providence 92, Georgetown 92, Boston College 91 and William & Mary 90.
Some schools' rates favored student-athletes rather than all students.
Oral Roberts had only 48 percent of all its students graduated, but 100 percent of its nine student-athletes did; Long Island University's rates were only 24 for all students but 70 for student-athletes.
Other schools had much higher rates for all students. Davidson had an 88 percent rate for all students, only 50 for its student-athletes. Jacksonville had 52 for all students, 25 for student-athletes; U.C.L.A. had 77 for all its students, only 51 for its student-athletes.
Adding the two percentages, the best colleges were Fairfield 194, Providence 190, Bucknell 187, Duke 184, Holy Cross 183, Stanford 182, Colgate 182, Georgetown 181, Siena 179 and Boston College 178. The worst were Texas Southern 34, Texas Pan-American 39, Chicago State 40, Prairie View 47 and Delaware State 48.
More than any game scores, these graduation numbers tell much of the story of college sports in America now. For better or for worse, for richer or for poorer, in classroom or in stadium.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
. . . As We Know It

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Begin by recognizing that welfare is a federally sponsored euphemism; when we talk about helping the helpless, we're talking about charity.
Charity is not a dirty word, though it is treated as such by many of those on the receiving end; they prefer "welfare," because it implies an entitlement with no need for gratitude. On the contrary, the word "charity" -- the tangible expression of generosity toward our fellow humans -- rates right up there with love and kindness. 
 How do we maintain or increase the amount of charity given to the helpless while cutting out the charity that undermines the self-reliance of the able-bodied? Everyone agrees that the dependent are entitled to support, just as the lazy are not; the winnowing of the deserving poor from the undeserving underclass is called "welfare reform."
The Original Clinton came to town talking about ending "welfare as we know it," which appealed to conservatives; the New Clinton, a liberal aberration who lasted 24 months, never got around to it; but the New New Clinton (a keelhauled version of the Original Clinton) now addresses the issue with verve and discipline.
In contrast, Republicans are approaching the ending of W.A.W.K.I. in disarray. Not about freezing the level of Federal funding and delegating its administration to the states, ending the era of ever-rising costs and individual entitlement; that bridge has been crossed.
The scrap within the Republican Party is about how the total is to be split among the states. In the G.O.P. Senate bill, each state would get as much as it previously received from Washington. But that would reward New York and California and others historically openhanded; Southern and Western senators insist the distribution be based on local need, and argue that states are no longer required to spend their own funds to get Federal charity dollars.
"If we get into a big formula fight," says Dole on doles, "it's going to be very difficult to pass any welfare bill." Assuming regional compromise (setting the pattern for larger Medicaid block grants), Republican leaders will then have to roll over right-wingers who want to add conservative mandates -- like denying additional payments to unwed teen-agers accused of breeding for profit. That emotional grabber is undercut by Catholic bishops who fear the Draconian lesson would lead not to abstinence or marriage but to more abortions.
Republican wrangling gave the Great Facilitator his opening. As forecast in this space with inexplicable prescience, Clinton has come out for state experiments leading to the privatization of welfare distribution.
For decades, the idea has been to get able-bodied welfare recipients into jobs; as Nixon put it, "off welfare into workfare." (I thought I coined workfare in 1969, but the civil rights leader Charles Evers had beaten us to it.) Job training programs haven't produced. The much-touted cutoff of benefits after two or five years may provide a needed incentive, but the wailing when it happens will be horrific.
Aptly choosing Independence Day for a speech about unwanted dependency, the President gave a waiver to Virginia to try its own workfare plan: "Like the states of Oregon, Missouri and a few others, it also allows money now spent on welfare and food stamps to go to employers to supplement wages to help create jobs in the private sector."
In this way, states use Federal welfare grants to make it profitable for private businesses to employ welfare recipients. No make-work; the temporary subsidy pushes the employer to hire and pulls the welfaree into an entry-level job.
But we can't expect a mother to report to work with a kid on each hip; "it is pure fantasy," Clinton says, "to believe we can put a welfare mother to work unless we provide child care."
Such job-tied baby sitting makes economic sense to conservatives, drips with compassion to liberals and is nicely laced with local initiative and state control to federalists.
Perhaps it's too soon to put faith in the man from Hope's latest approach to charity. Federal domination by waiver is troubling. But if America's natural generosity must now be accompanied by a satisfying snarl, the tough-minded tender-heartedness of the privatization of welfare is worth a close look.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Climb As Traders Await Fed's Rate Decision

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With trading subdued as investors and dealers awaited the outcome of the two-day Federal Open Market Committee meeting, Treasury securities moved higher yesterday.
Plenty of market analysts do not expect the committee, the Fed's policy-making arm, to cut short-term interest rates during the meeting, which began yesterday. But if the committee acts, it is likely to do so today. 
 The 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32, to a price of 113 10/32 , for a yield of 6.60 percent, down from 6.63 percent at the close of an abbreviated pre-holiday session on Monday.
Among the economic reports yesterday, the Mitsubishi/Wertheim Schroder weekly chain-store sales index was unchanged from last week, and the Johnson Redbook survey of large retailers was up 1.4 percent last month from May, continuing the recent saw-toothed pattern in retail activity measures.
"The Mitsubishi report projects June chain store sales will be up around 3 percent to 3.50 percent year-over-year," said James Hale, fixed-income analyst for MMS International in San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm. "This is yet another piece of data that fails to clear up the Fed policy debate among market participants. The Johnson Redbook, like the Mitsubishi report, lacks decisive influence on the policy debate."
The uncertainty over the F.O.M.C. stance was enough to keep trading nearly paralyzed. "There is definitely not much on the buy side of the market, as fund managers hold back," Mr. Hale said. "Some traders are looking to play the yield curve in the wake of any policy decision, especially selling anything with a maturity of under five years versus bonds if the Fed does not ease."
But he said there was "some merit to buying the long maturity" once that initial selloff and the employment report due on Friday were past "because loud cries about recession are bound to resurface."
Hamilton Davis, a vice president of government trading at Kemper Securities in Chicago, described the market mood as one of breathless anticipation. "Everyone is waiting for the Fed, but I don't think the waiting period will be over until after the employment report," he said. "We think the Fed is best served by waiting for the data."
Mr. Davis said reason was against easing and running the risk that the employment numbers would show surprising strength. As a result, he said, the committee may wait for the numbers and take its cue from them, he said. Any number less than 100,000 in the growth of nonfarm payrolls would put the Fed in an easing mode, he said.
"Right now dealers are taking neutral positions," he said.
Elsewhere, municipal bond prices were higher as some investors found yields more attractive than those of other fixed-income investments like Treasury securities. General obligation bonds due to mature in 20 years, and rated double-A, are yielding about 5.87 percent, or 91.5 percent of comparable Treasury securities. Analysts note that investors usually consider the tax-exempt bonds inexpensive when their yield is more than 85 percent of those of government securities.
In the corporate debt market, many companies are delaying bond sales until after the F.O.M.C. meeting. But the Standard & Poor's Rating Group recently reported that corporate bond sales increased 61 percent in the second quarter, as a steep drop in interest rates cheapened the cost of borrowing. It said companies issued $68.9 billion in bonds in the quarter, up from $42.8 billion in the first quarter.
Many corporations have used the proceeds of these debt offerings to refinance short-term debt at cheaper rates.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 7, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the credit markets misstated the average yields this week for participation certificates of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, or Freddie Mac. The yield for the 15-year certificate was 7 percent, not 7.03 percent; the yield for the 30-year certificate was 7.39 percent, not 7.53 percent. A corrected chart appears today on page D15.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks and Bonds Surge on Fed Rate Cut
The Federal Reserve's quarter-point cut in the Federal funds rate lifted the stock and bond markets, as traders became more optimistic about the economy and predicted that the Fed would now cut rates yet again. Treasury prices surged, pushing the yield on the 30-year bond down to 6.49 percent, from 6.60 percent. The Dow industrials rose to another record, climbing 48.77 points, to 4,664.00, and the S.&.P 500 index added 6.73 points, to a record 553.99. [Page D6.]
 
The rate cut did little to the dollar. In late New York trading, it edged up to 84.96 yen and was little changed at 1.3787 marks. [D5.]
 
Japan, Canada and France also moved to lower interest rates. In Tokyo, after the Bank of Japan announced that it would allow an interest rate to fall below the discount rate of 1 percent, stocks surged. [D4.]
 
A Look at TV Violence
Federal regulators and some members of Congress say they hope to clamp down on broadcast violence and require more programming for children. [A1.]
 
Retail Sales Sluggish in June
Spending at retail chain stores was relatively sluggish in June, rising 3.4 percent. Big department stores and discount chains had the biggest sales gains, as consumers continued to be cautious spenders. [D3.]
 
Mesa Adopts Poison Pill
Two big shareholders of Mesa Inc. said they would try to replace the board after it adopted a poison pill plan, a strategy Mesa's chairman, T. Boone Pickens, once decried. [D3.]
 
Radio Host Indicted Again
Sonny Bloch, the financial radio talk-show host, has been indicted again. Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said he had been charged with eight counts of tax fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice. [D2.]
 
Chemical in Microsoft Deal
Chemical Bank said it would expand its electronic banking services, including a new push into home banking, and would form an alliance with Microsoft to provide money management software linked to Chemical's computer network. [D4.]
 
First Capital Inquiry
Regulators are questioning why First Capital Strategists did not register as a commodities trading adviser until 1987 and with the S.E.C. until 1994. [D3.]
 
Germans Rule Benetton Ads Illegal
A Benetton advertising campaign that depicts an oil- drenched bird, child labor in Latin America and a human body stamped with the words "H.I.V. positive" was ruled illegal by a German appeals court, which said that "anyone who exploits feelings of pity in such an intense way for commercial interests violates competition law." Advertising. [D6.]
 
U.S. Praised on Trade
In a move that trade experts said was an attempt to soothe hard feelings with Washington, the European Commission said that the trade picture between Europe and the United States was brightening. [D2.]
 
Impotence Drug Approved
The F.D.A. gave Upjohn permission to sell alprostadil, the first prescription drug for the treatment of impotence. [A13.]
 
China Maintains Shanghai Zone
Chinahas decided not to revoke the preferential tax status of East Shanghai, one of dits economic-incentive zones. [D2.]

HEADLINE: $15.8 Million Settlement in Fatal '90 Club Fire

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
More than five years after the arson fire at the Happy Land Social Club in the Bronx killed 87 people, lawyers for families of the victims agreed yesterday to a $15.8 million settlement of all claims stemming from one of the deadliest fires in New York City's history.
The agreement ends more than $5 billion in lawsuits by providing an average $163,000 each for the families of the 92 dead or injured victims, before lawyers' fees and other costs are subtracted. 
 Lawyers in the case said that while the settlement seemed small compared with other high-profile wrongful death awards, the Happy Land case was complicated by questions of insurance liability, the bankruptcy of the building's wealthy owner, Alexander DiLorenzo 3d, and by the death of the club's operator in the fire. The jilted lover who set the 1990 fire in the illegal social club in the Bronx is now in prison, penniless and serving a life sentence.
Michael M. Lippman, counsel to the Bronx Public Administrator, which represents 50 families of the victims, many living in Honduras, said the families did not have a strong case for winning money from insurance carriers for the building's owner and makers of building products that gave off noxious fumes while burning. Further, he said the settlement resulted from wariness on the part of plaintiffs' lawyers about ultimately losing the case, and the defendants' eagerness to avoid costs and uncertainty of litigation.
But the victims' families, who under a 1991 court order had no say in approving the settlement, said they were disappointed. "It's not enough money for what I've lost," said Leticia Gamoneda, who lost two sons in the fire.
The pool of money will be divided among the families and surviving victims based on a formula for economic loss. Though lawyers in the case said the amounts have not been determined, families that lost the sole source of income in the fire would receive more than families that lost a child who was not working. Mr. Lippman said that a disk jockey who survived the blaze but suffered severe injuries is likely to receive the largest amount because his pain and suffering is assigned additional value in the formula.
The social club fire on Southern Boulevard in East Tremont cut an ugly gash in the Latin American community in New York and was the largest loss of life in a city fire since 146 people were killed in the Triangle Shirtwaist factory blaze on the same date 79 years earlier.
Julio Gonzalez set the fire in the early morning of March 25, 1990, after arguing with his ex-girlfriend, a club employee, and being thrown out of the establishment. Enraged, he returned with a dollar's worth of gasoline and set a fire on the stairs leading to the club -- the only exit -- trapping the victims. Mr. Gonzalez's ex-girlfriend, Lydia Feliciano, was one of the fire's six survivors.
Mr. Gonzalez is serving a sentence of 25 years to life in prison.
One of those killed in the blaze was Elias Colon, who had remodeled the club and was running it without proper licenses and despite safety violations, including no alarm or sprinkler systems. He rented the space from the building's two leaseholders, Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffe.
Though Mr. DiLorenzo, the building owner, and Mr. Weiss pleaded guilty in November 1990 to charges of failure to install a sprinkler system in the building, neither Mr. DiLorenzo, Mr. Weiss or Mr. Jaffe was found criminally negligent in the fire.
Yesterday's settlement, announced by Judge Burton B. Roberts, the administrator of courts in the Bronx, insures that the three men will avoid any further personal financial liability, but there were some doubts as to how much the plaintiffs could have ultimately got had they pursued the cases further.
In the real-estate boom of the mid-1980's, Mr. DiLorenzo and his two siblings owned a vast portfolio of more than 250 New York properties, valued at about $1.2 billion. He used the property as collateral to speculate on commodities and in one year alone, 1988, he lost $21.5 million, according to court papers in a lawsuit.
Justice Douglas E. McKeon of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, who assisted Judge Roberts in guiding the settlement negotiations, said in an interview that pursuing Mr. DiLorenzo's money as part of the Happy Land case seemed fruitless. "While once he was a very wealthy man, he now is in involuntary bankruptcy," the judge said. "It was apparent that he was insolvent."
Lawyers for the families were also frustrated in their effort to pursue Mr. DiLorenzo's insurance money. Three real estate insurance companies that insured Mr. DiLorenzo's properties contended that the Happy Land building was not on a list of holdings they insured.
When the families' lawyers tried to sue manufacturers of building supplies used in the club that gave off cyanide and other poisons while burning, they realized that they had no records to prove exactly what companies supplied which materials. If those records ever existed, said Leonard Weinstock, the lead plaintiff's lawyer, they were lost when Mr. Colon died in the fire.
As part of the settlement, Mr. DiLorenzo's 3 insurance companies and 11 producers or distributors of building materials agreed to pay $7.17 million. The insurance broker for Mr. DiLorenzo, Alexander & Alexander, paid $200,000. And the City of New York, which faced possible liability for allowing the club to operate despite violations, paid $250,000 and agreed to waive about $300,000 in fees on settlement disbursements.
The largest single payment was $6.8 million from the Scottsdale Insurance Company, which covered properties for Mr. Weiss and Mr. Jaffe. After the fire, Mr. Weiss sold some personal assets to his wife, the actress Kathleen Turner, Mr. Lippman said. "He made himself judgment-proof," Mr. Lippman said.
Nonetheless, the amount of the settlement drew questions from some lawyers not involved in the case. Stanley Rosenblatt, a personal liability lawyer in Miami, said a murky insurance situation could pose "a practical problem" in large wrongful death cases. But he said lawyers must aggressively try to "pierce the corporate veil" and attack liable parties' personal assets.
But Mr. Weinstock said that "under all the circumstances, we got a good settlement."

HEADLINE: Reduction's Biggest Impact: Fanning Hopes of More Cuts

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's move yesterday to reduce the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, is likely to have only a minor impact on consumers, at least in the near future.
Indeed, the Fed's decision to drop short-term interest rates merely mirrored what has already happened in financial markets. Long-term mortgage rates have already fallen almost one and a half percentage points, to 7.63 percent, since the beginning of the year, and yields on Treasury bonds have also dropped steadily. 
 Regarded as a harbinger of Fed activity to come, however, yesterday's change in direction is likely to signal a longer-term decline in interest rates that could eventually put more spending money into consumers' pockets, economists said. That, in turn, would increase purchases of big-ticket items like cars and houses, leading to the creation of more jobs and spurring the economy forward.
"A quarter-point in and of itself doesn't make any huge difference to the economy or consumers," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "But never in history has the Fed stopped after moving only a quarter-point, so there is a strong suggestion that there's more to come."
Indeed, the financial markets have already factored an even greater reduction in rates into the pricing of items like mortgages and bonds, he said. "Because of the market's expectations, if they hadn't acted, they ran the risk that things like mortgage rates and rates on auto loans would rise," which would have a negative effect on an economy already racked with hiccups, Mr. Steinberg said.
Banks have usually waited until the Fed moved rates by at least half a percentage point, but economists expect them to reduce the prime rate quickly because of the possibility that the Fed will move again relatively soon. The Banc One Corporation, the BankAmerica Corporation, Keycorp and the Harris Trust and Savings Bank yesterday lowered their prime rates to 8.75 percent from 9 percent.
Economists said yesterday that as a result of the Fed's move more banks were likely to reduce their prime lending rates, which would make home equity loans and some credit card debt less expensive.
The University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumer confidence has indicated since February that consumers, like traders and investors in the financial markets, have already anticipated a fall in interest rates. "It's not going to come as a surprise to consumers," Richard T. Curtin, director of the university's Survey Research Center, said.
The Fed's move would still send an important signal to consumers, he said. "This does indicate that Federal policy is supporting continued expansion in the economy, and that's an important element in consumer confidence," Mr. Curtin said.
Some economists argue that such confidence in lower interest rates, though, may be misplaced. David Lereah, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said the Fed's action might end up generating higher rates. He noted that economic data released last week showed a resurgent housing market and stable employment, signals of strength in the economy that were not so apparent a month ago.
"If the Fed's wrong and this economy is coming back and reaccelerating on its own, we may get higher long-term rates again fairly quickly," Mr. Lereah said.
Still, consumers with variable-rate mortgages, which tend to move in tandem with one-year Treasury notes, are also likely to see their costs ease. Interest rates on variable-rate mortgages, taking all charges into account, peaked recently at 9.5 percent, according to David Wyss, research director at DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass. He expects those rates to fall to around 8 percent in the aftermath of the Fed's action yesterday.
Consumers on fixed incomes, like retirees, will be affected to the extent that their interest-generating investments are short term. Interest rates on certificates of deposit hit a peak of 6.3 percent at the end of last year and dwindled to an average of 5.9 percent last month. Now, Mr. Wyss expects them to decline to about 5.75 percent.
"If you're in things like short-term C.D.'s, your income is going to take a hit," he said. "But it you're locked in long-term bonds, you're not going to feel anything."
Mr. Lereah of the Mortgage Bankers Association said that the cut in interest rates would be a boon to the housing market and might also inspire consumers to refinance mortgages. "If the Fed really does ease up on interest rates, that could set off a wave of refinancings that would free up income for spending on other things," he said.
Like cars. Economists said the Fed's move was especially fortuitous for auto makers, which will start delivering 1996 model cars to showrooms in September, just about the time consumers should start feeling the impact of lower rates. Car loans have risen from an average of 8.79 percent in December to roughly 9.75 percent now, according to Mr. Wyss. He expects yesterday's rate cut to push rates on auto loans down by about a quarter percentage point.

HEADLINE: Small-Town Practice Proves Attractive for Rising Number of Lawyers

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: HOMERVILLE, Ga.

 BODY:
When Jeff and Cathy Helms leave their law offices here on their daily stroll to lunch at Harpers Drug Store, they pass a half-dozen clients whose wills they wrote and, on occasion, a logger for whom they won a workman's compensation claim.
At Harpers they eat next to people whose timber leases, real estate closings and personal injury cases they have handled. Passing through the store are the proud parents of students on the Clinch County High School mock trial team, which the couple coached to a regional championship this year. 
Among the lunch crowd are clients of Jeff Helms's father, Jack, who was recruited by business leaders in the 1950's to be this town's first resident lawyer. Before his death in 1991 at 61, he served as municipal attorney, school board lawyer, all-purpose mediator and State Representative while building a lucrative practice that his son and daughter-in-law have taken over.
He also bequeathed them a way of living that an increasing number of practitioners find appealing.
"The setting and pace are conducive to practicing law and practicing life," said Robert Goldsmith, head of the University of Georgia Law School Alumni Association and a lawyer in Albany, Ga., population 78,122. "The caliber of law is every bit as sophisticated, challenging and exciting as anything else."
And like many other small-town lawyers, the Helmses are highly regarded, said Sheriff Winston Peterson of Clinch County, in sharp contrast to their urban colleagues. "We see them in civic affairs, walking down the street together or jogging together," Sheriff Peterson said. "You know, they really seem to like each other's company, too."
 
A Growing Number In Similar Practices
The American Bar Association does not keep statistics on precisely where its 860,000 members practice. But if the size of a law practice is a rough proxy for whether a lawyer is in a large or a small town, the annual survey of law school graduates by the National Association for Law Placement is suggestive: 35.8 percent of 1993 graduates, the last group surveyed, took their first jobs in firms of 2 to 10 lawyers, up from 24 percent in 1989. By contrast 19.1 percent of 1993 graduates took jobs in firms of 100 lawyers or more, down from 29.4 percent in 1989.
In a recent mail survey conducted by Lawyers Weekly U.S.A., a two-year-old publication in Boston, about 20 percent of the 431 lawyers who responded said they practiced in towns of under 15,000 people.
Elaine McArdle, the paper's editor, said the survey showed that the choice was not the only reason for the apparent growing number of small-town firms. "The biggest problem in the law right now," she said, "is that there are too many lawyers, period."
Gone are the go-go 80's, when the large firms descended on the top law schools and wooed the best students with big salaries, Ms. McArdle said.
There is little that is routine about a small-town law practice, which is what the lawyers who take to it say they like.
Robert W. Chasteen Jr., president of the 18,000-member Georgia Bar Association, and a lawyer in Fitzgerald, population 14,000, said, "It's a lot like being a country doctor because you have to engage in a general-type practice and people expect that you should be able to answer questions about patents, trademarks, corporate mergers and everything else."
And with the economies of rural areas diversifying from the farm and feed store to include manufacturing, Mr. Chasteen said, there is no shortage of legal work in rural America. In small towns nationwide, he said, "there is now the infrastructure and income levels to support more lawyers."
The American Lawyer survey of large law firms found that the annual compensation for partners in the nation's top 50 law firms ranged from $350,000 to $1.2 million. While The Lawyers Weekly U.S.A. survey found that a small percentage of small-firm lawyers could earn $500,000 to $1 million a year, the average salary in firms with six or fewer lawyers was $144,036 a year.
Mr. Helms and his wife, taking over an established practice, fall comfortably close to the average: Each earns $100,000 to $150,000 a year from the practice.
The Helmses are but 2 of the 10 lawyers in this south Georgia town of 2,560 people. As small-town lawyers, the Helmses find they are many things to many people: trusted friends and advisers to everyone from local business owners to widows wanting to know about selling their late spouses' small estates; civic leaders expected to volunteer for the library board; legal muscle to bail out someone's relative in the middle of the night, and, by the very nature of their work and locale, repository for intimate details about virtually everyone in town.
 
Unlikely Couple Sharing a Love
For Mr. Helms, his role seemed ordained. Speaking of his father, he said: "I remember being as young as 3 or 4 years old going with him to interview witnesses or to take depositions. It seems that even as a child I knew what was going on with people's legal problems in town. The firm could have been called Helms & My Boy as far as my father was concerned."
Today the firm is called Helms & Helms. One-half of the duo is a 34-year-old magna cum laude philosophy and political science graduate from the University of Georgia who once considered a career as a professional soccer player and who quotes the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein as he drives his pickup truck between appointments with clients and the cattle ranch he and his wife own 10 miles outside town.
Equally improbable in this landscape of slash pines and loblollies on the fringes of the Okefenokee Swamp is the partnership's other half, the diminutive and prim 34-year-old granddaughter of a former Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives who has no trace of a Southern accent and whose interests run toward complex product liability cases, nonfiction books and horseback riding.
Mrs. Helms concedes a tendency on the part of the good ol' boys around the courthouse to condescendingly "pat me on the head because I'm so short" (5 feet even).
And Mr. Helms recently turned red with embarrassment when John Griffin, a beefy, former truck driver for whom the lawyer won a six-figure accident settlement, observed that he "sort of looks like Opie Taylor on the Andy Griffith show."
It is only partly Jack Helms's legacy of trust that elevates the couple in locals' eyes; their involvement in civic affairs, Sheriff Peterson said, makes people feel they are "truly contributing to the community."
Such community work is a virtual requisite for small-town lawyers. "It's a way of meeting people in a town," Mr. Chasteen said, "but also a way of being seen as a regular guy."
It was the ability to give to the community in clear-cut and immediate ways that helped lure Mrs. Helms here. After being classmates with Mr. Helms in law school at the University of Georgia, she worked in construction-law practice in a large Atlanta firm and, as an Assistant District Attorney in Valdosta, near here, before joining her husband. Life for her here, she said, is seamless and less complicated.
"I think we have gotten some new clients from among people locally who hear about our work with the mock trial team," she said, "but I know we got a lot of new friends also."
 
In Small Towns, Additional Rewards
Those friends include Myra Guarino, 62, of Valdosta, who Mrs. Helms represents in a suit against the manufacturer of silicone breast implants. Mrs. Guarino had the implants in 1974 and she believes they caused numerous illnesses until she had them removed three years ago.
"A lawyer in Valdosta referred me to Cathy because she was so well-informed about this subject," Mrs. Guarino said, "and, quite frankly, I was a little surprised to find someone down here who knew so much. She's more cosmopolitan than most small-town lawyers. But you know, I've never driven up to Homerville to see her. She makes house calls and comes here to see me."
Mr. Griffin, the former truck driver, and his wife, Jenny, who often rode with him, retained the Helmses three years ago after his 18-wheeler was struck by another rig whose driver had fallen asleep. Mr. Griffin suffered injuries to his knee, back and shoulder and Mrs. Griffin's back was hurt.
A bear of a man with tattoos emblazoned on both arms, Mr. Griffin said that with his injured shoulder, "I can't go through those 15 gears anymore." Mr. Helms, he said, won him a settlement that allowed him and and his wife to start a feed store, exchange their trailer for a house and buy a pickup truck.
Sitting in Mr. Helms's office recently, Mr. Griffin allowed how he felt about his lawyer. "I was born and raised in these swamps around here and you don't go around loving other men, you know," he said. "But I like Jeff. He's real people."
Mr. Griffin had stopped by with his wife to drop off a few 25-pound bags of dog food from their store for the Helms's dogs: It was their way of paying for recent additional legal work that Mr. Helms had completed for them because, they said, he had refused all other forms of payment since the settlement two years ago.
"I don't have a choice," Mr. Helms said. "Once a client, always a client, and you're my client."
But Mrs. Griffin admonished, "No, we're your friends."
Such encounters punctuate small-town legal practices, said Mr. Goldsmith of the Georgia Law School Alumni Association, and make the practices that much more rewarding.
 
Knowing the Law Can Also Help
The practice of law can be equally challenging in a small town. The Helmses discovered this when they took a personal injury case to the State Court of Appeals, the state's second highest. They won a ruling that extended to Georgia civil cases the same prohibition against striking prospective jurors from a panel solely because of race that the United States Supreme Court had established at the Federal level months earlier.
"We knew about the Federal case and I don't think the opposing lawyer did," said Mr. Helms of the suit he tried in a town north of here. "We knew from past experience what his tactics were, and, since our client was black and his was white, we had an idea what he might do in jury selection. We basically laid a trap."
The Helmses appealed their loss of the case on the ground that opposing counsel had struck some potential black jurors for racial reasons only. Mrs. Helms wrote the briefs and presented oral arguments before the appeals court, and in late 1992 won a decision that sent the case back for a new trial.
"It's not an everyday occurrence to make state law this way," Mr. Helms said, "and we are extremely proud. We went back to retry the case and still lost, but it was a moral victory."
What may set the Helmses apart from other small-town lawyers is something they owe to Jack Helms's success. He became wealthy in his practice and that money has allowed the couple to avoid the incestuous political relationships in which many small-town lawyers become enmeshed just to survive.
Don Dupree, a Homerville automobile dealer and their friend, said he would probably not call them if he got in trouble locally "because Jeff and Cathy just don't play the game."
"A lot of your small towns have small-town justice where the judges know all the lawyers and who's right and who's wrong is less important than who you know," Mr. Dupree said. "So if I was going north of the Macon line, I'd call Jeff and Cathy because they can handle themselves. But down here, I know people who have better connections to the system than them."

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges 'Less Combat' By Politicians

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Drawing together many of his recent themes, President Clinton called on the nation's political figures today to have "more conversation and less combat" and to help Americans find some "common ground" as Republicans and Democrats debate the proper role of government.
In a wide-ranging speech, the President vigorously defended his vision of government as an agent to improve the lives of the middle class against the Republicans' call for less government. But Mr. Clinton also denounced "too much extremism of rhetoric and excessive partisanship" and said the way the political debate was conducted was as important to the country as its outcome. 
 "We can't restore the American dream unless we can find some way to bring the American people closer together," Mr. Clinton said. "Therefore, how we resolve these differences is as important as what specific position we advocate. I think we have got to move beyond the vision and the resentment to common ground. We've got to go beyond cynicism to a sense of possibility."
Mr. Clinton spoke for an hour from a stage at Georgetown University, the school he attended as an undergraduate and the forum for a series of speeches he delivered in 1991 setting out the philosophical underpinnings of his quest for the Presidency. And though Mr. Clinton couched today's address in nonpartisan terms, he appeared to be setting out his rationale for a second term.
At times speaking in highly personal terms, and barely glancing at his text, Mr. Clinton used his speech to enter the debate over political values and to thread his way between conservatives, who say the country's problems are rooted in a decline of culture and of personal responsibility, and liberals, who believe activist government is the answer to social ills.
"The best example of all to me that our problems are both personal and cultural and economic and political and social is the whole condition of the middle class economically," Mr. Clinton said. "I think it requires public and private decision-making, family values. Most families have them. But most families are working harder for less, so they have less time and less money to spend on their children. Now that's just a fact. That's not good for family values. And I don't believe exhortation alone can turn it around."
Mr. Clinton's aides said he would be making a series of appearances in the next few months to further explore his themes of citizenship and civic responsibility.
In contrast to Senator Bob Dole, a leading Republican Presidential contender who recently asserted that the entertainment industry was eroding moral values, Mr. Clinton in his speech dwelled at length on the economic trends that he said had eroded "middle-class dreams and middle-class values."
In themes reminiscent of his 1992 campaign, Mr. Clinton said that while average income had gone up, the median income in the country had gone down in the past two years, indicating a growing gap between the richest and poorest Americans. Job security has declined in the rush toward corporate downsizing, he said, and more people have become temporary workers.
In the face of such forces, Mr. Clinton called for a "relentless effort to change but not eviscerate government" and made the case for his proposals to balance the budget over 10 years while increasing education spending and providing tax breaks for families with children and new tax deductions for post-high school education. The Republican-controlled Congress recently approved a plan for a balanced budget over seven years with steeper cuts in Government programs and larger tax cuts.
"We have tried weak government, nonexistent government, in a complex industrial society where powerful interests that are driven only by short-term considerations call all the shots," Mr. Clinton said, blaming such policies for leading to the Great Depression.
Mr. Clinton was interrupted by sustained applause from a supportive audience invited from the realms of academia, religion, sports and the media, when he cited gun control and AIDS research as areas where Americans should be willing to contribute to a common social good.
Chastising the National Rifle Association, he disputed the notion that individuals should be punished for gun violence but that guns should not be controlled.
"You don't gripe when you go through a metal detector at an airport anymore," Mr. Clinton said, "because you are very aware of the connection between this minor inconvenience to you and the fact that plane might blow up. And you don't want that plane to blow up or be hijacked. Well, look at the level of violence in America. It's the same thing."
The President also took issue with recent remarks by Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who said the Federal money spent on people with AIDS should be reduced because they contracted the disease through "deliberate, disgusting, revolting conduct."
Mr. Clinton cited the cases of the late Ricky Ray of Florida, a teen-ager whose family was shunned after he and his brother contracted the AIDS virus through a blood transfusion, and of Elizabeth Glaser, who died of AIDS last year. At the 1992 Democratic National Convention, at which Mr. Clinton was nominated for the Presidency, Mrs. Glaser gave a moving account of her having gotten AIDS through a blood transfusion and having passed it on to her daughter.
Mr. Clinton added that "the gay people who have AIDS are still our sons, our brothers, our cousins, our citizens," and he noted that while smoking caused lung cancer, no one was proposing to stop treating lung cancer or searching for a cure.
The President's tone on these issues was one more of sorrow than of partisan attack as he assumed the same mantle of conciliation that he struck last month in his New Hampshire encounter with Speaker Newt Gingrich. Acknowledging that the electorate has shown itself increasingly tired of sharp partisanship and gridlock in Washington, Mr. Clinton said that political rivals should try "more conversation and less combat" and tone down the rhetorical extremes.
"We need to respect our differences, and hear them," Mr. Clinton said, "but it means instead of having shrill voices of discord, we need a chorus of harmony. In a chorus of harmony, you know there are lots of differences, but you can hear all the voices."
Aides said Mr. Clinton was expected to travel to Tennessee on Monday to attend a conference on family issues sponsored by Vice President Al Gore, and planned additional speeches on civic responsibility to the American Federation of Teachers later this month, religious leaders in September and business executives in October.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the President's Speech at Georgetown University

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton at Georgetown University today. They were made available by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:
Today I want to have more of a conversation than deliver a formal speech, about the great debate now raging in our nation, not so much over what we should do, but over how we should resolve the great questions of our time here in Washington and in communities all across our country. I want to talk about the obligations of citizenship, the obligations imposed on the President and people in power, and the obligations imposed on all Americans. 
 Two days ago we celebrated the 219th birthday of our democracy. The Declaration of Independence was also clearly a declaration of citizenship. It was a declaration of interdependence. "For the support of this Declaration, with a firm reliance on the protection of divine providence, we mutually pledge our lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honor." . . .
Middle-class values, strong families and faith, safe streets, secure futures -- these things are very much threatened today, threatened by 20 years of stagnant incomes, of increasing inequality of incomes, and increasing insecurity in jobs, in retirement, in health care.
They are threatened by 30 years of social problems of profound implications, of family breakups, of a rising tide of crime and drugs, of declining birthrates among successful, married couples and rising birthrates among young people who are not married. They are threatened by the failure of public institutions to respond. The failure of bureaucracies encrusted in yesterday's prerogatives and not meeting the challenges of today and tomorrow. The schools, the law-enforcement agencies, the governments and their economic and their other policies. They are threatened by the sheer pace and scope of change as technology and ideas and money and decisions move across the globe at breathtaking rates. . . .
Politics has become more and more fractured, just like the rest of our lives, pluralized. It's exciting in some ways, but as we divide into more and more and more sharply defined organized groups around more and more and more stratified issues, as we communicate more and more with people in extreme rhetoric through mass mailings or sometimes semihysterical messages right before election on the telephone, or 30-second ads designed far more to inflame than to inform, as we see politicians actually getting language lessons on how to turn their adversaries into aliens, it is difficult to draw the conclusion that our political system is producing the sort of discussion that will give us the kind of results we need. But our citizens, even though their confidence in the future has been clouded, and their doubts about their leaders and their institutions are profound, want something better. . . .
What do we have to do now? First of all, we've got to have this debate that is looming over Washington. It's a good thing. We are debating things now we thought were settled for decades. We are now back to fundamental issues that were debated like this 50, 60, 70 years ago.
There is a group who believe that our problems are primarily personal and cultural. Cultural is basically a word that means in this context, there are a whole lot of persons doing the same bad thing. And that's what people, and if everybody would just sort of straighten up and fly right, why things would be hunky-dory, and why don't they do it? I'll give you two examples. . . .
The N.R.A.'s position on gun violence, the Brady bill and the assault weapons ban. Their position is: Guns don't kill people, people do. Find the people who do wrong, throw them in jail and throw the key away. . . .
Second example is the one that dominated the headlines in the last couple of days, what Senator Helms said about AIDS: I'm sick and tired of spending money on research and treatment for a disease that could be ended tomorrow if everybody would just straighten up and fly right. . . .
I would say to you that there are some things that mere exhortation to good conduct will not solve, that require other responses that are public, or that are private, but go beyond just saying these are personal and cultural problems. I also think that if we want to maintain a public response there must be a relentless effort to change, but not to eviscerate, the government. . . .
I believe that a democracy requires a certain amount of common ground. I do not believe you can solve complex questions like this at the grass-roots level or at the national level or anywhere in between if you have too much extremism of rhetoric and excessive partisanship. Times are changing too fast. . . .
Every citizen in this country's got to say, "What do I have to do for myself or my family," or nothing else counts. The truth is that nobody can repeal the laws of the global economy, and people that don't have a certain level of education and skills are not going to be employable in good jobs with long-term prospects. And that's just a fact. . . .
The second thing is, more of our citizens have got to say, "What should I do in my community?" You know, it's not just enough to bemoan the rising crime rate or how kids are behaving or whatever. . . .
We can redeem the promise of America for our children. We can certainly restore the American family for another full century, if we commit to each other, as the Founders did, our lives, our fortunes, and our sacred honor. In our hour of greatest peril and greatest division, when we were fighting over the issue which we have still not fully resolved, Abraham Lincoln said, We are not enemies but friends, we must not be enemies. My friends, amidst all our differences, let us find a new common ground.

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE TRIMS A KEY RATE; FIRST CUT SINCE '92

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Under mounting political and economic pressure to stave off a possible recession, the Federal Reserve reduced short-term interest rates today for the first time since 1992.
But the Federal Reserve's top rate-setting committee made only a small reduction, reflecting its confidence that any downturn would be brief and mild. It trimmed the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 5.75 percent from 6 percent. The less critical discount rate, which the Federal Reserve levies on banks for short-term loans, was left unchanged at 5.25 percent. 
 "As a result of the monetary tightening initiated in early 1994, inflationary pressures have receded enough to accommodate a modest adjustment in monetary conditions," Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said in a statement today.
For consumers and business, the decision should mean slightly lower costs for borrowing. Indeed, some big banks began moving after the announcement to lower their prime lending rates, which influence the cost of home equity loans, small business loans and some credit card balances. [Page D4.]
Since interest rate reductions often take several months or longer to affect the pace of economic growth, the immediate impact of the decision is likely to be its effect on the financial markets, which soared on the action. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 48.77 points, to 4,664, while interest rates fell in the bond market. [Pages D6 and D15.]
Investors in the markets had been awaiting this meeting for weeks, as speculation intensified about how the Federal Reserve might respond to a string of Government statistics that showed a sharp slowdown in business activity. Some Fed officials as well as investors had begun to worry that inaction could lead to a plunge in the stock and bond markets that might make a recession more likely.
The news was also welcomed at the White House, which is acutely aware of the damage a downturn would cause to President Clinton's re-election prospects.
More broadly, the decision marks an important point in the nation's business cycle. The Federal Reserve had steadily cut rates from July 1990 to September 1992 as it tried to arrest the recession that destroyed President George Bush's re-election hopes. It then raised them from February 1994 through February of this year to control inflation by braking the economy's momentum.
In the past, the Federal Reserve has tended to keep cutting rates for a while once it starts. Yet in the last few weeks Mr. Greenspan had hinted at his reluctance to stimulate an economy he considers in good shape for the long term. That suggests that further cuts may also be small and slow in coming. And if the economy rebounds faster than the Federal Reserve expects, there is even a chance that the central bank may respond by once again raising rates.
Mr. Greenspan described the move today as a consequence of the Federal Reserve's success in keeping the economic expansion from getting out of hand last year. He declared in his statement that the central bank's seven increases in short-term rates in the last 17 months had kept inflation under control.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, took pains in a statement today to counteract any interpretation of the Federal Reserve's action as a signal of economic difficulty. "Many of the factors behind the recent weakness are likely to operate with less force in the future," they said. "Sales of homes show evidence of a rebound; export growth should pick up in future months; the demand for capital goods remains strong, and businesses appear to be well along in the process of paring inventories."
Both the Clinton Administration and the Federal Reserve have a strong stake in maintaining public confidence in the economy. As several Federal Reserve officials said in interviews last month, the biggest threat to the economy would come if millions of Americans suddenly began fearing for their jobs and cut back on their spending, leaving retailers' shelves full of unsold goods and forcing a ripple of layoffs across the nation.
A welter of Government statistics during the last two months have pointed to a slowing economy with little risk of inflation. The Commerce Department said today, for example, that its index of leading economic indicators had fallen by two-tenths of a percent in May, the fourth consecutive drop. Economists consider it a warning of a possible recession ahead when the index falls for three months in a row. That picture has been clouded, though, by recent signs in the housing market and elsewhere that economic activity may perk up again later this year.
At the same time, inflation has only inched up. Despite an economy operating at close to full capacity, consumer price inflation rose during the first five months of this year at an annual pace of 3.6 percent, barely up from last year's increase of 2.7 percent. Inflation in raw materials like grain and industrial materials like steel, which tends to precede rising consumer prices, has slowed sharply in the last year.
Financial markets have soared during the last month on expectations of a cut in rates. The Federal Reserve's top officials, including Mr. Greenspan, may have grown increasingly reluctant in the last several weeks to risk causing turmoil on Wall Street by leaving rates unchanged, analysts said.
Whenever the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, it risks driving down the value of the already weak American dollar by making short-term investments less attractive in the United States. Possibly because the discount rate, which is sometimes used to signal the currency markets, was left unchanged, today's rate reduction produced only a small drop in the dollar against the German mark and little change against the Japanese yen.
The goal of the Federal Reserve's seven interest rate increases in 1994 and early this year was to brake inflation. To do that, the Federal Reserve slowed the growth of the money supply and restricted the nation's economic growth so as to prevent the appearance of inflationary bottlenecks in the production of goods and services.
But there were plenty of people today contending that the central bank had gone too far in raising interest rates, needlessly sacrificing jobs to trim a few tenths of a percentage point off the inflation rate. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee, quickly criticized today's move as too little, too late.
"This is only a small step by the Federal Reserve in admitting its previous severe interest rate policy was wrong," he said. "It is already too late to stop the economic harm caused by the Federal Reserve's misguided doubling of interest rates."
Republicans were quick to blame the Clinton Administration for the economy's slowdown. "The recent weakness in economic data signal the damage done to the economy by President Clinton's 1993 tax hikes," said Senator Connie Mack, the Florida Republican who heads the Joint Economic Committee.
But most economists contend that tax changes have a very limited effect on the ups and downs in the business cycle, which is more affected by interest rate changes.
