HEADLINE: Chemical Aims to Expand Electronic Banking

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Chemical Bank said yesterday that it would expand its electronic banking services beginning in October, including a new push into the home banking arena that it has tried unsuccessfully to develop for more than a decade.
As part of the program, the bank announced an alliance with the Microsoft Corporation to provide money management software linked to Chemical's private computer network. Microsoft will help Chemical market the new services by providing it with names of registered users of Microsoft products in the bank's area, a spokesman for Microsoft said. 
 Chemical, a unit of the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York, becomes the seventh big bank to forge such an alliance with Microsoft. The bank also disclosed plans to deploy 235 new automatic teller machines, including some that will offer advanced features like handwriting recognition and instant verification of deposits. By 1996, the company said, new A.T.M. cards will double as debit cards, enabling Chemical customers to make purchases at more than 12 million merchants worldwide.
Millions of personal computers have been installed in the New York metropolitan area since Chemical began its home banking experiments in the early 1980's, but the bank still has only a few thousand regular on-line customers. And these use their computers for relatively simple banking chores, including checking of account balances and statements, and transfer of funds.
Chemical plans to offer its customers the choice of its own home banking software or a copy of Microsoft Money for Windows 95, a new version of the financial management program that Microsoft recently tried to dump in favor of a more popular rival program, Quicken.
The Chemical deal is the first bank alliance by Microsoft since the collapse of its proposed $2 billion merger with Intuit Inc., the maker of Quicken. To lessen potential antitrust concerns, Microsoft would have sold Money to Novell Inc. had the Intuit deal been completed.
Earlier, Microsoft signed up six other big banks for alliances, including Chase Manhattan in New York and banks in North Carolina, Michigan, Illinois, Minnesota and Oregon. Microsoft is expected to announce similar bank agreements in coming weeks.
William M. Bluestein, a research director at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., said Microsoft had "a tremendous marketing problem with Microsoft Money."
"They're weakened by their tacit admission that Quicken was a better product," he said. "Now they're bringing out a new version, but they have to say, 'This product we wanted to get rid of really isn't all that bad.' "
Matthew L. Cone, the business development manager at Microsoft, said such an analysis was unfair. "Microsoft wanted to acquire Intuit not for Quicken, but for Intuit's management team, organizational structure and creative talent," he said.
Mr. Cone said programmers continued to work hard to improve Money even while Microsoft was proposing to sell it to Novell. "They kept working even when they knew they could become surrogate parents and deliver the baby to another company," he said.
Ronald A. Braco, senior vice president in charge of electronic banking for Chemical Bank, said he was impressed with Microsoft Money for Windows 95. He declined to say whether the bank negotiated with Intuit or other makers of financial software as well as with Microsoft.
Mr. Braco said Chemical's own home banking software, called Excel -- which is not related to Microsoft's spreadsheet program of the same name -- will be offered to bank customers who want a simple, no-frills program for basic banking tasks. Microsoft Money will be offered to more advanced PC users, he said, but no decision has been made on whether to give away the software or offer it at a discount.

HEADLINE: In the Line of Fire;
Sights on Clinton, G.O.P. Assails His Economist

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Few operations of the Government are smaller or cheaper than the White House's Council of Economic Advisers. So why are Congressional Republicans so interested in abolishing it?
That question confronts the council's new chairman, Joseph E. Stiglitz, appointed on the same day last week that a House Appropriations subcommittee voted to eliminate financing for the council. 
 Representative Jim Ross Lightfoot, the Iowa Republican who is the subcommittee chairman, said the vote to kill the council mainly reflected a sense that President Clinton already had enough economists in other agencies, like the Office of Management and Budget.
"We've got the National Economics Council, the O.M.B. and we have the C.E.A. all dealing with finances and money and so on," he said in an interview. "The question is whether these functions are duplicative, all dealing with money and advice and so forth."
But some Democrats have complained that the Republicans are also using partisan differences with the council's previous head, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, as an excuse to kill it. Although the head of the council has always been a Presidential appointee whose job included acting as a spokesman for an administration's economic policies, the Republicans argue that Ms. Tyson went too far.
"There was that criticism made -- I never made it, but I've heard it -- and I think some of it is justified," Mr. Lightfoot said. "My understanding of C.E.A. is nonpartisan, unbiased interpretation of what is going on -- like the C.I.A. on what is going on politically -- and that line may have been stepped over a little bit."
The question is whether the naming of Mr. Stiglitz, which the White House describes as having fallen by coincidence on the day of the subcommittee vote, will take the steam out of Republican efforts to kill the council.
As chairwoman of the council the last two years, Ms. Tyson emerged as a leading advocate for the Administration's domestic policies. Politically savvy, forceful, with a skill for sound bites that made economics seem simple, she raised the council's visibility. She also rubbed more than a few Congressional Republicans the wrong way.
Mr. Stiglitz's economic views are much like Ms. Tyson's, but his style is very different. Mr. Stiglitz, 52, is literally a graybeard in a White House still dominated by youth. (Ms. Tyson is 48, but looks younger.) While Ms. Tyson has long devoted her attention to the hottest economic issues of the day, Mr. Stiglitz is a theoretician best known for his original ideas and mathematical arguments on issues of interest mostly to other economists.
His delivery is not made for television: he chooses words with care, pausing in midsentence long enough, it sometimes seems, for Newt Gingrich to hold a roll-call vote of the entire House. And he comes across as less confrontational.
But it's not clear whether this will be enough to persuade the Republicans to back off.
Indeed, Administration officials say the Republicans' intent is to annoy the President, not to end economic partisanship, because council chairmen have lobbied for Administrations of both parties. They see the subcommittee's move as breaking down a long-honored understanding that Presidents of whatever party are given a reasonably free hand with the White House budget.
Backing the White House is a bipartisan group of past chairmen of the council, created in 1946 to help carry out the Employment Act, the first big piece of economic legislation after World War II. Herbert Stein, the chairman under President Richard M. Nixon, said he thought that Ms. Tyson's views were within the mainstream of current economic thought and that she was not excessively partisan. "The Council of Economic Advisers is appointed by the President," Mr. Stein said. "He appoints people he regards as sympathetic. He doesn't appoint people he has to fight with all the time."
The council, with a budget of $3.4 million this year, gives the President advice about the impact of Government decisions on the economy. And that advice frequently challenges the views of many of the special interests that dominate decision-making in Washington.
The council has quarreled with career economists at the Agriculture Department, for example, over the value of farm subsidies. Mr. Stiglitz said in an interview today that he viewed the council's role as off-setting established interests of many sorts. "Unlike many other agencies whose charge it is to be attentive to particular aspects of our multifaceted economy," he said, "the C.E.A. takes a national perspective analyzing impacts of economic policies on every major sector and group -- on workers, on firms, on consumers and on financial markets."
For her part, Ms. Tyson acknowledges that she engaged in what she describes as heated exchanges with the Republican-controlled House and Senate budget committees in the weeks before she moved to her new White House job as head of the National Economic Council. But she scoffed at any notion that she brought undue partisanship to the council.
"I have always tried to adhere to the highest professional standards," she said. "Clearly, I don't see the world the way some Republicans do."
Mr. Stiglitz will probably face less such criticism, in part because he has more armor than Ms. Tyson against conservative attacks. He is clearly comfortable among conservatives; before coming to the Administration, he was a fellow at the conservative Hoover Institution on the campus of Stanford University (he was also a professor at Stanford). When a visitor came to his office last week, the top magazine on his coffee table was a freshly thumbed copy of the magazine Regulation, published by the Cato Institute, which has a free-market view.
To be sure, Mr. Stiglitz's academic writings show he is clearly a liberal. He has concentrated on issues of market failures rather than on government failures. He is also a longtime advocate of universal health care coverage.
"I would not confuse a certain academic manner of speech with a lack of ideological conviction or a lack of partisan feeling," said an Administration official who insisted on anonymity.
Mr. Stiglitz acknowledged today that he thinks government should play a strong role in the economy. "One of the major responsibilities of government," he said, "is to insure that all of society's resources, and in particular its human resources, are fully utilized."
Yet Mr. Stiglitz, with his air of an absent-minded professor, appears likely to be a much less controversial figure in Washington than Ms. Tyson was.
The council's chairmen have varied in influence, even over the course of a single Administration. Michael J. Boskin was very influential at the beginning of the Bush Administration, for example, but a couple of years later, after his advice had become less welcome, he had to threaten to quit before getting a one-on-one session with President Bush.
Under Ms. Tyson, the council gained influence. That partly reflected the fact that Ms. Tyson communicated well with a President who sometimes talks like an economics-wonk wannabe. But it also reflected Ms. Tyson's close political alliance with Vice President Al Gore.
 A few months after President Clinton took office, Ms. Tyson and Mr. Gore decided in a conversation that the President should be getting economic advice more comparable to his national security advice, Ms. Tyson said. As a result, the council began producing a weekly economic briefing paper for the President, and Ms. Tyson was guaranteed a weekly meeting with him.
Part of Ms. Tyson's influence also reflected her ability to express economic ideas in simple, forceful language, both at White House meetings and on television. By contrast, Mr. Stiglitz admitted, "I haven't done a lot of television."
Mr. Stiglitz has led a privileged academic life, teaching only two or three times a week, pampered by a succession of the world's best universities because of his glittering reputation. Inside the Beltway, he may stand in Ms. Tyson's shadow, but among economists he is an unquestioned star who is widely expected to win a Nobel Prize someday.
After graduating from Amherst College and receiving his doctorate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Stiglitz was appointed a full professor of economics at Yale University at age 26. He later held Britain's oldest and most prestigious chair in economics, the Drummond Chair in Political Economy at All Souls College at Oxford.
During his academic career, Mr. Stiglitz focused not on the operation of the overall economy but on the economic decisions of individuals or companies or government agencies. He has been particularly active on problems of operating when information is incomplete, such as the difficulties facing health insurance companies in trying to gauge the extent to which people seeking individual coverage are particularly bad risks.
That interest in so-called microeconomic issues has carried over into the Government. While Ms. Tyson spent much of this spring battling Congress over budget cuts, Mr. Stiglitz was putting a great deal of energy into devising an Administration plan to simplify pensions.
Mr. Stiglitz said in the interview that he planned to be much more active in issues involving the overall economy, but quickly returned to his interest in making specific Government programs work better. "It's an area which I was always interested in, but it's also an area where I think there is really bipartisan consensus," he said.
This seems to suit House Republicans. "From what little I know of him," Mr. Lightfoot said, "I don't expect him to make a lot of partisan remarks -- he doesn't strike me as that type."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rate Cut By Fed Pushes Treasury Prices Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surged yesterday after the Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates by a quarter of percentage point.
The move matched the expectations of many in the market, which had already priced in a cut of that size. But many trader and analysts are still uncertain about how far the Fed's new course will take interest rates. 
 The central bank reduced the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, to 5.75 percent from 6 percent. The discount rate, which the Fed charges banks for short-term loans, was left unchanged at 5.25 percent. It is the first rate reduction since Sept. 4, 1992, and represents an about-face in monetary policy. The Fed had doubled the Federal funds rate over seven rate increases beginning in February 1994.
Some analysts had doubted that a rate cut would come at this meeting because of recent signs that the economy was not slowing as sharply as had been previously believed, increasing the possibility of a resurgance in inflation in the months ahead. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds. Still, the move by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making group, was a relatively small reduction.
"The quarter-point move was one that I think all members of the Federal Open Market Committee could live with," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Securities. "A half-point move would have been too much for some, while an unchanged policy would have been too little for others."
The price of the 30-year bond jumped 116/32 , to 11423/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.49 percent, from 6.60 percent on Wednesday.
Prices of shorter-term maturities, typically the most sensitive to changes in Fed policy, also rallied strongly, driving their rates down.The rate for a three-month bill fell 12 basis points, to 5.36 percent, and the rate for a six-month bill fell 17 basis points, to 5.24 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The yield spread between the two-year note and the 30-year bond widened to 98 basis points yesterday from 84 basis points on Wednesday, indicating that investors had indeed been expecting a cut in rates.
And the sharp surge in the short end of the market yesterday suggested that traders expect further cuts this year, said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Mr. Chan said the quarter of a percentage point move by the Fed indicated that among Fed policy makers, neither the anti-inflation hawks nor the recession-fearing doves were in control. "It appears that this was a compromise reached in the 11theleventh hour," Mr. Chan said. "The move in my judgment may turn out to be a shrewd one" for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, he said, if today's employment report for June is weaker than expected. "The compromise may have prevented the F.O.M.C. from cutting rates more sharply if they had waited until they had seen the employment report."
The Labor Department's employment report today may not be quite the market mover it has been in the past.
"Clearly some of the anticipation that normally surrounds these numbers may be lessened because of the Fed's action today," Mr. Fine of Chase Securities said.
"Another point worth thinking about is the fact that the Fed moved right before the release of the payroll number, which should show the market that the number, by itself, is not the be-all and end-all of economic statistics."

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoys Press the I.R.A. To Take Steps to Yield Arms

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 6

 BODY:
The United States Ambassadors to Britain and Ireland have reminded Gerry Adams, leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, that the Clinton Administration wants him to advance the Northern Ireland peace effort.
The Administration is particularly interested, the Ambassadors say, in the area of decommissioning of arms by the I.R.A., in order to enhance the possibility of convening full-fledged peace negotiations. 
 The diplomatic contacts came before this week's violent protests in Northern Ireland. President Clinton, whose plans to visit Ireland, Northern Ireland and Britain were announced today, would like to have peace talks under way by the time he arrives in late November. Irish-American support for Mr. Clinton, which has increased with his involvement in the peace effort here, would help him in the 1996 election.
The United States Embassy in London declined to comment on a newspaper report in today's Times of London that the American Ambassador to Britain, William Crowe, delivered a "strongly worded" message from the Administration on the subject of arms when he met with Mr. Adams here last week. But one official said, "We have no quibble with that story."
The American Ambassador to Ireland, Jean Kennedy Smith, said in an interview that she was aware of Ambassador Crowe's conversation with Mr. Adams and that she had sent an official letter to Mr. Adams in Belfast that simply restated American policy: all sides in Northern Ireland should lay down their down arms and enter negotiations.
The policy was outlined by President Clinton last May in a speech in Washington to a conference on economic development in Ireland. But in that speech, the President set no timetable for decommissioning or full-fledged talks including Sinn Fein.
Mrs. Smith, said in an interview that she sent a message to Mr. Adams and that she had not taken a hard or tough line with him. Her message to Mr. Adams, she said, "was encouraging and supportive of the peace process and the talks process."
Mr. Adams and Sinn Fein consider good relations with Washington essential to their immediate goal: being invited by Britain to join all-party talks on Ulster. Sinn Fein hopes that Washington will continue to press the Government of Prime Minister John Major to convene the talks soon.
But Irish officials are worried that American pressure might weaken after this week's rioting, the worst in the 10 months since the I.R.A. declared a cease-fire. British officials and local Catholic residents have said that Sinn Fein and the I.R.A. stirred up the violence, which began in protest of Britain's release on Monday of a soldier who had been serving a life term for the 1990 killing of a Catholic girl in a stolen car that ran through an army checkpoint in 1990.
Sinn Fein has denied the accusations that it orchestrated the riots, in which hundreds of cars and trucks were hijacked and torched. The violence ended on Wednesday, after Mr. Adams called for calm.
Britain has insisted that the I.R.A. make progress on decommissioning before Sinn Fein is invited to full-fledged negotiations toward a settlement of the conflict between the Roman Catholic minority and the Protestant majority in Ulster.
Mr. Adams has said that the I.R.A. cease-fire is adequate evidence of its peaceful intentions and that decommissioning is an unacceptable pre-condition to roundtable negotiations.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Unraveling of a Land Swap: No School, No Plant Expansion

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON 

 BODY:
Two years ago, it appeared to be the perfect civic deal: a major manufacturer in Brooklyn and the city's School Construction Authority would swap two adjacent pieces of land, allowing a long-delayed school to be built and giving the manufacturer the space it needed to expand its 700-worker plant. And both the city and state would offer financial help.
But now, the deal -- brokered late in 1993 by former Mayor David N. Dinkins and former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- is dead. A lawsuit blocks the construction of the badly needed intermediate school in East New York. The manufacturer, Blue Ridge Farms, is talking about moving its food-processing plant -- and the jobs -- to the South. 
 And the warm expressions of cooperation and goodwill have dissolved into bitter charges of deception, delay and bad faith.
"I don't know who is at fault, probably everyone," said Cesi Mullane, the leader of a local coalition of parents pushing for the school to be built. "It's a shame we have to be for or against the school or the jobs at the plant. But there has to be an end to it."
The people of East New York thought they had reached an end -- a paradise of sorts -- in 1993 when the School Construction Authority, which oversees the construction of city schools, agreed to give up a parcel of land it owned next to the Blue Ridge plant. That would have allowed the company to build a pasta-production annex. In return, the company was to give the school system a larger plot for a new $30 million school.
In addition, the city agreed to contribute several million dollars in tax incentives and capital investments to the company, which employs hundreds of residents in one of the city's poorest neighborhoods. And New York State agreed to help with the land-condemnation process and said it would cover the costs of environmental studies and any litigation.
But the deal began to unravel with the election of Gov. George E. Pataki. Alarmed by the details of the land swap, the new Governor's appointees decided they would not honor the terms of the deal.
"It was a blank check they had been given, a sweetheart deal," said Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the State Urban Development Corporation, which rejected the deal. State officials said the deal would have cost the state more than $1 million and exposed it to the potential damage of any litigation.
State officials said they were concerned that the previous owner of the city property -- a man involved in a long personal dispute with Blue Ridge Farms -- might sue if his land ultimately was used by the company. They also said they were afraid that environmental groups might take legal action seeking to block any expansion of the manufacturing plant in a neighborhood that is a mix of commercial and residential areas.
"The terms were outrageous, the risks great," Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the state development agency, said. "It was rejected on its merits."
Before becoming a state official, Mr. Gargano was president of a development corporation run by his son. In 1985, the corporation bought the land that is now owned by Blue Ridge and involved in the proposed swap. Sale records show the corporation made a $1 million profit when it sold the land to Blue Ridge in 1987.
Mr. Gargano described himself last week as a "passive partner" in the corporation and said he saw no conflict of interest in deciding whether the state should be involved in the deal.
On April 25, the state development agency, in a letter sent jointly with the city's Economic Development Corporation, informed Blue Ridge Farms that it would have to accept a modified deal under which the company would assume the risks of potential litigation or settle for expanding on the site it was to swap with the School Construction Authority.
Officials of Blue Ridge Farms -- which makes salads and hot entrees and which had $70 million in revenues last year -- said the ultimatum violated their agreement and said expanding on their own site was unrealistic because the parcel owned by the School Construction Authority prevented it from building a contiguous annex.
In a swift series of subsequent events, the city told the Board of Education to go ahead with plans to build the school on the current site, and the Schools Chancellor told the School Construction Authority to put the contract for the school out to bid.
In answer, Blue Ridge Farms went to court and was granted a temporary restraining order preventing the start of construction. Blue Ridge officials said they are prepared to sue the city for damages and relocate their operation out of state, the very result the initial deal with the former state and city administrations had sought to avert.
"We have no choice," Seymour Siegel, the chief executive officer of the company, said.
And so the scene has come full circle in East New York, and if anything, mutual mistrust has only grown.
Pataki administration officials contend that Blue Ridge should have sealed its deal before Mr. Cuomo left office and that it was the company's lack of organization and fiscal soundness -- the company owes $900,000 in unpaid city taxes -- that prevented it from doing so.
Blue Ridge officials say the city should go ahead and complete the swap without the state's involvement, repeating their long-held position that building the school on a plot of land that stands squarely in the middle of their facility will be a nightmare for the schoolchildren.
The city, which insists that it never backed away from its willingness to commit money and tax breaks, says that legally it needs the state's involvement in order to go ahead with the deal. And the Board of Education says it merely wants to get a school built and will do so at whatever site it is directed to use.
"The city never wants to see a business leave, and it will work overtime to keep them here," said Forrest R. Taylor, chief of staff for Deputy Mayor John Dyson. "But there are times when businesses ask for what it is beyond the city to give."
Mr. Siegel, whose company has an $18 million annual payroll, disputes the Giuliani administration's claim that it cannot legally go ahead with the swap without the state.
"Everyone says that City Hall could get this done if it wanted to," Mr. Siegel said. "I have no idea why it doesn't seem to want to."
Meanwhile, the people of East New York have been left angry and divided, suspicious of Blue Ridge, the city and the state. Juan Lao, a father of three who works as a maintenance supervisor at Blue Ridge, said he finds it unthinkable that a deal cannot be worked out.
Marilyn Camacho, who has worked at Blue Ridge for eight years, said, "We had it all, and now they want to take it all."
The Rev. Patrick Mahoney, the pastor of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church, said, "People feel once again backed into a corner. I don't know why it has all come apart."

HEADLINE: Retailers Report Their Sales Were Sluggish Last Month

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Spending at the nation's retail chain stores was sluggish during June, sales figures released yesterday show. Analysts said the lackluster results were consistent with a slowdown in the economy.
Big department stores and discount chains registered the biggest sales gains, as consumers continued to be spend cautiously, gravitating to stores offering markdowns on summer merchandise. 
 Analysts attributed gains at big chains like May Department Stores, Dillard Department Stores and Federated Department Stores in large part to a rise in apparel sales.
Comparable-store sales rose by 4.6 percent percent at May, by 4 percent at Dillard and by 4.8 percent at Federated.
"In June, Americans entered a wardrobe-replacement mode," said Kurt Barnard, publisher of Barnard's Retailing Report, an industry newsletter based in Scotch Plains, N.J. "For the first time in a couple of years, they are buying clothing at department stores, which offer low prices and huge variety, things you don't find at specialty retailers."
Goldman, Sachs's retail composite index, a weighted average of the same-store sales of more than 60 retailers, rose 3.4 percent last month, compared with a 6.4 percent gain in June 1994 and a 3.7 percent increase in May.
Same-store, or comparable-store, sales are for stores open at least a year. The measure is considered a better gauge of a retailer's performance because it factors out sales in new stores.
"The sales numbers are pretty consistent with what we have had all year, with the exception of hard specialty goods, like home furnishings and home improvement items, which have softened," Richard N. Baum, a retailing analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said.
Sales of hard goods dropped sharply in June compared with the month a year ago, he said, because the summer of 1994 began with a period of exceptionally hot weather.
"By comparison, this June was unseasonably cool," Mr. Baum said. "As a result, sales items like air-conditioners and lawn furniture were down from a year ago."
The gain in apparel spending at department stores was at the expense of specialty retailing chains like Limited Inc., the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation and Gap Inc.
On a comparable-store basis, Limited sales rose 1 percent in June. But that was better than the performance at Ann Taylor, where comparable-store sales fell by 10.3 percent, and Gap, where they dropped 4 percent.
Ann Taylor also said yesterday that it expected a loss of 8 to 12 cents a share in the second quarter. Yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Ann Taylor fell $3.25, to $20.375; Gap lost $2.25 a share, to $34.25, while Limited fell by 12.5 cents, to $21.875.
Even as big department store chains were gaining business that might otherwise have gone to specialty retailers, nationwide discount-store operations continued to take advantage of the move to value shopping, often at the expense of regional chains.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's biggest retailer, posted a 5.5 percent rise in same-store sales for a five-week period ending June 30. And the Kmart Corporation, the second-biggest retailer, had a 6.3 percent gain for a five-week period ending June 28.
By contrast, same-store sales at many regional discounters fell last month. Sales at the Caldor Corporation, a big Northeast chain, were down 6 percent.
"The national chains clearly outperformed the regionals," Mr. Baum said.
While yesterday's decision by the Federal Reserve to lower a key interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point was intended to shore up the economy, retailers have not planned on a quick bounce in consumer spending, analysts said.
"We believe retailers are well positioned for a soft landing," said Jeff Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "Inventories and expenses are very tight."
And though retailers are generally an optimistic lot, Mr. Baum said, they should remain wary. He said two of the three leading indicators he uses to determine future consumer spending patterns -- average hourly wage growth and consumer installment debt as a percentage of disposable income -- were signaling caution. Wage growth has been flat through June, while consumer installment debt is very high.
"We think the consumer is going to be pretty stingy for the rest of the year," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China to Keep Coast Areas' Special Status

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, July 6

 BODY:
After months of rumors and speculation, Shanghai's Mayor made an announcement today that amounts to a vote to keep promises to foreign investors and not to yield to demands for equality from investment-starved inland areas.
Mayor Xu Kuangdi, smiling broadly as he addressed a room full of reporters, said that after long political debate in Beijing, China's leaders had decided not to revoke the preferential tax status given to East Shanghai, one of China's fastest-growing development zones and a barometer of the nation's efforts to modernize industry. 
 Until a few years ago, East Shanghai was a vast area of marsh and farmland, perhaps best known for having produced the gangster who dominated the Shanghai underworld in the 1920's and 30's, Du Yuesheng. Just across the river from downtown Shanghai, East Shanghai can be roughly compared geographically to Brooklyn a century ago, in the years after the first bridge connected it to Manhattan.
Known here as Pudong, meaning "east of the Huangpu River," East Shanghai was chosen by the city's leaders in 1990 as an area that if it attracted enough foreign investment could help them realize their hopes of again making Shanghai the international trading and finance center it once was.
With the city's downtown area too crowded for new manufacturing or office space, East Shanghai provided an alternative that is close and free of congestion and traffic. In the area along the east side of the city's waterfront, a new financial center was planned as a home for the Shanghai Securities Exchange and the main branches of every major Chinese bank.
Western companies were skeptical at first. But $3 billion of Government spending, in five years, has produced two major bridges, four shipping wharves, a complex of roads and a number of high-rise buildings, as well as water, electric and sewage plants. A new airport is also under construction.
More than 3,000 companies have committed $7 billion in investment since the special zone was opened in 1990, according to the East Shanghai New Area administration and information office. Although some of the 100 foreign companies that have begun operating in East Shanghai complain about high land prices and insufficient electricity, many people are deeply impressed by the amount of construction that has already been accomplished.
One of the prime attractions for foreign companies is the reduced tax rate. The standard corporate tax for foreign-financed enterprises in Shanghai is 33 percent of profit, but in East Shanghai the rate is 15 percent. Moreover, taxes are forgiven for the first two years of profitability, and only half -- 7.5 percent -- is due in the third, fourth and fifth years of profitability.
Earlier this year, as political debate in Beijing included more and more talk of the need to share wealth with China's poorer inland provinces, senior leaders began speaking about "adjusting" tax rates in special economic zones, including East Shanghai.
Although it was not clear what adjusting meant, some businessmen feared that corporate income-tax breaks might go the way of the former exemptions from duty on cars imported through East Shanghai; the exemption was abruptly dropped in 1993.
Last month, before the new decision was announced, Fan Zonglin of the East Shanghai administration and information office explained why corporate taxes might have to be rejiggered.
"The central Government wants to have a fairer tax policy," Mr. Fan said. "Other areas complained about special economic zones. There is a need to balance different areas in the country."
For now, at least, such concerns seem to have taken a backseat to the need to keep promises to foreign investors.
Mr. Xu said specifically that corporate income-tax rates would not change, at least for five years, either in East Shanghai or in China's other special economic zones.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Remains Little Changed After Interest Rate Cut by Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was little changed against most major currencies yesterday after the Federal Reserve trimmed interest rates for the first time in almost three years.
Lower rates often weigh on the dollar by making United States deposits less attractive, but because the Fed's quarter-point cut had been anticipated by many investors, the reaction of the dollar was muted. 
 "A cut was certainly priced in," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "I don't think the interest rate differential shifted enough to prompt a global re-evaluation of the dollar."
The policy-making committee of the Fed cut the Federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 5.75 percent from 6.0 percent.
In late New York trading, the dollar was at 84.96 Japanese yen, up from 84.85 yen late Wednesday. It was at 1.3787 German marks, little changed from 1.3794 marks, and 4.8236 French francs, down from 4.8242 francs.
The French central bank also made a quarter-point cut in a key interest rate yesterday, cutting to 7.25 percent the 5-to-10-day bank credit, which establishes the ceiling for money market rates. The move was seen as a response to the economic package announced by the Government of President Jacques Chirac on June 22.
The Bank of Canada also cut its key overnight lending rate by a quarter-point.
With the Fed's committee meeting behind them, traders said they would focus on employment figures being released today for further clues on the strength of the economy and the outlook for future rate moves.
The Fed's rate cut was the first since September 1992, and comes after seven rate increases over the last 17 months.
Jeffrey Yu, chief currency dealer at Sanwa Bank in New York, said the quarter-point cut "is very neutral."
"It just says to the market that they're aware of the slowdown in the economy," he said.
The first test of the wisdom of the Fed's action could come tomorrow, when the Government releases unemployment figures for June, traders said.
The United States economy lost 101,000 jobs in May and 7,000 in April, fostering speculation the economy was heading for a recession. "If there's continuing weakness in the employment numbers people will make noises about more cuts down the road," Mr. Yu said.

HEADLINE: This Time, the Fed Trails the Market

 BODY:
The bankers who set loan and deposit rates and the investors who buy and sell Treasury bonds apparently concluded months ago that the risk of an overheated economy was fading and higher interest rates were no longer needed to protect them against inflation. The Federal Reserve waited until yesterday to ratify that thinking with its first cut in the Federal funds rate after a yearlong series of increases. Many rates that directly affect consumers had already fallen in anticipation of the move, and analysts say long-term rates are not likely to fall further soon, though short-term rates may drop. Articles, pages A1 and D4.

HEADLINE: Grade Inflation Demeans Good Students

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Congratulations to college administrators ("In a Change of Policy, and Heart, Colleges Join Fight Against Inflated Grades," news article, July 4) who are finally recognizing that grade inflation can only be curbed by policy supported from the top. 
 In my years of teaching at Boston University's School of Management, I refused to lie to students, and like it or not, B-plus or even B class averages are lies. Grade inflation not only constitutes false promises to students whose work is average or inferior, but it also demeans the accomplishments of students who truly excel.
Professors award high grades most often, I believe, to avoid having to deal with angry and self-righteous students and their parents. Over my strong objections one semester, the chairman of my department changed a student's F (32 out of a possible 105 points) to a passing grade. The justification? "Both of his parents are lawyers."
That student now holds the same degree as his peers who earned it.
 
JANET W. WOHLBERG
Boston, July 4, 1995

HEADLINE: Must AIDS Infants Be Punished Too?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was disheartening to read of Jesse Helms's views of the victims of AIDS and his efforts to cut funds to the Ryan White Care Act of 1990 (news article, July 5). As medical director of a clinic for H.I.V.-positive children funded by the Ryan White Care Act, I see daily the positive impact these funds have on the lives of children with H.I.V./AIDS. 
 Ryan White funds help us provide H.I.V.-positive children with comprehensive medical and psychosocial services. The children have access to their doctor 24 hours a day, and we are able to decrease emergency room visits and hospitalization for them.
Senator Helms contends that funds should be cut because AIDS sufferers are responsible for their disease due to "deliberate, disgusting, revolting conduct."
Does he believe that these children are responsible for their disease through the act of being born, and therefore should suffer?
No one asks to be infected with the virus that causes AIDS. Most of the mothers of the children in my program were infected unknowingly through heterosexual sex and did not find out they were H.I.V.-infected until they were pregnant.
AIDS is the leading cause of death in children 1 to 4 years old in New York City. To consider cutting funds to such a devastating public health problem is not only heartless but also economically foolish. Without primary care programs these children will develop life-threatening infections, which could be easily prevented with medications.
I invite Mr. Helms to visit my program and see firsthand how the Ryan White dollars are being spent to improve the lives of these children.
 
JILL STOLLER, M.D.
Medical Director
Pediatric Consultation Service
Jacobi Medical Center
Bronx, July 5, 1995

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Art for Profit
Buying art purely as an investment is an idea commonly frowned upon in the art world today. But 21 years ago, when the British Rail Pension Fund decided to invest 2.9 percent of its assets in Impressionist and Old Master paintings, Old Master drawings, Chinese and European works of art and antiquities, it was a downright scandal.
It was considered outrageous that railroad workers' money was being invested in something as elitist as art, and Sotheby's, the pension fund's adviser, was thought to have a conflict of interest because most of the art was bought at auction. 
 Over eight years, the pension fund paid about $64 million for 2,245 items. The fund later explained that its decision to invest in art was caused by the poor economic conditions at the time; it said that in addition to 30 percent annual inflation, "the London Stock Market had fallen heavily, creating huge losses on many investment portfolios; the property market had collapsed; many leading financial institutions were overstretched, and exchange controls and a higher dollar premium made it difficult to diversify overseas."
In 1987, British Rail began to sell its collections through Sotheby's. It has been auctioning slowly, and the latest sale was on Wednesday in London.
A group of 27 Old Master paintings, which were part of Sotheby's main Old Master paintings sale, performed well. They brought $8.2 million, above the auction house's $7.2 million top estimate. David Adams, who oversees the pension fund's investments, said he estimates that the sale performed at "inflation plus 3 percent, a shade under the average profits from our sales." But the results were about what was expected, he added, given the quality of the works and the current market.
Included in the auction were works that Old Master experts say reflect the safe buying patterns of the pension fund. Acquiring works for investment purposes, the fund's art experts were not adventurous, seeking paintings they thought would remain fashionable.
The results, on the whole, were successful. The biggest surprise was the price for Salomon van Ruysdael's "Haarlem 1600-1670" (1659), a dreamy scene of ships on the Waal River, which Sotheby's had estimated would sell for $318,000 to $477,000. Robert Noortman, a London dealer, bought it for $2.4 million. The price made a tidy profit for the fund, which paid only $406,000 for it in 1978 at a Sotheby's sale in Amsterdam. Another work that did exceptionally well was Peter Paul Rubens and Jan Bruegel the Younger's "Landscape With Pan and Syrinx" (1615), which sold to an unidentified buyer for $1.1 million. Sotheby's high estimate was $795,000.
But most of the works brought prices around their estimates and two works failed to sell. Even so, prices were far above what the pension fund had paid. "The Tiepolo Family," for example, an unfinished portrait whose estimate was $795,000 to $1.1 million, sold for $967,000. Despite some questions about attribution (some experts believe it was done by the younger Tiepolo brother, Lorenzo; others, including Sotheby's, attribute it to Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo), the work proved a good investment. The pension fund paid $175,000 for it in 1976 at Sotheby's in London.
The pension fund still has about a quarter of its collection. "Some antiquities and works of art are likely to be sold within the next year," Mr. Adams said. It still owns many Old Master paintings, about two sales' worth, one of which Mr. Adams said may take place at Sotheby's in New York in January.
 
The Tate Project
 The Tate Gallery in London is inching closer to realizing its goal of transforming the 100,000-square-foot Bankside Power Station on the South Bank of the Thames into the Tate Gallery of Modern Art. Stephen Dorrell, Britain's National Heritage secretary, has announced that the Tate is among the 83 applicants (out of 525) being seriously considered for a grant from the Millennium Fund, which is supported by Britain's new national lottery. The Tate could receive about $80 million, a nice start to raising the nearly $168.5 million needed for the new museum.
But a grant from the Millennium Fund is not a windfall without strings: the museum would be required to match the $80 million. Not surprisingly, Nicholas Serota, the Tate's director, said he was talking to several potential donors.
"Most of the projects short-listed by the Millennium Fund were not arts but environmental ones," Mr. Serota said. But in many ways, the new Tate reflects aspects of both categories. The first national gallery to be built in Britain since the 19th century and London's first modern art museum, the project is also expected to help revitalize the run-down borough of Southwark. A marketing survey concluded that the new museum would attract about two million visitors a year and create about 2,400 new jobs.
The completion of Shakespeare's Globe Theater, which is to open next July next door to the new Tate, will also help revitalize the area. And the Manhattan Loft Company, a London-based developer, recently announced plans to convert a warehouse about 200 yards from the Tate into loftlike apartments.
 
A President Is Named
 As the Los Angeles County Museum of Art continues to search for a director, it has decided to take the same route as the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York: it has named a president and chief executive officer to work alongside the director. Andrea L. Rich, the executive vice chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles, will fill the new post Nov. 1.
Her job will primarily be administration and raising money, leaving the curatorial responsibilities exclusively to the director. Museum officials hope the director's job, which has been vacant 22 months, will look more attractive to candidates now that the administrative and fund-raising tasks will be someone else's responsibility.

HEADLINE: U.S. TO ESTABLISH FULL HANOI LINKS, TOP OFFICIALS SAY

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Twenty years after the war in Vietnam ended, President Clinton has concluded that the time has come to establish full diplomatic relations with the former enemy and may announce the decision as early as next week, senior Administration officials said today.
The President has not yet signed a formal order granting Vietnam full diplomatic recognition, which would be the United States' most important step towards burying the bitterness of the Vietnam War. But Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, is completing a draft order recommending the policy change, which is expected to be presented to the President within the next few days. 
 In preparation for the announcement, the White House has drawn up a list of leading lawmakers and foreign leaders who will be informed as soon as the President makes his formal decision. White House officials have also begun to prepare arguments that can be used to explain why the move is a necessary step in a four-year process begun by the Bush Administration to provide the fullest possible accounting of Americans missing in the Vietnam War.
The Vietnamese Government has not yet been informed of the President's intentions, a senior Administration official said. Nor has the White House chosen a candidate to become the first United States Ambassador to Hanoi.
The move to establish full diplomatic relations, which has been endorsed by Mr. Clinton's senior diplomatic, military, economic and political advisers, comes after more than a year of debate within the Administration on whether Vietnam has cooperated fully in determining the fate of 1,619 United States service personnel who are still listed officially as missing in the war.
Indeed, The Administration has been steadily moving toward the decision for months, approving quiet visits aimed at resolving problems and broadening ties between Washington and Hanoi.
Diplomatic relations between the two countries will have a direct effect on American companies by allowing them to receive United States-sponsored financing and insurance that will help them do business in Vietnam.
Administration officials acknowledge that establishing full diplomatic relations with Vietnam would be a reward for its cooperation with the United States in releasing documents about missing servicemen and returning the remains of servicemen killed in Vietnam.
Moreover, they said, they hope increased contact with the Hanoi Government may make the Vietnamese even more forthcoming.
"We see this as the most effective way to meet our priority of getting the fullest possible accounting of those Americans missing from the Vietnam era," said one Administration official involved in the process. "Our experience shows that when you cooperate with Vietnam, you get more concrete results than if you just hold them at arm's length."
In establishing relations with Vietnam, Mr. Clinton will inevitably face intense opposition from conservatives and veterans groups, who contend that such a move would betray his past promises to the families of missing servicemen and Vietnam veterans.
Mr. Clinton also faced criticism when he decided in February 1994 to lift the 19-year-old trade embargo on Vietnam. But that response proved politically manageable and quickly died down -- particularly because the move was widely seen as advancing United States business interests in Southeast Asia.
There was even less political fallout when Mr. Clinton opened low-level diplomatic relations with Vietnam shortly afterward, allowing an official representative of Hanoi to open an office in Washington.
There continue to be political risks for a President who agonized 26 years ago over avoiding service in a war he said he "opposed and despised." In recent weeks, however, White House aides have concluded that these risks are outweighed by the fact that there may be a higher political price to pay if he refuses to establish relations.
Mr. Clinton has received support on the issue from three decorated war veterans in the Senate -- John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat; John McCain, the Arizona Republican, and Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat.
The three senators are poised to introduce an amendment to the State Department Authorization Bill next week urging that the United States grant Vietnam full diplomatic recognition, a nonbinding resolution that is expected to pass. A McCain-Kerry resolution calling for an end to the trade embargo was approved in a bipartisan 62-to-38 vote in January 1994, paving the way for Mr. Clinton to lift the embargo the following month.
On the other hand, two Republicans -- Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, and Senator Robert Smith of New Hampshire -- plan to introduce an amendment to the same legislation that would withhold financing for an Embassy in Vietnam.
Senator Dole, the leading Republican candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, is scheduled to be the main speaker later this summer at the annual meeting of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and Missing in Southeast Asia, a group that rejects the Administration's assertions that Vietnam is cooperating on the issue.
As a candidate for President, Mr. Clinton told the national convention of the American Legion in 1992 that he would not move toward establishing relations until he received the fullest possible accounting of Americans missing in action.
When he formally announces his decision, the President is likely to praise Vietnam's increasing cooperation over the years. He gave a preview in remarks on Memorial Day while presenting a new postage stamp commemorating prisoners of war and those missing in action in Vietnam. At that time he said Hanoi had been more cooperative "than ever before." Of the effort to account for the missing, he said, "There is nothing like it in all the history of warfare."
Setting up ties wit Vietnam may make it possible for Secretary of State Warren Christopher to visit Vietnam when he travels to Asia at the end of the month to meet with foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Vietnam is to join the group at this meeting, and Mr. Christopher wants to have the matter settled by then.
If Mr. Christopher then travels to Vietnam, he will be the first Secretary of State to visit the country since the American-backed Government in Saigon fell to Communist forces in 1975.
Publicly, Administration officials emphasized that Mr. Clinton had still not decided whether to establish relations, but was poised to make a decision soon. There is a reluctance to make such an announcement until veterans' groups and others opposed to the decision have been briefed.
"This is now a question that will shortly be before the President," the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said today.
Mr. Burns said the Administration was still assessing new documents handed over recently by Hanoi concerning missing American servicemen. Last week the Defense Department called the recent case of documents the most informative to date on the outstanding cases.
 But those who advocate recognition have pushed Mr. Clinton to announce it as soon as possible, and not wait until the 1996 Presidential campaign gets any closer. Some of these advisers have also argued that Mr. Clinton should get ahead of the issue by acting before the Senate takes up the issue on the floor next week.

HEADLINE: Nikkei Surges On Rates News

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 7

 BODY:
Stocks surged today after the Bank of Japan said that it would push short-term interest rates lower in an effort to revive the economy.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 956.19 points, or 6.27 percent, at 16,213.08. Trading was heavy. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 426.45 points, or 2.88 percent. 
 "It's an incredible market, stronger than I expected," said Shigeru Akiba, director of yen equity trading at UBS Securities.
Expectations of lower interest rates also helped the dollar surge against the yen. In late Asian trading, it was quoted at 85.70 yen, up from 84.96 in late New York trading on Thursady. The rise in the dollar prompted buying of shares of auto and electronics exporters, which led the stock market higher, traders said.
A weaker yen makes Japanese exports less expensive abroad.
Shares of export companies was also helped by optimism that lower interest rates in the United States would lead to more demand for goods from Japanese exporters.

HEADLINE: Japan, France and Canada Join the Assault on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, July 7

 BODY:
The Japanese central bank announced today that it would push interest rates lower in an effort to shore up the nation's faltering economy.
The Bank of Japan said it would let the overnight call rate, the rate for overnight loans between banks, fall below the discount rate. But the central bank said it had no plans to lower the discount rate, which is already at a record low of 1 percent. 
 Japanese stocks and bonds soared after the announcement as traders saw it as a sign that a rate cut was imminent.
"This is probably just a warm-up for a discount rate cut," said Chris Calderwood, an economist at BZW Securities here.
In April, the Bank of Japan made a similar announcement just before it cut the discount rate.
The move came after a wave of rate cuts on Thursday in Europe and North America. Both the French and Danish central banks cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point.
And after the Federal Reserve cut its target for the Federal fund rates to 5.75 percent, from 6 percent, the Bank of Canada followed suit, lowering the upper end of its overnight lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 7.25 percent. Some banks in the United States and Canada lowered their prime rate.
But Kunio Kojima, a director of the Bank of Japan, said today that the announcement was unrelated to the Federal Reserve's rate cut.
"Today's decision is not intended to prepare for a cut in the discount rate," Mr. Kojima added.
After announcing its change in monetary policy, the central bank added 300 billion yen, or $3.52 billion, to the banking system, pushing down the overnight loan rate. The rate fell as low as 0.85 percent, brokers said.
Lower interest rates could provide a jump-start to Japan's sluggish economy, analysts said.
"It's not the answer to everything but it's a welcome development," Mr. Calderwood at BZW Securities said. "It's not going to change the currency much and it's not going to change the structural problems that plaque the Japanese economy. But it's just a pain killer that makes the adjustment easier."
While the Bank of Japan said in its statement that it still saw forces that support a recovery, the economy was "somewhat at a standstill."
In France, the nation's newly independent central bank on Thursday lowered the 5-to-10-day bank credit, which sets the ceiling for money market rates to 7.25 percent from 7.50 percent.
It was the second slight easing in French monetary policy since the May presidential elections and was widely interpreted as a response to the package of spending cuts, tax increases and steps to increase employment that the Government of President Jacques Chirac announced on June 22.
The new rate cut was foreshadowed earlier in the week by the governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, who in an interview with the newspaper Le Monde gave a cautious welcome to the Government's mini-budget. His statement also signaled an end to the disagreement that surfaced between Mr. Trichet and Mr. Chirac during the presidential campaign, when Mr. Chirac seemed prepared to abandon France's traditional policy of keeping the franc in lock-step with the German mark to reduce inflation and reinforce its political alliance with Germany.

HEADLINE: Sales Tax Is Wrong Bailout for Orange County

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Orange County's Threat to Us All" (editorial, July 2) chided the voters of California's Orange County ("a very wealthy area") with "arrogance" because they rejected an increase in the sales tax to 8.25 percent. The increase was the centerpiece of a plan making up for losses incurred by County Treasurer Robert Citron's rogue trading in the derivatives market. You explained that the "outrageous" outcome of this vote was due to an "anti-tax ideology," which threatens "the very concept of government as a shared enterprise with benefits for all." 
 Political economists would view the matter differently. Sales taxes are the most regressive taxes yet devised: only the relatively well-to-do pay income and real estate taxes, but even the poorest of the poor have to pay sales taxes. Worse still, sales taxes bite further into the incomes of the poor because they spend a greater portion of their incomes on items subject to sales tax.
The only virtue of the sales tax is that it's easy to collect. Its appeal to those who view government as an equitable enterprise is nil.
As it happens, New York City (also "a very wealthy area") went through an experience similar to Orange County's 20 years ago. New York's bankruptcy was averted by, strange to say, an increase in the sales tax.
Did the voters of New York City humbly vote for this increase? No, it was imposed upon them by their State Legislature.
Would the voters of New York City have approved it if they'd been allowed to vote on it? I think not.
 
ROLLINS MAXWELL
New York, July 2, 1995

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unemployment Falls As Job Market Grows
The job market showed surprising strength in June as employers added 215,000 payroll jobs, and the unemployment rate eased to 5.6 percent. 
 Still, there were pockets of weakness. Factory jobs dropped 40,000, the third straight sizable decline. Such unevenness blunted the second-guessing by some analysts of the Federal Reserve's decision Thursday to cut short-term interest rates. [Page 1.]
 
By a quirk of the calendar, the Fed's Open Market Committee on Thursday missed knowing by a few hours the details of the unemployment report. [36.]
 
Employment figures for the New York-New Jersey region were stagnant. The jobless rate for New York State fell to 5.9 percent, and the City's slipped to 8.1 percent. New Jersey's rate edged up to 6.6 percent. [36.]
 
Dow Quickly Tops Milestone, Jumps 146.63 for the Week
Just two days after topping 4,600, the Dow industrials soared past 4,700, as the market enjoyed its best week since last August. The average closed at 4,702.73, up 38.73 points for the day and 146.63 points for the week. Technology and banking stocks rose. [37.]
 
The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 6.52 percent, from 6.49 percent, as some traders took profits. Many doubted the Fed would cut interest rates again soon. [46.]
 
Stocks Surge in Japan
Tokyo stock prices jumped 6.3 percent, with the Nikkei index closing at 16,213.08. The market was lifted by an unexpected cut in interest rates and investor hopes for stronger measures to revive the economy. [35.]
 
Mexican Stocks Rise Again
The Mexican stock market has regained most of the ground it lost after the peso devaluation in December. Some big international funds are buying again, although stock values in dollar terms are still deflated. [34.]
 
I.B.M. Forms New Division
I.B.M. said it would create a division responsible for expanding the company's offerings to consumers, bringing multimedia computers and desktop software under one roof. The company's shares traded above $100 for the first time in nearly three years, reaching $100.625 before closing at $99.50, up 62.5 cents. [34.]
 
Music Channel Plan Dropped
A tentative plan to start a rival music cable channel to MTV has been dropped by five of the biggest music companies, including Time Warner, Sony, and Thorn EMI. The decision was attributed in part to the dismissal of Robert Morgado as chairman of Warner Music. He was seen as the chief mover behind the plan. [36.]
 
Coors Extends Benefits
Coors Brewing will offer full benefits to the unmarried domestic partners of employees, whether gay or straight. The new policy allows employees to add unmarried, live-in partners to health and life insurance policies, pensions and other benefits. [34.]
 
Nextel Approves McCaw Stake
Nextel shareholders approved a $1.1 billion investment by Craig McCaw of cellular fame and his family to buy wireless licenses from Motorola and a merger with Onecomm. [35.]
 
Greenpeace Shows Its Reach
Greenpeace won a major victory when it got Royal Dutch/Shell to drop its plan to sink an old oil platform in the North Atlantic. The scope of the Shell campaign also reflects the financial strength of the group. In two months it spent more than $1 million on communications and equipment, including chartered boats and helicopters. [3.]
 
Latin America Tied to Cuba
Latin America has increasingly ignored the U.S. trade embargo of Cuba. Mexico is Cuba's largest foreign investor, and the Americas supply half of Cuba's imports and a quarter of the island's foreign tourists. [1.]
 
Coffee Up on Export Limit
Coffee prices rose on signs that Brazil was set to limit exports as part of an effort by Latin American producers to force prices higher. On the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, the contract for September delivery jumped 8.8 cents, to $1.2985 a pound. [43.]

HEADLINE: Rate Setters Miss Data, Just Barely

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
While Federal Reserve officials were meeting Thursday morning to decide whether to cut short-term interest rates, another agency was quietly putting the finishing touches on the most important set of monthly economic figures published by the Government.
By a quirk of the calendar, the central bank's Open Market Committee missed knowing by a few hours that the Labor Department would report today that employers' payrolls expanded by 215,000 in June and that the unemployment rate edged lower. 
 Despite the Fed's likely frustration, officials insist that no effort was made to depart from normal practice. This meant that the Bureau of Labor Statistics sent the report in midafternoon by encrypted fax to the Council of Economic Advisers, which relayed the information to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, alone. The Fed's announcement was made at 2:15.
"They would not have seen these data," Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said flatly this morning. And if the Fed had tried to get an early peek, the B.L.S. would have refused to respond or even accept a call on the subject, she said. It is all part of jealously guarding the integrity of the statistical system, to insure that market participants and others do not take advantage of advance information for political or financial gain.
There was one exception. The staffs of both the Fed and the Labor Department have more leeway about sharing preliminary data. Sometime on Wednesday, Fed economists were given partial figures, on employment in manufacturing, mining and utilities.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Rates Little Changed in Region

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
While the national job market showed signs of strength yesterday, employment figures for the New York-New Jersey region were largely stagnant.
The unemployment rate for New York State fell to 5.9 percent in June from 6.3 percent in May. But New Jersey's unemployment rate rose to 6.6 percent from 6.5 percent, and New York City's rate slipped to 8.1 percent from 8.2 percent. The national rate fell to 5.6 percent, from 5.7 percent. The number of people on payrolls remained steady in both states. 
 John L. Wieting, the new regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor, said the two states continued in a holding pattern as they lagged behind the national economic recovery. But he also saw some cause for optimism.
"While the economy in New York and New Jersey isn't moving ahead, there aren't any signs either of further weakening," Mr. Wieting (pronounced WEE-ting) said. "There were fears that a slowdown in the national picture, such as occurred in the first two months of the second quarter, might have serious adverse impacts here. And I think that it's somewhat of a silver lining that we didn't see any further weakening of the situation."
Employment figures for Connecticut were not available yesterday. It is not among the 11 states for which the Labor Department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month.
Mr. Wieting noted that the 5.9 percent unemployment rate in New York State in June returned the state to where it was at the beginning of the year.
And, he added, the downward movement reflected in the latest rate was an indication of lower labor market activity, meaning that fewer New York State residents were seeking jobs.
"There was no growth in the number of employed," he said. The number was 7.9 million in June, about what it has been in recent months.
Similarly, in New Jersey, the number of employed held steady at 3.9 million.
In New York City, he said, "you've got an economy that is basically flat, and it's not moving ahead."
"While the nation has to date recovered well more than the jobs it lost during the last recession, in this region we haven't made up the losses that we saw."
Mr. Wieting said that the biggest industries in the region, like financial services and particularly banking, were still going through restructuring and consolidation. And, he added, manufacturing jobs are still being lost.
Mr. Wieting said the number of employed New York City residents totaled 2.9 million in June. That is about the same number as has prevailed through the first half of 1995.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Leading Academic Hospital, Squeaking by, Seeks Merger

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Convinced that it cannot survive on its own in a medical marketplace racked by budget cuts and dominated by managed care, Presbyterian Hospital, one of the city's leading academic hospitals, is actively looking to merge with another medical center.
Executives at Presbyterian, the hospital at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, have begun discussions with two other leading centers, the New York Hospital and New York University Hospital, and hope to cement a partnership within a year, said Dr. William Speck, President of Presbyterian. 
 Presbyterian officials say the affiliation is critical because despite an aggressive campaign to hold down costs, they are barely getting by. And they face further financial troubles as they struggle with Medicare cuts and the rise of competition brought on by managed care.
Even as the hospital courts a partner, the equally acclaimed medical school affiliated with it for the last 65 years, Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, is independently considering joining with another school. Doctor Herbert Pardes, dean of the medical school, says it is facing economic pressures of its own, partly as a result of the hospital's problems. Medical schools are heavily subsidized by payments from their allied teaching hospitals, and when an academic hospital's revenues are threatened, programs at its medical school are often early casualties.
These changes reflect increasing turmoil in a hospital industry desperately trying to cope with demands for cheaper, more efficient care. Those demanding the changes are Federal and state governments, insurance companies and, most important, the increasingly powerful health maintenance organizations that are spreading across the country.
The mergers of major hospitals in New York would mirror a trend in other cities, where health maintenance organizations have gained a significant market share. It would also fulfill the predictions of health economists who have long argued that New York City has too many hospital beds.
Dr. Speck said that merging two hospitals could result in great savings. They would be able to consolidate departments duplicated at both centers, for example, ending up with a cardiology department at one of the hospitals and a neurosurgery department at the other.
Billing, purchasing and laundry service could be combined as well, he said.
These changes are likely to lead to some layoffs, continuing a decline in the city's health care industry, which has been one of its most vital.
"This year," Dr. Speck said, "we realized that in order to compete, our only acceptable option was to merge with another academic health care center. And we've been talking to everyone who would listen."

 Officials of the two possible partners acknowledged that there were preliminary discussions but declined to give details.
Presbyterian is considering this radical change even though it has undertaken a drastic and largely successful program to reorganize and streamline its operations over the last two years, as a way to improve its perennially precarious financial picture.
Its executives have dramatically decreased the time patients spend in the hospital, so much so that the average maternity patient now stays only 36 hours, far less time than at most New York City hospitals. And with shorter stays, it has been able to eliminate more than one-third of its 1,000 hospital beds.
At the same time, Presbyterian has significantly broadened its patient base. It has forged relationships with a half-dozen community hospitals in the suburbs, and allied itself with community medical groups as well as foreign-trained primary-care doctors practicing in Harlem and Washington Heights. .
But the financial gains of these moves have been offset by huge cuts in Medicaid and the state budget, as well as the uncertainty of funding from Medicare and from the National Institutes of Health, the Federal agency that finances major medical research projects. Revenues have also been hurt by the unexpectedly swift rise of H.M.O.'s, which demand deep discounts from hospitals for care.
"If the Medicare cuts and market changes are as great as we anticipate," Dr. Speck said, "simple re-engineering will not be enough. We've closed beds and changed from R.N.'s to the less expensive L.P.N.'s, and we think if we don't do anything beyond that we couldn't compete on cost and would be dead in the water." R.N.'s are registered nurses, and L.P.N.'s are licensed practical nurses.
By all accounts, mergers of prestigious hospitals are likely to be fraught with internal political peril. It would be hard to combine neurosurgery departments, for example, when each considers itself among the best in the city.
The basic problem for Presbyterian as well as the other academic centers in New York is that they are expensive places to care for the average patient. They have vast arsenals of advanced medical machines that are costly to maintain, and they have traditionally charged patients higher prices to subsidize the teaching and research they regard as essential to their mission.
The sophisticated technology -- from positron emission scanners to molecular genetics labs -- is largely irrelevant to the care of a patient who has simple pneumonia. And insurers, particularly H.M.O.'s, have little interest in subsidizing all the equipment.
So the region's H.M.O.'s are now demanding deep discounts from the academic centers. And many are referring their patients to smaller, cheaper hospitals with lower overhead.
On top of problems that span the industry, Columbia-Presbyterian must overcome the fact that it is located in a poor neighborhood in Washington Heights. Its principal competitors in New York City -- New York Hospital, New York University Medical Center and Mount Sinai Medical Center -- all sit in neighborhoods filled with paying patients. But Presbyterian's location means that most local customers are covered by Medicaid or not covered at all. Moreover, many affluent patients are reluctant to go there.
As a result, Columbia-Presbyterian is disproportionately affected by the cuts in Medicaid and Medicare. Thirty-eight percent of Columbia-Presbyterian's patients are on Medicaid; it is the largest Medicaid provider in the state. Twenty-six percent of its patients are covered by Medicare; it is the second-largest Medicare provider in the country.
Doctors at Presbyterian and at the medical school say they are ambivalent about the aggressive campaign to establish financial stability for the future, complaining that their workloads have been expanded in the effort to hold down costs. Doctors-in-training who say they came to Columbia to learn cutting-edge medicine, express resentment at being sent to work at the community hospitals that are Columbia-Presbyterian's latest affiliates.
As a doctor who completed his training last month put it, "The primary concern is not how are we best going to train the next generation of internists, but how are we going to pay the bills?" He spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
Although Dr. Speck acknowledges that physicians now face a more rigorous workload, he says it is the price of survival, adding: "We're asking the housekeepers to sweep more floors and the dietary people to deliver more trays. Now it's the physicians' turn." He said that state regulations on how many hours a resident can work -- known as the Bell Commission laws -- might have to be bent to create greater efficiencies.
The academic centers that Dr. Speck has tried to woo are circumspect about the prospects.
Paul Macielak, vice president and vice provost of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said, "The medical center has had and continues to have discussions with Columbia-Presbyterian." But he added that the discussions were not about "formal mergers in the legalistic sense" but about other types of joint ventures and business relationships.
Theresa Bischoff, executive vice president and deputy provost of the New York University Medical Center, said: "In light of changes in the health care environment there are many conversations going on between various medical centers, including continuing discussions between Columbia-Presbyterian and N.Y.U."
Health economists have predicted that the struggle for survival over the next five years will result in numerous hospital closings in New York and that Columbia-Presbyterian might well number among the extinct.
But Dr. Speck insists that despite its financial problems, Presbyterian, in its new, more cost-effective incarnation, would make an attractive partner. .
"People look at our neighborhood and go 'yuck,' " he said. "But frankly, 500,000 people live here who have nowhere else to go, and if we can capture their business we can succeed."
