HEADLINE: Slide From Riches for Landlord in Happy Land Case

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The building housing the Happy Land Social Club, where 87 people died in a 1990 arson fire, was owned by Alexander DiLorenzo 3d, scion of a real estate empire that at one time put him in the same league as Donald Trump or other New York tycoons. But lawyers for the victims who filed suit over the tragedy, which was caused in part by conditions in the building, found Mr. DiLorenzo so deeply enmeshed in financial problems that they gave up on seeking damages from him.
 "If we had gone after DiLorenzo, we would have spent 5 or 10 years trying to to figure where his money was, or if there was any left," said Paul E. Bleifer, who represented the families of 17 of the victims. 
 The story of Mr. DiLorenzo, whose holdings were once valued at $1.2 billion but who is now mired in bankruptcy, is marked with a series of failed investments, foreclosures, tax problems and a string of lawsuits -- including one by his own brother and sister.
 While many details of his finances are unclear -- he and his lawyer declined to be interviewed -- it appears that his financial fall was precipitated by unsuccessful purchases of distressed buildings, large losses in the commodities market and the fallout from the recession.
 On Thursday, lawyers for the Happy Land victims and their families agreed to a $15.8 million settlement of all claims stemming from the fire in East Tremont, the Bronx. The settlement, providing an average of $163,000 for each family or injured victim, was far less than the total of $5 billion that they had originally sought, and a tiny amount compared to the awards in some other high-profile wrongful death cases.
 Although lawyers for the Happy Land plaintiffs said they were handicapped in many ways, one of the chief roadblocks in winning large damage awards was the dire financial condition of Mr. DiLorenzo, they said. "In the end, we had a gun to our heads," said Susan Karten, who represented five of the families. "We saw what was going on with DiLorenzo, and did what we could."
 In 1975, along with his brother and sister -- Marc and Lisa -- Mr. DiLorenzo inherited a portfolio of more than 200 New York City buildings and commercial lots from his father, the late Alexander DiLorenzo Jr. The elder Mr. DiLorenzo had assembled his holdings in a partnership with the late Sol Goldman, a developer.
 The properties included some of Manhattan's most valuable. The choicest were a parcel of land under the St. Moritz Hotel on Central Park South; other lots under prominent buildings on Wall Street, Madison Avenue and Fifth Avenue; and an entire block of Greek Revival brick houses facing Washington Square Park.
 Alexander DiLorenzo 3d, known as Alex, was named in his father's estate as head of the family real estate trust. He immediately set an eccentric course among the city's major landowners and investors, several people in the real estate industry said. As far back as 1990, one real-estate broker, speaking in an interview on condition of anonymity, summed it up: "Alex buys funny things."
 Mr. DiLorenzo's financial problems appear to have culminated on Aug. 20, 1993, when court records show that some real estate assets owned by himself and his family trust were ordered liquidated under an involuntary bankruptcy filing. That bankruptcy filing was cited by several of the lawyers for the Happy Land victims' families as their biggest impediment in collecting damages from Mr. DiLorenzo.
 The current status of Mr. DiLorenzo's finances was unclear yesterday, and he declined comment through his lawyer. "In view of ongoing proceedings, it would be inappropriate for Mr. Alexander DiLorenzo 3d or his counsel to make comment at this time," said his lawyer, Carl R. Hollander.
 Nor was it clear exactly what finally precipitated the bankruptcy case. But according to court records reaching back into the 1980's, and people in the real estate industry, Mr. DiLorenzo's financial problems began to accumulate long before the Happy Land fire.
 A private man, who has always sought to avoid publicity and rarely has socialized with others among New York's elite real estate families, Mr. DiLorenzo set a course soon after receiving his inheritance that diverged sharply from most other large real estate investors.
 Instead of investing in well-established and highly valuable Manhattan lots and buildings, as his father had, he bought block after block of fading apartment houses on Riverside Drive in Harlem, dozens of buildings in the Bronx and other properties in blighted sections of the city.
 From 1975 to 1985 -- a time when a real estate boom bestowed fortunes on others who invested in the most sought after areas of Manhattan -- Mr. DiLorenzo's newly acquired properties lanquished.
 Then, in October 1988, he was sued by his brother and sister, who sought to wrest control of 250 properties, which court papers at the time valued at $1.2 billion. The lawsuit charged him with "squandering" the family's holdings, and alleged that Mr. DiLorenzo had borrowed heavily against the trust's real estate to speculate in the commodities market. In one year, 1988, he had lost $21.8 million, according to financial records submitted in the lawsuit.
 The suit "goes so far as to claimed that Alex is pursuing a 'scorched earth policy,' " said the presiding judge in the case, Justice Harold Baer Jr. of State Supreme Court. But the judge refused to remove him as head of the family trust, and ordered the DiLorenzo siblings to work out the differences among themselves.
Since then, records in State Supreme Court, bankruptcy and other courts show that the problems facing Mr. DiLorenzo have multiplied.
 In 1991, hurt by a deep recession in the New York City real estate market, he and the DiLorenzo family trust were sued in a foreclosure proceeding by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for dealing with the assets of failed thrift institutions.
 At the time, Resolution Trust and the B.R.T. Realty Trust Company, based in Great Neck, held a $68 million mortgage on properties controlled by Mr. DiLorenzo, who had missed three monthly payments. The outcome of the 1991 foreclosure suit could not be determined last night.
 Other legal problems followed, leaving the court records replete with judgments against Mr. DiLorenzo for failure to pay his lawyers and creditors, to make timely payment of mortgage loans and to pay his taxes. From 1989 to 1992, the judgments totaled over $3 million.
 Lawyers representing the Happy Land fire victims said yesterday that they had been unable to sort through the complexities of Mr. DiLorenzo's financial problems, but had concluded that they were so severe that trying to collect damages from him would have been futile.
 Even determining what lawyers have represented Mr. DiLorenzo in his various legal tussles has proved daunting, they said.
 One of the lawyers for the victims, Jay Weinstein, said, "DiLorenzo is someone who goes through more lawyers in a week than I go through underwear."

HEADLINE: PAYROLLS SWELLED BY 215,000 IN JUNE; JOBLESS RATE FELL

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The job market perked up in June as employers added 215,000 payroll jobs while the unemployment rate edged down slightly to 5.6 percent, the Labor Department reported today.
Despite a stronger overall performance than most analysts expected, there were some pockets of weakness. Factory jobs -- which tend to be better paying than most -- dropped 40,000, the third straight sizable decline. Such unevenness blunted the second-guessing by some analysts and investors of the Federal Reserve's decision on Thursday to reverse course and cut short-term interest rates for the first time since 1992. The Fed acted before it was fully aware of the latest report, which suggested that the current economic slowdown is unlikely to turn into a recession. 
 Still, many economists say they expect the Fed to cut rates further, though not necessarily right away.
"It is incumbent on the Fed to support confidence of consumers who retain jobs so that spending does not start to slip again," said Rosanne M. Cahn, an economist at CS First Boston in New York. "Another interest rate cut will be part of the process."
Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan, apparently responding to the Fed's quarter-point cut, trimmed its own already low short-term interest rates and joined with the United States in a coordinated effort to support the dollar on the world's currency markets. [Page 17.]
Lower American rates tend to make the dollar less attractive. And without a comparable move by Tokyo, they would have tended to push the yen still higher, making Japanese goods more expensive in world markets.
The dollar surged, as did stock markets in this country, but interest rates moved modestly higher as some traders concluded that another rate cut was not imminent at the Fed's next rate-setting meeting in August.
The White House called the labor-market report, which included revived growth in the dominant services sector, "a welcome sign" that the economy's abrupt slackening this spring will not worsen.
"While too many working families are still struggling, the current economic slowdown is likely to be temporary," Joseph E. Stiglitz, recently elevated to chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement.
The Government's report late this month on total output of goods and services is expected to show scarcely any economic growth -- and possibly a slight decline -- for the quarter that ended last week. Gross domestic product advanced at a 2.7 percent annual rate in the first three months of 1995 and at a 5.1 percent rate in the final quarter of 1994 -- the kind of torrid growth the Fed had in mind when it engineered a series of interest rate increases over the last 18 months to forestall inflation.
But private analysts tend to agree with the Clinton Administration that the economy may have already bottomed out, with excess inventories now pared enough to spark resumed growth.
"We've probably already moved out of the decelerating phase of the expansion and are back into moderate growth," said Joel L. Naroff, senior vice president and chief economist at First Fidelity Bancorporation in Philadelphia.
In California, where the job market improved significantly last month, John O. Wilson, chief economist for the Bank of America, agreed, predicting a 2 percent growth rate for the nation in the second half of the year. The jobless rate in California retreated to 7.6 percent in June from 8.5 percent in May.
The expansion of payrolls by 215,000 in June was about twice that of the consensus prediction and was in addition to upward revisions for both April and May that showed the job market had not been as weak this spring as had been thought at the time.
May's job shrinkage is now put at 46,000 instead of 101,000, while April's 7,000 decline was transformed into a gain of 8,000.
On the other hand, the June survey period was later in the month than is typical, and the additional time to capture workers in the statistical net swelled the gain by 50,000 to 100,000, according to a rough estimate by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
After two months of relatively sluggish growth, service jobs climbed 114,000 to move back into line with the trend during the current business expansion. The amusement and recreation sector was particularly strong, but sizable gains were also posted in engineering and management services and in health services.
Construction, aided by drier weather, added 42,000 jobs, partly recouping declines in April and May, but the temporary help category showed little change for a second straight month and remained down by 57,000 since February. State and local governments added 35,000 jobs last month.
The separate household survey, which the Labor Department relies on to calculate the unemployment rate, reflects a strikingly large divergence from the job data provided by the payroll tally. After a 926,000 decline in May followed by a feeble 58,000 rise last month, the number of people with jobs, or actively looking for them, averaged 179,000 fewer in the second quarter than in the first three months of the year.
Since employment, as measured by the household survey, also fell in the quarter, the jobless rate has not risen. In fact, it eased in June by a second straight one-tenth of a point.
Although there were no big swings among demographic groups, a rise in the jobless rate for blacks, combined with a lower rate for Hispanic workers, returned the two groups to a more traditional relationship. In May, for the first time in two decades, the Hispanic jobless rate, at 10 percent, was slightly higher than the black rate.
Geographically, unemployment in the West fell five-tenths of a point, to 6.6 percent, last month while the rate in the Midwest fell three-tenths of a point, to 4.3 percent. But the rate edged up to 6 percent from 5.9 in the Northeast and to 5.6 percent from 5.4 percent in the South, the department also found.
Among the most populous states, the only significant changes were a 1.4-point drop in the jobless rate for Illinois, to 4.1 percent, and California's improvement of nine-tenths of a point. The jobless rate in New York fell to 5.9 percent, from 6.3 percent in May, while the rate inched up in New Jersey to 6.6 percent from 6.5.
Mr. Wilson of the Bank of America said the June rise of 54,000 payroll jobs for California, whose recovery has lagged behind the national rebound by two years or more, was one of the biggest in recent memory.
Still another element of today's report was a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in average hourly earnings, a development that troubled some analysts still worried about potential inflationary pressures. But Robert B. Reich, the Labor Secretary, dismissed the move as inconsequential.
"I don't see any sign of wage-price pressure," he said in an interview.

HEADLINE: Japan Joins U.S. to Block Fall by Dollar

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Seeking to prevent the Federal Reserve's Thursday interest-rate reduction from weakening the dollar, the Japanese Government pushed down interest rates slightly in Tokyo today and then intervened in American currency markets with the United States to prop up the dollar.
The combined effect was a sharp rise in the dollar's value against the yen, as many traders concluded that Washington and Tokyo were more closely coordinating their economic policies and would prevent any further fall in the dollar. In late trading, the dollar had surged 1.80 yen, to 86.76 yen to the dollar. 
 The Japanese stock market soared in response to reduced interest rates, with the most widely watched index rising more than 6 percent. [Page 34.]
The dollar was also up against other currencies, although not so sharply. It was at 1.3925 marks today from 1.3787 marks late Thursday, to 1.1580 Swiss francs from 1.1427 and to $1.5951 to the British pound, compared with $1.6007 on Thursday.
David F. DeRosa, the director of foreign exchange trading in the New York offices of the Swiss Bank Corporation, said the United States and Japan appeared to have coordinated their interest rate cuts because "they both happened within hours and were followed by an intervention in which those two intervened and nobody else."
A Treasury spokeswoman confirmed that the intervention had been coordinated with the United States. "The Federal Reserve Bank of New York operated in exchange markets on behalf of Treasury and the Federal Reserve System, jointly with Japanese monetary authorities," the spokeswoman said.
Still, it was unclear whether the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan had coordinated their interest rate cuts. Bank of Japan officials denied any coordination, Bloomberg Business News reported. The Federal Reserve declined comment.
Not even Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, could have known for sure in advance whether the Fed's top rate-setting panel would vote as it did to shave a quarter of a percentage point off its target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans.
And when central banks have coordinated interest rate reductions, the central bank of the country with the stronger currency has traditionally gone first. A rate reduction tends to weaken a country's currency by reducing the return on investments.
But Mr. Greenspan did attend a meeting on June 11 in Basel, Switzerland, at the headquarters of the Bank for International Settlements, a secretive agency sometimes referred to as the central bank of central banks. The heads of other big central banks attended the same meeting and in the past have exchanged detailed hints at these meetings of their future policies. Indeed, central bankers have sometimes told each other more in Basel than they say about their plans to treasury or finance ministry officials in their own countries.
In any case, the Federal Reserve's rate reduction clearly put Japanese authorities in a difficult position by potentially undermining the dollar and strengthening the yen. The yen's sharp rise this year has already limited Japanese exports and restrained the country's emergence from five years of economic stagnation.
The Bank of Japan responded today by announcing that it was adding money to the Japanese financial system, driving down the interest rate for overnight loans among banks. This interest rate hit a record low of 0.75 percent before recovering to 1.06 percent -- still down from 1.24 percent on Thursday.
William R. Cline, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, a nonpartisan research group here, said, "The Japanese economy remains extremely weak -- the United States' cutting the interest rate is sort of an ideal time for Japan to cut its rate."
Conspicuously absent in today's currency market intervention and in this week's rate reductions was Germany's central bank. Despite some recent signs of weakness in the German economy, the powerful Bundesbank has been reluctant to cut interest rates because of lingering signs that German inflation may not fully be under control.
Yet many officials in Germany and elsewhere in Europe have been irritated by the United States' willingness until now to let the dollar slide, which has made American goods cheaper and more competitive in European markets.
The American and Japanese rate cuts will put pressure on the Bundesbank to follow suit when its top rate-setting panel meets next Thursday. But Kevin J. Lawrie, a foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said, "The Germans don't like to be pressured by outside sources -- they'll adjust their monetary policies as and when they see fit."
The United States and Japan limited their intervention to trades involving the dollar and the yen, but the dollar's rise against the yen dragged the dollar's exchange rate up against the German mark as well, traders said.
Stephen Flanagan, a currency trader in the New York offices of Credit Agricole, estimated that the United States and Japan each swapped about $250 million worth of yen for dollars today. That is a modest amount by currency intervention standards.
But the dollar, nonetheless, surged for three reasons, Mr. Flanagan added. The United States and Japan appeared to be cooperating closely. Currency traders were taken by surprise. And the dollar was already rising even before the intervention, in response to a Labor Department report this morning that employment rose strongly in the United States last month.

HEADLINE: Gulliver's Japanese Travels;
Hitting the (Narrow) Road in Two U.S. Behemoths

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 7

 BODY:
The attendant, his eyes squinting and his head cocked to one side, peered at the car from the front. He walked around to the back and peered at it from there. He consulted with a co-worker.
Then he crossed his arms in front of him to form an "X." The Cadillac Concours was not going to be allowed into his department store parking lot. 
 As the driver, I protested indignantly that the lot was closed to American cars. No, the attendant replied, the car was simply too wide. The elevator that carries automobiles to the upper floors of the garage is only 5 feet 9 inches wide. The Cadillac, I later checked, was about 8 inches wider than that.
The question of the Cadillac's width has a new relevance, if partly symbolic. Now that the United States and Japan have reached a trade agreement to open the Japanese market, will some American vehicles still be locked out because, as Japanese officials have long contended, they are too big or too fat or otherwise ill suited for that market?
To get to the bottom of this billion-dollar question, I drove a couple of American cars around Tokyo for 10 days.
Besides the Cadillac, chosen because it is the archetypal big American luxury car, I also drove a Ford Explorer XL, typical of the sport utility vehicles that are popular in the United States and, increasingly, in Japan.
While far from doing a scientific survey, I found many situations in which these cars, built for the American open road, seemed decidedly out of place.
During those 10 days, I was denied access to a couple of parking lots and had trouble parking in others. I saw crowds of pedestrians part in awe -- or was it scatter in terror? -- as my burly Cadillac or powerful Explorer plowed down narrow shopping streets. And I drew dirty looks from other drivers when I blocked traffic, trying -- but failing -- to make narrow turns on residential side streets.
Still, over all, it was possible to take the cars almost everywhere, and the rides were comfortable.
First, the issue of steering wheels. Typical of American vehicles sold here, the Cadillac and the Explorer had steering wheels on the left. In Japan, where people drive on the left side of the road, the wheel is usually on the right.
I found the left-side steering wheels to be no problem when driving or passing other cars. In fact, in some ways, I found it easier than having the wheel on the right.
Driving in Tokyo is like running a slalom. Except on main roads, there are no sidewalks. Pedestrians, utility poles and parked cars jut out from the left, forcing cars to weave around them. Sitting on the left side of the car, I found it easier to keep track of these obstacles.
The main difficulty with left-side driving was in paying tolls or leaving parking lots, because the booths are invariably on the right.
It did not take long to encounter the problem: To get the Cadillac out of the parking garage near General Motors' offices, I had to open a gate by holding up an electronic card against a detector -- on the right side of the car. I had to shift into park, slide across the seat and stick my hand with the card outside the window, then slide back and start the car before the gate went down again.
Fortunately, to help make the task of paying tolls easier, both Ford and G.M. equipped the cars with coin holders next to the driver's seat. Unfortunately, the coin holders were designed for American coins. They could not hold the big 500-yen coins, which are needed because even a short trip on a Tokyo expressway costs 700 yen, or about $8.25.
It is not that the companies have ignored adapting their cars. Masato Fukui, manager of engineering and quality control at the Japanese unit of the Ford Motor Company, ticked off more than 15 changes made in the Explorer to conform to Japanese regulations or to make the cars more suitable for the Japanese market.
These included installing retractable side-view mirrors to help the cars fit into tight spaces, and having the dashboard gauges labeled in kilometers instead of miles. To meet Japanese regulations, Ford has changed the tailpipe so it points straight backward instead of diagonally backward and installed turn signals on the sides of the front and rear fenders.
Except for the entry-level XL, the Explorers sold in Japan also come with running boards to help the shorter Japanese climb into them. "For a Japanese lady wearing a kimono, it's almost impossible to climb up into that high-floor vehicle," Mr. Fukui said.
Yoshikazu Hojoh, who is in charge of adapting G.M. cars for Japan, said more than 30 revisions had been made in the Cadillac. But somehow both companies did not change the coin holders, simple pieces of plastic that no doubt could have been obtained from any number of Japanese vendors.
The most obvious characteristic of the American vehicles is their size. Parked side by side with Japanese cars at a restaurant, the Cadillac stuck out like a basketball player in a room full of jockeys.
The Concours is big, even when compared with Japanese luxury cars. The 1995 Concours is 17 feet 7 inches long and 6 feet 5 inches wide. The Toyota Lexus LS 400 is 16 feet 5 inches long and 6 feet wide.
Detroit offers some vehicles here that are smaller than the Cadillac and Explorer, but are hardly subcompacts. Cars that analysts say might fit well, like Chrysler's Neon and G.M.'s Saturn, are not sold here yet, though they will be. There are no American-made cars sold here by the Big Three with engine sizes smaller than 2 liters, even though such cars account for 80 percent of the market.
When I first brought home the Explorer, my wife, Kasumi, who is Japanese, looked out the window at it and practically screamed.
"I'm so embarrassed!" she exclaimed. In Japan, people do not like to call attention to themselves, and she was afraid that the neighbors would see this monstrosity sitting in front of the house. "This is terrible," she said.
In reality, though, it wasn't. If any neighbors noticed, no one said a word. (Even if you call attention to yourself, many people will pretend not to pay attention.) And my wife soon realized that there were many Japanese vehicles of similar size and shape on the roads.
Moreover, once she managed to climb into the Explorer -- our model lacked the running board -- she found it comfortable.
The Explorer's problem was not its length as much as its height. That prevented entry into one parking lot that used an elevator rather than ramps to move cars in and out. This type of garage is common in narrow buildings in Japan.
But many Japanese vehicles also have a height problem. Mitsubishi Motors' Pajero, the leader among Japanese sport utility vehicles, can be a little taller, at about 6 feet 2 inches, versus 5 feet 9 inches for the Explorer. The Pajero, however, is not as long or wide as the Ford.
The Explorer, with a 4-liter engine, is listed at 3.295 million yen, or about $38,700. A similarly equipped Pajero, with a 3-liter engine, sells for 3.438 million yen, or $40,400. Ford sold 1,877 Explorers in Japan last year. A right-hand-drive model is scheduled to reach the market here before the end of the year.
Parked in a neighborhood frequented by young people, the dark-green Explorer drew some good reviews. "Compared with Japanese cars, it looks tough," a college student said. Another student was able to identify the vehicle by sight as an Explorer.
Hajime Hatanaka, a businessman, said, "I like the way it looks." But he added, "I don't have that much interest in American cars."
The Cadillac had many buttons for moving the front seats every which way and for storing the position in memory. The seat even had a heater. Such features might appeal to the gadget-loving Japanese -- or be lost on them.
"It's just like a toilet," a Japanese passenger said when she saw the seat-heating button. In Japan, a high-tech toilet seat that can be pre-warmed is a popular product.
Parked near a family park, the shale-beige Cadillac received mixed reviews. None of about a dozen passers-by recognized it as a Cadillac; one young man guessed it was a Lincoln.
Ikuko Kameyama, a 32-year-old housewife, said, "It's a splendid-looking car." But she added: "I drive only small cars. I think I'd get a lot of attention if I drove a car like that."
Reiko Aoki, who is 31, said: "It's large. I can see it's an American car."
Her companion, Yuichi Nakata, added, "I want to ride in it but I don't want to drive it."
Some said they would rather buy a Japanese or European luxury car, if they could afford such a vehicle at all. The Concours has a list price here of 6.65 million yen, or more than $78,000. The Lexus LS 400, which is called the Celsior here, sells for 5.1 million to 6.5 million yen, or $59,900 to $76,300.
Fuel costs are another potential problem. The Cadillac gets about 16 miles to the gallon, according to Japanese ratings. With premium gasoline selling for about $6 a gallon, it could cost about $118 to fill the tank. The Explorer gets about 15 miles to the gallon.
G.M. sold 1,850 Cadillacs in Japan last year, up 14.3 percent from 1993. Mr. Hojoh said G.M. was trying to reduce the price of the smallest Cadillac sold here, the Seville, to the level of Japanese luxury cars and introduce a right-hand-drive version, possibly by 1998.
And can it be that the Cadillac suffers from an image as the vehicle of choice for Japanese mobsters? Several people said that this image was fading and that the mobsters, apparently in search of better price or quality, had switched to Mercedes-Benzes.
Mr. Hojoh said the Cadillac was also losing this class of traditional customer to Japanese luxury cars. With the economy slumping and a crackdown on organized crime under way, many mobsters can no longer afford the Cadillac, he said. Moreover, he said, a Japanese car does not attract as much unwanted attention. "It's very easy to camouflage," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Got some strange looks barging around Tokyo in this big Cadillac.; It sure stood out like a cruise ship next to those Japanese cars -; and I was darn lucky to wriggle my way out of some tight spots. (Dennis B. Gray/Mercury Pictures for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Latin America Now Ignores U.S. Lead in Isolating Cuba

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 7

 BODY:
One Brazilian company has a contract to paint the peeling Havana Libre hotel, long a symbol of Cuba's revolution. Another is shipping an entire cigarette factory to Cuba to revive tobacco production.
Once an obedient follower of the United States trade embargo on Cuba, Latin America increasingly ignores Washington, choosing to develop full economic and diplomatic relations with the Communist Government. The United States is the only country in the Americas with a trade ban on Cuba and one of only five that do not have formal ties with it. 
 Mexico is now Cuba's largest foreign investor, and the Americas supply half of Cuba's imports. As tourism supplants sugar as Cuba's leading source of foreign exchange, Latin America supplies one quarter of the island's foreign visitors.
"The rapprochement between Latin America and Cuba is completely normal," said Ney Sroulevich, who imports Cuban cigars to sell in Brazil. "The countries are closer, the shipping costs are cheaper, and Latin America now produces good products."
Latin America's new independence from Washington is a product of several factors: a strong drive toward regional economic integration, the end of Cuban support for leftist guerrilla groups in the area, and the disappearance of Cuba as an ideological challenge with the collapse of its economy.
Although Latin trade and investment are too small to bail out Cuba's floundering economy, the emerging unanimity in the hemisphere has left American diplomats helplessly watching the tide turn against United States policy at a time when Washington is reassessing the wisdom of trying to isolate Cuba.
After foreign ministers at an Organization of American States meeting in Haiti last month called for reinstating Cuba's membership in the group, Alexander F. Watson, the State Department's top official for Latin America, said, "It's absurd to think today of admitting a country with a Stalinist Government to an organization which increasingly makes efforts to consolidate democracy in the hemisphere."
Harriet C. Babbitt, United States representative to the group, said in an interview today: "We agree that engagement with the Cuban people is useful. But we disagree that increased engagement with the Cuban Government would be useful."
While the Clinton Administration debates loosening travel restrictions on Cuba, free travel to the island is already a reality for almost all of the rest of the Americas. Cuba's airline, Cubana de Aviacion, flies to 10 Latin American countries, and about 220,000 people from the region expected to visit Cuba this year.
Thirty years ago, Mexico was the only country in the region to maintain diplomatic relations with Cuba. Today, among all the Latin American nations, only Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, Guatemala and Honduras have not moved to restore ties. But Honduras's new President, Carlos Reina, has received Cuban officials, signaling that he intends to normalize relations.
In Paraguay, South America's last holdout, the Senate voted in May to renew diplomatic relations with Havana.
"We have full relations with virtually all of Latin America," said Orlando Bogur, first secretary of the Cuban Embassy in Brasilia.
A diplomatic offensive by Cuba has paid off with votes in favor of United Nations resolutions condemning the United States embargo. With Latin nations no longer abstaining, supporting votes jumped from 59 in 1992 to 101 in 1994. In the last vote, only three countries from the region abstained -- Argentina, El Salvador and Guatemala. The only country that supported the United States was Israel.
"Until now, the policy of all or nothing has not gotten us anywhere," Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, Secretary General of the Organization of American States, said last month. "The debate on the present and future of Cuba has been monopolized by the most extreme positions."
Cuba's opening to Latin America is also part of its own turn to foreign investment and free-market policies after the collapse of its patron, the Soviet Union. A decade ago, 85 percent of Cuba's trade was with the Soviet bloc. From 1989 to 1993, Cuba's foreign trade plunged by 72 percent to $4.1 billion.
Now, regional trade and investment have become increasingly important.
With Cuba starting to sell state companies, investors from Argentina and Mexico have an edge because their countries have accords that allow investors to swap shares in Cuban state companies for trade debts. Cuba has run up large trade debts with Latin America: $1.3 billion to Argentina, $340 million to Mexico, $50 million to Colombia, and $30 million to Brazil.
While Latin American multinational companies enter Cuba attracted by the lack of American competition, they are edgy about the threat of expanded United States sanctions. A bill pending in Congress would penalize foreign companies and their executives that do business in both Cuba and the United States. In a meeting in May, foreign ministers of 14 Latin America countries declared their opposition to the bill.
Jorge Mas Canosa, the hard-line Cuban exile leader in Miami, recently sent letters to Latin American and European ambassadors in Washington, urging them to stop investing in Cuba.
"You are taking a major risk and will incur major losses by doing business in Cuba during the tenure of the dictatorship of Fidel Castro," said Mr. Mas Canosa, chairman of the Miami-based Cuban American National Foundation. "Any entrepreneurial, commercial or economic undertakings in Cuba are illegitimate activities, as illegitimate as the system that allows them."
Despite these and other threats, dozens of investors and exporters turned out for conferences held last week in Brazil's four most important cities by Ernesto Melendez Bachs, Cuba's Minister of Foreign Investment and Cooperation.
"We are going to paint the Havana Libre," said Mauro Saccomani Moreira, export manager for Brazil's largest paint company, Tintas Renner, S.A. In addition to sprucing up the newly privatized hotel, the company, which dominates Cuba's paint market, is competing against Spanish and Venezuelan companies for a contract to repaint much of Havana's historic center next year.
To revive Cuba's flagging cigarette industry, Cuban officials have signed a deal to place most of local cigarette production in Brazilian hands. Under the deal, Souza Cruz, the Brazilian subsidiary of British American Tobacco, is to plant 1,730 acres of Virginia-type tobacco in Cuba and to ship to Havana machinery for a factory capable of producing 6 billion cigarettes, half of Cuba's annual consumption.
"Our intention is to eventually export, first to Latin America and the Caribbean, and then later to the United States," Milton C. Cabral, the Souza Cruz financial director, said today at his officer here. "Diplomatically, we don't see any problems for our association because both countries, Brazil and Cuba, enjoy harmonious diplomatic relations."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Stocks Soar by 6.3% on Unexpected Rate Cut

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

 BODY:
Tokyo stock prices jumped 6.3 percent yesterday, lifted by an unexpected cut in interest rates and investor hopes that the Government would take stronger measures to aid Japan's sagging economy. But some analysts said they doubted the market's buoyancy would last.
The Bank of Japan surprised financial markets by announcing yesterday that it would lower a key short-term interest rate. The announcement gave further momentum to the stock market, which had risen during the three prior sessions. 
 The initial impetus came from Government officials who had begun to give new assessments of Japan's troubled economy, acknowledging that it remained weak. The market had been so depressed in the last few weeks that the mere acknowledgment of economic weakness by the officials gave stocks a surprising lift.
"They might finally take the proper policy measures," said John F. Bahrenburg, a market strategist at Merrill Lynch Japan Inc. "Now it seems they have a greater appreciation of the risk of a deflation spiral and the economy entering into a recession again."
The Nikkei index of 225 shares, the benchmark stock indicator, jumped 956.19 points, or 6.3 percent, to close at 16,213.08 yesterday. That was its highest closing level in nearly two months.
In its announcement yesterday, the central bank said it would add funds to the money market, pushing down the interest rate that banks charge one another for loans overnight. It said it would allow the rate to fall below the discount rate, which is charged on loans that banks obtain from the central bank.
The overnight rate had already been slipping in the last few weeks. It declined to a record low of 0.75 percent at one point yesterday, below the discount rate, which at 1 percent is at its lowest level ever. The overnight rate settled at 1.06 percent, down from 1.24 percent on Thursday. Analysts said the central bank had set a target for the rate of around 0.75 percent.
The Bank of Japan said it was not yet considering a cut in the discount rate.
The central bank's announcement, made late in the morning in Tokyo, followed by less than eight hours the news of a similar step by the American central bank. The Federal Reserve announced in Washington on Thursday afternoon that it would allow the Federal funds rate, which like the Japanese overnight rate reflects the cost to banks of raising funds in the money market, to decline to 5.75 percent from 6 percent.
One reason for the Japanese rate cut was apparently to offset the potential impact on the currency market of the Fed's cut. In general, interest rate cuts lower a currency's value because they reduce the returns available from investments denominated in that currency. By lowering its own interest rates, Japan hoped to offset any downward pressure exerted on the dollar by the Fed's rate cut.
The rate cuts in the two countries were not carried out as part of a coordinated effort. But Japan did join with the United States yesterday in intervening in the currency market, buying dollars and selling yen. The strong yen has hurt Japan's economy.
More important than its impact on the currency market, the Bank of Japan's rate cut indicated that the central bank was decisively easing monetary policy to help spur investment and stimulate the economy.
Japan's economy has been sagging since the beginning of the 1990's. Economic output rose only one-tenth of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1995 from the prior three months, and some economists believe the economy contracted during the second quarter.
Government economic officials had been saying that the economy was on its way to recovery. This week, however, they began to concede that the economy was still weak and hinted that strong measures were needed.
While traders were encouraged by today's market activity, equity strategists and economists were cautious. Some said the market's rise could be a technical gain that might be erased by profit taking.
"It remains to be seen if this liquidity-driven bull is sustainable," said Mineko Sasaki-Smith, an economist at Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. "It's probably a technical rebound."
Others said that while stocks might gain further, the rise might be marked by periodic dips. A major factor would be whether the Government did, in fact, take concrete steps to aid the economy and address a mounting number of economic woes.
Many in the financial community have been calling for measures to further deregulate the economy.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Stock Exchange Is Regaining Lost Ground

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 7

 BODY:
The battered Mexican stock market has managed to regain most of the ground it lost after the peso was devalued in December, although stock values in dollar terms are still far below previous levels.
Today, the leading index of the Mexican stock exchange rose for the 11th time in 13 trading days, gaining 54.10 points, or 2.25 percent, to 2,457.18, a high for the year. While in pesos the market has gained a little more than 1.1 percent since the beginning of the year, in dollars, the exchange is still down more than 18 percent. The dollar has risen 21.28 percent against the peso for the year. 
 Market analysts here and in the United States said local investors in Mexico were principally responsible for the recent surge, which took many people by surprise. More recently, they said, some big international funds dedicated to Mexico and Latin America have started to buy again.
Scott Kalb, managing director of Smith Barney's International Asset Management fund, said that since the devaluation, the Mexican market has been propelled primarily by local investors.
"Some foreign money has gone in and come out quickly and there's been a little bit of buying of fundamentals, but not a lot," Mr. Kalb said. "Even this week there might have been some institutions that recognized it would be dangerous to be too underweighted in Mexico. But I don't think many of them are convinced that they need to be waiting in line to get back into Mexico in a big way."
Some of the recent activity may also have been due to hedge funds that had to buy before prices rose too high. Hedge funds are big investment partnerships that make big bets on bond, commodity, currency and stock markets.
The decision on Thursday by the United States Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates for the first time since 1992 also appears to have given the Mexican market a boost. Lower interest rates in the United States should allow Mexico to reduce interest rates as well, eventually making it cheaper for Mexican companies to borrow money.
The Mexican economy has recently shown a number of signs that investors see as positive. Inflation rates are dropping and the Government has re-entered the international debt market for the first time since the devaluation, offering $500 million in notes that will be handled by Citibank and Credit Suisse.
Despite such signals, however, most analysts were reluctant to declare an end to Mexico's economic emergency.
"The optimism now is too great," said Rodolfo Navarrete, assistant director of analysis for the Vector Casa de Bolsa brokerage firm in Mexico City. He worried that the market surge had come even as most companies continued to be battered by a deep national recession. "I get the distinct impression that the rise could be temporary," he said.
No matter how long the current rally lasts, the stock market's strong recovery within months of the worst economic crisis in a decade has been unexpected. The day before the peso was first devalued on Dec. 20, the stock exchange index stood at 2,231.11. After the devaluation, the market sank steadily, reaching a low, on Feb. 27, of 1447.52.
Mr. Kalb of Smith Barney said that after the devaluation Smith Barney's international equity portfolio reduced its Mexico holdings to 2.5 percent from around 6 percent. They remain at that level.
Jeffry H. Taylor, an analyst at NatWest Securities in Washington, said that when Mexican stock prices dropped sharply over the first few months of the year, some investors found them attractive despite the overall weakness in the nation's economy.
"But cheap prices are enough only if you're looking at good quality," he said. Shares of Telefonos de Mexico, the national phone company, were a good buy when prices dropped because the telephone company's market was secure, he said. "But to just go in and buy a weaker company because prices are low means taking a big risk," he added.
Many investors say they want to see company earnings for the second and third quarters before deciding whether Mexico's economy has really hit bottom. Government officials have said they expect the economy to drop as much as 5 percent in the second quarter, with a light recovery coming only in the final quarter of the year.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Fall on Data Showing Jobless Rate Drop

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday after a stronger-than-expected employment report raised concern that the Federal Reserve might not again cut rates any time soon.
The Labor Department reported yesterday that the nation's unemployment rate fell to 5.6 percent in June from 5.7 percent the previous month. The report even led some bond traders to question if the Fed was justified in cutting short-term interest rates on Thursday. The Fed lowered its Federal funds target rate, or the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, by 25 basis points, to 5.75 percent. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point. 
 Traders said the surge in new jobs combined with Thursday's reduction in interest rates had shaken even those investors most optimistic for lower yields. But the market bounced back in the afternoon, with intermediate maturities especially strong. It prompted one securities trader to describe the five-year note as "almost bulletproof" since it was virtually unscathed by the strong employment report. Analysts said the strength of the five-year maturity had buoyed the prices of other maturities.
But the late recovery in bond prices prompted some investors to take profits and sell. By the close of the New York market, the price of the benchmark 30-year bond was down 14/32 of a percentage point, to 11411/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.52 percent, from 6.49 percent on Thursday. The price of the five-year note edged down 2/32 , to 10018/32to yield 5.74, up only a basis point from Thursday.
 "It appears that a near-term top may be in place in the Treasury market," said Margo Evashevski, a Treasury analyst with MMS International in San Francisco. "The September bond in the futures market was able to set a new 1995 intraday high at 1166/32 this morning on post-rate-cut euphoria. But the much-stronger-than-expected employment report sent the bond lower in a hurry. The report also brings further rate cuts into question, which suggests that the short and intermediate securities have more down side left."
Eric Hamilton, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said that the ability of the market to bounce back from the bearish payroll data suggested staying power at these price levels. "Portfolio managers are behind the eight ball once again starting out the new quarter," he said, "and you can expect some forced buying as they look to catch up to their benchmarks.
"Add the fact that the Treasury is expected to cut the size of the next couple of auctions by $2 billion, and rate cuts overseas -- which will probably force some overseas investors into our market searching for yield -- and you have all the makings in place for a decent run higher, with increasing demand chasing decreasing supply."
Elsewhere, municipal bond prices were little changed, as fund managers saw investors add cash for the first time in four weeks. In the corporate debt market, analysts expect corporate borrowing will pick up soon because Government bond yields plunged after the cut in a key lending rate. As a result, managers expect a supply of new issues will hit the market in response to the lower borrowing rates.

HEADLINE: Why Banks Have to Remain Impartial Lenders

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In opposing evaluations of the Glass-Steagall laws, Marc Intrater ("Banking Laws Keep an Industry Down," letter, July 2) and John W. Moscow ("Bigger Banks, Bigger Problems," Op-Ed, June 28) focus solely on safety and soundness. The safety and soundness of our banks and banking system may be important, but it is a peculiarly defensive ground on which to justify or condemn regulation. 
 There always have been other considerations behind the separation of commercial and investment banking in this country.
"Safety and soundness" look to the survivability of banks and banking systems in times of stress. Failure here is the major hazard toward which bank regulation has been directed since the 1930's.
But the Supreme Court and the regulators have recognized a range of subtle hazards against which the Glass-Steagall barriers also defend. In any reassessment of banking law, these should not be ignored.
Our banking system -- including not only commercial banks but many near-bank institutions that have been encroaching on their turf -- functions ultimately as a conduit of money from underspenders to overspenders.
Resources not used by those who spend less than they earn are aggregated and made available to those who can use them for development of capital and entrepreneurial projects, to the general benefit of all.
Ideally the market for that aggregated surplus should be free and unbiased: those projects that offer the best combination of certainty and size of return, those projects that society in all its consumption roles most wants, should have highest priority.
Lending decisions should be made on the basis of creditworthiness alone.
If commercial banks were allowed to hold ownership interests in capital-consuming enterprises, their lending decisions would no longer be made solely on the basis of creditworthiness of applicant projects.
Suppose a bank had an ownership interest in a construction company: would it be inclined to lend to a rival construction company, even if that rival had the more creditworthy projects?
If banks held stakes in the entities that provide the demand for scarce capital, their lending decisions would be biased in favor of their own holdings and against their competitors.
Preserving an unbiased market for borrowed capital by preserving the role of creditworthiness as the sole basis of lending decisions is sufficient ground for preserving the Glass-Steagall separation of commercial and investment banking.
And for a sound economic future, it is reason for restricting the increasing encroachment of other financial institutions into the conduit role that used to be almost exclusively the preserve of our commercial banks.
 
MICHAEL SINCLAIR
Ann Arbor, Mich., July 3, 1995
 
The writer is a professor at New York Law School.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

SECTION: Section 1; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 498 words

HEADLINE: Your Attention, Please

 BODY:
Republicans have a right to their suspicions about President Clinton's calls for an end to harsh partisanship. Mr. Clinton never hesitated to slug them in the eye back when he had the Congressional majority to back him up. But a President without votes on the Hill must placate more often than threaten. So Mr. Clinton's "common-ground" speech at Georgetown University can be read by political realists as an attempt to make a virtue of necessity. The necessity, in Mr. Clinton's case, was created by his party's collapse at the polls in 1994. If 1996 is to be any different for the Democrats -- and more to the point, their standard-bearer -- Mr. Clinton needs Republican help in establishing himself as a bipartisan leader.
Even allowing for this most cynical reading of the politics of his speech, the President is right on its core ideas. The ills afflicting American society do not flow from the fact that the middle class no longer possesses the moral perfection of, let us say, Jesse Helms and Phil Gramm. Mr. Clinton is closer to the truth when he points up that "middle-class values and strong families" are threatened by a consistent economic battering for which no end is in sight. 
 Any student of postwar history can grasp Mr. Clinton's point that decent family incomes are crucial to progress in education, health and general social stability. The favored doom-signs of the new Jeremiahs -- crime, illegitimacy, drug abuse -- flourish in environments of expanding poverty. The proliferation of middle-class values requires the existence of a middle class that is thriving rather than threatened, prosperous rather than pinched.
Yet there is no relief in sight for the economic squeeze that Mr. Clinton described for students at his alma mater, and that is not simply a matter of the changing global economy. The middle class, while incessantly praised by Beltway orators, has few friends in Washington. Representative Dick Armey and the flat-taxers are pushing new tax schemes that will hit the middle class harder than the wealthy. Corporations are taking as profit money that once got plowed back into higher wages and new jobs. Meanwhile, business and financial-community influence in Washington are at a 50-year peak, and that was true under the deposed Democratic Congressional leadership as well as with the lobbyist-loving Gingrich-Dole team.
Mr. Clinton has spotted a strong issue, but it may not be an easy one to exploit. Senator Bob Dole and Speaker Newt Gingrich are whizzes at stroking the middle-class voters with cultural issues while punishing them economically.
Then there is always the question of how long Mr. Clinton can keep his attention on the important themes he defined at Georgetown. He spoke there of the "obligations imposed on the President." Central among those is the obligation to believe in -- and preach about -- a few important things for a long time instead of believing in virtually everything for at least a few minutes.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: A Mover of Markets

BYLINE: By Saul Hansell; Saul Hansell writes about finance for The Times.

 BODY:
The red digital clock pulses 12:30:00, and Dan Dorfman's image beams into this smooth and sterile control room of the CNBC cable network like some sort of wayward space alien disrupting a NASA launch. It's six minutes until Dorfman, a columnist for Money magazine, presents his daily dose of stock market news, rumors and tips on CNBC.
A technician has switched on a remote camera in Dorfman's office at Money, and the small, balding man with black electric tape eyebrows appears on a control-room monitor scribbling furiously on a legal note pad. At 12:34, Dorfman is writing away as CNBC gives its regular update on the O. J. Simpson trial. When the clock blinks 12:36, Kevin McCullough, the gray-haired anchor, introduces Dorfman. 
 "Our story here: Giving U.S. Shoe the boot," Dorfman pants into the camera, bobbing and weaving while holding his pad in front of him.
Dorfman quotes "a bear analyst," Jeffrey Stein, with the Cleveland brokerage firm McDonald & Company, who says shares of U.S. Shoe Corporation are "dead money" and "should be sold now." Dorfman explains Stein's reasoning, racing through a staccato stream of sentences, punching up about every third word.
"Stein's six-month target: 16 bucks a share, a decline of 16 percent from current levels," Dorfman concludes, allowing himself what appears to be his first breath in three minutes.
Back to the controlled world of McCullough the anchor. "While you were talking, Dan," he says, "we looked up the latest quote on U.S. Shoe. We now have it down 1/2 at 18 3/4."
It's a throwaway line, but it's essential to understanding why Dan Dorfman earns $900,000 a year from the column and the television spots, probably the biggest salary of any financial journalist. It explains why this two-minute daily segment is CNBC's most popular business feature, drawing an estimated audience of 500,000 people, both amateur investors at home and pros on trading desks, and why Money lured him from USA Today in December. It's why Dorfman has raised the ire of more than a few corporate chieftains and why many traders and other journalists worry that Dorfman is manipulated by some of his sources on Wall Street for their own gain.
Simply put, Dan Dorfman moves markets.
Invariably Dorfman's television reports set off a flurry of trading in the stocks he mentions. By the end of this day, 537,000 shares of U.S. Shoe traded, 60 percent more than usual; the price dropped by 62.5 cents. Often, the stocks move by several dollars.
"There are lots of people who make statements about the stock market, but there is no one who has the direct effect Dorfman has," says Homer Livingston Jr., the recently retired president of the Chicago Stock Exchange. "Whenever he talks, he disturbs the market." Waves of orders for stocks mentioned in Dorfman's reports proved so disruptive to traders on the Chicago trading floor that the exchange passed a rule last year permitting the temporary removal of stocks he mentions from its electronic trading system.
Daniel Donald Dorfman, 63, has been moving markets for more than three decades. In the late 1960's, he shot down hundreds of high-flying stocks while writing The Wall Street Journal's trademark Heard on the Street column. He continued to cultivate some of the most plugged-in sources on Wall Street, writing a series of financial columns for The Journal, then later New York magazine and USA Today. Along the way, he broke some of the most important stories in finance, like the impending merger between Time Inc. and Warner Communications, and he punctured the balloon of overvalued stocks like College Bound, a once high-flying test firm that ultimately went bankrupt. Yet Dorfman's power only hit its current heights in 1990, when he began appearing on CNBC right in the middle of the trading day.
Of course, long before anyone dreamed of 500 channels, before cops chased robbers across the Internet and before media were multi, the stock market was -- in today's parlance -- an interactive, multiplayer game. For more than half a century, the average stockbroker's office lured contestants into electronic Monetary Kombat with nothing more than a telephone, a ticker tape and a Dow Jones news teleprinter.
But now CNBC merges these into a smooth blend of news, gossip and prices. The tips and trends still call out to investors big and small, luring them to run to their broker or pick up the phone and trade. Instantly, the new prices scroll across the ticker tape that snakes along the bottom of the TV screen, updating the state of play. Next move, the viewer.
With his Mickey Mouse ties and squeaky voice, Dorfman pops into this play like a bug-eyed monster on a video-game machine. With each report, different players jump, pull back or lunge, take a loss or seize an opportunity. Dorfman says he's democratizing the market, delivering information to the masses that has been available to the elite. Critics say he's used by sources to spread rumors that make the game all the more unfair for those out of the know.
Yet both fans and foes agree that if you trade stocks, you have to know what Dorfman is saying. Most big brokerage firms have CNBC playing on their trading floors. Pros tend to view Dorfman's reporting with a healthy dose of skepticism but they still use it: some to take a Dorfman-inspired rally as a way to get out of a position, others to take advantage of Dorfman's following among small investors, buying the stock as soon as he spits out the name and selling it the next hour or the next day before the demand subsides. Even small investors who are wary of Dorfman's tips are nonetheless drawn by his seeming access to the inside track. On a recent sunny Thursday afternoon, Albert A. Furst, wearing white sneakers and a polo shirt, sits in a seat arranged airplane-waiting-room style in the middle of the low, long storefront office of Shochet Securities, one of a dozen stockbrokers lined up along 41st Street, the financial center of Miami Beach. Shochet calls it the "board room," but the office looks more like a tropical outpost of OTB, with a stock ticker and TV playing CNBC in front of the seats and brokers to take orders in the back.
It is 12:35, the O. J. report ends, and the anchor introduces Dan Dorfman. His story today is that Scott Black of Delphi Management told him that Plains Petroleum will be bought out within six months for at least $31 a share. (By the end of the day, its stock will jump 50 cents to $23.50 on 18 times its usual trading volume.)
Furst, a former New York stockbroker, shakes his head, and says he promises not to trade another Dorfman story again. "I've traded some of his picks and most of them were losers," he says, glancing up regularly at the stock ticker. Furst says he bought California Federal Savings a year ago, after Dorfman said it would be taken over or its stock would rise to $21. The savings-and-loan's stock fell from $15 to $9.75, and it remains independent.
"You get fooled once, twice, three times, after that you watch your step," Furst says.
As it happens, Plains turned out to be a winner. Two months later, it agreed to be bought by Barrett Resources Corporation for $30.22 per share.
Dorfman and his assistant, Karyn McCormack, occupy a corner of Money's sleek gray quarters. Most Money editors work in private offices, but Dorfman actually had a wall taken down in a somewhat vain attempt to be in an open newsroom. For a reporter, Dorfman keeps his desk oddly free of paper.
Dorfman shows me two of his tools, the small shopping bag of pre-tied neckties to be easily donned just before air time, and a 20-year-old, overflowing, red leather phone book. "A lot of the people in there are dead," he sighs.
Without prompting, he starts to talk about Coca-Cola and Quaker Oats. Last January, Dorfman reported that stories were circulating among traders that Coca-Cola had offered $60 a share for Quaker, which owns the Gatorade sports drink line. Suddenly, Quaker shares jumped up $4.50 to $36.50. And the normally staid Atlanta soft drink company issued an unusual statement:
"It is the policy of the Coca-Cola Company not to comment on rumors about acquisitions or divestitures. That remains our policy. However, today we would like to elaborate on our statement and observe that Dan Dorfman does not have a clue."
CNBC stood by Dorfman and the story. But the incident seems to bother him. "The Coca-Cola thing is kooky." he says. "I thought it was a dopey reaction from a classy company." Dorfman recites, tensely, what he sees as the litany of criticisms of him and his work. "They say I'm long on rumor and short on fact-checking; that's what offends me. I know I have achieved some success and I'm visible. But the one thing that bothers me about some of these stories is that I wish they wouldn't paint me as some sort of loose cannon. I spend more time checking than anyone could possibly imagine."
The Coca-Cola company was actually the most recent of a number of possible suitors for Quaker Oats that Dorfman had mentioned over the last six months. "I heard the rumor three times in a two-week period," Dorfman explains. "So I called up the co-head of mergers at a major brokerage firm. He said, 'You must be calling about Coke.' " Dorfman asked the banker what he thought of the story. "He says, 'I think it's not true, but I don't know,' " Dorfman says. McCormack, his assistant, did call up Coke before the broadcast, but the company didn't comment.
On the air, Dorfman distinguishes between things he has "heard" -- rumors about which he is often quite skeptical -- and those he has "learned" -- facts from company insiders or government documents.
His first column in February for Money was one of the latter; he wrote that Larry Tisch was looking to sell CBS. But even with something he learned, Dorfman insists that readers should not trade on the basis of his reporting.
"Should someone buy CBS stock?" Dorfman says. "Absolutely not. People I checked with at CBS say CBS is gone. I firmly believe that. I don't know when. I don't care if people buy or sell CBS. That's not what I'm here for. I'm telling them what I hear."
Actually, most of Dorfman's reports are neither rumor nor fact. They are what he calls "one man's opinion" -- the case for or against a stock by a money manager or analyst. Dorfman is looking for unusual, interesting views, and he doesn't care if they are consistent. Three weeks after reporting the rumor that Coke was going to buy Quaker Oats for $60 per share, for example, he quoted an analyst, William Leach of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who figured Quaker would fall to $19. (The stock dropped $1 that day, to $34.)
Dorfman says one of his best stories of the last year was about Spectrum Information Technologies, the once high-flying Long Island technology company now in Chapter 11. In January, Dorfman heard a tip that John Sculley, the former Apple Computer C.E.O. who had just joined Spectrum, would quit.
"I called Sculley, and he denied it," Dorfman recalls. "Then Dan Dorfman, the reporter, begins to go to work. My source says, 'Sculley's lying,' but he is short the stock, so who do you believe?" Dorfman knows well that traders who sell stocks short -- that is, bet that their price will fall -- often have the best information on companies' weak spots. But they also stand to profit by spreading rumors that drive down the price, whether they are true or not.
Dorfman says he made one call to check out the story, but as usual, won't say to whom. "Somebody in the computer business said, 'Dan, he's going.' " Several days later, Sculley quit.
I ask Dorfman why he thought that his source would know more about what Sculley would do than Sculley himself?
"People always know," he says, repeating his lifelong mantra. "People always know."
DORFMAN BEGAN HIS PURSUIT OF knowledgeable insiders when he covered retail management for Women's Wear Daily in the 1960's. He says he quickly figured out the value of cultivating sources on Wall Street. "There are some people who get information first, and those are the ones I want to know," Dorfman says.
He started life in 1931 very much the outsider. He bitterly tells of getting beaten up during his two years in an orphanage after his parents divorced, being ignored by his mother when he returned to her in Brooklyn and being beaten up again in the rough hallways of the New York School of Printing on 34th and Eighth.
"I was scared, worried, and angry at the world, angry for my upbringing," he says. "If the pool room burned down, I would have been homeless."
He wanted to go to college and law school, but his mother thought a trade was more stable. The Army helped bail him out of an unhappy career as a printer by giving him some experience on a base newspaper in Germany. After he returned, he finagled a job as a copy boy at Fairchild Publications, the parent of Women's Wear.
His friends see Dan Dorfman's life as a one long sprint away from his bitterness of his childhood.
"No one looked at Dan Dorfman in high school and said this guy will be the highest-paid financial journalist in the history of the profession," says Beth Belton, an economics reporter for USA Today and a friend of Dorfman. "They looked at him and said he isn't so brilliant, he has no family connections, he'll be lucky to have a job. Now he's a player. Dan isn't any more complicated than that. That's what drives him."
Dorfman works so much that he rarely takes a vacation. He is divorced and has a grown daughter. None of his friends have ever seen his east midtown apartment.
Dorfman's relatively simple life style is adorned by a penchant for expensive restaurants, where he invariably ignores the highly touted menu to order a dry grilled piece of fish, and a fondness for rare aperitifs, which he invariably spills on his jacket.
"When I have dinner with Danny, I frankly tell the waiters you may have the worst experience in your life," says Richard Stern, one of Dorfman's close friends and a former editor for Forbes. "Food goes back to the kitchen all the time. Wine goes back all the time."
Dorfman was equally fussy at USA Today -- not for privileges of power, but simply for accommodation of his drive. "He would want the air-conditioning on Sunday because he would work all day," Belton remembers.
Dorfman agrees: "They call it N.I.N. -- for News Immediacy Now -- it's like an orgasm. I need it."
More than ever, the daily CNBC appearances, which Dorfman started in 1990, make his life a high-wire act. He wakes up each morning most often not knowing what the topic of his 12:36 report will be.
He casts his net first at an 8:15 breakfast with a source. Then he works the phones madly through midmorning until he comes up with an idea he can use.
"Dorfman's calls are usually quick," says a money manager who talks to him regularly. "Do you know this, what do you know about it? What else is going on? Yes, I do. No, I don't. Boom boom boom. Goodbye."
Once Dorfman finds an idea, his assistant checks the facts and figures and calls the companies in question for comment (to their frustration, often with just minutes until air time). Lunch is at his desk, so he doesn't miss any phone calls. Dinner with sources is at 8 P.M.
Some traders and analysts -- even top corporate executives -- seek out a breakfast or dinner with Dorfman to promote their views. Others have become friends with him over decades in the business and enjoy swapping the latest gossip. Dorfman, of course, is trolling for ideas he can use and to get sources to let him use their names along with their views. Some regret the experience.
"I got so much grief from my friends," says a money manager quoted by Dorfman about why he liked a stock. "They said to me, 'What are you doing, trying to bail out of a position?' "
Of course, that is precisely what many traders and other stock-market journalists figure is on the mind of more than a few of Dorfman's sources. Indeed, over the years Dorfman's editors have not always been convinced that he was being skeptical enough of his sources' motives. In the heat of the takeover frenzy in the late 1980's, for example, several USA Today editors criticized Dorfman for being too ready to print that putative raiders had bought blocks of various companies' stocks, recalls Tom Petruno, Dorfman's editor then and now a columnist for The Los Angeles Times.
"Raiders would often run up to 4.9 percent," Petruno says, just under the 5 percent limit that the S.E.C. requires for positions to be disclosed. "The next thing you know, they would be out when the stock was up 2 or 3 points. We would ask: 'Is this person for real? What does he really want to do?' Dan would say, 'I just report what I know.' " Ultimately, the paper told him not to print those stories about raiders' positions.
The ethical mine field of stock-market journalism was illuminated by the criticism aimed recently at a column by James J. Cramer in Smart Money magazine, a personal-finance publication of Dow Jones & Company. Cramer, an investment manager, praised four small stocks that he said his funds owned. Their prices surged after the column was printed. That's all fair game, but Cramer was criticized because he bought more shares in the companies while the magazine was on the presses.
Dorfman himself rebuked Smart Money and Cramer, who says he did nothing wrong, with the banner of its archrival Money over his shoulder. "Did readers get a fair shake?" Dorfman asked. "The answer clearly is no." He said Cramer had an obligation to say he was buying more of the stocks.
And that is Dorfman's main response to those who criticize him for promoting the positions of others. (Dorfman hasn't bought a stock for himself in four years, he says.) He will simply tell viewers that his source has a position in the stock that he is talking about.
He knows well that he is caught in a war between the "touts" spreading rumors to boost prices and the "shorts" doing the same to profit from price declines. He argues that the only way to sort out the truth is to search out those who have the most incentive to find out what is really happening, and that those are usually people who have a financial stake in the situation.
"I use the user," Dorfman says.
The bottom line for viewers, however, is not who is used, but who is right. The few studies done on Dorfman show that stocks he praises do tend on average to rise and those he criticizes are more likely to fall.
But conducting such a study is no easy task. Take U.S. Shoe, for example, the stock to which Dorfman gave the boot, quoting one money manager that it would fall to $16 a share. Just a month before, Dorfman quoted another analyst who called the same company "a stock to own" because it was worth at least $36 a share.
Should anyone who bought U.S. Shoe on Dorfman's first bullish report feel used? Not at all; just two weeks after Dorfman's dour report, an Italian company made a hostile bid for U.S. Shoe. They ultimately bought it for $28 a share.
