SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
As a Beat, Business Is Booming

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
IRVING R. LEVINE STILL shivers at the memory of Jan. 8, 1971. That was the day NBC News asked him to try his hand at business reporting. Mr. Levine had just completed a lengthy tour as a foreign correspondent in Moscow, Rome and London. He wanted to cover the State Department next. But his bosses handed him the economics and business beat.
"It was a barren time," Mr. Levine, who is 72, said the other day. "Producers just weren't interested in those stories." 
 Today, he still plies his trade as NBC's chief interpreter of the Federal Reserve, the Dow Jones index and other bastions of the business world. But now Mr. Levine, whom many journalists regard as the dean of television business news, competes with hundreds of journalists from dozens of programs. Although the ratings would hardly threaten Peter Jennings, financial news has become the growth industry of the medium.
Four years after acquiring its troubled rival, Financial News Network, CNBC broadcasts 14 1/2 hours of talk shows and business-news updates every day. Executives at the cable channel, which is owned by NBC, said it would earn $50 million in pretax profits this year. And Cable News Network is about to throw the brightest spotlight yet on business: if all goes as planned, CNN will start an all-business news network, with 12 hours a day of financial news reporting and analysis, on Jan. 1.
"Business news has been accorded a status it never had before on television," said Everette E. Dennis, the executive director of the Freedom Forum Media Studies Center. "People now regard business news as more important to their lives than political news."
That may be more true of people in Silicon Valley than those in Sarajevo. But major American media companies like NBC, Turner Broadcasting System and Bloomberg Business News are scrambling to develop news programs -- even entire networks -- devoted to business, in Europe and Asia as well as the United States.
As financial news becomes pervasive on television, it is also becoming more sophisticated. Lou Dobbs, the mellifluous anchorman of CNN's primary business-news program, "Moneyline," is host of a show that differs little in style or substance from "CBS Evening News."
"We want to be the viewer's principal source of business and market news worldwide," said Mr. Dobbs, who is overseeing the development of CNN's new network, which will be called CNN Financial News, or CNNFN.
Such ambitions would have seemed ludicrous in the early 1980's, when CNN, FNN and other networks first got into financial news. In those days, business news still appealed to a narrow audience of Wall Street traders and other professional money managers. They watched business programs to get the latest pronouncements from the Fed chairman -- or other events that could drive the capital markets up or down.
Now, several trends have conspired to make financial news a hot commodity: the growth of a global economy has propelled trade and commerce to the top of the nation's political agenda, and the explosion of mutual funds has turned millions of Americans into armchair investors.
Ron Insana, an anchorman at CNBC, recalled that when he started out at Financial News Network in 1984, he served as a one-man news department. Mr. Insana had to keep track of the news-agency wires, edit taped footage, schedule stories and write the introductions for those stories.
One day, in May 1985, FNN's two anchors both called in sick. Suddenly, the 24-year-old Mr. Insana found himself delivering the news. "I was ad-libbing about stuff I knew nothing about," he said.
These days, Mr. Insana trades quips with top corporate executives and Wall Street analysts on his midday talk show, "Inside Opinion." He has been nominated for major awards and is finishing his first book, a compilation of stories about life on Wall Street.
Save for a receding hairline and a slightly nerdy appearance, Mr. Insana would be every inch the network anchor. But he said his job requires more than blow-dried looks.
"Look, none of us will ever sit in Brokaw's chair," he said. "But this is a different gig. It's a skill position."
Mr. Insana, Mr. Dobbs and other financial journalists are proud of their ability to discuss the arcana of interest rates or shifts in the commodities markets. Some would not trade it for anything.
NEIL CAVUTO, A 36-YEAR old anchorman at CNBC, said he has turned down offers to switch to more conventional broadcast beats like politics, social issues and crime. "Covering the latest mayhem on the streets of the city is not my cup of tea," said Mr. Cavuto, who is host for the daily "Money Wheel" and "Market Wrap" programs on CNBC.
Mr. Cavuto and other up-and-comers, like David Faber, the 31-year-old Wall Street correspondent at CNBC, believe that their specialized knowledge will make them coveted employees as CNN and Bloomberg begin scouting talent for their fledgling services. (Last week Bloomberg began a 90-minute business news program, from 5:30 to 7 A.M. on USA Network.)
Indeed, some business reporters have already become prized properties. Kitty Pilgrim, a CNN correspondent in her late 30's, recently became the host of her own program, "Your Money." Colleagues of Ms. Pilgrim said she was courted by other networks when her contract came up for renewal recently.
As CNN and CNBC seek to expand their fairly narrow audiences, though, some broadcast executives are starting to ask whether business reporters need to speak less like M.B.A.'s and more like laymen.
IN 1993, NBC HIRED ROGER Ailes, the acid-tongued Republican image consultant, to be president of CNBC. His mandate is to broaden the network's appeal beyond its traditional audience of traders and retirees who play the stock market from their easy chairs.
Among his most visible changes, Mr. Ailes removed the "ticker," the stock tape that scrolls across the bottom of the television screen, during CNBC's personal-finance programming, which is on from 7 to 8 P.M. "By 6 in the evening, people just aren't watching it anymore," he said.
Mr. Ailes said his move was part of a bigger effort to make CNBC palatable to younger viewers. He has sharpened the look of the network by improving lighting and camera angles, and by coaching the anchors on how to jazz up their interviews with corporate executives or money managers. Dan Dorfman, CNBC's famously jazzed-up market watcher, has resolutely resisted any efforts to improve his on-camera appearance.
Mr. Ailes said CNBC would also experiment with more general-interest programming, including a business program devoted to entertainment.
Some veteran financial journalists believe that television should worry less about appearances and more about covering business overseas.
"Our preoccupation with domestic navel-gazing has distracted us from paying attention to events outside the U.S.," said Louis Rukeyser, the host of "Wall Street Week With Louis Rukeyser," a PBS public-affairs program about business that is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year.
Mr. Dobbs, whose department already produces 10 business programs for CNN, said that foreign news will be a key component of CNNFN. He already has 100 editorial employees in his midtown Manhattan studio. Employees at CNN said he may hire another 40 to fill out the new network, which will be based in New York. Mr. Dobbs declined to discuss his plans.
Mr. Ailes and Mr. Dobbs have sharply different views of CNN's motives in starting a new channel. Mr. Ailes said CNN is worried by the growing prominence of CNBC. He said Mr. Dobbs is gunning for CNBC's audience of professional money managers and at-home investors. But Mr. Dobbs contended that CNN appeals to a much broader news audience and that its new network will, too.
No matter how one slices the television business audience, the numbers are far from spectacular. CNBC's business programs are watched by an average of 206,000 viewers a day and CNN's "Moneyline" is seen by 353,000 a day, the A. C. Nielsen Company said. Those numbers represent a fraction of the viewership for even the last-place network newscast. Indeed, the crucial question for executives at CNN and CNBC is, Are there enough viewers to justify all this business news?
Mr. Levine of NBC pointed out that when push comes to shove on television, financial news still gets shelved in favor of more dramatic stories. Right now, for example, the O. J. Simpson trial has squeezed many business stories off "NBC Nightly News," he said.
"When you get an O. J. Simpson or an Oklahoma City or a Bosnia," he said, "financial news is pretty much at the bottom of the list -- because it usually lacks the visual qualities of these stories."

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By TERENCE NEILAN

 BODY:

Grand Canyon of Spain
 
Q. In 1978 my wife and I went to Spain and visited El Chorro de Gargantua, or the Grand Canyon of Spain, north of Malaga, and found it to be an extraordinary experience. But no one we speak to has ever heard of it. Were we in the Twilight Zone? -- Harold Alan Pincus, M.D., Chevy Chase, Md.
 
A. Your memory has got it almost right. 
 What you have in mind is known as La Garganta del Chorro, and sometimes as the Gorge of Los Gaitanes.
It is essentially a canyon that has been created between two mountains by the River Guadalhorce, with deep, perpendicular-sided ravines that can be reached only by way of a narrow footpath known as the King's Way. Access to the path, which has been worn away over the years and and should be approached with caution, is made by crossing a wooden footbridge that spans the canyon. The reward for your efforts -- the hike is considered of medium difficulty and takes about three hours to complete -- comes at the canyon's inner valley, an area of quiet waters and green pastures.
La Garganta is near a town called Alora, which has Roman and Moorish remains, and is 30 miles from Malaga. But the hiking path is reached from the village of El Chorro, 30 miles north of Malaga on Route 332. El Chorro can also be reached by train from Malaga.
Next to El Chorro railroad station is Refugio del Chorro, a center that organizes half-day and full-day tours of the area. You can also sleep there for about $4 a night, calculated at 125 pesetas to the dollar, if you take your own sleeping bag. Half-day tours are $8, full-day $12.
Horseback riding is also available for $10 an hour or $50 for a day and climbing lessons are given throughout the year. For more information call (34 95) 249 72 19.
A reservoir and camping area, called Camping de los Ardales, is some four miles north of Garganta del Chorro. More information: (34 95) 245 80 87.
The Alora tourist office can be reached at (34 95) 249 83 80 and the Malaga tourist office at (34 95) 221 34 45.
 
Passage to Panama
 
Q. I have long desired to sail through the Panama Canal, but the thought of having to take a long cruise to accomplish this has not appealed to me. Are there any feasible alternatives not involving a cruise? -- Richard J. Delaney, the Bronx
 
A. There are a couple of ways of doing it, both involving ships run by Argo Tours of Panama City.
Panama Discovery Tours, which acts as the agent in the United States for Argo, specializes in tours to Panama.
Most consist of activities centered around Panama City and the canal and most include a full or partial transit of the waterway.
For your purposes it would probably be best to concentrate on what the company calls its Panama Discovery Tours, which run from three to eight days. The three-day tour consists of two nights in a hotel and either a partial transit of the canal and a guided tour of Panama City or a full transit of the canal.
Prices for a double range from $240 a person in economy class to $363 in deluxe. Prices for a single go from $306 to $510. Air fares and meals are extra.
The longer tours add such features as a train ride through a rain forest, a day of swimming and exploring on Taboga Island, visits with Embera Indians or a visit to Drake's Island, burial place of Sir Francis Drake.
Prices range from $369 for a double in economy for the four-day tour to $1,295 for a deluxe double on the eight-day trip. Singles run from $468 to $1,959. Some meals are included.
Tours will run from July 27 to Aug. 3, Aug. 24 to 31, Sept. 28 to Oct. 5, Oct. 26 to Nov. 2, Nov. 23 to 30, Dec. 21 to 28 and Dec. 28 to Jan. 4, 1996.
More information: Pacific Discovery Tours, Post Office Box 130, Clarita, Okla. 74535; (405) 428-3476, fax (405) 428-3499.
If you want to make your own canal transit arrangements, Argo's two ships, the Islamorada, which holds up to 125 passengers, and the 500-passenger Fantasia del Mar, make full transits every other month from Dock 17 in Balboa, on the Pacific Ocean, to Cristobal, on the Atlantic. Passengers are taken back to Balboa, a distance of about 45 miles, on an air-conditioned bus.
The trip, which takes from six hours to eight hours or more, depending on canal traffic, costs $90, children 12 and under $69.
The partial transits are made every Saturday starting at 7:30 A.M., when one of the ships leaves Balboa and sails through the Miraflores Locks.
It then cruises the Miraflores Lake up to Pedro Miguel Locks. At that point it goes back past Balboa to beyond the harbor breakwater. After cruising off the coast it heads back to Dock 17, arriving at about 11:30 A.M.
The cost of the partial transits is $45 a person, $25 for children 12 and under. The price includes brunch.
More information: Argo Tours, Apartado 9662, Panama 4, Republic of Panama; 011 (507) 228-6069, fax 011 (507) 228-1234.
 
Nepal and Bhutan
 
Q. I am off to Nepal and Bhutan in October. Where can I get tourist information for these two countries? -- A. Bottenhorn, Flushing, Queens
 
A. Official tourist information on the Himalayan kingdom of Nepal can be obtained from Nepal's Mission to the United Nations or from its embassy in Washington.
Write or call the Nepal Mission to the United Nations, 820 Second Avenue, Suite 302, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 370-4188. The embassy is at 2131 Leroy Place N.W., Washington D.C. 20008; (202) 667-4550.
Bhutan, also a Himalayan kingdom, has had no official tourism office in the United States since 1987. But a privately run company called Bhutan Travel, which specializes in trips to that part of the world, says it would be happy to send out information. It can be reached at 120 East 56th Street, New York, N.Y.; (212) 838-6382.
 
Ireland on a Tandem
 
Q. My husband and I are planning a trip to Ireland and would like to do some sightseeing by tandem bicycle. Could we arrange to rent one for our arrival? -- Emily Miller, Ann Arbor, Mich.
 
A. There is only one store renting tandems in Dublin, according to the Irish Tourist Board. Contact Joe Daly Cycles, Main Street Lower, Dundrum, Dublin 14, Ireland; (353 1) 298 1485. Rates are $25 a day, calculated at $1.67 to the pound. Daly's has three tandems but reservations are strongly advised.
In other towns the local tourist board offices will be able to help. For a list of their addresses and phone numbers contact the Irish Tourist Board, 345 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10154; (212) 418-0800 or (800) 223-6470. TERENCE NEILAN

HEADLINE: Manhattan Renters Find Tighter Market

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
MOBILITY is theoretically the beauty of renting. There's no need to worry about selling in order to relocate. But what if there's nothing much out there to rent?
Inveterate renters who insist on staying in Manhattan -- to say nothing of outsiders relocating to the city -- are finding shrinking availabilities and higher prices these days. The situation was foreseeable, and widely foreseen, even five years ago during the depth of the doldrums in the real-estate market. It was a buyer's market then in sales as well as rentals. But gradually vacancies were absorbed. 
 Meanwhile, new construction came almost to a standstill -- and hasn't revived yet. The supply-demand balance has turned.
One result is a brisk renting pace at West End Towers, formerly known as Manhattan West, on the West Side and the Brittany on the East Side, the only major new apartment projects on the market this year. At West End Towers, a nearly completed development with 1,000 apartments on West End Avenue between 61st and 63d Streets, the Brodsky Organization, the owner-builder, expects the entire rent-up to take a year, compared with the more typical year and a half in a project of that size.
"It's a hot market -- we've already rented 500 apartments," said Daniel Brodsky, the developer.
The Brittany, a 273-unit building at York Avenue and 92d Street, rented out between October and May, according to Glenwood Management, the owner. One line of one-bedroom apartments had six prices increases during the rent-up period. They were offered at an average rent of $1,800 a month at the start and at $2,000 a month at the end, Glenwood said.
Another consequence of the tightened market is that owners no longer offer brokers a payment to rent out apartments, thereby increasing the pressure on brokers to collect a full fee from tenants -- usually 15 percent of a year's rent.
Many tenants feel they cannot afford such a fee, even if they get a quality of service that seems to justify it, which is not always the case. At 15 percent, a tenant renting a $1,200 apartment has to be ready for an initial payment of at least $4,560 by move-in time -- $1,200 for the first month's rent, $1,200 for a security deposit, and $2,160 as the fee.
The level of brokerage costs has brought forth a competing form of middleman service, offered by the The Apartment Store, operating from loft premises on East 29th Street. At a fixed rate of $125, it provides customers with a fax or e-mail of available Manhattan apartments that fall within a client's rent ranges, size and desired location. The faxes are dispatched regularly until an apartment is found. A staff of nine keeps in touch by phone with 920 owners or managing agents to get listings, said Barry Feinsmith, the owner. There are none below $800 a month.
Still another effect of the tighter market is the slowdown in turnover in existing housing. With fewer availabilities and higher prices, more people stay put. At the Rivergate, a 700-unit rental built in 1985 between First Avenue and the East River from 34th to 35th Streets, about 250 apartments were vacated and rerented each year from 1992 through 1994, said Gene Waggelman, the director of leasing. This year, half that many will be rerented, he said.
"The move-outs have slowed," Mr. Waggelman said. "There's no new construction. The apartment glut has been absorbed."
Figures supplied by city officials show a substantial drop in new construction by historic standards. Last year building permits were granted for only 560 housing units in Manhattan, 428 of them in the private sector. The five-year average from 1990 through 1994 was 1,250 units a year.
In the 80's, housing completions averaged 3,600 a year in Manhattan in the public and private sectors. In the 70's the 10-year average was 4,500 a year. In the more ebullient 60's, the average was 10,200 units a year.
In the 1992 book "Scarcity by Design," Peter D. Salins and Gerard C. S. Mildner contend that the shortages and high prices apartment seekers find are the inevitable consequence of public policies involving housing. They cite the price controls and occupancy protections of rent regulation, the city's strict land-use controls, the high degree of public participation in housing ownership and management and a property-tax system that favors single-family housing over multifamily housing.
ROOT causes aside, the Manhattan residential market appears to be marching into familiar territory, with greater rental shortages and higher prices, but with a new twist. More than in past cycles, there are availabilities in the for-sale market. This is the result of widespread conversions in the 80's, and the sharp decline in the sales market in 1990. Many owner-occupants have moved and kept their units as rentals, though co-op boards resist long-term rentals.
Feathered Nest, one of the city's most active rental agencies, with a staff of 90, reports that two-thirds of the apartments it finds for renters are in co-op or condominium buildings. These are primarily listings from individual owners.
In addition, conversion sponsors or their investor-successors have tended to rent out rather than sell vacancies in apartments that have never had an owner-occupant, making these apartments, at least until the sales market strengthens, part of the rental housing supply.
Younger renters in Manhattan often say they eventually intend to leave the city, especially when they are ready to buy rather than rent and may have children to raise. They recognize that the longer they stay put in one residence, the stronger the case becomes for ownership rather than renting. With the help of a mortgage loan, the buyer can acquire a growing stake in an asset that under normal circumstances will appreciate in value by an amount that will at least have kept pace with inflation.
Nonetheless, the shift to home-ownership also involves the assumption of responsibility for the property -- or, in the case of a co-op or condominium, a share of the responsibility -- that many individuals feel unprepared to accept. For them, renting may be the best alternative even in the long term.
The desire for housing flexibility -- mobility -- and the consequent dedication to rental life is clearly on view at West End Towers. It has made a confirmed renter of Dennis S. Walker, for example. A 35-year-old native of Kansas, Mr. Walker became president of the Givenchy Corporation's North American operations last December. He came to the city in 1984, three years after graduating from Kansas State with a business and accounting degree.
During a varied career on the business side of the design world he lived in seven Manhattan apartments -- a $750-a-month studio on West 47th Street; a $1,000 floor-through in a brownstone on West 96th Street, shared with a roommate; a $250 sublet on West 45th Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues; a $925 studio with a skylight in a renovated 27th Street walk-up; an $1,850 one-bedroom duplex at Second Avenue and 17th Street; a $1,100 subleased one-bedroom co-op on West 92d Street, and a $1,200 furnished one-bedroom on East 88th Street. In between, he moved back to Kansas City for six months in 1993.
Now he lives in a sunny 16th-floor one-bedroom with a long terrace facing east at 55 West End Avenue. The rent is $1,875. "I'm the kind of person who moves around," Mr. Walker said. "I need flexibility. If I need to move to Paris or somewhere else, I could do it. But actually I see myself staying where I am for a while, maybe four years."
In the same building, Patricia McCaffery, a mezzo-soprano, teaches opera singers. She came to New York from Florida at the age of 21 in 1970, and since then has sung and coached in New York, Michigan, Arizona and Connecticut. "Over 25 years I've rented or sublet seven apartments," she said. Now she lives in a $2,500-a-month two-bedroom in a line of apartments in which the living room abuts no other apartment and lies below an open terrace, assuring no objections to singing lessons from neighbors.
About 50 percent of the one-bedroom renters at West End Towers have been sharers, said Sandy Rotkoff, the leasing director. In a typical situation, they have just finished business school, earn about $40,000 a year with prospects of a 15 percent year-end bonus, and can afford a $1,700 rent, she said. Two-thirds of the apartments are studios or one-bedrooms.
Apartment seekers with lesser means have bigger problems. Success goes to the dogged, the ingenious, the patient and the lucky, or some combination thereof. Some have turned to a newly published volume called "Gabriel's Apartment Rental Guide," by Michael Gabriel, a former Glenwood Management leasing agent, which is available in bookstores. It lists the features of more than 300 buildings and the phone numbers to call for rental information, and gives neighborhood and other housing-related information. Others use agents and newspaper ads (often leading them to brokers), or shoe leather, or tips from friends.
"Finding an apartment in New York is one of the most debilitating, demeaning, horrible experiences anyone can go through," said Terri Semper, 35, who arrived from California last year and took a job as assistant to the president of a record company. "In North Hollywood I paid $765 a month for a huge two-bedroom in a courtyard building. Here I pay $1,250 a month for a studio."
Ms. Semper found the inability to present an unblemished credit record a major hurdle in renting an apartment. As a teen-ager 17 years ago she had too many credit cards and was late in some payments. She had no problems renting in Los Angeles, and no further credit problems, but she was rejected in six buildings in Manhattan when she acknowledged her credit history, she said. West End Towers accepted her with a two-month security deposit.
"Even a minor blemish on your record and you can't get an apartment!" she said. "I wish someone had stressed that to me when I was a kid."
Susan Platt, 25, had her employer's help. She was transferred to New York from Denver by an insurance brokerage, Rollins Hudig Hall, which picked up the brokerage fee of Marc Lewis Realty. She rented a $1,000 studio at 88th Street and Lexington Avenue. The search took two days.
MARC OROMANER, 24, was earning about $35,000 a year working as a production associate at CBS and living with two roommates on East 52d Street near First Avenue. He wanted to move into his own apartment. "My idea of a studio apartment was $600 a month," he said. "Everybody said, 'Yeah sure.' " He pounded the pavements between Third and First Avenues from 35th Street to 59th Street, back and forth, looking for signs. That led him nowhere.
He finally rented a second-floor studio in a five-story walk-up around the corner from his old apartment on First Avenue for $770 a month, using the Marc Lewis Realty firm and paying, reluctantly, almost the entire brokerage fee of 15 percent of a year's rent. "I got them to knock off $100," he said.
Many management companies now want renters to be earning 50 times their monthly rent, a tougher standard than they required a few years ago. It means that an individual renting an $800 studio should be earning at least $40,000. Starting salaries for college graduates are often lower than that, which is why so many young people live with parents or roommates.
But the 50-times standard is not universal. Rose Associates, for example, says it uses 43 times the monthly income (a $34,400 income acceptable for an $800 studio). "The tightening market is no reason to raise the multiplier," said Adam R. Rose, executive vice president.
At Normandie Court, a 1,477-unit development at 95th Street and Third Avenue, about three-quarters of the roughly 500 two-bedroom apartments are occupied by sharers, according to Stephen Dolnick, director of residential leasing for Milstein Properties, the owner. Three occupants each earning about $35,000 a year can take on a two-bedroom apartment renting for about $2,100 a month. If one or two leave, replacements arrive. Parents often guarantee the rent.
But in the longer term, tenants expect that rising income will enable them to move on to their own apartments, whether or not they pair off through marriage or a partner.
West End Towers has tapped into that vein, too. One of its new tenants is Lorin Konner, 23, a production coordinator for MTV, who had been sharing with two other young women on East 86th Street. "I wanted to live alone," she said. After moving in with her parents for a while in Wyckoff, N.J., she moved into a fourth-floor studio last January at $1,175 a month in rent.
The newly married Elizabeth Herbert and Dr. Jerald Vizzone are moving tomorrow into a 22d-floor one-bedroom renting at $1,760. Mrs. Vizzone said she has lived in five different rentals over nine years. "Word of mouth is the most successful way of looking," she said, but she found her way to West End Towers via The Apartment Store, the eight-month-old fax service.
Mr. Feinsmith, of The Apartment Store, said he had a database of 227,000 apartments in about 1,200 buildings in Manhattan, from Columbia University to the Battery on the West Side and from 96th Street to the Battery on the East Side. The availability rate in these apartments ranges from 0.4 to 0.6 percent, he said.
A computerized breakdown of availabilities on June 21 by location indicated that apartment hunters looking for larger apartments (two bedrooms and more) would have to pay at least $2,000 a month on the Upper West Side (defined as north of 60th Street) and upwards of $1,500 on the Upper East Side. But the one-day snapshot showed East Side two-bedrooms ranging as high as $20,000 a month; the upper edge was $6,800 on the West Side.
It is probable that the most experienced young apartment-shoppers -- with financial resources -- do best in the search. Joshua Mondschein, 30, is a Manhattan native and a self-employed life insurance and employee benefits consultant whose business grosses in six figures. In the last seven years he has lived in Tudor City; at 201 East 12th Street; at 111 Fourth Avenue between 11th and and 12th Streets, and at Broadway and 76th Street. Now he rents a $1,350 studio with a terrace at 75 West End Towers.
"Each move helps me to re-evaluate how I'd like to live," he said. "Every apartment has been different. Ultimately when I buy, I'll have a perspective on different types of buildings. I expect to live in Manhattan the rest of my life."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Sheepshead Bay;
Should There Be a Fishing Village or a Loehmann's?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT seemed like a great idea, way back when. Take Sheepshead Bay, with its active deep-sea fishing fleet, broad promenade and protected bay; add a few more seafood restaurants and nautical shops; keep mundane stores out, and voila: A nautically themed magnet for fishing buffs and tourists, right on Brooklyn's southern shore.
At least, that's what city planners envisioned in 1973, when they created the Special Sheepshead Bay District, a 20-block tract from Sheepshead Bay Road to Knapp Street. Emmons Avenue, running along the water and home of Lundy's seafood restaurant, was to be the district's cultural heart. 
 Well, it never happened. Irving Lundy, who owned much of the land in the district, died in 1977, and Lundy's closed two years later. Although the city has rebuilt several piers, the fishing fleet, once more than 40 boats strong, is down to about 20 boats. Indeed, the area is known more for its high rate of car theft than for its fishing boats.
"We've just got to accept that the district's goals were never realized," said Mitchell Corby, director of the City Planning Department's Brooklyn Office.
Now Sheepshead Bay lies at the heart of a brewing controversy over whether the fishing village idea should be given a second chance, or whether the city should just cry uncle on the idea of quaintness and opt instead for conventional development.
On one side sit the Bay Improvement Group and the Sheepshead Bay Fishing Fleet Association, which insist that city bureaucracy, developer shenanigans and bad economic timing -- not anything fundamentally wrong with the concept -- has kept the fishing village from becoming reality.
"Special districts have characteristics that outweigh the need for short-term development," said Steven M. Barrison, president of the Bay Improvement Group. "A protected harbor is such a characteristic."
But his opponents, including Community Board 15 and several real estate developers, have lost their taste for endlessly delayed gratification. They want to put conventional retailing on Emmons Avenue.
"Maybe this isn't the best use for waterfront property, but no one is knocking on our door offering to do other things," said John E. Nikas, Board 15's chairman.
It is no academic argument. Emmons Avenue Development wants to build a retail center, anchored by a 28,000 square-foot Loehmann's fashion discount store, on a weed-strewn lot at Emmons and 21st Street that it bought in 1986 with the idea of building condominiums.
The Loehmann's building is prohibited by the special zoning, which restricts stores to 35 feet of frontage and 3,500 square feet of total space.
EMMONS was turned down for a zoning variance, but refiled, saying that new findings about the difficulties of building on the land qualify it for a hardship variance. Even those opposed to the building expect the variance to be granted when the Board of Standards and Appeals votes on July 18.
The developers say the arguments against the building are specious. "The same building, with a bunch of 3,500-square-foot stores instead of one Loehmann's, would be pretty close to what would be allowed, even with the existing zoning," said Jay A. Segal, a lawyer with Rosenman & Colin who represents the developers.
Anthony Clemenza, Emmons Avenue Development's president, also says he does not understand all the fuss. "This site is in dire need of development, the community board loved our project, and it can bring year-round jobs and people to an area where for 10 months a year you can roll a bowling ball down the street and hit nothing," he said.
Even without Loehmann's, the Emmons Avenue tide is turning toward conventional retailing. Lundy Management Corporation, an investor group, is converting the long-empty landmarked Lundy's restaurant at 19th Street into a covered mall, anchored by a much-smaller version of the original Lundy's and an oriental restaurant on Emmons, and up to 50 small shops inside.
The Department of City Planning also seems ready to give up on a fishing village. A few months ago Mr. Corby's staff issued proposed modifications to the zoning that would allow 50 feet of frontage on stores and would widen the types of stores allowed.
"The district must be made more flexible to mesh with the times," Mr. Corby said.
He certainly gets no argument from George Hofman, who is putting up an 11,000-square-foot retail building at 23d Street and Emmons. Mr. Hoffman says his building is 60 percent rented, but he has had to forgo tenants who would pay higher rents.
"They won't let me put in a bank or a pharmacy or a doctor's office," Mr. Hofman said. "It is the height of absurdity, the tyranny of the few. They've tried for this fishing village for 20 years, it just hasn't worked, and it's not going to work."
Not surprisingly, such talk infuriates the fishing-village proponents. They insist that inadequate parking facilities in Sheepshead Bay have sent would-be anglers and fishing boats to the Jersey Shore and Long Island, and that better parking and touristy-type shops would quickly bring them back.
They insist that Loehmann's and other conventional retail stores could find ample inland space to build. (Mr. Nikas says other available sites are too small.) They want the city to condemn the land along the waterfront and use it to create parking and the type of retailing that would support the fleet.
"A building of the size and scale of the Loehmann's is the worst thing that could happen to the waterfront," said Anne O'Driscoll, president of the Fishing Fleet Association. "What we need is parking, and small stores where you can buy a cup of espresso and a T-shirt for the kids."
That would help the entire district, Mr. Barrison insists. "A fishing village with entertainment and tiny shops will bring more people than a women's discount store," he said.
Maybe so -- provided those people are not wooed away by City Island, that Bronx area near Orchard Beach. The island, once a major shipbuilding center, is replete with seafood restaurants and tiny shops. Le Refuge, an inn, opened there last year. Several community activists want to turn the area into what Jackie Kyle, a local realtor, calls "the next Mystic Seaport," referring to Connecticut's successful nautical tourist spot.
NOT every City Islander loves the idea, though. The island is plagued with traffic congestion, and many residents fear that any influx of tourists, without adequate parking to absorb their cars, would make their streets even more impenetrable than they are now. But there are no developers vying to put up retail behemoths in City Island, and Georgina E. Soccodato, vice president of the Northeast Bronx Coalition, says she is pretty sure that local land owners can be persuaded to convert some of their vacant land to parking.
"City Island is the star of the Bronx; it should be turned into a year-round tourist attraction," she said.
For now, City Island's spruce-up plans are politically stalled. Bronx Assemblyman Stephen B. Kaufman says that the state Urban Development Corporation had committed funds to redo some of the facades of City Island's stores, but the project went on hold when the administration changed.
"My goal is still to get that money and make this a truly beautiful place," he said.
Even city officials admit that City Island has a better chance of making a go of it than does Sheepshead Bay.
"City Island already has the restaurants, the nearby beach and the physical insularity," said Henry J. Stern, the city's Commissioner of Parks and Recreation. "Sheepshead Bay is geographically awkward."
It is also, it seems, a place where only the retail developers are ready to spend money. Mr. Stern's agency recently asked for bids to build a $1.4 million playground and parking lot on some city-owned waterfront property. He figured that in an area where everyone complains so bitterly about inadequate parking, the parking fees would pay back the cost.
There were rumors that Lundy Management would spring for the project, but the June 9 deadline for bids came and went without one submitted bid.
"With all the grand plans, the Loehmann's folks are the only ones who have come up with money for anything," Mr. Stern said.

LENGTH: 1056 words

HEADLINE: NEWS AND TOPICS: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
Saving a Wilderness for Tourists,and More Endangered Species

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: MAURICE RIVER TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine a landscape of more jarring contrasts. A river thick with organic debris zigzags slowly across a lush, marshy plain teeming with life. Less than 1,000 feet away, behind a stand of pines, sits a vast, blasted-out desert, humps of exposed sand surrounding a crystal-clear dredging pond that glows an unearthly bluish-green in the sun.
This is the Manumuskin Preserve, 3,257 acres of primeval river, pine-oak forest and abandoned sand mines near the state's southwestern edge. A month ago, after a long and tangled land-use struggle, it was acquired by the Nature Conservancy, the environmental group that buys land all over the country to preserve it forever. 
 Its dedication on June 9 marked the preservation of a gem -- albeit slightly compromised -- that biologists say is home to the largest assemblage of rare and endangered species in the state. In recent years, it was slated first for a hazardous waste dump and then housing with an industrial park.
But the preserve is more than just a fenced-off beauty spot. As the sand mines revert to nature, officials who initially resented the Nature Conservancy's entry into local politics now hope to make the park a centerpiece of a move to bring more nature-based tourism to this scenic but chronically depressed township.
In a community where land use is already severely restricted by state pinelands and coastal zone regulations, local officials seem to be letting go of their dreams of attracting big business and setting their sights on bird-watchers and hikers instead.
"Eco-tourism is the future as we look at it," said Mayor Jack Feltes, who is also public works director for Cumberland County. He added that the township was also trying to persuade the State Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife to build a $4 million interpretive center in the hamlet of Leesburg.
The township's Delaware Bay coast already draws legions of birders every spring, but this relatively affluent group of tourists have few places to spend their money.
"We certainly have the resources, but we don't have the restaurants and the shops," said Leslie Ficcaglia, chairman of the township planning board and a vocal environmental advocate who envisions a local economy built around bed-and-breakfasts, antique stores and river tours.
Not everyone is so optimistic. "I hang in there because I do hope this area is beginning to develop," said Harry Whitlam, owner of the Port of Call restaurant, just down Route 47 from the preserve. "All I can say is I hope it happens down the road."
Still, such shifts in long-range economic planning are getting a push from Trenton these days. State tourism officials held regional workshops on rural tourism and eco-tourism for local officials and the travel industry in Cape May and Warren Counties this spring.
"Many counties are looking to eco-tourism as a way to develop their assets in a way that is harmonious with the environment," said Linda Conlin, director of travel and tourism in the State Commerce Department. "It encourages both residents and visitors to develop an appreciation of our natural resources while generating a revenue stream to help protect those resources."
The land and water that are now the Manumuskin Preserve have been at the center of a decadelong tug-of-war. In 1986, the state decided that the property -- owned and mined by the Warner Company, now a subsidiary of the global waste-handling giant Waste Management Inc. -- would make an ideal spot for a site ominously known as a hazardous waste entombment facility. But it didn't reckon with the sensitive joint vetch, an endangered relative of the sweet pea that proved to be New Jersey's spotted owl.
The vetch, which bears a delicate yellow flower with a brush of sienna, is not merely a coup for environmental scorekeepers. It is a botanical coal-mine canary, sensitive to the slightest impurity in water or soil, and it grows in only four other spots on the planet. Its presence -- along with that of 31 other rare plants; 15 threatened or endangered birds, including bald eagles, and the pine snake, corn snake and dotted skipper butterfly -- was enough to banish the dump.
Then the landowner proposed expanding its mines and building up to 300 homes and an industrial park. This touched off a three-way litigation brawl involving Waste Management, various environmental groups and the township. Along the way, the Manumuskin and another tributary of the Maurice, as well as the Maurice itself, were designated for Federal protection under the Wild and Scenic Rivers Act.
Finally, last December, Waste Management sold the tract to the Nature Conservancy for $2.4 million, half the appraised value of the land, and donated the other half. The tract is by far the largest of the conservancy's 23,000 acres of preserves in the state.
On an early summer morning, the Manumuskin smells like its name and looks like the kind of place where you might expect a brontosaurus to come lumbering around the next bend. Its low marsh of spade-leafed arrow arum, purple-spiked pickerel weed, pink swamp rose and fledgling vetch seems to stretch on forever. Marsh wrens twitter from nests hung in the cordgrass, and every 50 feet or so, red-bellied turtles stand like sentries at the edge of the water, sunning themselves on mud banks dotted with holes for muskrats and river otters. The towering and indestructible phragmites, or foxtail grass, that chokes most of the state's less pristine marshes is nowhere to be seen.
Even the former sand mines, which supplied South Jersey's glass industry, have their own stark beauty -- picture a 20-acre pondful of Caribbean dropped down in the middle of a miniature Badlands of wind-sculptured dunes. The water in the dredging ponds is actually pure, exposed groundwater from the 17-trillion-gallon aquifer that underlies most of the Pinelands, and looks green only because of diffracted sunlight.
Jay Laubengeyer, the Nature Conservancy's bioreserve manager, led the way to one of the smaller ponds, undredged for 15 years, where layers of natural sediment have already started to build up, providing habitat for the insect-eating sundew plant on the shore and sunfish and bluegills in the water.
"If that big pond is the 'before' picture," he said, "this is kind of halfway to the 'after.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jay Laubengeyer of the Nature Conservancy at the Manumuskin Preserve, home to many endangered species. Town officials hope it can be the focus of a tourism industry that draws bird-watchers -- but few beachgoers -- to Delaware Bay beaches (see map). (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2317 words

HEADLINE: Junior Achievement

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY and JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE power and influence of New Jersey's delegation to the House of Representatives is etched in stone, literally: dozens of important buildings erected over many years with Federal dollars and the federally subsidized roadways that helped define the state.
The delegation's members were also immortalized by Congressional longevity of legendary proportions and their ability, year after year, to herd billions of dollars to their home turf. 
 But the buildings, the roads and the legends are almost all that remain of such heady days. For the current members of the delegation, Washington and their role bear almost no resemblance to the past and the parliamentary giants whose sometimes dictatorial hold on power meant money and jobs in their districts and assured them of re-election and greater seniority.
The eight Republican and five Democratic House members from New Jersey -- three of them freshmen and two others in just their second term -- came to a brand-new Washington in January for the start of the 104th Congress and its Republican Contract With America. The 1990 Census had reduced their number by one, and a wave of retirements placed the group's seniority at the lowest point in a quarter-century.
Perhaps more significant, it is a group whose moderate bent makes it seem almost liberal in a sea of hard-right conservatives. And for the first time in a generation, the delegation lacks the comfort of a major committee chairmanship.
Despite it all, it is a group that has shown -- at least in the early going -- that it is well suited to thrive in Washington's new, Republican-driven environment of smaller government, tax cutting and less spending.
"People recognize that the New Jersey delegation is not going to be playing second fiddle to anyone," said Representative Rodney P. Frelinghuysen, a freshman Republican from Harding, in Morris County.
There was a time when that would not have been an issue.
The Federal office building in Newark bears the name of Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., who became powerful as chairman of the Judiciary Committee and achieved national fame during the 1974 Watergate hearings. The Public Works Committee was headed by Representative James J. Howard, a Democrat who died in 1988 after more than 20 years in Congress. In his career, he doled out billions for construction projects, and Interstate 195, which cuts across the central part of the state, was dedicated to his memory.
"It's arguable that up to a few years ago, New Jersey had the most powerful delegation in the United States," said Representative Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood, the dean of the state's Democratic delegation. "We had three full committee chairmen, and every other Democrat was at least chairman of a subcommittee."
But retirements during the last six years cost the delegation more than a century's worth of House seniority -- Mr. Rodino (40 years), Robert A. Roe (25 years), Matthew J. Rinaldo (20 years), William J. Hughes (20 years), Frank J. Guarini (14 years), Bernard J. Dwyer (12 years) and Dean A. Gallo (10 years) -- and the committee positions and political muscle that longevity traditionally brought.
brought.
Whatever vestige of traditional clout that New Jersey commanded after the retirements between 1988 and 1994 was further eroded by the overwhelming Republican victory that not only stripped Mr. Torricelli and other Democrats of their leadership on subcommittees but also redefined power in Washington.
"Are we as powerful as New Jersey delegations have been historically?" said Representative Bob Franks, of New Providence in Union County, a Republican who began his second term in January. "I don't think anybody is as powerful anymore.
"But there has been a wholesale change in the attitude about what power is around here," he went on. "The definition of an effective congressman before we got here was the biggest pig at the trough, the one who could bring home the most bacon. Now we are about cutting the size of government and spending and that has meant some major adjustments."
What the New Jersey delegation might have lost in individual influence, however, it has made up in a political realignment on Capitol Hill caters to newcomers who are sworn to term limits, budget reduction and tax cuts. With the first Republican majority in 40 years and 73 freshman Republicans, the realignment is nearly revolutionary.
One of the first tasks set by the new Speaker, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, was to rewrite House rules so that committee chairman may not serve more than three terms or six years before relinquishing the gavel. Mr. Gingrich also applied the rule to himself.
"It's a different Congress, and more and more of its members don't believe the way to get re-elected is to become Washington insiders," said Stephen A. Salmore, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and a Republican consultant.
Despite its moderate tilt, the New Jersey delegation has fared well in general under the new conservative House leadership by staking out a centrist position.
"This puts them in the middle in a negotiating role and enables them to gain leverage for New Jersey's interests," Mr. Salmore said.
That point was driven home by a recent debate in the Appropriations Committee over whether to extend the moratorium on offshore drilling. The committee's Republican leadership opposed the extension, but the California and Florida delegations appealed first to New Jersey and then to other coastal states for support and were able to extend the ban.
"The New Jersey delegation did a good job opposing the Clean Water Bill because of its impact on wetlands and by supporting continuing the moratorium on offshore drilling, two pretty important issues for the state," Mr. Salmore said.
IN the delegation, Representative H. James Saxton, an 11-year veteran from Mount Holly, in Burlington County, is the closest to the new center of power. He is vice-chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, the congressional counterpart of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and wrote the Republicans' talking points -- a kind of briefing paper on the points they wanted to emphasize -- in defense of their Contract With America.
But the Speaker ignored seniority in handing out committee assignments.
To the annoyance of some veteran Republican members, Mr. Gingrich bypassed dozens of them in favor of underclassmen who he felt would be less resistant to change and more reliable foot soldiers -- a move that placed three junior members from New Jersey on powerful committees.
That strategy, however, has not always worked to Mr. Gingrich's liking.
In March, Representative William J. Martini, a freshman Republican from Clifton, in Passaic County, was one of the leaders of an uprising against the proposed $500-per-child tax credit that was one of the centerpieces of the Contract With America. Mr. Martini and about 100 Republicans and 23 Democrats were able to force the Speaker to accept an amendment to withhold the credit until Congress guaranteed it could balance the budget.
Although Mr. Martini and the other seven Republicans in the delegation -- including its two other freshmen, Mr. Frelinghuysen and Frank A. LoBiondo of Vineland, in Cumberland County -- have voted in lockstep with the leadership, the freshman bloc has also exerted some independence.
"We have a fresher point of view that has not been softened by years in the Legislature or by the process, which tends to make incumbents not as forthright," Mr. Martini said. "For this I credit the leadership, which has encouraged us to speak out."
In a shift that was no less profound, the Republicans have made it their mission to cut spending drastically, spending, a move that would shut off yet another measure of traditional power in Washington: pork-barrel politics, or the ability of even low-ranking members to bring millions or billions of dollars home for projects and programs.
"I think we in the New Jersey delegation reflect what has happened to the Congress," said another Republican, Representative Richard A. Zimmer, of Delaware Township in Hunterdon County.
Three terms as the representative for the 12th District in central New Jersey make him senior to more than half of the members of the House.
"It doesn't take as much to be senior anymore," said Mr. Zimmer, who won a seat on Ways and Means, the powerful tax-writing committee. He is the first member of the Ways and Means Committee from New Jersey since Representative Robert Winthrop Kean ( the father of former Gov. Thomas H. Kean), who was a member of the House from 1939 to 1959.
Two other junior members of the delegation have seats on major committees -- Mr. Franks on Budget and Mr. Frelinghuysen on Appropriations.
Despite the changes in Washington politics, the delegation is still tightly united behind the meat-and-potatoes issues of New Jersey politics -- the coast, mass transportation, military-base closing.
"Historically, the New Jersey delegation has pulled together on a bipartisan basis for the good of the state when a broad issue presents itself," said Marge S. Roukema, a Republican from Ridgewood in Bergen County who was elected in 1980.
Mrs. Roukema's 14 years in Congress make her not only the dean of the delegation but also the longest serving of all 49 womenin the House of Representatives.
The Republican majority's largely conservative agenda has given rise to more frequent and much sharper differences than with some of the previous delegations.
"They walked too much in lock step with the leadership in supporting the Contract With America," said Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat from Hudson County who in 1992 became the first Hispanic member from New Jersey. "The delegation as a whole is younger and more conservative in my view, but it is energetic and has several reflective individuals."
Members nowadays are apt to be identified more with the issues that they champion rather than the delegation bloc.
For example:
*Mr. Torricelli, the ranking member of the Subcommittee on the Western Hemispehere of the International Relations Committee and a member of the Select Committee on Intelligence, has made foreign affairs, the military and intelligence gathering his domain.
*Representative Donald M. Payne, a four-term Democrat from Newark and the delegation's only black member, is the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus and a leading expert on African affairs.
*Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat from Long Branch in Monmouth County, with seven years in Washington, is the ranking member of the Commerce Subcommittee on Energy and Environment and a leader in the drive to end ocean dumping of sewage sludge.
*Representative Christopher H. Smith, a Republican from Washington Township in Mercer County, has risen to national prominance because of his strong anti-abortion views. From his new position as chairman of the Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights, he has introduced legislation that would limit the availability of abortions.
*Mr. Menendez, of Union City, represents one of the most ethnically diverse and urbanized districts in the United States. He has staked out immigration and mass transportation as his specialities.
Seven terms in the House have made Mrs. Roukema a recognized expert on banking issues -- she is chairman of the Banking and Financial Services Committee -- but not the kind of with the political renown that some of her predecessors had.
"We don't have a lot of marquee names in the delegation anymore," said Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Bellmawr in Camden County who has spent his five years in Congress preaching budget cuts. "If you were writing about this delegation 10 years ago you would have been talking about the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, the chairman of the Public Works Committee and other significant members of the House."
Indeed, the marquee name associated with the New Jersey delegation nowadays is not even a member, but the Governor -- Christine Todd Whitman, a popular Republican who has been talked about as a possible vice presidential candidate in 1996 and was picked by Mr. Gingrich to deliver the party's response to President Clinton's budget message.
That is not to say that the delegation is without its would-be stars.
Mr. Andrews, 37, succeeded Jim Florio -- who left Congress in 1989 to make a successful bid for Governor and was defeated in 1993 by Mrs. Whitman -- and has made it widely known that he is considering a run for the governorship in 1997. Mr. Torricelli, 43, is considered another of the state Democratic Party's rising stars and has also been mentioned as a possible gubernatorial candidate.
On the Republican side, Mr. Zimmer is seeking the party nomination to challenge the state's senior United States Senator, Bill Bradley, a Democrat, next year. And Mrs. Roukema at least toyed with the idea of a Senate race last year but decided against it.
Compared to the "sagebrush rebels," -- the nickname that Mr. Frelinghuysen and others have assigned to the firebrand conservatives from the West and Northwest who have helped define the new Congress -- even some New Jersey members who are considered conservative back home are viewed in the new Congress as "squishy" Republicans, soft and ill-defined.
But Mr. Frelinghuysen says it isn't ideology but old-fashioned personal contact that enables lawmakers to line up allies in a fight. "I've developed a close working relationship with a colleague on the Budget Committee from California and have been able to ask him for help on legislation when I needed it," he said.
"I've found things much more complex down here than I did when I was a State Assemblyman back home. But one thing that is valuable everywhere in politics and government is the personal touch."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Largely new and untested, New Jersey's Representatives have found a playing field more suited to freshmen than to House chieftains of the past. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Rating the Delegation: A Report Card" lists New Jersey Representatives;
 
"8 Republicans, 5 Democrats: The New Jersey 13, by District"
 
 ROBERT E. ANDREWS, 37, Democrat, first elected in 1990. Lawyer and former professor of law at Rutgers. Former chairman of the Camden County Board of Freeholders. Has positioned himself as a different type of Democrat; kept his 1990 campaign promise to oppose all tax increases during his first term, and was one of only 11 Democrats to vote against President Clinton's 1994 budget, which included higher taxes. This year he was one of nine Democrats to vote for the G.O.P. welfare overhaul. Considered a leading contender to run against Governor Whitman in 1997.

 FRANK A. LoBIONDO, 49, Republican, first elected in 1994 in his second try. Received strong support from local labor unions and from the National Rifle Association. Operations manager for a family-owned trucking business. Served as Cumberland County Freeholder for three years and State Assemblyman for six. In the House, has supported lower taxes, spending cuts and reduced Federal regulations.

 H. JAMES SAXTON, 52, Republican, first elected in 1984. Former teacher and real estate broker who served nine years in the State Legislature. Generally conservative, but led the state delegation this year in bucking the Republican leadership in a losing fight against legislation that would sharply diminish protection of wetlands. Voted against Clinton's economic plans and assailed his health care plan, saying to require employers to pay 80 percent of health care costs would endanger jobs and wages.
 
 CHRISTOPHER H. SMITH, 42, Republican, first elected in 1980. From the beginning, a passionate anti-abortion voice; co-chairman of the House Pro-Life Caucus, and opposed the G.O.P. leadership on eliminating welfare payments for babies born to unmarried teen-age mothers and mothers already on welfare, on the ground that such a freeze would encourage abortions. Strong human-rights advocate, active in efforts to resettle Vietnamese boat people facing deportation from camps in Asia.

 MARGE ROUKEMA, 65, Republican, first elected in 1980. Senior Republican woman in the House. Former high school teacher of government and history. Independent-minded moderate who does not mind differing with her party, especially on child support, child nutrition and abortion. A prime advocate of the family leave measure that was signed into law by President Clinton after two vetoes by George Bush. Strong opponent of term limits: "The Founding Fathers got it right. They established term limits when they wrote the Constitution. They are called elections."

 FRANK PALLONE JR., 43, Democrat, first elected in 1988. Lawyer who was a Long Branch City Councilman for six years and State Senator for six years. Self-described fiscal conservative and "maverick" who opposed President Clinton on Nafta, the 1994 budget bill and moving into Haiti without Congressional approval. Reliable champion for the environmental concerns of his coastal district.

 ROBERT D. FRANKS, 43, Republican, first elected in 1992. Former political consultant and State Assemblyman (1980-92). As Republican state chairman, he organized the campaign that led to the Republicans' taking control of the Legislature in 1991. Attacked President Clinton's economic policies as more big government but has supported the White House on family leave, gun control and easing voter registration. Only member of the delegation in either party to favor diminishing wetlands protection.

 BILL MARTINI, 48, Republican, first elected in 1994, defeating Representative Herb Klein, a freshman Democrat, by 2,000 votes. Former assistant U.S. attorney, assistant Hudson County prosecutor, Clifton City Councilman and Passaic County Freeholder. Has made cutting the deficit a top priority. Took on the issue of illegal immigration in the 1994 campaign and is now seeking laws to cut off all social welfare benefits except emergency medical care for illegal aliens, beef up enforcement and streamline deportation proceedings. Leader of the freshman Republicans' effort to defer all tax cuts until experts certify that the budget is on the way to being balanced.

ROBERT G. TORRICELLI, 43, senior Democrat in the delegation, first elected in 1982. Lawyer; aide to Gov. Brendan Byrne and Vice President Walter F. Mondale in the 1970's. Early this year unsuccessfully sought the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee. Has indicated interest in running for governor. Expert on Latin American affairs; a vocal opponent of Fidel Castro, he sponsored the act that tightens the economic embargo on Cuba. Has criticized Clinton policies on Haiti and Bosnia. House Ethics Committee is investigating whether he broke House secrecy rules when he revealed a paid C.I.A. informer's role in two killings in Guatemala.

 DONALD M. PAYNE, 60, Democrat, first elected in 1988. First black member of Congress from New Jersey; chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. Former public school teacher, businessman and community development executive; former Essex County Freeholder and Newark City Councilman. Strong advocate for urban housing and employment. Called for early intervention in Somalia and assailed the Clinton Administration's initial policy of forcibly returning thousands of Haitian boat people.

 RODNEY FRELINGHUYSEN, 49, Republican, first elected in 1994. Spent a decade each as Morris County Freeholder and State Assemblyman. Citing his work as a budget expert in the Assembly, was able to get a seat on the powerful Appropriations Committee, which has jurisdiction over a third of the Government's $1.5 trillion budget. While determined to cut "pork," he has promised to work to finance state priorities, including transportation, coastal and flood-control projects.


 RICHARD A. ZIMMER, 50, Republican, first elected in 1990. Lawyer and former corporate executive. Front-runner to challenge Senator Bill Bradley next year. Former State Assemblyman and Senator. This year, he landed a seat on the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee. Has introduced legislation that would phase out many Federal agriculture subsidies. Leader in the effort to eliminate the space station program. Fiscally conservative, but also an environmentalist and supporter of abortion rights.

 ROBERT MENENDEZ, 41, Democrat, first elected in 1992. The only Cuban-American Democrat in the House and the state's first Hispanic Congressman. Former Mayor of Union City; served in both houses of the Legislature. Has pushed for political change in Cuba, and supports tightening the U.S. embargo, but has sponsored a bill that would provide aid to Cuba once it has taken steps to democratize. Supports tax incentives and enterprise zones as a way to attract business investment to depressed areas. (Pg. 8) (MONICA BORKOWSKI)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;
Expect the Unexpected: Spread the Risk

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
WHAT if the optimists are wrong? What if the economy crash lands? Or what if it booms -- and the Federal Reserve jacks up interest rates again, instead of easing them as it did Thursday?
And, to raise a specter that is haunting millions of Americans, what if another stock-market meltdown interrupts the Dow Jones Industrial Average's seemingly unstoppable march to 5,000? 
 The reigning bulls on Wall Street scoff at such fears as doomsday talk. But investors have a right to be nervous for the simple historical reason that bad news usually takes the market by surprise. Few foresaw the 1987 crash, and few anticipated 1994's interest-rate run-up and consequent bond-market disaster.
"The conventional wisdom is so often wrong," said Stephen Savage, the editor of the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey. "People just tend to follow it."
To protect themselves against the three great threats to their portfolios -- a surge in interest rates, a bear market and a recession -- analysts urge investors to avoid putting too much money into mutual funds that are overexposed to any one of them.
But that can be tricky. General stock funds are often much less diversified than the investing public imagines, and are thus more vulnerable to economic reversals. More than four-fifths of the Copley fund, for example, is invested in utility stocks, which tend to go down when interest rates go up. Last year, it fell 8 percent as the Fed tightened credit, more than most bond funds.
To find the funds most likely to give investors an unpleasant shock, we sorted through the 1,066 diversified domestic stock funds with assets of least $30 million tracked by Morningstar Inc., a Chicago fund-research firm. We studied their portfolios and history to determine which ones were making the kind of outsized bets that should give investors pause. (The information about the portfolios was the most recent available but in some cases may have been outdated.)
Here, then, is a look at the potential dangers of investing in mutual funds that are overexposed to sudden shifts in the economic landscape.
 
Interest Rates
 Say interest rates head back up -- whether due to a resurgence of anxiety over inflation or a sinking dollar. While anyone who owned a bond fund last year remembers how much those funds can suffer if a manager bets the wrong way on rates, plenty of stock funds can also get hurt. Watch out for any balanced or income fund that has invested heavily in bonds, warned Martin Skala, an editor for Outlook, the investment newsletter published by Standard & Poor's, the New York research firm.
Investors might also want to be cautious about any stock fund with large positions in industries that are traditionally affected by interest-rate moves. Utility companies, which borrow heavily, and financial services like banking and insurance companies are among them. Most funds try to diversify across industries, but many are heavily invested in those areas.
Among the funds that seem to be exceedingly vulnerable to an interest rate swing is the Stratton Monthly Dividend Fund. Although it changed its name from the Energy and Utility Shares a decade ago, this equity-income fund apparently hasn't changed its strategy. Its portfolio is composed entirely of stocks in utilities like Oklahoma Gas & Electric and financial services like real estate investment trusts. To be sure, these stocks are paying the kind of high dividends that shareholders looking for income want. But there is a risk to principle: In 1994, as interest rates rose, the fund fell 12 percent.
Of course, this year's lower rates have already helped some of the funds with sizable holdings in financial services, among this year's best-performing industries. Two funds with more than half of their stock portfolios in bank and insurance stocks, the Vontobel U.S. Value and Weitz Value funds, had gained nearly 20 percent at the end of June. Vontobel, one of the World funds, bet big on financial-services stocks, which made up nearly two thirds of the 36 stocks it owned at the start of the year. While Vontobel didn't fare badly last year, Weitz Value was down nearly 10 percent.
 
Recession
 Investors may also want to make sure their favorite funds aren't betting too heavily on a soft landing. Despite the Fed's best efforts, including Thursday's quarter-point cut in short-term interest rates, there's always a chance the economy will slip into a recession.
If that happens, funds that invest in cyclical industries like heavy manufacturing, which tend to decline in a weakening economy, could perform poorly. And those without much in the way of foreign stocks would lack the protection of gains in countries with growth economies.
Morningstar found that 29 diversified stock funds had invested at least a third of their portfolios in cyclical industries. CGM Capital Development, for example, which is closed to new investors and therefore not on our list of recession-vulnerable funds, had roughly two thirds of its holdings in cyclical stocks at the beginning of the year. The same bet by Ken Heebner, the fund's manager, cost the fund dearly in 1994 when cyclical shares fell out of favor. The fund lost 23 percent of its value, making it one of the year's worst performers.
Funds with a strong geographic emphasis towards America's heartland, such as the Roulston Midwest Growth and Victory Ohio Regional Stock funds, have invested heavily in cyclical stocks, filling more than a third of their respective portfolios.
But a fund's bias isn't always so obvious. The Babson Enterprise II Fund, for example, invests in the stocks of fast-growing small companies, but more than a third of its portfolio is filled with cyclical stocks like Modine Manufacturing or Kennametal. Those stocks, although less expensive than many of the usual high-flying technology issues owned by its peers, helped contribute to a loss of 7 percent last year.
 
Bear Market
 If the Dow ever reverses course from its dizzying 22.6 percent climb this year, including a 38.73-point spurt Friday to 4,702.73, funds that have exhibited the most volatility and have the highest price-to-earnings ratios will probably be hit hardest, analysts say.
One measure of a fund's performance, its so-called beta, is seen as a fairly reliable indicator of how it will fare in both good times and bad with respect to the wider market. The higher a fund's beta, which compares its historical returns with an index, usually the S.& P. 500, the more likely it is to exaggerate the stock market's moves. Morningstar calculates the beta after deducting the T-bill rate from the returns of the fund and the index and comparing those adjusted returns. A fund with a beta of 1.5, for example, is expected to beat the market by 50 percent in a bull market and trail it by 50 percent in a bear market.
Take the Smith Barney Special Equities Fund. It returned a spectacular 32 percent over the year ended June 30. But when the market sputters, the same fund often sinks; in 1990, when the S.& P. 500 fell by 3 percent, the fund nosedived 25 percent. Only investors who don't mind a rollercoaster ride will be able to stomach the next downturn.
Many high-beta funds are also betting heavily on volatile technology stocks, which have had an incredible run this year and have been the subject of continued speculation about when they'll stumble. Oberweis Emerging Growth and Dean Witter Developing Growth have roughly half of their portfolios in these stocks.
A crash wouldn't be pretty. While Oberweis managed to come out of 1990's downturn unscathed, some of the other funds have had some sizable losses during previous bear markets. For example, MFS Managed Sectors fell 14 percent in 1990 and IDS Growth lost 19 percent of its value in 1984. Ancient history? Maybe -- but history has a way of repeating itself.
