HEADLINE: Union Goal of Equality Fails the Test of Time

SERIES: Affirmative Action: Labor's Faltering Experiment

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
By 7 A.M., nearly 30 men have gathered in the hiring hall of the Iron Workers Local 401. They talk quietly in groups at small gray tables, like diners in a restaurant waiting to be served. Several who are black sit apart. All are waiting for a glass window at one end of the hall to slide open and the hiring boss to call out jobs.
Six times this year, the window has opened for Michael Sharpe, one of the black men. But none of the jobs lasted long, and he has averaged only eight days of work a month, half the number this year of most white members of Local 401. The others at his table tell similar stories. 
 "I have often wondered whether I don't last on jobs because I don't work hard enough or I lack skill," Mr. Sharpe said. "I have concluded that the problem is I am black."
Mr. Sharpe, a tall, thin 32-year-old, says his Christian faith reassures him that he will get ahead eventually. "God is just," he said. But that is not much solace today. Local 401 recruited him in 1987, as part of the Federal Government's "Philadelphia Plan," to help raise its minority membership to meet the goals of affirmative action. That was a boom time for construction in Philadelphia, with enough work for everyone, white and black. But now, in harder times, when Mr. Sharpe works, a white man does not.
The Philadelphia Plan, American labor's longest-running experiment in affirmative action, is faltering. More than 25 years after the Government set about trying to break the white monopoly in this city's construction industry, renewed struggles over a shrinking pie and constant changes in the rules of the game are eroding the program's initial gains.
At one time the plan was a model for similar efforts elsewhere in the country. But the backsliding here has now become another symptom of the national decline of affirmative action, once viewed by blacks and other minorities as a Federal commitment to their economic progress but now seen increasingly as something of a hollow victory.
The Philadelphia Plan, based on an executive order issued by President Lyndon B. Johnson, was put in place by the Nixon Labor Department in 1969 to increase jobs for minorities, mainly blacks, in high-paying skilled trades, which were tightly controlled by the unions. The goal was to employ them in proportion to their numbers in the area's work force.
For a while there were gains. The unions opened their ranks and pitched their apprenticeship programs to train more blacks. The ironworkers, electricians, carpenters, heavy-equipment operators and other skilled trades unions now have a black membership of about 15 percent, up from zero in the 1960's.
But like Mr. Sharpe, who graduated from Local 401's apprenticeship program, the blacks do not obtain much work these days. A recent tour of construction sites in Philadelphia turned up very few members of minorities working at skilled jobs. And Government officials say the picture is the same in other cities.
Keeping blacks out of union jobs is potentially damaging for organized labor. Nationwide, black workers join unions more frequently than any other group, Labor Department data show. One of every five blacks employed in America belongs to a union. For them, union jobs are a path to middle-class incomes. But the skilled trades unions, which control nearly one million jobs that often pay $18 an hour and up, still resist their presence.
The economy gets some of the blame for this resistance. "Many unions have made significant efforts to increase black membership, but in a shrinking job market, blacks have a very hard time keeping jobs," said Bernard E. Anderson, Assistant Secretary of Labor for employment standards.
The unions themselves acknowledge the resistance, but also shift part of the blame to the decline of blue-collar work. "Minorities have been trying to enter the skilled trades just as opportunities have shrunk," said Robert A. Georgine, president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Resistance has been great because too many tradesmen have been sitting on the bench. At times, there has been resentment they might lose out."
For Mr. Sharpe, that translates into arms-length treatment by white foremen, who decide who stays on and who gets laid off when work tapers off. Mr. Sharpe may get his share of hiring-hall assignments, but once on the job he is in a foreman's hands. Twice this spring, he says, he has been "pushed aside."
"There were 14 of us erecting a department store at a shopping mall," Mr. Sharpe said. "I was the only black, and when the work slacked I was laid off with two whites. Two weeks later I was back on that job, and when the work slacked again I was again laid off, and all the whites went on working."
Local 401, which is affiliated with the International Association of Iron Workers, occasionally sends out black foremen. But the vast majority are white. For Mr. Sharpe, that spells discrimination. "We are not the cousins and uncles and nephews of these foremen," he said. "And in this union, family and friends come first."
 
The History
A Long Resistance To Black Workers
Organized labor, in all its public statements, shuns discrimination. When the subject comes up, Thomas R. Donahue, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., produces a list of 11 resolutions and reports issued since 1981, each declaring the labor federation's unwavering support for civil rights and affirmative action.
"The union movement has tried very hard to bring about diversity at every level," he said.
History tells a different story. Until after World War II, unions were virtually closed to black workers except for those made up almost entirely of blacks, like the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters. As recently as 1964, the International Association of Machinists allowed its local chapters to exclude blacks. And the United Automobile Workers, a pioneer in organizing blacks, was plagued until the early 1940's by what were described then as "wildcat hate strikes" by whites protesting working alongside blacks.
Not until World War II did the strikes stop, and only then because the Federal Government made its first incursion into promoting integration in unions and threatened to prosecute the strikers. The next incursion came in the 1960's, with the rise of the civil rights movement and President John F. Kennedy's executive order authorizing unions to sign up Federal workers, a huge source of black recruits.
Increasingly, blacks also took jobs in private industry once held by whites, and joined unions representing secretaries and receptionists, health and child-care workers, clothing and textile workers, clerks, janitors, cooks and waitresses, meter readers and insurance adjusters.
But the high-paying skilled trades -- the main targets of affirmative action -- remained white, male strongholds. "Before the Philadelphia Plan," said James Jones, a lawyer who drew up the plan, "affirmative action was a farce."
 
The System
Pointing Fingers At the Hiring End
Affirmative action, still a Federal requirement despite recent Supreme Court decisions that have diluted it, kicks in if a project involves Government financing -- and most construction work in Philadelphia does. Contractors who bid for this work are asked to make a "good-faith effort" to give minorities enough hours to meet goals set by Federal as well as local requirements. These goals are based on the available pools of white and black workers in the area. Contractors usually shift the burden of meeting the goals to the unions that supply their workers.
That prompts sarcasm from Edward Coryell, president of the Metropolitan District Council of Carpenters. Pulling a folder of letters from contractors out of the clutter on his desk, he says they all make the same request -- that he refer qualified minority workers for possible employment in future projects.
"I have my secretary call them and ask how many minorities they want tomorrow and where to send them," Mr. Coryell says. Do they ever request any?
In reply, Mr. Coryell summons his secretary, Maureen McGovern. "They all say, 'Thank you, we'll make a note of it,' " she said. "None has ever called back, and I have been doing this since 1981."
The tenacity of white resistance to change can be gauged in a court action that dates to the early 1970's. At that time, several contractors joined Local 542 of the International Association of Operating Engineers in a legal challenge to the Philadelphia Plan. One charge was that it set quotas, which are impermissible, rather than goals. Later, the contractors dropped out of the suit, and Local 542 finally signed a consent decree promising to recruit and train blacks as heavy-equipment operators.
That was in the mid-80's, and the Federal District Court here is still riding herd on Local 542, which riles Thomas P. Danese. He is a 40-year-old former backhoe operator who took a union job as business representative two years ago. At the suggestion that Local 542 is backsliding, Mr. Danese jumps for his manila folders and the papers inside with columns of numbers detailing the local's progress in meeting the court's affirmative-action goals.
Even so, progress over the years has waxed and waned. By 1989, a court-appointed outside expert, Marc Halpern, decided that the union had fulfilled the goals. The court withdrew from the case -- only to reappoint Mr. Halpern in 1993 after blacks filed new complaints that they could not get work.
Mr. Halpern agreed with these complaints. "The last four years completely wiped out the arduous effort" that had been made in the 1980's, "and set this union back to a percentage of minority hours worked not seen since 1985," he wrote in a 1993 evaluation.
Mr. Danese says it is not quite that simple. He came into office as part of an elected slate of six new officers, all white, who blamed the incumbents for the backsliding. The insurgents got enough support from black members to win the 1993 election by 21 votes in a union that has 3,200 active members. Now, for the first time, two of the local's nine executive board members are black.
Seated at a conference table and sporting thick metal cuff links and a tie clasp with "542" in raised numerals, Mr. Danese listed data from the quarterly reports that he sends to Mr. Halpern. Twenty-one percent of the membership in Philadelphia is minority, he said, and there are similarly high percentages for the local's four other districts.
Moreover, he said that "30 percent of the people we send out on jobs are minorities." And then came the caveat: "They represent only 16 percent of the hours worked. The contractors aren't keeping the black workers more than a day or two."
Mr. Halpern, troubled by this pattern, finally decided that the contractors, not the union, were resisting, and promised last December to put pressure on the contractors. But they insisted that many black operators were not sufficiently skilled.
"The resistance at the hiring end is a resistance based only on qualification," said John R. Smith Jr., general manager of the Contractors Association of Eastern Pennsylvania.
Mr. Halpern's solution was to identify 75 minority operators whom the union considered skilled. He invited the first 25 to come to the local's training sites for a week or two to brush up their skills, and said he would then push the contractors to hire them. Only 3 of the 25 agreed. "That says something about lack of interest," Mr. Danese concluded.
The black members offered a different view. "White or black, people don't want to train for free," said Clifford Brock, one of the two black members of the local's civil rights committee. "They want to train and get experience the way whites did, on the job. And chances are the people who got those letters have other jobs on the side, and can't afford to retrain now for free."
For Michael Sharpe, the ironworker, there is another reason that blacks are skeptical. Local 542 and his own local, 401, once maintained mandatory hiring halls, which meant that all job assignments came through the halls. But as construction declined, Local 401's white majority, like those in some other unions, voted to permit contractors to bypass the hiring hall and hire union members directly.
To Mr. Sharpe, that meant that white foremen were free to hire their white friends, without any oversight from the union, and give them more hours than blacks.
"I have been at this work nine years now, and I have tried to walk onto jobs and I have been unsuccessful, although the person doing the hiring knew my work," Mr. Sharpe said. "A mandatory hiring hall system would put pressure on a union to give everyone a share of the work."
David Missar sees it differently. He is a 41-year-old white man whose father, grandfather and three uncles were ironworkers. "I was welcomed with open arms into this union, and I guess in that respect, I have had it pretty easy," he said.
He has been a foreman for a decade, and he has worked with Mr. Sharpe, whom he considers a skilled ironworker. Still, Mr. Missar says he resents affirmative action.
"I have always felt that it is reverse discrimination, forcing employers to hire some blacks who are not qualified," he said. "And when there aren't enough jobs to go around, people get difficult."
When Mr. Missar recruits directly, bypassing the union hall, he invariably calls whites. "They are the people I know best," he said. But then he adds, "I would not want to trade shoes with Mike, even if he were more skilled than I am, because I know it would be harder."
 
The Struggle
Racial Wage Gap Embitters Blacks
Affirmative action's failures have contributed to a racial wage gap among union members. White unionists, because they hold most of the better-paid jobs, have got closer to a middle-class wage than blacks. Whites earned $514 a week on average last year, the Labor Department reports, compared with $405 a week on average for black unionists. That was barely above the average weekly wage of $385 for all non-supervisory workers, union or not.
Those figures gall black workers, who have warmly embraced unions as an avenue to higher pay and benefits. Twenty-one percent of black workers in the United States today belong to unions, far more than any other group, the Labor Department says. And at a time when union membership is declining, mostly because whites are dropping out or are reluctant to join, black recruits are the main hope for reversing the labor movement's diminishing power, some union leaders say.
"Black workers are more struggle-oriented than whites," said Joseph Uehlein, a white A.F.L.-C.I.O. official active in organizing campaigns.
But gaining power in the union movement through recruitment is likely to be a very slow process for blacks. Nearly 17 million Americans belong to unions, but black Americans account for only 15.5 percent of the total, far short of enough voting power to shape union policies or demand the best jobs.
"We might be well into the 21st century before this changes," said Barry Hirsch, a labor economist at Florida State University who specializes in union demographics.
Lacking the clout of overwhelming numbers, blacks have a hard time getting into the top union posts. In Philadelphia, while some blacks hold lower-level positions, the top officers in each local are white.
They could name blacks to their slates, but Joseph J. Dougherty, who runs Local 401, explains why he does not. "If we tried to designate some slots for black officers, that would split the union," he said. "You can't push this too far."
Still, Kevin Lumpkin, a 34-year-old black ironworker, ran twice on his own for Local 401's executive board, and the first time, in 1987, he lost by only 24 votes. "I got white votes then," he said.
But as the economy weakened and the competition intensified among the union's 680 ironworkers for a shrinking pool of jobs, votes slipped away. When Mr. Lumpkin ran again, in 1993, he lost by a wider margin.
"I spoke out on on tough issues, like sending out African-Americans as foremen, and I lost some of my white support," Mr. Lumpkin said. "What we need is someone to represent minorities on the executive board and raise our concerns a lot harder than they are raised now."
 
Other Articles
 Earlier articles examined the issue on campus, the status of minority- and women-owned businesses that supply corporations with goods and services, and the corporate scene. Later articles will examine affirmative action in other areas of American life.

HEADLINE: Clinton Tries to Ease Effects of Base Cuts

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
Looking for ways to lessen the economic pain that base closings would bring to California and Texas, President Clinton directed Pentagon officials today to provide more answers about the prospects for shifting military jobs in the two states to the private sector.
Mr. Clinton met for 90 minutes with Defense Secretary William J. Perry and other top officials to discuss the latest recommendations from an independent panel on military base closings. 
 The panel, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, has recommended that maintenance centers at McClellan Air Force Base in California and Kelly Air Force Base in Texas be shut down and that the work be parceled out to other bases. In the case of Kelly, the commission left privatization as an option.
Mr. Perry has yet to give the President a formal recommendation on the commission's plan, but he has made it clear that he favors shifting some military work to private employers as a way to preserve jobs. At today's meeting, Mr. Clinton asked for more information about prospects for moving jobs to the private sector at both bases, aides said.
McClellan's future has become a hot political issue because of the effect of previous base closings on California and because of the importance of that state's 54 electoral votes to Mr. Clinton's re-election hopes.
Mr. Clinton has until July 15 to decide whether to accept or reject the commission's latest recommendations.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Schools Go in Summer

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 8

 BODY:
While many students were enjoying the uninterrupted liberty of long summer days, students here at Garfield High School began the '95-'96 school year on Wednesday.
July and August are no different than October and November here. 
 Two-thirds of the students are always attending classes.
Like 200 other schools in the city, Garfield is on a year-round calendar, sacrificing summer freedom for the utility of easing overcrowded classrooms and hallways. The same calendar is being considered by other crowded school systems across the country, notably New York City, which expects to begin an experiment within a year at two to four schools to cope with a budget that does not provide money for building new schools.
At Garfield, Adela Hernandez, a 14-year-old freshman, finished eighth grade just two weeks ago and began high school on Wednesday. "I didn't like just having six days of vacation," she said. "I wanted to have more. We didn't get to enjoy anything."
But students accustomed to the schedule see advantages. "This school has so many students," said Alma Ortiz, 16, a senior. "If they put in the kids who are on vacation now, the campus would be totally crowded."
Most schools on year-round schedules -- 1,200 out of about 2,000 nationwide -- are in California. A recession and dearth of voter support for classroom construction has left the state little choice.
In the giant Los Angeles Unified School District, the nation's second largest after New York, more than 270,000 children, 42 percent, are on a year-round calendar. Neighborhoods with swelling immigrant communities, like Garfield's Hispanic east side, are most likely to have such schedules.
Year-round education can effectively expand a school's capacity by 25 percent, or even 50 percent, depending on the system used. While air-conditioning and administrative costs are higher, the expense is far less than than the cost of building and maintaining new schools.
In Garfield's case, the schedule allows 4,200 children to be taught on a 3,200-desk campus. To achieve this, the student body is divided into thirds. At any time, one-third of the school's students and teachers are on one of two eight-week breaks. This replaces the traditional 10- to 12-week summer vacation.
Once they get used to it, said the Garfield principal, Maria E. Tostado, "kids love it. And my parents, they're so used to year-round now that they don't think about it much."
Maria Quiles, a 15-year-old sophomore, said that summer courses do not get in the way of social life. "After school we go somewhere like the beach or go see friends who are on vacation, so it's the same thing," she said.
But Gabriel Cabrera, 18, who graduated on June 27, complained that all through high school, he never really had a vacation. To stay in the band (he played tuba), he had to show up for practice every day at 6:30 A.M. -- even during his eight-week breaks.
"I didn't get a decent vacation," Gabriel said. "I haven't been off since the 10th grade. Sometimes I wanted to sleep in, but I couldn't."
In fact, anyone in the music program, on a sports team or taking an advanced placement course must continue to show up at school during their eight-week breaks. Without such a policy, the band might march in chaos during the football half-time show. Some basketball team members would miss pre-season practice. And students in advanced placement courses who are off in March would be ill-prepared for the standardized tests, given in the spring.
Proponents said year-round scheduling has some benefits beyond eliminating crowding. Steven H. Walters, a coordinator for year-round schools in Los Angeles, said frequent breaks are an advantage to failing students. They usually would wait until summer school to retake courses or earn credit for extra work.
"What we're doing now with the traditional calendar is saying, 'Hang in there Johnny. In June, we'll get you some help,' " Mr. Walters said.
Charles E. Ballinger, executive director of the National Association of Year-Round Education, described an added advantage, saying "students forget less" in an atmosphere of continuous learning.
But Thomas E. Hutton, a math instructor at Garfield, said the reverse is true. To make the rotating schedule fit within 12 months, instructors work and students attend school for 163 days instead of the traditional 180 (though days increase to 7 hours and 40 minutes from the usual 7). This gives students more time to forget, he said. "For my personal life it's great," Mr. Hutton said. "But from the point of view of education, it hurts."
Louis Tapia, a 16-year-old junior, said he liked the extra weeks away from class. "I would rather be going year-round anyway because we get more time off."
Across the city, parents and some teachers were not easily swayed by supporters when the city experimented in 1991 with having all schools go to a year-round schedule. While more than 200 overcrowded schools like Garfield continue on a year-round calendar, parents and teachers at 540 mainly affluent and spacious suburban schools rebelled and returned to a nine-month calendar in 1993.
Gilbert Lozano, a 15-year-old sophomore said that given the choice, he would choose Garfield's year-round schedule over a traditional calendar, even though he admits having a pang of regret when he sees other students on vacation. "When they're doing fun stuff, I'm just here at school learning," he said.
His revenge, he says, will come during his eight-week break in November and December. While his friends are doing algebra and English, he'll be learning to ski.

HEADLINE: Aid Packages For Retailers In Poor Areas

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
Hoping to replicate New York City's success over the last decade in rebuilding abandoned housing, the Giuliani administration for the first time will offer packages of vacant land and financing to develop retail stores along some of the city's most blighted commercial strips.
The administration wants to spur the opening of dozens of neighborhood businesses -- groceries, pharmacies, video stores, laundries and restaurants -- that officials and housing experts say are essential to the revival of poor neighborhoods where the city has built thousands of affordable homes for working families. 
 New York, like other cities, has offered abandoned properties for commercial development in site-by-site negotiations, but that approach has done little to revive beleaguered shopping areas. With the new effort, the city intends for the first time to take a more comprehensive step, creating development zones and offering public and private dollars for construction, as well as vacant land and tax abatements.
In all, $25 million will be spent in five zones to develop 250,000 square feet of commercial or retail space, creating an estimated 1,000 jobs over the next few years. The administration has already selected the first zone: 270 square blocks in Brooklyn bisected by Broadway, a shopping strip that has yet to recover from arson and looting in the 1970's.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is to announce tomorrow that the city has cobbled together the money to finance the new stores from Federally guaranteed loans and grants, private contributions and city construction funds.
The pot includes the first contribution -- $2.5 million -- from the New York City Partnership, a private group whose members include top executives of the city's largest companies. The partnership will coordinate the project and search for potential developers in much the same way its subsidiary, the New York City Housing Partnership, has helped the city rebuild housing.
Deborah C. Wright, the city's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, said the administration's new program reflected a realization that the city must rebuild retailing as well as housing or put the new homes at risk.
"The operating assumption has always been if you build the housing, the retail will come," she said. "It's taken us 25 years to figure out it's not coming back by itself. There's a real cost in leaving these strips vacant."
For Mr. Giuliani, the project represents his most significant proposal so far for urban renewal, one that aims to fulfill his campaign pledges to rebuild as many businesses as homes in poor neighborhoods. And it underscores the Mayor's drive to tap private financing and support as much as possible at a time when the city faces nagging budget problems and has reduced its spending on capital construction projects.
In fact, the city's contribution to the project is modest: $2.5 million in capital funds that will pay for improvements to abandoned properties that have fallen into the city's hands through tax foreclosures.
The bulk of the financing will come from Federally guaranteed loans and from grants the city was able to secure from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
The administration's effort aims to follow the model the city has used to finance and oversee the creation or renovation of more than 50,000 homes over the last decade. In that effort, the city gave away the vacant properties to nonprofit organizations or private developers who then used a variety of city subsidies, bank financing and Federal guarantees or credits to build the housing.
For the new project, the city has joined with the partnership, which has agreed for the first time to contribute its own money for economic development and has already secured commitments from five banks to help finance the construction of new businesses.
"It's a logical sequence to what the partnership has been doing in the area of housing over the last decade," said Jerry I. Speyer, the president of Tishman Speyer Properties in Manhattan and chairman of the partnership.
The first of the five zones (called Partnership Plazas) is an irregular octagon where Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant come together, bounded by sections of Flushing Avenue at the north, Wilson and Bushwick Avenues on the east, Atlantic Avenue on the south and Malcolm X Boulevard on the west.
The zone includes about a dozen commercial properties, totalling 370,000 square feet, that defaulted into the city's hands in the 1970's and have remained abandoned. In roughly the same area, the city has overseen the development of about 2,600 homes, many of them through the Housing Partnership.
Richard J. Schwartz, the Mayor's senior adviser, said that the city hoped to encourage developers to open at least a handful of stores on those sites, which range from 12,000 to 60,000 square feet, to create "a critical mass" of retailing that would ultimately attract others.
The new retailers could eventually own their stores themselves, receiving a full exemption on property taxes for 12 years. The city has also pledged to improve services -- from street lighting to policing -- in the new zones.
The task now is to find businesses willing to start up in a neighborhood that has lain fallow for two decades, although officials said the package of financing already in place increases the chance for success.
Roderick B. Mitchell, the president of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation, a nonprofit organization that has supported retail development in the neighborhood, said the city has had the capacity to finance retail projects for years but has so far failed to use it well.
Mr. Mitchell said the part of the $25 million dedicated to the Brooklyn zone did not represent "a lot of money" for development. But, he added, "anything that will encourage economic development is a good thing."

HEADLINE: California's Squabbling Legislature Just Stumbles Along

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, July 8

 BODY:
There was a time, 20 years or so back, when the Legislature here was considered one of the most professional, innovative and productive in the nation, a major force in leading California to its pre-eminence after World War II as the richest and most powerful state in the Union. Other states looked to the Golden State for legislative example and guidance.
And then there is today's California Legislature, more specifically the lower house, the ideologically sundered, procedurally stumbling, squabbling, wobbling California Assembly. 
 The uncivil national political discourse bemoaned a few days ago by President Clinton in a speech in Washington can be found here in full-throated cry.
All the usual causes are present, and then some: hard-right and hard-left agendas with no middle ground, programmatic needs that far exceed economic means, powerful and selfish special interests, a breakdown in party discipline and allegiance, term limits, recall elections, ballot initiatives, Presidential ambition and just plain meanspiritedness
"It's the same stuff that you find in a lot of states, only bigger and worse here," said Tony Quinn, a veteran Sacramento lobbyist and former legislative aide. "Well, this has always been a cutting-edge legislature. Trouble is, now it's also a dysfunctional family."
In the California Assembly in the summer of 1995 -- the state Senate, thus far, is much less troubled -- Republicans and Democrats are not satisfied simply to fight one another in the age-old accepted manner. There is a get 'em tone in a great many of their exchanges.
One day last week, a Republican member gleefully referred to a Democratic member's recent hospitalization for cancer, then expressed "hope" that the surgeons also had managed to "cut the malignancy out of his heart."
Equally serious is the spectacle of Republicans fighting Republicans and Democrats fighting Democrats.
When the longtime Democratic Speaker, Willie L. Brown, outmaneuvered Republicans and kept control of the Assembly despite technically being outnumbered by the opposition, Doris Allen, the Republican Assemblywoman from Orange County who sided with him on the crucial vote, was pilloried as the equivalent of a Nazi collaborator.
Faxes distributed by her furious party colleagues said she would have been a perfect fit in the Vichy Government that the conquering Germans set up in France during World War II.
When Mr. Brown subsequently gave Ms. Allen the Speaker's job, at least in title, the next round of faxes suggested a dog was her chief political adviser.
Finally, when Assembly members are not fighting with each other these days, they are ganging up on Gov. Pete Wilson, who has himself added considerably to the tension and confusion in Sacramento by entering the contest for the Republican Presidential nomination.
Democrats are doing all they can to derail his proposed 1995-96 budget, especially his call for a tax cut. As a result, serious legislative action in the Assembly is all but nonexistent.
Should the cut ever pass, it would be something Mr. Wilson could boast about out on the Presidential campaign trail, possibly offsetting criticism of him for supporting a tax increase in earlier years.
Sherry B. Jeffe, a former Asssembly aide who now teaches political science at the Claremont Graduate School, near Los Angeles, considers political decorum in Sacramento today, particularly in the Assembly, to be the worst in modern memory.
"This once great deliberative body," she said, "has sunk to the level of a petulant sand-box fight, except little kids aren't as mean and hateful as some of these folks."
In her view, term limits have increased pressure on legislators to move faster and with less caution and comity to complete their agendas before they must leave.
At the same time, she said, a tendency has developed to resort to recall elections to punish wayward legislators and to rely on ballot initiatives to win passage of measures that legislators will not act upon.
On a day to day basis, the California Assembly's sessions have become so raucous and unruly -- the incessant gavel pounding and calls for order go ignored and only add to the din -- that the Sergeant-at-Arms has quietly assigned extra personnel to the floor, just in case the hotheads spiral totally out of control and go from flipping obscene finger signs at one another to actual fisticuffs.
Raising the ad hominem ante in one exchange on Friday, Assemblyman John Burton of San Francisco, insisted, over the Chair's repeated objections, on referring to Governor Wilson, a relatively slight man, as "the little fellow downstairs."
Given a final admonishment by the Chair to desist, Mr. Burton deadpanned, "I'm not talking about the Governor, his excellency. I'm talking about the shoeshine boy downstairs."
At that, Assemblyman Peter Frusetta of Tres Pinos, in the Monterey area , rose and managed, somehow, to make himself heard above the tumult. Noting that some television stations now broadcast Assembly sessions, he said, as the members finally quieted and turned to listen:
"I feel sorry that the people of California have to witness this buffonery. It wouldn't be accepted in a high school auditorium. It's a terrible disparaging of this body. I didn't come here for laughter or mockery."
There was some scattered applause as he took his seat. And also some laughter and mockery.
"Oh, he's shocked that there's gambling going on here," someone quipped in one corner of the Assembly chamber, alluding to the timeworn line from the movie "Casablanca."

Assemblywoman Jackie Speier applauded, but others were outraged. Gov. Pete Wilson's Presidential aspirations have added tension and confusion to the legislative caldron in Sacramento, Calif. HEADLINE: The Whitman Effect

 BODY:
In political terms, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey has had a sensational first year and a half in office. With a recently enacted $16 billion budget, she has cut income taxes as promised in two years instead of three, without shredding local aid or social programs. Small wonder that she is being talked about for the national Republican ticket. But these achievements are accompanied by genuine risks to the long-term financial health of the state. Looked at closely, Mrs. Whitman's fiscal practices reflect less of a Republican revolution in downsized government than the same old game of spending now and paying the price later.
 The Governor's first year in office was marked by a reduction in annual payments to the state employee pension fund, which allowed her to implement the first phase of her promised 30 percent cut in the income tax rate. This page was critical of that move as certain to raise the state budget liability for pensions drastically in future years. But Mrs. Whitman persuaded the legislators, if not the bond-rating agencies, that the pension system was "overfunded" and that it was a matter of equity that current taxpayers not have to foot the bill for future retirement costs. She was unfortunately employing a dubious practice to which desperate governors and mayors across the country have been turning in these years of fiscal stringency. 
 This year, however, Mrs. Whitman has expanded the practice of incurring obligations without providing the means to pay for them. A multibillion-dollar transportation program is to be funded by new and newly refinanced bonds that are going to drive up the cost of debt service. It would have been much more courageous and fiscally sound for Mrs. Whitman to level with the voters and say that this expense should be met by a modest increase in the state gasoline tax.
 The Governor also "paid" for the tax cut by inflating tax revenue projections and by optimistically assuming that there will be savings from her privatization programs. In fact, efforts to reduce the size of the work force have lagged behind her initial plans, and the privatizations have not achieved any real savings at all.
 But budgets are more than bottom lines, and Mrs. Whitman does deserve credit in key areas. She has responded to court orders by increasing state education aid to poor districts at the expense of wealthier districts, although an even greater effort will be needed if the demands of equity are to be met. Democrats charge that the small increases in school aid these last two years will drive up local property taxes, and many independent analysts agree. But it is too soon to tell if that will happen, and Mrs. Whitman is right to demand that local school districts do more to cut their own exploding administrative costs.
 Even more impressive, Mrs. Whitman has resisted the impulse of Republicans in New York and elsewhere to try to cut welfare benefits. Her eloquent arguments that such cuts hurt families and children should be heard by fellow Republicans, along with her appeals for moderation on abortion and other social issues. But those looking for Mrs. Whitman to have a national impact should be watching the economic indicators carefully to see whether the gambles she is taking on taxes and budgeting end up costing taxpayers more money and hurting the state's future financial health.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Clinton Shopping Network

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Attention, D-Mart shoppers!
 The Democratic National Committee has put out a catalogue with its exciting new fall collection from the White House. (Political-machine washable and made in the U.S.A.) 
 It's a fresh, fun approach to a classic product: access.
 For $100,000 a year, you can become a "Managing Trustee" of the Democratic Party, which entitles you to all kinds of goodies, including two meals with the President and two with the Vice President, two issue retreats, "private, impromptu meetings" with Administration officials when they visit your hometown, an upgrade to "Honored Guest Status" at the '96 Chicago convention and your very own D.N.C. staffer to assist with your "personal requests."
 You also get to tag along with party leaders on a foreign trade mission. (For a bit more, do you get to talk tough to the Japanese?) The D.N.C. briefing will be faxed to you every day, with insider tidbits like this from July 6: "Priorities? Wilson skipped base closing hearing to honor fat cat contributor."
 Bargain hunters can go to the women's department, where, for a $1,000 contribution, you get a reception with the First Lady, Tipper Gore or top female Administration officials.
 The catalogue was designed by Christopher Dodd and Donald Fowler, the Democratic Party chairmen, to raise $66 million for the '96 elections. Since this was reported in The Chicago Sun-Times by Lynn Sweet, the capital has been awash in moralism.
 Republicans have long believed in pay-per-view. For $100,000, businessmen in Team 100 could go to a black-tie dinner with President Bush after enduring a don't-worry-be-happy economic policy briefing by Dick Darman and Michael Boskin. But Haley Barbour, the Republican Party chief, scorned the D.N.C. "price list" as "crass." "What would it cost to fly in the cockpit of Air Force One?" he drawled.
 I think I detected a note of envy in his voice. But Mr. Barbour is right. Crass it is. The Democrats are supposed to be the party of average working Americans, the party of campaign finance reform. And Bill Clinton did run on a promise -- echoed during his New Hampshire meeting with Newt Gingrich -- to fight "big money interests" and break up those "cliques of $100,000 donors."
 White House officials protest that they cannot "unilaterally disarm" and that they are only "stylizing" G.O.P. fund-raising techniques. Actually, they are unilaterally perfecting the black art they protest, bringing it to new heights of tawdry sophistication.
 Senator Dodd was unapologetic when I called him. "We're very honest," he said drily. "We like to tax 'em and we like to raise money from 'em if we can. Anyway, the Republicans charged $92,000 for a picture with George Bush. We give dinner and a picture with Clinton for that." Asked what sort of "personal requests" the D.N.C. staffers were prepared to fulfill, he laughed and said, "I wondered that myself."
 So what does an ordinary citizen get in return for a vote? "Hopefully," Mr. Dodd replied, "good government, as Huey Long would say."
 Right. Enough about ethical anxiety. Let's shop!
 Perhaps the D.N.C. should think really big, as in "1996 GOING-OUT OF-BUSINESS SALE -- EVERYTHING MUST GO!" It is easy to conjure up hot sellers.
 * For $50,000, Al Gore will come over and help you choose your long-distance service.
 * For $20,000, the dapper Warren Christopher will instruct you in the art of accessorizing.
 * For $15,000, a seminar on money management by Ron Brown and Pamela Harriman.
 * For $10,000, Bruce Lindsey will tell you what he does for a living.
 * For $5,000, Paul Begala will explain how the press is undermining the Clinton Presidency.
 * For $4,000, Dick Morris will explain how Paul Begala is undermining the Clinton Presidency.
 * For $3,000, George Stephanopoulos will explain who Dick Morris is.
 * For $1,000, a trip to the Super Bowl with Don Tyson.
 * For $500, Henry Cisneros will reflect on "Why Really Good-Looking Men With a Whole Lot Going for Them Make Really Dumb Choices."
 * For $100, a trip to the Super Bowl with Mike Espy.
 * For $10, Ira Magaziner will help you choose your H.M.O. For $10,000, he won't.
 Act now. Supplies are limited. Not void even where prohibited.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The Federal Reserve reports May consumer credit. Forecast: up $9 billion. 

Banks in Japan to set the July prime rate this week. Analysts said the long-term rate could fall to 2.9 percent, from 3.1 percent, and short-term rates to 2 percent, from 2.375 percent.
 
Tuesday
 
The House Ways and Means Committee begins three days of hearings on more than 200 miscellaneous tax proposals whose backers hope to attach them to the budget reconciliation bill later this year. Topics include accounting issues, capital gains and pensions.
 
Japan's Economic Planning Agency issues its monthly report. It is expected to acknowledge that Japan's recovery is stalling, reversing the current assessment of a gradual recovery.
 
Motorola and Nike expected to announced quarterly earnings. Forecast: 73 cents a share for Motorola and $1.40 a share for Nike.
 
Wednesday
 
Japan and the United States are scheduled to open talks on increased American cargo flights.
 
The Senate Commerce Committee plans to hold a hearing on several measures aimed at curbing violence on television.
 
Thursday
 
The policy-making council of the Deutsche Bundesbank meets. Analysts said inflation concerns would keep the bank from following other countries in easing interest rates.
 
The Labor Department reports producer prices for June. Forecast: up 0.1 percent. The index was unchanged in May.
 
Friday
 
The Labor Department releases June consumer prices. Forecast: up 0.3 percent, the same increase as in May.
 
The Federal Reserve reports industrial production and capacity utilization for June. Forecast: production up 0.1 percent, after falling 0.2 percent in May; utilization at 83.6 percent, edging down from 83.7 percent in May.
 
The Commerce Department releases retail sales for June. Forecast: up 0.5 percent, following a 0.2 percent increase in May.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Rates: Can't They Get It Right?
You'd think that with today's computers, which can land a space ship on the head of a T-bill, economists could simply figure out where interest rates should be -- and leave them alone, for heaven's sake. But no: it's up and down, up and down, with incessant speculation beforehand and the actual changes heralded by 1,427 trumpets (adjusted for inflation). So it was that on Thursday the Fed, having decided that all those rate increases over the past year and a half may have tipped the economy toward recession, sent one key rate down a notch. It took its time, though: the free market had started sending things like bond yields and mortgage rates down some time ago. 

But wait! The very next day those recession warnings seemed way off target, for new figures showed that the job picture was a lot better than expected. Payrolls grew by a healthy 215,000, and the unemployment rate slipped to 5.6 percent from 5.7. What do you think, Mr. Greenspan?
 
MILITARY SPENDING
 
Please, Have Some More!
Logic would suggest that when the Pentagon held out its tin cup to this pinch-billion Congress, it would get less than it asked for. But if you want logic, get a computer. For not only is Congress not denying the military folks anything, it's trying to give them more than they asked for. That's right, $7 billion more next year alone. The rationale: combat readiness must be shored up, new threats must be met. The criticism: the budget's a throwback to the long-gone cold war. And here's one of those astounding coincidences that keep popping up in Washington: of 31 states represented by members of the relevant House panel, 26 got nearly $500 million in barracks and other construction goodies the Pentagon never requested.
 
DRUGS
 
Kudlow Didn't Lick It After All
It was a compelling tale: At the top of the Wall Street game as chief economist at Bear Stearns, Lawrence Kudlow made a dramatic public confession of a drug problem, said he'd licked it, and started fresh. That was 15 months ago, and his rebirth certainly seemed the real thing when, for one thing, he shared a dais with Alan Greenspan recently. But reality did not turn out so tidy. Last week Mr. Kudlow entered a six-month drug-treatment program, his wife said, after three shorter treatments failed. She just sued for divorce to keep him from draining their retirement account to feed his cocaine habit, she said, and this helped convince him to seek help. "It came down to saving his life," she said.
 
AUTOS
 
Electric Cars: Not So Fast
It was oh-so-simple to decree that 2 percent of 1998 cars sold be electric, as California, New York and Massachusetts have done. The trouble is, those cars are due in two short years, and the cars aren't nearly ready -- at least ones people would actually buy. Something had to give, and recently, sure enough, a distinct cracking sound could be heard. Gov. William Weld of Massachusetts offered Detroit a deal: the electric mandate wouldn't kick in until two years after someone, somewhere, built an acceptable vehicle. There's another compromise being discussed: equip "hybrid' vehicles with small gasoline engines to recharge the batteries -- since recharging is a huge hurdle. But don't hold your breath for that fleet of clean electric cars.
 
ENTERTAINMENT
 
Another Blockbuster
Remember when movies, if they were big enough hits, eventually achieved blockbuster status? Those days are long gone. Today's summer films have blockbusterdom thrust upon them from the start; they cost such ridiculous sums that anything less is unacceptable. With blockbuster season officially upon us, just look at these numbers: "Pocahontas" cost $45 million to make, "Apollo 13" $51 million, and "Batman Forever" $95 million. But you almost have to add those together to get to the $175 million that "Waterworld" (due July 22) reportedly cost. Is it possible that such a movie, now matter how many zillions of tickets sold, could actually earn money? If so, they'll have to think of a new superlative; "blockbuster," the word, will have been washed away.
 
PRODUCTIVITY
 
Independence, Squared
You can bet that American business will never let another holiday be labeled with a number, not a name. If the Fourth of July were known just as Independence Day, it would have long since been shunted to a Monday. A neat three-day weekend, than back to the grind. But face it: you just can't say, "July 4 will be observed on July 3 this year" -- even in a society so lax it allows words like "Lite." So with July 4 impudently falling on Tuesday last week, the nation pretty much ground to a halt on Monday -- in a productivity sense, that is; people at the beach or reading a book surely thought the day progressed very nicely indeed.
 
HINDSIGHT
 
Did Iacocca Burn His Options?
Suppose someone owed you $32 million. It wouldn't be a great idea to irritate that person, would it? And Chrysler, understandably, is quite irritated indeed at an ex-employee named Lee Iacocca, who linked up with one Kirk Kerkorian in a failed effort to take over the company. Mr. Iacocca happens to have a whole lot of stock options he has yet to cash in -- options that would give him an instant $32 million in profit. But he got a rude surprise last week when, after trying to exercise some of them, Chrysler informed him that a former executive forfeits those options if he acts "in a manner adversely affecting the company." Trying to take the place over would seem to qualify.
 
PUBLISHING
 
Just Another Humble Scribbler
 
The book tour -- it's simply part of the book-selling business. "I'm just thinking of how to sign books," Newt Gingrich said, answering some silly question about whether he was running for President. And sign he did last week at Barnes & Noble on Fifth Avenue -- more than 650 copies an hour of "To Renew America" -- as part of a 25-city tour. Yes, some impertinent souls shouted things like "Stop the war against the poor." But more typical was a woman who, hugging the newly signed book, cried: "I love you! I love everything you do!"
 
ADVERTISING
 
United Critics of Benetton
It's always seemed like a bizarre way to sell clothes: "H.I.V. positive" stamped on a human body, an oil-soaked bird, a bloody uniform from the Bosnian war. It gets Benetton attention -- no doubt about that. But what's it all about? Is it, as Benetton says, a way of highlighting social ills? Or is it, as critics assert, an "exploitation of suffering" that goes too far? A German court sided firmly with the critics last week, saying that exploiting feelings of pity "violates competition law" and ruling that the ad campaign was illegal.

HEADLINE: July 2-8: It's the Economy, Stupid;
The President Watches As the Federal Reserve Turns On the Heat, Sort of

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve cut short-term interest rates last week in what was the latest turn in the up-and-down, arms-length relationship of a Democrat and a Republican who find their fates intertwined: Bill Clinton and the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan.
 Both men, of course, want a healthy economy. But they also have a strong interest in seeing a healthy economy next spring: Mr. Greenspan will be up for re-appointment; Mr. Clinton will be up for re-election. 
 The Fed chairman has said that he expects a slowdown or possibly a recession this summer and a rebound by the end of the year, rate cut or no rate cut. But it is not a bad insurance policy to enact a rate cut now whose effects might show about the time his second four-year term expires in March.
 The action -- so slight it hardly guarantees a boom -- still reduces the likelihood of any serious effort to challenge Mr. Greenspan's reappointment on the ground that he puts the fight against inflation ahead of economic growth, as many Democrats charge.
 For Mr. Clinton, nothing usually matters more to a President's prospects for re-election than the condition of the economy. Since the Civil War, virtually every time the economy has been in a recession the opposition candidate has won the Presidency. One note of caution: the growing economy did the Democrats as a party no good in 1994, when the Republicans swept them out of control of the House and the Senate. RICHARD L. BERKE

HEADLINE: Price of Loyalty?

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
When the Devils moved to New Jersey and sought to develop a fan base there, the team required all new season subscribers to pay an upfront fee of at least $2,000, refunded at the rate of one-tenth per year, to obtain their season tickets. Those fans who shelled out their cash for a pig in a poke showed how fan passion and loyalty for a team and its players can sometimes defy common sense. Now that the Devils have won the Stanley Cup, those supporters may suffer the indignity of their team leaving town before they have the opportunity to revel in their championship. 
 Any business requires the taking of risks. Pro sports team owners hedge their risks by leveraging their threats to leave town against the mouthwatering offers made by hungry cities seeking to entice them with taxpayer-subsidized economic goodies. Obligating the public to provide for the owners' economic well-being, while public funding for so many social needs is disappearing, is obscene.
 
JAMES R. GRISI
New York

HEADLINE: Summary of Major Actions in the Legislature's 218th Session

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 8

 BODY:
The 218th session of the New York State Legislature opened in January with a plea from Gov. George E. Pataki for more open government and bipartisan cooperation. It ended at 5 A.M. on June 30 after 26 weeks of backroom maneuvering and sustained partisan squabbling.
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, scored an early victory when he signed the death penalty into law on March 7 after several weeks of difficult negotiations that soured his relationship with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat. 
 The next four months were dominated by a bruising battle over Mr. Pataki's proposals to shrink state government, sharply reduce welfare and Medicaid spending and cut personal income taxes. The Legislature eventually restored many of his budget cuts and trimmed the size of the tax cut. But the new Governor could still claim victories in having engineered one of the largest tax cuts in state history and having reduced general fund spending, albeit by just a hair, from the previous year.
The long budget fight left little time to debate other issues. When the session ended, the Legislature had failed to reach agreement on bills that would have expanded interstate banking, increased criminal penalties for bias-related crimes, required notification of mothers with H.I.V.-infected newborns and increased the minimum wage.
The session's other major accomplishments included an overhaul of state sentencing laws, first passage of a constitutional amendment that would allow casino gambling and the first increase in automobile insurance minimum limits in 38 years.
The Assembly passed 1,439 of the 7,814 bills introduced in that House; the Senate passed 1,459 of the 5,575 bills introduced. A total of 774 bills passed both Houses. Of those, Mr. Pataki has as of today signed 135 and vetoed 13.
These are the major actions of the Legislature this year:
 
The Budget
Few in Albany seriously believed that Mr. Pataki could deliver on his campaign pledge to obtain the first on-time budget in 11 years, but few thought the fight would be as bitter or long as it was. When it was enacted on June 7, the budget was the second latest ever, missing last year's record by five hours.
The Republican Governor initiated combat on Feb. 1 by proposing a plan that would have cut general fund spending by $1.1 billion, or 3.5 percent, while reducing personal income taxes by $6.8 billion in 1998.
Bitterly opposed to Mr. Pataki's deep proposed cuts to health care, higher education and welfare, the Assembly Democrats joined labor unions, hospitals and advocates for the poor in waging a costly advertising campaign against his budget. Mr. Pataki, whose popularity dropped below 40 percent in several polls during the conflict, replied with his own advertising blitz, accusing Democrats of being tax-and-spend liberals.
In the end, the Legislature rejected Mr. Pataki's deepest welfare cuts, reduced from $1,600 to $750 an increase in state college tuition and trimmed the tax cut to a three-year plan worth $3.6 billion by 1997. The legislators added $50 million in business tax cuts. And they restored more than $100 million in pork items that Mr. Pataki had originally opposed, including spending for stadiums, hunting clubs and scouting troops.
The final budget cuts general fund spending by $334 million, or 1 percent, to $32.8 billion. However, total state spending, which includes Federal money, will actually rise this year by $1.5 billion, or 2.5 percent, to $63.5 billion.
After the budget fracas, the Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and Mr. Silver each proposed legislation to prevent late budgets by lengthening the amount of time for negotiations. But they could not agree on a plan.
 
Education
LEGISLATION SIGNED Eliminates tuition assistance program grants to prisoners.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would require schools to suspend for one year students caught carrying firearms in school.
Would give state officials broader authority over the Roosevelt, L.I., School District.
Would require all school districts in Nassau and Suffolk counties to hold their budget elections on the third Tuesday in May.
Would authorize the City University of New York to move its graduate center to the B. Altman building.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have abolished the State Board of Regents.
Would have established a commission to screen candidates for the Board of Regents.
Would have allowed schools to use Channel One, the current-events television program for teen-agers that includes commercials.
Would have permitted the military to recruit on state university campuses.
Would have required New York City to maintain the same level of aid to public schools as in previous years.
Would have prohibited illegal immigrants from enrolling at public colleges.
Would have required schools to have instruction on the proper care, use and respect for the American flag.
 
Transportation
LEGISLATION SIGNED Increases the speed limit on 1,100 miles of state and Federal highway to 65 miles an hour starting Aug. 1.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would allow nighttime construction on state highway projects in Long Island and New York City.
Would allow New York City to sell 400 new taxicab medallions.
Would reduce the allowable noise levels of motor vehicle audio systems.
Would allow police officers to ride on the Long Island Rail Road free.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have lowered the limit for alcohol blood level for drivers under 21 to 0.02 percent from 0.1 percent.
Would have prevented deliverers who use bicycles from riding on sidewalks.
Would have made driving a school bus while intoxicated or under the influence of drugs a felony.
Would have increased fines for passing a school bus that was receiving or discharging passengers and had its blinking red lights on.
 
Environment and Energy
LEGISLATION SIGNED Gives the Governor control of the Long Island Power Authority.
Establishes the Long Island Pine Barrens as the state's third forest preserve.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would increase penalties for illegal dumping of refuse.
Would create a commission to help the state develop plans to protect sensitive coastal areas along Long Island Sound.
Would extend the Hudson River Greenway, a system of hiking and biking trails, along the entire length of the Bronx and Manhattan riverfront.
Would establish a moratorium on new commercial fishing licenses.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have allowed individuals to sue companies for continuing pollution problems.
Would have required farmers and commercial pesticide applicators to report annually the types and quantities of chemicals they use.
Would have required the state to consider the socio-economic characteristics of a community before issuing it permits for incinerators and other polluting facilities.
Would have allowed owners of billboards on state highways to cut trees obscuring their billboards in exchange for paying an annual fee that would finance the planting of new trees in urban areas.
Would have required all state environmental regulations to be renewed every five years.
Would have allowed the killing of beavers without a permit in designated areas.
 
Welfare and Families
LEGISLATION SIGNED Combines all state reimbursements to local governments for foster care, foster care prevention and child protective services into a single block grant.
Requires employable Home Relief recipients to enroll in work programs.
Lowers welfare benefits for parents with persistently truant children in grades one through six in selected school districts.
Extends electronic fingerprinting of welfare recipients statewide.
Requires teen-age parents in welfare families to live at home rather than establishing their own welfare households.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would reduce from 30 days to 7 the period that the family of a missing child must wait before receiving state-financed counseling.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have prevented undocumented immigrants from receiving funds for health, education and welfare services.
Would have required Family Court judges to consider domestic violence by one parent against the other when determining child custody and visitation cases.
 
Government and Ethics
LEGISLATION SIGNED
Ends automatic exemptions from jury service for 20 categories of citizens, including doctors, lawyers and people over 70.
Ends mandatory sequestration of juries in criminal trials except for cases involving the most violent felonies.
Increases the daily fees paid to jurors from $15 to $27.50 in 1997 and to $40 in 1998.
Extends the authority of the courts to allow trials to be recorded with audiovisual equipment.
Eliminates the State Energy Office and the Commission on Cable Television while folding the Alcohol Beverage Control Boards into the State Liquor Authority.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would authorize a constitutional amendment that would restrict the amount and kind of borrowing the state can do without voter approval.
Would exempt certain state workers laid off because of budget cuts from the ban against doing business with their former agencies.
Would extend through June 30, 1997, a program authorizing judges to allow television cameras into their courts.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have prohibited fund raising by state agency heads and other top public officials.
Would have authorized the secession of Staten Island from the City of New York.
Would have provided for the public financing of state elections.
Would have lowered the top limit for contributions to candidates running in New York City and would have imposed the same financial disclosure requirements on all candidates, regardless of whether they participate in public campaign financing.
Would have limited statewide elected officials to two terms.
Would have allowed citizens to put issues directly on the referendum ballot by collecting signatures on petitions.
Would have limited the growth of local revenues from property taxes to the inflation rate, provided the state maintained its local aid to the previous year's level.
 
Consumer Affairs
LEGISLATION SIGNED
Would ban disabled veterans from peddling in midtown Manhattan but would require the city to establish new exclusive peddling zones for veterans.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would clarify the law to specify that real estate agents and house sellers do not have to disclose murders, suicides, or felonies that have occurred on the property or the H.I.V. status of previous occupants.
Allows consumers who purchase goods by telephone to cancel their purchases within three days.
Gives users of personal emergency response devices a seven-day right to cancel their contracts and to cancel contracts if they enter a nursing home.
Would require in-line skaters under 14 to wear helmets and require in-line skates to carry warning labels recommending helmet use and have rubber brakes.

LEGISLATION FAILED

Would have prohibited rental car companies from discriminating against consumers based on where they live.
Would have allowed health club members to cancel membership contracts within seven days of joining.
Would have required telephone companies to provide to consumers, free of charge, a block on calls to phone sex services.
 
Business and Labor
LEGISLATION SIGNED Increases pension payments to most retired state and local government workers.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Extends for two years the state law requiring state and local government workers to pay union dues even if they choose not to join the union.
Requires promotions for certain sergeants and lieutenants in the New York Police Department.
Dictates staffing levels in the detective bureau of the New York Police Department.
Allows an independent arbitrator, and not the Police Commissioner, to have the final say in disciplinary cases involving New York police officers.
Allows liquor stores to operate on Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve in years when the holidays fall on a Sunday.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have allowed out-of-state banks to open branches in New York State, either by purchasing or merging with New York banks.
Would have provided tax abatements and other incentives for commercial and residential development in lower Manhattan.
Would have raised the state's minimum wage above its current level of $4.25 an hour.
Would have prohibited workers compensation eligibility for workers who are injured while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
Would have allowed New York police officers to refuse assignments in transit stations and housing projects after the merger of the New York Police Department with the Housing Police and the Transit Police.
 
Crime and Justice
LEGISLATION SIGNED Institutes the death penalty, by lethal injection, for first-degree murder, a crime that includes contract killing, torture killing, serial killing, second conviction for murder and murder in the commission of a felony. Provides narrowly for life without parole as option to death penalty.
Provides for major overhaul of sentencing statutes, lengthening prison terms for violent felons and mandating that longer portions of sentences be served. Also allows for alternatives to prison for nonviolent drug crimes.
Authorizes the state to test convicted rapists for H.I.V. or other diseases at the request of victims.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would require convicted sex offenders to register with the state upon release from prison and would provide for notification to the community in which the offenders reside.
Would provide that drug dealers could be convicted even if prosecutors could not prove that defendants knew the weight of the drugs they sold.
Would create the new crime of carjacking.
Would establish an amnesty law exempting anyone who turns in a gun to the police from weapons possession charges.
Would require graffiti vandals sentenced to community service to spend at least half that time cleaning graffiti.
LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have banned 19 military-style assault rifles, large-capacity clips and would have imposed higher sentences for assault-weapons crimes.
Would have increased penalties for crimes in which bias was motivating factor, including race, sex or sexual orientation.
Would have permitted use of Chemical Mace or pepper spray in self-defense.
Would have raised the minimum age that a child could appear in sexual performances or pornographic material to 18 from 16.
Would have made it a felony for adults to lure minors into sexual conversations or to disseminate graphic materials to minors via computer.
Would have mandated a 10-day minimum jail term for a first conviction of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs; one year for a second conviction.
Would have strengthened the so-called stalking law by increasing penalties of repeated harassment despite an order of protection.
Would have denied bail to defendants awaiting sentencing for felony sex offenses against children.
Would have created specific misdemeanor statutes against "aggressive" panhandling.
Would have made paddling a punishment for graffiti.

LEGISLATION PASSED
Would raise minimum levels of auto liability insurance for the first time since 1957 to $25,000 for injury to one person, $50,000 for all injuries and $10,000 for property damage.

LEGISLATION FAILED
Would have required notification to mothers or other guardians whose newborns tested positive for the H.I.V. virus; also would have required AIDS counseling for all pregnant women.
Would have required doctors to notify parents before performing an abortion on minors under age 16 still living at home.
Would have permitted family members or friends to make decisions on treatment -- and refuse life-sustaining measures -- for incapacitated patients.
Would have required insurance companies to pay for certain treatment considered experimental for people with serious illnesses.
Would have prohibited local governments from enforcing anti-smoking laws more stringent than state statutes.
Would have prevented bonuses to Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield employees in years when the company lost money.
Would have established internal panels within health maintenance organizations and other insurers to determine appropriateness and adequacy of medical procedures.
Would have required health maintenance organizations to inform potential members about benefits and financial arrangements with doctors.
Would have required health maintenance organizations and other insurers to pay for at least two days of care after birth.
Would have prevented payment of life insurance benefits to a spouse convicted in the death of the insured.
Would have set minimum standards for companies that remove lead paint.
 
Agriculture
LEGISLATION SIGNED Abolishes Office of Rural Affairs and incorporates its duties into the Department of State.
LEGISLATION PASSED
Would permit New York wineries to ship their products directly to individual buyers in 13 other states and would allow New Yorkers to buy up to two cases of wine per year from wineries in those states.
Would permit wineries to sell wine produced in New York State on Sundays at county fairs and farmers' markets operated as nonprofits.
Would prohibit taking of some farmland by eminent domain for use as a dump or trash incinerator.
Would give property tax breaks to owners of orchards and vineyards during periods of replanting.
Would provide loans to help farmers rehabilitate housing for migrant workers.
