HEADLINE: Committee in the House Prunes the Budget Tree

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 8

 BODY:
As the House Appropriations Committee passes the halfway mark in writing spending bills to fulfill Republican pledges of a leaner Federal budget, the House's ruling right wing is expressing delight at what has been cut. But it is what survives that ruffles them.
The National Endowment for the Arts, which sponsored Robert Mapplethorpe's contentious photographs of the human anatomy, is bloodied in the legislation being churned out of the appropriations panel, but the endowment is still standing. So is the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal law firm that conservatives accuse of promoting a liberal agenda in the courts. 
 So are the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Appalachian Regional Commission, icons of the New Deal and the New Frontier, respectively. So are loans to Russia, and the Energy Department, the Education Department, Interior Department land purchases and a host of other agencies and programs that raise the blood of hard conservatives to a rolling boil.
That they should prove so hardy in so deeply a conservative Congress, at least so far, may be surprising. But their survival illustrates a political rule that transcends party dogma and the transfers of Congressional power: when it comes to spending, the Appropriations Committee marches to its own drummer. And it can do without excessive kibitzing, thank you.
"Everyone's entitled to their opinion of whether we should cut one program or another," the panel's chairman, Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, said. "All these bills are going to the floor. They can change them if they've got the votes."
Some surely will try. "We're certainly looking for further action," said Mike Russell, a spokesman for the Christian Coalition, a conservative religious group that plans to press lawmakers to end the arts endowment, the Legal Services Corporation and additional education programs.
As Mr. Livingston notes, any rifts between his committee and other legislators or lobbies have little to do with the deficit. The Congress that returns Monday from a week off will find that the House Appropriations Committee, once the packinghouse for Federal pork, has transmogrified into something of a slaughterhouse.
Seven of the 12 main spending bills in its jurisdiction have now been sent to the House floor. Gone from the proposals are the markers for highway "demonstration projects," new courthouses and many other political favors that were legislative staples in years past. Dozens of Federal panels and programs, like the modest $318,000-a-year Susquehanna River Basin Commission and the not-so-modest $340 million-a-year Advanced Technology Program in the Commerce Department, are headed for extinction.
When the House and Senate Budget Committees drew up a broad framework for Federal spending last month, they gave Congress's appropriations panels a kitty of roughly $532 billion -- a third of the entire 1996 budget -- to spend on discretionary programs like roads and education and environmental protection. To date, every spending bill produced by the 13 House Appropriations subcommittees has come in below the budget committees' ceilings: $13 million below in farm spending; $202 million below in foreign affairs spending; $272 million below in energy and water projects spending, among others.
"Fact is, we're trying to cut harder than they want us to," Mr. Livingston said. "These guys are busting their backs to work within the budget allocations and do their job. There's not one subcommittee chairman who hasn't picked up the mantle of responsibility given in the Contract with America, and toed the line."
Arithmetically, Mr. Livingston is right. But as a matter of political philosophy, rightward-leaning Republicans fault the appropriations panel on two counts. First, they say, it has not wiped out the vestiges of liberalism in social spending. And second, it has kept alive wasteful but politically popular programs whose budgets might mushroom.
The social crusaders -- the religious right and many of the House's newer members -- are unhappy that spending on the arts, public television and other Democratic creations would merely be reduced under the Appropriations Committee's proposals, rather than disappear entirely. The arts endowment, for example, would lose $51.6 million of its $133.8 million budget; the Legal Services Corporation would get $278 million, a cut of $122 million, and a sheaf of restrictions on its activities.
Mr. Livingston scoffs at the notion that his subcommittee chairmen have gone soft on such programs. Some have constituencies that simply outweigh the hard right, while others are merely taking a slower course toward extinction than conservatives may like. For example, both the arts endowment and the National Endowment for the Humanities would be eliminated in three years under the House Budget Committee plan.
"That's not exactly a tap on the wrist," Mr. Livingston said.
Perhaps the larger question is raised by fiscal crusaders, the so-called deficit hawks, who worry aloud that the Appropriations Committee is trimming too many programs but not abolishing nearly enough. Led by the Budget Committee chairman, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, they argue that any program not wiped out now, while the Republicans have the political momentum, will thrive again in a less frugal Congress.
Mr. Kasich tried an unsuccessful end run around the Appropriations Committee early this year, seeking to shift some of its decision-making power to his committee. He and Mr. Livingston profess to have good relations now, which is not the same as saying they are in agreement.
The Budget Committee's staff director, Rick May, said this week: "We need to start tearing programs out by the roots instead of trimming them around the edges."
Mr. Kasich and his supporters, including much of the House's freshman class, want to swing the big stick. It was they who proposed wiping out the Energy and Education Departments, closing the T.V.A. and the Surgeon General's office and eliminating export subsidies, the Maritime Administration and most new Federal land purchases.
Mr. Livingston's troops have given them some victories. As a prologue to an effort by the leadership in both houses to abolish the Commerce Department, the House appropriations committee would save $340 million a year by wiping out a longtime Kasich target, the Commerce Department's Advanced Technology Program, which gives research grants to corporations. A host of minor agencies and commissions would also bite the dust, saving scores of millions.
The appropriations panel boasts of canceling 60 agencies or programs so far, with many more to come, though some of its claims, like the closing of a House parking lot, seem a bit strained.
But many of Mr. Kasich's larger targets have escaped, though rarely unscathed. The Tennessee Valley Authority, a mid-South power producer long criticized as past its prime, loses a quarter of its $142.9 million budget; the Appalachian Regional Commission's $282 million anti-poverty budget is halved. Deficit hawks wanted to kill the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, which spends $34 million a year to guarantee loans for American businesses trading abroad. But its budget would double under appropriations committee legislation now heading toward the House floor.
The Small Business Administration budget would drop from $923 million to $590 million a year; the Economic Development Administration, a perennial target, would lose only $90 million of its $440 million budget.
That political patrons have saved many of these programs is beyond doubt. The T.V.A., the Appalachian commission and the Economic Development Administration were largely rescued by Representative Harold Rogers, a Kentucky Republican who runs the subcommittee that approves Commerce Department spending. Some business trade subsidies were preserved by Representative Sonny Callahan of Alabama, who heads the subcommittee on foreign operations spending.
Daniel Mitchell, an economist at the conservative Heritage Foundation, said: "The chairmen and subcommittee chairmen up on the Hill tend to be the representatives who've been here for 15, 20 or more years, and so they're the ones least likely to have noticed the rumblings" from the last election. "Some of the appropriators just aren't part of the revolution."
But, Mr. Mitchell noted, it is impossible to take politics out of politicians, and maybe not all that desirable, either.
Mr. May pointed out that Mr. Kasich's budget panel set only broad spending guidelines, was able to look at the long-term fiscal picture and was not besieged by lobbyists and constituents seeking to save their piece of the pie. "Appropriators, by their nature, only look year to year," he said. "They know next year they'll be back again," facing the same angry lobbyists and voters.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about Republican efforts to reduce Federal spending omitted part of the House Appropriations Committee's budget proposal for the National Endowment for the Arts. When an allotment for matching grants is included, the proposed budget is $99.5 million, or $62.9 million less than was allotted in 1995; the proposed budget is not $82.2 million.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
A 30-Something Tower Tries So Hard for a 90's Look

BYLINE: By PAUL GOLDBERGER

 BODY:
IT SEEMED, AT FIRST, LIKE THE best idea in the world. Why not reface 320 Park Avenue, the bland 34-story tower of glass and aluminum that since its completion in 1962 has rarely been thought of as anything other than a black mark on the street? Nobody much liked this dreary box: indeed, the building, across from St. Bartholomew's between 50th and 51st Streets, and its virtual twin next door epitomized the banality of postwar corporate architecture.
 Spiffing it up with some granite, a few ornamental moldings and a fancy top would be an easy way to turn this into a more serious building. And surely a post-modern tower would be a lot better on the great boulevard that has suffered so mightily at the hands of modern architecture than the commercial mediocrity of the origninal Emery Roth & Sons structure. 
 Anyway, so it appeared in 1993, when the architects Swanke, Hayden & Connell were commissioned by the Mutual of America insurance company to renovate 320 Park as a new headquarters. (The company purchased the building from the ITT Corporation, which had long used it as its headquarters.) Now, two years later, the work is done, the chrysalis of scaffolding has come off and the new 320 Park has been revealed to the world.
 Alas, $75 million worth of cosmetic surgery is not enough to give this 33-year-old body the youth it so clearly desires. In fact, as with a person whose face lifts reveal rather than hide true age, there is a sense of desperation to this whole venture that only makes the building look worse. In one step 320 Park has been transformed from a run-of-the-mill piece of commercial modernism to a shrill, overanxious piece of post-modernism. Which is worse, honest 1960's cheapness or disingenuous 1990's attempts at art?
 Since 350 Park Avenue, the mate of 320 Park, remains in more or less its original form (a new marble lobby was recently added) it is possible to compare before-and-after versions, a rare chance in the real world. I leave it to you to make up your own mind as to which building inflicts the least damage on the cityscape: the one that tries not at all or the one the tries much too hard.
 Why is this whole effort so disappointing? Part of it is the matter of fashion. We like to think that if buildings bespeak of the fashions of their time, at least they are there for the long haul, and that unlike hemlines, they don't change with the wind. Of course, they often do: this is far from the first time a new building has been built over the skeleton of an old one, though more often this change of architectural garb goes in the opposite direction and is a matter of replacing an ornate masonry skin with a modern glass one. Up the street, for example, the glass-fronted 430 Park Avenue was once a stone-faced apartment house; across town, the garish white One Times Square was once the handsome stone Times Tower.
 But when the owners of a building give in so quickly to the whims of fashion, one of the most enticing phenomena of architecture is lost -- the way in which the sense of a single moment, present at a building's conception, can mellow into something more lasting over time. The original version of 320 Park, mundane though it was, represented, as clearly as any book or film, a particular sensibility of the late 1950's, the heady postwar years of pragmatism and optimism when the building was designed.
 To think of this sensibility as existing only for a generation -- which is all that it has been -- suggests that ther was something flimsy, shallow, about the whole concept underlying the original design. Of course there was something pretty flimsy and shallow about the original design, and nothing would be worse than to pretend that 320 Park Avenue was a serious work of modern architecture in the manner of its great neighbors, Lever House or the Seagram Building, erected just a few years before. The 320 Park buikding was quick and cheap, put up as nothing but an enclosure around rentable space, without any illusions of architectural merit.
 But if it's dangerous to romanticize the original impulses behind 320 park, its's equally wrongheaded, I think, to treat this ordinary architecture as completely expendable. As the passage of time gives a certain patina to everything in the cityscape, even the banal buildings of the 1950's and 1960's possess a growing ability to evoke a moment of history, to be a kind of collective memory, which is, in the end, among the greatest gifts any work of architeicture, good or bad, can convey to us.
 THE ORIGINAL VERSION OF 320 Park Avenue was born of practicality more than great vision, but the new design, for all its pretense at grandeur, emerges out of a no less pragmatic instinct. There was a powerful economic incentive to renovate this tower rather than replace it, even though everything about the building was dated as its architectural style, and given the total reconstruction necessary on the original frame, a completely new building could have been cheaper.
 But it sould have had to have been roughly 40 percent smaller, since both 320 and 350 Park were started before the city's 1961 zoning ordinance took effect and did not have to comply with provisions that reduced the size and bulk of building permissible on these sites. Had 320 Park been torn down instead of renovated, a new building would have had to meet today's tighter zoning requirements.
 The "wedding cake" shape of 320 Park has always been rather graceless -- a bulky bottom, then a band of setbacks out of which is extruded a narrow, boxy tower. Sadly, putting post-modern clothing on this shape (changed slightly in the new version) makes the proportions no more natural and, if anything, calls attention to the awkwardness of the building's overall form. The original version at least had the decency to be quiet; the new one, with its six separate kinds of sheathing -- stone and glass in every kind of combination -- just shouts. This building aspires to dignity but comes off only as a piece of facile decoration. Is it classical? Modern? A kind of post-modern riff on Art Deco? None of these, or all of them? Take your pick. And the awkward triangular top, a gable topped by a strange metal sculpture-mast, does the one thing I never thought possible, which is to make me yearn for the pleasure of flat-topped buildings on the skyline.
 To give the building its due, the reworking of the mechanical systems has permitted ceiling heights that are eight inches higher than the mean original ones, and the new, two-story lobby is a big improvement on the low-ceilinged old one. It has some nice light fixtures, too.
 But the most telling detail of the whole enterprise is the way in which the northeast corner of the building, which contains the BMW Gallery, has been handled. Gray granite pilasters, which have been plunked onto the facade in a glib attempt at classical formality, obviously didn't fit with a German automaker's idea of sleekness. So the granite on this corner stops at the second floor, seeming to dangle 12 feet up.
 It looks absurd and renders this attempt at classical symmetry hollow. In the end, the clunkiness of it all clearly demonstrates that the fast, no-nonsense style of the original 320 Park had no monopoly on cynicism; there is plenty of it behind the new design, too. It just depends on whether you like your architectural exploitation plain or with all the trimmings.

HEADLINE: More and More Are Living Alone

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LUTZ 

 BODY:
UNLIKE the bustling family nests of old, new households on Long Island are just as likely to consist of people who live alone.
For the Island, which developed largely around growing families, the implications of the change are far reaching, according to specialists in health, housing and government affairs. 
 The experts paint a picture of an increasingly isolated populace in ever greater need of affordable rental housing, home care and other services. "It's mind boggling to think about," said the Nassau Commissioner of Senior Citizen Affairs, Rena Iacono.
Although Long Island are still larger than the national average -- 12 percent larger -- they have declined in size by 17 percent, to 2.96 people last year from 3.58 in 1970, according to the Long Island Regional Planning Board. In that period the number of households has increased 24 percent, to 870,000 from 700,000, the board said.
Many of the newly formed households consist of men and women who live alone. From 1980 to 1990 one-person households increased, to 142,000 from 113,000, and as a proportion of all households, to 17 percent from 14, the board said.
Although many of the new one-member households are unremarkable, increasingly they are being formed by troubled people who have moved from New York City to reduce expenses, said Dr. Max Cohen, a psychiatrist in Garden City for 40 years and a staff member of the Psychoanalytic Center for Training and Research at Columbia University.
"New York City," Dr. Cohen said, "has been a magnet for people from all over the country who came here and lived essentially isolated, anonymous lives. A significant proportion of them had social problems. A significant number were what we'd characterize as schizoid. With economic pressures and the increase in rents in the city, there has been a movement of some of those people out into the immediate suburban area."
An increasing number of new one-member households are made up of people leaving psychiatric institutions whom the authoritieshave encouraged to live alone, said Marie McDermott, director of research and evaluation in the Nassau County Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities.
Over the years the department has placed in housing thousands of people whom the state ordered released from the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Hospital in West Brentwood. Since the 50's the patient load has declined, to 1,000, Ms. McDermott said. It was once 16,000.
She said 1,000 people lived in housing that the county kept track of, most are in some form of supervised homes. But 20 percent are in standard apartments. No records are available on how many of those are alone, but the number is rising, she said.
"There are," Ms. McDermott added, "definitely people in the system who need to be alone, because when they're teamed up with a roommate they're more likely to get into problems because of their mental illnesses. These people don't have the capacity to live comfortably with someone else."
Mental-health agencies, Ms. McDermott said, "are now developing more apartments where these people can live alone because of this problem."
The agencies are trying to establish additional one-person arrangements for formerly institutionalized people, even though living alone itself can be a source of stress without proper monitoring, she said, adding:
"Most of the data in the mental-health literature support that people who are living alone and do not have a support network are more vulnerable to the stress of life. So if they have a mental illness, too, and they're not getting the kind of support they need, naturally they're more vulnerable to having the problem exacerbated."
The evidence is anecdotal, Dr. Cohen said, but he said he saw a connection between living alone and mental illness. "In the old days," he said, "we saw people who had at least by and large been successful and well enough to establish and raise families. It's a different kind of person who lives alone out here. They tend to be more isolated, have more difficult or serious problems emotionally."
Whether a patient receives support services when living alone depends in large part on a willingness to cooperate with the treatment authorities, if the services are available. "We need a good 1,000 more beds just to handle what we expect will be the need in the next five years," Ms. McDermott said.
Isolation can be worse for the elderly, more of whom are living alone. The Planning Board reports that as the number of one-person households grew in the 80's, so did the elderly living alone, to 69,000 from 56,000, a 23 percent increase.
One way that old people who live alone fight isolation is by going to centers for the elderly for meals and opportunity to socialize.
For Dorothy Krash, 86, who lives alone in a ranch house in Massapequa, the companionship that she finds two days a week at a center in Farmingdale helps, she said, adding, "It's better than group therapy."
For Libby Boch, 72, the county center in New Hyde Park is where she relieves anxiety that she feels when she is alone. Ms. Boch, who is blind, goes to the center three days a week and, on other days, to private centers. Ms. Boch, who lives in a house that her sister owns, wonders what would happen if the centers were not there. "I think I'd go crazy," she said.
Many elderly people who live alone resist selling their houses, even if the maintenance has become difficult, said Ms. Iacono. "They prefer to stay in their own homes for as long as possible," she said.
Because her health has declined a bit, Ms. Krash has given up social activism, and a trip overseas did not turn out well because she was unable to keep up with the younger people. She continues to fret over a son who died many years ago at 19. Her husband died 10 years ago, and her daughter had a liver transplant. Ms. Krash, who now sees a psychotherapist, plays her piano and recorder and tends her garden, and she vows to keep her house, even though the upkeep is a burden.
Old people who want to keep their houses are becoming more knowledgeable about how the law could affect them, said George Roach, chief lawyer for the Senior Citizens Bureau of the Suffolk County Legal Aid Society. There was a common misconception, he said, that if a spouse, usually the husband, went to a nursing home his wife would have to divorce him to keep the house. "That really doesn't happen and shouldn't happen," Mr. Roach said. Under the law, he said, the spouse may keep the house, as well as other assets and apply to Family Court if additional income is needed.
Many elderly people, Mr. Roach said, have moral reservations about living unmarried with members of the opposite sex. Many also preferred not to live with members of the same sex, said Margaret Christy, Director of Community Development in Southampton.
A county program to promote house sharing for economic purposes a few years ago did not generate much interest, she added.
But the number of unmarried elderly housemates might be greater than it appears, contributing in part to an increase in the number of nonfamily households. Such arrangements are often kept confidential, Mr. Roach said, adding that the participants often do not report that fact to Social Security.
If, for example, a wife received benefits based on her late husband's income and that income was greater than her companion's, her benefit could be reduced.
Mr. Roach said another typical problem for an elderly woman who moves in with a man, whether or not they are married, is a failure to have her name on the house's deed. The man might, without her knowledge, sign over the property to his children. "He goes into a nursing home, and when he dies, his kids are on the doorstep saying: 'Hey Mabel, pack your bags. You're out of here.' And she doesn't have a leg to stand on."
Barring financial problems, many older people who live alone are able to hold onto their houses as long as they are healthy. "The big issue is health-care concerns," Mr. Roach said. "You don't have a spouse now or a companion, or you don't have a child to come in and look in on you. That old, 'I've fallen and I can't get up,' is very true."
That is why home care is so important, said Maureen Porta, Senior Citizens Program Administrator in Suffolk County. "We see a very great increase in the demand for in-home community-based services," Ms. Porta said, "because not only are more people living alone, the greatest population increase is in the old-old. These people have multiple and chronic health conditions. Many are unable to drive and they need extensive community support to remain at home."
The County Office for the Aging provides 850 people over 60 with services like shopping, light housekeeping and grooming, assigning case managers who assess the handicap. All the in-home programs are oversubscribed, Ms. Porta said, adding that 500 are on a waiting list from which they will be chosen based on how severely they are impaired.
Some towns provide home services. In Southampton, where one-fourth of the population of 45,000 is older than 60, the town delivers 150 hot meals a day and serves a total of 150 at its three centers for the elderly, Ms. Christy said. The program is financed mostly by the State Office for the Aging.
For the elderly who want to live alone but cannot maintain their houses, affordable rentals are scarce, said Patricia Lunetta, Director of the Suffolk County Office for the Aging.
In Suffolk the number of elderly living alone grew 31 percent, to 30,000, from 1980 to 1990.
Modern planning calls for housing to fit a community's "life cycle," Ms. Christy said, adding:
"You have small apartments for the newlyweds. You have small homes when they are ready to upgrade, when they have one or two children. You have larger homes for larger families. And then the elderly finish the cycle and move back into apartments. Unfortunately, Suffolk wasn't planned that way."
The area has an oversupply of single-family detached homes, she said.
One of the few developments with rentals for the elderly is being built by the Long Island Housing Partnership in Bay Shore. Each of eight three-bedroom houses under construction on the western side of East Third Avenue will have attached a subsidized accessory apartment reserved for the elderly. "There's definitely a need," said Peter J. Elkowitz, vice president of the partnership.
The complex is one part of the group's activities. Most of the houses that it builds are aimed at families, focusing on the smaller ones typical of today.
Nationally, demographers say, households with children under 18 account for fewer than half of all families.
"Most of our homes are the 1,200-square-foot three-bedroom type," Mr. Elkowitz said. "We find that sufficient. Maybe years ago that would not have been sufficient if you have a family size of four or five or six."
The growing number of vacant schools is visible evidence of the shrinking households. Some developers are turning them into housing for the elderly.
"The need is definitely growing because the demographics are there," said Wayne L. Kaplan, a partner in the Kapson Group of Woodbury, which operates four adult homes on the Island.
One project, the 106,000-square-foot former Larkfield School on 12 acres at Cheshire Place and Larkfield Road in East Northport, is being rebuilt as a so-called assisted-living facility. Construction on the 200-bed home, which began in February, is scheduled to be completed in the winter, Mr. Kaplan said.
Kapson has also converted a former elementary school on 14 acres off Beverly Road in Huntington Station into a 200-bed adult home that was fully occupied four months after it had opened, and the home maintains a waiting list. Kapson is developing other adult homes on and off the Island.
Other developers are converting former schools into adult homes, as well, and others are converting buildings to other uses for the elderly. The center in New Hyde Park is a former school.
Most adult homes are aimed at people who do not need full nursing-home services but cannot continue to live alone. More comprehensive, so-called life-care communities, are being planned for elderly people who are still able to live alone but want lifetime security.
Residents sign a contract under which they move into independent living units that are essentially standard apartments. As they become increasingly debilitated, they move into adult homes and then nursing homes, all usually on or near one site.
The government-approval process for such developments is extensive, including reviews by building agencies and the state's Departments of Health, Social Services and Insurance, as well as the Attorney General and Office for the Aging. None has been built on the Island.
A plan for a life-care community on 104 acres in Southampton was recently turned down by the Town Board because of local opposition, said Mr. Kaplan, who is on the New York State Life Care Community Council, which approves the projects. William G. Thompson, a local builder and trustee for the project, said he intended to seek a new site.
A life-care community being developed by Episcopal Health Services in Smithtown was recently approved to accept deposits in an attempt to test the market, Mr. Kaplan said. Unlike the Southampton plan, the Smithtown project would use existing buildings, including the St. John's Village housing complex, the Lutheran Center for the Aging and the Bishop Jonathan G. Sherman Episcopal Nursing Home on the grounds of St. John's Episcopal Hospital.
Most adult-living developments with health-care components require substantial assets, as much as several hundred thousand dollars up front and thousands a month. Some elderly people, unable to afford the price or preferring to live with their families, move in with their adult children and grandchildren, Mr. Roach said.
But, he said, those who have neither money nor willing relatives are facing the bleaker prospect of life in a community hospital. "You see whole wings of elderly geriatric patients who are there essentially convalescing," Mr. Roach said. "They need nursing-home care. But there aren't any beds for them to move into because they don't have the financial resources."
Ms. Lunetta said the budget of the Suffolk Office on Aging had declined, to $8 million from $11 million in the early 80's. "If the trend continues," she said, "services will definitely be decreased." The congregate-meals plan, which receives $4 million a year, might serve four, rather than five, hot meals a week. A frozen dinner might function as the fifth.
In Nassau, failure to increase the $14 million budget for the Senior Citizen Affairs Department could mean reduced services. "Funding has not kept pace with the growing numbers of older people," Ms. Iacono said. Although she supports the goal of balanced budgets, she said, "We're concerned that the kinds of changes made are carefully thought out."
